HEADLINE: Pataki Pledges 'Bold Steps' And Job Cuts 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. and RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
Six days after pleading with Congress to bail out New York State, Gov. George E. Pataki vowed today to cut at least $3 billion in state spending over the next 18 months, and to start by trimming 5,000 workers through a hiring freeze and early retirements.
 "As we certainly, appropriately, make the case to Washington, we also have to take bold steps right here at home," Mr. Pataki said. "We have to lead by example." 
 For the first time since the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, which dealt a severe blow to state finances, Mr. Pataki acknowledged that, as a last resort, he could not rule out laying off employees or postponing tax cuts already enacted. He also declined to rule out tax increases, an extraordinary concession from a Republican who has made tax cuts a signature issue.
State budget officials estimate the state will lose about $9 billion in revenue over the next 18 months because of the attacks.
"We are going to do everything in our power to avoid layoffs, to avoid tax increases," Mr. Pataki said. "As we go forward, we are going to have to look at all the different options. We're going to wait until we have the action plans back from the different state agencies."
Last week, Mr. Pataki asked for $54 billion in federal aid for recovery from the destruction of the trade center, but he got a lukewarm reception from both Republicans and Democrats in Washington. Members of Congress questioned his request for $12 billion to help the city and state make up for lost revenues -- relief that the federal government has not provided in previous disasters -- and for $3 billion for apparently unrelated transportation projects.
On the day that Governor Pataki released his aid request, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced that the city would freeze about $1 billion in planned city spending, and impose a hiring freeze.
Aides to the governor said today that New York State also had to demonstrate to Washington that it was absorbing some of the pain on its own, and not asking the federal government to solve the entire problem. Mr. Pataki hinted at that need, himself, saying, "We have to show the rest of the country that we are dealing with the economic and fiscal impacts of this horrible attack here in New York State every single day as we go forward."
In addition to reducing the state work force of about 193,000, the governor said he would refinance the state's $37 billion debt and ask state agencies to cut nonessential spending on things like travel and new equipment.
But the governor said that those actions would save only about $1 billion and that he had called the heads of state agencies to find another $2 billion in savings. He made it clear that the other cost-cutting steps he might take would depend on how much the state could persuade Congress and President Bush to provide.
Speaking at a hastily convened news conference in the Capitol, Mr. Pataki also said he would not agree to a supplemental budget of the sort lawmakers have been discussing for two months, to plug holes left in the spending plan the Legislature approved in August. Legislative leaders put that budget at about $81 billion, while the governor's office contends it is $84 billion.
"I think the idea of a supplemental budget that increases spending is something that, in the light of a $9 billion economic impact, we just couldn't consider," he said.
The governor's announcement came as the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, released new figures that threw into stark relief just how badly the state's treasury had been hit by the trade center attack and an economic recession that was worsening even before Sept. 11.
State officials say that the worst of the fiscal picture probably will not become public until January, when the governor, kicking off a re-election year, is to propose his budget for the 2002-2003 fiscal year.
Mr. McCall characterized the state's fiscal condition as "not positive, and uncertain." Because the economy had already begun to slow down before Sept. 11, and because just five weeks had elapsed since the attack, he said, "it is very difficult to know what kind of impact this disaster is going to have."
Carole E. Stone, the state's budget director, has predicted that New York will lose at least 87,000 jobs, many of them highly paid, because of the collapse of the twin towers. She has projected a drop in income taxes to $2 billion below what was projected this fiscal year and $5.6 billion in the next.
In setting a target of $3 billion in savings, Mr. Pataki and his staff provided few details. The governor said the hiring freeze would apply to all state agencies except those concerned with public safety and health care, but he would not say how much he hoped to shrink the work force through attrition.
He promised to submit an early-retirement bill to the Legislature, but did not provide any specifics. He said he would "eliminate, as of today, all nonessential discretionary spending by state agencies," though he and his aides offered neither examples nor an estimate of the savings. He and his staff also declined to say how much could be saved by refinancing state debt.
Mr. McCall, a Democrat who plans to run against Mr. Pataki next year, dismissed the governor's announcement today as "a very vague plan," noting that the trade center attack followed a long-running budget stalemate between the governor and the Legislature. "This came in the absence of any real budget and financial plan, so we kind of never knew where we were in the first place," he said.
Mr. McCall also said that Mr. Pataki's quick, broad-brush presentation seemed inadequate when compared with the much longer, more detailed news conference Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani held last week to explain his plan for getting New York City through its fiscal year. The mayor "was dealing with the same degree of uncertainty, but he was much more definitive about what the city had to do," Mr. McCall said.
Legislative leaders responded cautiously to the governor's assertion that the state could not afford a supplemental budget, and argued that more should be spent on education and social services provided by private organizations under contract to the state.
"While money is limited, we are in a situation of triage," said the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Democrat.
The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican, said he agreed that a broad supplemental budget of the kind debated before Sept. 11 was not appropriate. "However," he said, "we must also consider how we can address vital needs in education, assisting not-for profit organizations and, in particular, helping police, fire and other emergency services."

HEADLINE: Schools Closest to Twin Towers Struggle for Continuity 

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
As debris and concrete dust from the collapsing World Trade Center rained down around them on Sept. 11, 1,300 students from two small public high schools ran toward the East River, with some vaulting over park benches as teachers chased the stragglers. An aide gave a piggyback ride to a girl in a wheelchair. 
 Helping to lead the escape, Ada Rosario Dolch, principal of the High School for Leadership and Public Service, tried not to think of her younger sister, Wendy Wakeford, who worked for Cantor Fitzgerald in the north tower and is now presumed dead. 
 Leadership and its sister school, the High School of Economics and Finance, were one and a half blocks south of the twin towers, closer to the terrorist attack than any other school in the city. But being so close to the disaster has not seemed to give them any advantage in the help they have received during the five weeks since the attack. 
The schools, which once shared some teachers and programs, have been split into two cramped public school buildings in different parts of Midtown Manhattan, where they are struggling to maintain a precarious sense of community, miles from their home base and the financial district that was a source of internships and support. They can no longer share advanced calculus, history and literature teachers, so they have had to rejigger teaching assignments. Seniors no longer have a college application office. Many extracurricular activities, like sports and theater, are suspended. The students from Economics and Finance start school at 1 p.m. and finish at 6 p.m., when most of their peers are home for dinner.
Meanwhile, the students at both schools have watched the American Stock Exchange, which was next door to them, resume operations -- though exchange employees say it appears to be the only building on the block that is functioning. Still, the students wonder why their turn has not yet come.
Right or wrong, the students say they also feel overshadowed by the attention paid to Stuyvesant High School, perhaps the city's most prestigious and best-known public school. In the wake of the disaster, its 3,000 students were temporarily relocated to Brooklyn but returned to their building, at Chambers and West Streets, a few blocks from the trade center, on Oct. 9. The Stuyvesant students were cheered on by Chancellor Harold O. Levy, who set up a temporary office in their building to reassure everyone that the building was safe.
Jisung Chun, a senior at Economics and Finance, said she was shocked that most people she met did not even realize there were two schools right next to the terrorist attack. "I tell people that I still can't go to my school because of Sept. 11, and they say, 'Oh, you go to Stuyvesant?' " Jisung said. "I don't want people to say that. Stuyvesant is a great school, but this is a great school."
Zulaimy S. Ortiz, a senior at Economics and Finance, talks of a near-silence surrounding their continued exile. "It felt like nobody really cared," she said. 
Stuyvesant is a school with many children of affluent and influential families, including the daughter of United States Senator Charles E. Schumer. The parents at Economics and Finance and Leadership and Public Service are New York's quiet backbone, not its movers and shakers. Zulaimy's mother is a paraprofessional in a public school; her father was recently laid off. Annica Jarrett's mother is a nurse's assistant; her father lives abroad. Hiu-Kien Michael Wong's parents own a Chinese takeout restaurant in the Bronx. Their families live far from the corridors of power.
David Klasfeld, deputy chancellor for operations, said yesterday that the Board of Education was not shortchanging Economics and Finance or Leadership and Public Service. The schools are unique, he said, because they are still within the so-called frozen zone, the radius around the site of the recovery effort where no one is allowed without clearance at police and National Guard checkpoints.
One building was temporarily used as a morgue, and the board itself, he said, has had trouble getting access to evaluate the extent of the damage and begin cleaning up. Mr. Klasfeld said the board would consult parents about what they want to do. "Is this the place that they want to be?" he asked. "These are the kinds of decisions that the school community -- with us -- has to make."
He said that the frozen zone changes from day to day and that board officials thought the schools could be opened in a month. Some people who work in the area say that estimate is overly optimistic. "There are huge trucks coming in and out of here 24 hours a day," said one Wall Street executive. "It's one thing to have adults in a secure building, but another to have 1,000 kids right next to a disaster area, unable to go out, passing military checkpoints every day. It could be a nightmare."
The American Stock Exchange, which had been operating in borrowed space, opened two weeks ago only because it was a White House priority, said Robert J. Rendine, the exchange's senior vice president for communications. 
The students wonder why, instead of doubling up with other schools, they have not been offered a temporary home of their own -- an armory, an empty office building, a warehouse. "I hear about companies donating space for offices, and I want to say, 'Hey buddy, we've got a school here,' " said Harvinder Kaur, another senior at Economics and Finance.
Zulaimy said she and her mother had drafted a letter to Donald J. Trump, asking if he could spare a building, but had been too shy to send it.
But Mr. Klasfeld said that legal requirements for a school -- like bathrooms, space and access -- were not so simple.
Once separated by a footbridge, the sister schools are now separated by several avenues. The 750 students from Economics and Finance, once at 100 Trinity Place, are sharing space at Norman Thomas High School, at 33rd Street and Park Avenue. Another 550 students from Leadership, at 90 Trinity Place, are doubled up with Fashion Industries High School at 24th Street and Eighth Avenue. If they need a counselor to help them apply to college, they must hunt one down in coffee or computer rooms. Some colleges have been kind enough to waive deadlines, said Dr. Patrick W. Burke, principal of Economics and Finance.
The students missed three weeks of school and are worried about falling behind, especially in advanced placement courses. "We need those credits for college," Harvinder said.
Beyond the academic losses, their sense of community has been wounded as well. The small schools attracted enterprising students to the capital of world finance. Hiu-Kien recalls that his internship at Morgan Stanley introduced him to "the best people I ever met."
Zulaimy wanted to go into the hotel business, and through her school, had secured an internship at the Marriott World Trade Hotel. The Marriott was crushed by the falling south tower. "I've been laid off," she said, putting her head in her hands. 
Zulaimy was watching the TV news the other night when she caught a glimpse of her school building through the wreckage of the World Trade Center. "I ran around the apartment screaming and laughing," she said. "My father didn't understand what was wrong with me. I was happy just to see it still standing."
While few of the students have had the heart to look at their damaged buildings, Ms. Dolch, the principal of Leadership, has returned to retrieve purses, wallets and documents. When she first entered, she said, she felt as if time had stopped. Half-eaten breakfasts and newspapers dated Sept. 11 littered the desks. She cleaned up the coffee oozing out of the bottom of the paper cup she had left on her desk. She wants the clock to start ticking again. 
"The truth is, when I walk into the building, I have a great big smile on my face," she said.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ANTITERROR BILL; 
House and Senate Leaders Clash on Banking Measure

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN and KURT EICHENWALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
With some bankers and conservative groups alarmed about legislation intended to make it harder for terrorists to move money through the banking system, House and Senate leaders are clashing about whether to include banking controls in the pending terrorism bill.
 Leaders in the Republican-controlled House say broad new rules designed to crack down on domestic and international money laundering should be dealt with separately from a bill that would provide the government with more policing power to combat terrorism. 
 The Senate has passed a single, comprehensive bill. Democratic leaders say they will not take any more action on the overall bill unless it includes tougher banking rules. 
Terrorists involved in the Sept. 11 attacks left a long paper trail of bank accounts, credit cards and money transfers showing that they used the ordinary banking system with little scrutiny. As a result, both sides in the debate say the attacks highlight the need for tougher banking procedures. Money-laundering legislation in the House and Senate would impose similar mandates on banks to scrutinize customers and report suspicious activity. It would also give the Treasury secretary broad powers to track money overseas and to punish foreign governments that fail to help in the crackdown.
But the urgency of fighting terrorism has not entirely overtaken a longstanding debate about whether banks are doing enough to make sure that criminals do not use the international financial system to help commit crimes.
The philosophical differences, people involved in the wrangling said, were revealed in procedural battles because opponents were reluctant to formally oppose any measures viewed as vital to fighting terrorism.
Senate Democrats said the banking controls must be considered as a package with the new terrorism law. Otherwise, Republican opponents will find a way to delay or kill the provisions, said Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, whose money-laundering bill was incorporated into the Senate's terrorism bill.
"If the bill is separated," Mr. Levin said, "it could be the death warrant for our anti-money-laundering legislation."
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, has repeatedly said there will be no terrorism bill without the money-laundering measures included.
On the House side, Representative Dick Armey, the Texas Republican who is majority leader, told reporters today that the House would vote on its own money-laundering bill "no later than tomorrow." Mr. Army continued to reject the Senate strategy of linkage.
"We want to deal with them separately," he said. 
Though the White House backed the Senate bill when it was completed last week, it has taken a largely hands-off position on the tussle between the House and Senate over how to handle the banking rules.
Claire Buchan, a White House spokeswoman, said the Bush administration wanted the terrorism package to become law as quickly as possible. If the banking rules get in the way of doing that, Ms. Buchan said, then the administration does not oppose handling them independently.
"If it's possible to move them together quickly, then we'd like to see them together," she said.
"If not, then we'd like to see the counterterrorism bill done quickly" and the banking legislation done shortly thereafter, Ms. Buchan said.
The neutral position, several lawmakers and Congressional aides said, reflects a debate within the administration over how strongly to push the new banking controls. Law enforcement officials, including Attorney General John Ashcroft, have pushed hard for new rules that would allow law enforcement officers to scrutinize bank accounts and have easier access to bank records filed with the Internal Revenue Service and other federal agencies.
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill and Lawrence B. Lindsey, the White House economic adviser, often criticized money-laundering rules as burdensome and ineffective before the Sept. 11 attacks. Since the attacks, Mr. O'Neill has been leading the administration's high-profile campaign to curtail terrorists' access to the financial system.
Mr. Lindsey has continued to oppose some new banking measures as draconian. His office has taken the lead in seeking to work out differences between House and Senate versions of the terrorism bills, Congressional staff members and White House officials said.
Conservative groups and bankers have lobbied against the measures, although their approach has been low key relative to the intensive efforts to kill such legislation in the past.
Some 25 conservative leaders organized by the Center for Freedom and Prosperity sent a letter to President Bush earlier this month urging him to reject the Senate's proposals on money laundering. They called the new rules a back-door effort to eliminate international competition in the financial industry and argued that it gave too much power to the Treasury secretary.
Some banking groups, including the influential Texas Bankers Association, have also pressed House supporters, including Mr. Armey, to strip some of the most contentious provisions from the banking bill, Congressional aides said. 
"Bankers are very uncomfortable with this bill," said Bert Ely, a banking consultant who opposes the new legislation. "It tries to turn banks into spies for the government. But in this environment, most bankers are very shy about saying so."

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 Operations and Diplomacy

ANTI-TALIBAN STRATEGY: Sharply intensified airstrikes against Taliban troops near Kabul, and soon, perhaps, at the front with the Northern Alliance, are designed to crack the regime while it is reeling. A1

AGREEMENT WITH PAKISTAN: The United States and Pakistan said they would work to create a broad-based government in Afghanistan that could include some moderate elements of the Taliban. A1

NORTHERN ALLIANCE'S ULTIMATUM: A senior rebel official declared that his group would not accept members of the Taliban in any coalition government in Afghanistan. B3

THE REFUGEE FLOW: Up to 2,000 Afghans are thought to be crossing into Pakistan each day, traveling on smuggler routes and hiding out in homes of earlier arrivals. B1

DEVELOPMENTS IN AFGHANISTAN: American pilots for the first time were freed to choose their own targets. As airstrikes continued, two American bombs badly damaged a Red Cross aid-storage compound near Kabul. B2

AID WORKERS' FRUSTRATION: International relief groups said that bombing was making it nearly impossible to deliver large amounts of food to starving Afghans. B3

The Anthrax Threat

A POWERFUL GRADE: The anthrax bacteria mailed to the Senate majority leader's was in a highly potent form, and the letter bore strong similarities to the one sent to the NBC offices in New York, officials said. A1

TROUBLING RAMIFICATIONS: The discovery of high-grade anthrax spores suggests that somewhere, someone has access to germ weapons with the potential to inflict huge casualties if the right delivery system is used, experts said. A1

CHASING ANTHRAX REPORTS: Another wave of anthrax scares rolled across the country, and the F.B.I. said it had responded to more than 2,300 reports in the past few weeks. B4

MAIL INVESTIGATIONS: In the dozens of anthrax investigations carried out each year, virtually all turn out to be hoaxes. Now, investigators are embarking on what may be a much more daunting task. B4

URGING CALM IN FLORIDA: Gov. Jeb Bush came to South Florida, urging calm in a community that for weeks has been on the verge of panic about exposures to anthrax. B5

STRAINED HEALTH SYSTEM: Doctors are being deluged with calls from frightened citizens demanding to be tested for anthrax, straining the nation's system of health providers and laboratories. B5

NEW YORK'S DOCTORS: With panic spreading about anthrax, doctors in New York are having to diagnose diseases they have only read about, and they are becoming public health educators overnight. B1

TENSION IN ABC INQUIRY: The inspection of ABC News offices in New York was delayed as federal investigators and the police argued over how extensive the survey needed to be to ensure safety. B6

A CHILD WITH ANTHRAX: The ABC employee whose 7-year-old son became the second person in New York confirmed to have anthrax talked about how an office party two weeks ago led to a fearful ordeal. B6

LINKS TO NEW JERSEY: With investigators swarming over Trenton because of anthrax-bearing letters that were postmarked there, New Jersey finds itself at the center of an international terrorism inquiry. B6

THE DRUG DILEMMA: The United States is considering whether to buy cheaper generic versions of the antibiotic Cipro. But the move would carry troubling consequences with it. A1

DRUG PRODUCTION INCREASED: The German company that makes the antibiotic Cipro said that it was tripling production of the drug. B7

ANTHRAX DRUGS: While public attention has focused on the antibiotic Cipro as an anthrax treatment, officials say other drugs are very likely to work as well for less cost. B7

Securing the Nation

CONGRESSIONAL SAFETY: A fleet of police cars barricaded the front of the Capitol, tourists were banned, and many lawmakers sought assurances of security as an anthrax investigation continued. B8

THE SECURITY CHIEF: A week after being chosen to coordinate the homeland security effort, Tom Ridge began accepting media interviews, promising to find ways to help reassure Americans soon. B8

GUARDING AIR TRAFFIC: The nation's air traffic control centers are poorly protected, the president of the controllers' union said, adding that having a tower knocked out would cause dire problems. B8

AIRPORT SECURITY VIOLATIONS: The airport security company that was fined $1.2 million last year for hiring felons to screen passengers at Philadelphia International Airport has committed more violations at other airports, officials said. B8

DEBATE OVER BANKING: House and Senate leaders are clashing about whether to include banking controls in the pending anti-terrorism bill. B9

QUESTIONS FOR BIN LADEN: CNN announced that it had submitted six written questions to Osama bin Laden through a man who claimed to be a representative of Al Qaeda. B9

THE MEDIA WAR: Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld became the latest senior administration official to grant an interview to Al Jazeera, the news network based in Qatar, trying to counter propaganda from Osama bin Laden. B9

The Terrorism Inquiry

ATTACKERS' CLOSE CALL: The day after Christmas, two pilots were said to walk away from a stalled training plane that blocked a taxiway at busy Miami International Airport. For the pilots, Mohamed Atta and Marwan al-Shehhi, it was a close brush with the law while training for their attack on the World Trade Center. B1

SETBACKS IN BELGIUM: American investigators said that Belgian authorities had denied them access to suspects and evidence in an inquiry into the European network linked to Osama bin Laden. B9

The Aftermath in New York

SURVIVING, BUT TENUOUSLY: Lauren Manning, a Cantor Fitzgerald employee critically burned during the trade center attack, vowed that day to fight to live, for her husband and son's sake. She and a handful of others still cling to life at New York Presbyterian Hospital. A1

THE EMBASSY BOMBERS: Courthouse security will be bolstered for tomorrow's sentencing of the four men convicted in the bombing of American embassies in Africa. B10

SKYSCRAPER REOPENS: One Liberty Plaza, the skyscraper next to the trade center, was the subject of many rumors of collapse and major structural damage. Today's reopening celebration joyously proves the rumors wrong. B10

MANHATTAN TRAVEL LIMITS: City officials raised the possibility that the partial ban on single-occupancy vehicles entering Manhattan might become permanent. B10

THE OTHER DEATHS: As thousands of families who lost someone at the trade center have mourned in the glare of history, thousands more who lost someone to sickness, age or accident have mourned in its shadow. D1

Business

MORE BAILOUTS UNLIKELY: Despite helping airlines and insurers, the Bush administration is refusing calls for emergency aid to other industries hurt by the terror attacks. C1

JOBLESS, WITHOUT AID: The plight of workers displaced in the trade center attack points out an unemployment insurance system that has not kept up with changes in the labor force. C1

The Arts

DRAMA ON THE RADIO: In the shadow of the trade center, WNYC-FM, New York's public radio station, has dealt with journalistic triumph, technical nightmares and financial calamity since the attacks. E1

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
CATERPILLAR'S EARNINGS MISS WALL STREET'S FORECASTS

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 Third-quarter earnings at Caterpillar fell 5 percent, missing Wall Street's expectations, as the company, a heavy-equipment maker, coped with higher costs. Caterpillar also forecast a larger-than-expected decrease in full-year profit because of economic uncertainty. Net profit was $205 million, or 59 cents a share, down from $216 million, or 62 cents a share, last year, Caterpillar said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had expected earnings of 62 cents. Third-quarter sales were $5.06 billion, up from $4.78 billion in 2000. The company, based in Peoria, Ill., said it expected profit for the year to be down 10 to 15 percent from 2000, more than the 5 percent to 10 percent forecast earlier.

HEADLINE: Deepening Wrinkles in the New Economy 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The strong productivity gains of the late 1990's were concentrated in only 30 percent of the private sector and are likely to be whittled away in the coming months and years, according to a study released yesterday by McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm. 
 During the boom years from 1995 through 2000, many economists, journalists and Wall Street analysts declared that a new economy had emerged, one in which the productivity growth rate -- and standards of living -- had improved more rapidly because of information technology. But now that the boom has given way to more than a year of weak growth, widespread layoffs and, lately, the beginning of a recession, the new economy is being re-evaluated. The McKinsey study is the most detailed look at the 1995-2000 period published so far. 
 The yearlong study examined productivity in 59 sectors and came to a conclusion that other experts are reaching in this postboom period, in which the stock market bubble has burst, exuberant business investment is disappearing and Labor Department revisions have reduced earlier estimates of productivity growth. More downward revisions are expected.
The productivity statistics are important because they measure the amount of output or revenue that the nation's workers produce each hour on average. The more that output increases, the more revenue there is for an employer to channel into wages or profits or both. The Labor Department had originally pegged the productivity growth rate at 2.8 percent a year in the late 1990's, up from 1.4 percent from 1973 to 1995 -- a long period of stagnation.
The 2.8 percent figure was lowered recently to 2.5 percent. The McKinsey researchers and other experts say that while there has been an improvement since 1995, mainly because of computers and information technology, the long-term productivity growth rate is likely to fall back to about 2 percent.
"We have tried not to settle on a specific number, simply because we do not think anyone can know what will happen in the next few years," said William Lewis, director of McKinsey's Global Institute, which produced the study. 
That uncertainty is a far cry from the optimistic proclamations of an increasingly efficient new economy, an optimism still maintained by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. He is counting on a higher productivity level to help limit the damage from the recession that the United States is most likely in.
The McKinsey study found that nearly all the surge from 1995 through 2000 occurred in six sectors: retail, wholesale, telecommunications, securities, the assembly of computers and the manufacture of semiconductors. Kevin Stiroh, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has also studied productivity industry by industry and has arrived at a similar conclusion in a study that will be published soon.
The improvement came sometimes from the use of computers, sometimes from the actual manufacture of computers and chips and sometimes from the way in which companies were reorganized or operated, regardless of information technology.
"I.T. investment had a significant impact on productivity in some industries and virtually none in others," the McKinsey study found.
Wal-Mart's rapidly rising productivity and its huge share of retailing, for example, brought up the overall average in that industry. "McKinsey attributes a lot of Wal-Mart's productivity gains to the large scale of its stores and the organization of its supply chain," said Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate in economics who was on an advisory committee for the research. "A lot of that could have been achieved without computers."
Productivity surged in the securities industry, partly because of the Internet and online trading, but also because of rising stock prices. That helped to make mutual fund workers and money managers, among others, more productive. Their output was measured in the value of the stocks they handled. In recent months, stock prices have fallen or remained flat, reducing output per hour.
The assembly of computers and the manufacture of semiconductors contributed significantly to the productivity surge in the late 1990's. But that was mainly because the time spent in production remained essentially unchanged while the speed of these devices increased several fold. As speed rose, so did "quality" and therefore dollar value as measured in the government's accounts -- and therefore worker output.
"Computer speed is likely to increase at the same rate in coming years, but people and companies are likely to buy fewer computers," Mr. Lewis said, explaining that the private sector no longer needs so much additional speed.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Intel Meets Forecasts and Expects Slightly Better Earnings

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
The Intel Corporation met its financial projections for the third quarter today and said it expected profitability to slightly improve in the last three months of the year, leading some analysts to predict that the semiconductor industry has seen the worst of its precipitous sales decline.
 Paul Otellini, general manager of the Intel group that makes microprocessors for personal computers, said the results reinforced his view that the second quarter had been "the bottom," adding that the timing for Intel's recovery was unclear. 
 The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said its sales improved by 3 percent over the second quarter, to $6.5 billion, largely on the strength of increasing sales of chips and other components to personal computer manufacturers. Revenue declined 25 percent from last year's quarter, when sales and investment gains reached record highs. 
Many investors, though, have stopped judging technology companies by how their results compare with those heady times.
Early in September, Intel had predicted that its sales would fall "slightly below" $6.5 billion. The company's chief financial officer, Andy D. Bryant, attributed the revenue level reported today to a successful introduction of Intel's new chip, the Pentium 4. Mr. Bryant said the company was more than halfway to its goal of replacing the Pentium III in all new desktop PC's.
"It appears as if there is actually demand for the product," he said in an interview. Mr. Bryant said he expected Intel to report revenue of $6.2 billion to $6.8 billion this quarter. "Our expectations," he added, "have been tempered by the weak economy and declines in consumer confidence."
Analysts focused on Intel's prediction that its gross profit margin would improve by one percentage point in the fourth quarter, to 47 percent, after declining by two percentage points in the third quarter from the second. Intel has waged a pricing war with Advanced Micro Devices, its smaller rival in chips for desktop PC's, that has steadily eroded the profitability of both companies.
Intel said it earned $106 million in the quarter, or 2 cents a share, a decline of 96 percent from the corresponding period last year and half its earnings level in the second quarter.
After excluding special items related to acquisitions, Intel reported earnings of $655 million, or 10 cents a share, compared with 41 cents in the third quarter of 2000. The earnings matched Wall Street estimates, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.
Strengthened by sales to students and to European technology managers returning from vacation, the third quarter typically shows strong improvements over the second quarter.
Jonathan Joseph, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, said the so-called seasonal improvement had not been as not as strong as usual. But adding that "these aren't normal times," he praised the results as strong indicators of an eventual upturn.
"We think the worst is behind, not only Intel but the semiconductor group as a whole," Mr. Joseph said. "Intel has traditionally been a leader out of the downturn."
Intel said it gained market share from Advanced Micro during the quarter. That was supported by preliminary data from Mercury Research in Scottsdale, Ariz., which said Intel shipped 77.5 percent of all PC chips during the quarter, compared with 76.7 percent the quarter before. Advanced Micro's share declined to 21.5 percent from 22.2 percent, Mercury Research said.
In regular trading today, shares of Intel gained 58 cents, to $24.96. They climbed as high as $26.20 after hours, falling back to $25.45.
The personal computer market is mired in its steepest slump. Dell, the market leader, recently reaffirmed its forecasts for the quarter, but Compaq and Gateway lowered their projections after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11.
Steve Kleynhans, a vice president with the Meta Group, a research firm in Stamford, Conn., said customers had many compelling reasons to buy PC's, including increased power, the forthcoming Windows XP operating system from Microsoft and features like rewriteable DVD players in machines that cost less than $1,000. But he added that consumers and small businesses were too uncertain about their jobs to buy new computers this year. "Buying a new PC, no matter how cool it is, is probably a few notches down on the priority list from where it was just a few months ago," he said.
In separate announcements today, two other makers of chips or chip equipment, ASM Lithography Holdings and Royal Philips Electronics, both based in the Netherlands, sent mixed signals about their prospects for recovery.
Philips posted a loss for its fiscal third quarter and said chip sales declined 43 percent. But it also said it expected a slight improvement in sales in the fourth quarter and extended mild hopes for a recovery in chip sales by the middle of 2002.
ASM Lithography said it would cut 1,400 jobs, or 17 percent of its work force, by the middle of next year "as a consequence of the continuing downturn in the semiconductor industry." It also said it was moving more quickly than expected to consolidate operations of the Silicon Valley Group, purchased for $1.6 billion earlier this year.
The company said it would close one plant in Ridgefield, Conn., and two in California, one in Orange County in the south and the other in Scotts Valley, near Santa Cruz, and take a restructuring charge as high as 430 million euros, or $390 million. An American spokesman for the company said he expected no noticeable rebound until the last months of 2002.

HEADLINE: Businesses Finding That Good Security Is No Longer Optional 

BYLINE:  By REED ABELSON and JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
They are hiring security guards, requiring employees to wear identification badges at all times, taking X-rays of packages and reviewing evacuation plans.
 Businesses across the country are trying not only to make their employees and offices safe but also to reassure people, perhaps the hardest job of all. For help, they are often turning to outside security firms and consultants to identify which measures they need right away and what changes should be made permanently. The most common advice is to examine current security and then to spend more on equipment and on people with better training. 
 "We're getting tremendous demand to do security analysis at company locations," said Timothy Dimoff, the president and founder of SACS Consulting Inc., which specializes in security issues. "The focus is going to be more on control," he said -- who has access to offices and plants and how mail and other deliveries are screened. 
While many large companies have long taken security concerns seriously, other companies are listening and responding to consultants' advice for the first time. Evaluations "are getting much more credence," said Alan Bernstein, the chief operating officer of the Wackenhut Corporation, which provides security services and guards.
Though companies are reluctant to describe their heightened measures out of fear any information could be used against them, organizations as varied as Verizon Communications and the Girl Scouts have taken immediate and visible steps to improve their security over the last month. Just as the airline industry has tried to reassure travelers with the presence of armed marshals and increased scrutiny of what and who gets on a plane, the first steps seem to be adding security guards and putting up concrete barriers at their facilities.
With employers spending more, security companies are blossoming. Stocks of companies providing equipment or guards have risen sharply since Sept. 11. Wackenhut's shares, for example, have risen from $16.70 on Sept. 10 to close yesterday at $23.55. The stock of American Science and Engineering, which makes X-ray gear, has more than doubled, from $5.75 to $14.47.
Not all of corporate America is convinced of the need for additional precautions but managers know they need to reassure their workers. "You need to make your people comfortable and want to come to work," Mr. Bernstein said. But what exactly will put people at ease is uncharted territory.
"We're all winging it," said William P. Callahan, president of United Intelligence Group Inc., a security consulting firm. Because the threats are so new, he said, no one knows what makes sense -- spending hundreds of millions of dollars to put in irradiation equipment at the Postal Service or, maybe, doing nothing.
The standard on security "will slowly evolve," as it has overseas in places like Israel, said Richard Maurer, a security consultant with EDI Ltd. Consulting Engineers. "We are just catching up with most of the rest of the world. It is painful."
But some consultants say companies must drastically change how they approach security as dangers previously unthinkable become real. Companies simply need to spend a lot more on security, said Ira A. Lipman, chairman and president of Guardsmark Inc., which provides security services. "If you make things tight, then you don't really have to be fearful," he said. "And it's been my experience that employees are more comfortable working for an employer that has tight security." 
Companies that do not necessarily see themselves as likely targets of attacks worry that someone besides a terrorist, like a disgruntled employee, will try something in the current environment. "They're worried about the copycats, the looney tunes," Mr. Dimoff said.
It is unclear how long some of the new procedures will last. Guardsmark, which has had an increase in demand for guards for offices between Washington and Boston, enters one-year contracts that are automatically renewed but can be terminated on 90 days' notice.
Some companies -- especially smaller ones -- are focusing on immediate threats and will eventually decide to scale back their efforts, conceded Mr. Bernstein of Wackenhut. 
For now, many large organizations are trying to take whatever precautions they can. "We've looked at everything," said Liz Sheppard, a spokeswoman for the Girl Scouts, whose headquarters is just a few blocks away from the Empire State Building, a possible target. 
The Girl Scouts brought in a consultant to help review all its policies, from how it handles mail and packages to how it can safely evacuate its employees in light of concerns about whether to follow instructions broadcast by the building management during an emergency.
Other companies have also taken immediate steps. "Our security people have never been so busy," said Eric Rabe, a spokesman for Verizon Communications. While employees were always required to show badges to enter offices, security guards are now looking at identification and searching any bags. The company is also employing more guards, he said. Verizon also tracks the location of all its 100,000 vehicles around the country, Mr. Rabe said.
Large corporations that are well known to the general public seem to be moving most quickly, according to consultants. "Not all companies are at the same risk," said Michael G. Cherkasky, president and chief executive of Kroll Inc., a security consulting firm. "Companies that have a high profile or have international aspects to them have different risk profiles" than smaller firms, he said.
Delivery companies are also taking specific steps. Airborne Express said it was paying more attention to first-time shippers who were not already in the company's database. Those individuals will have to fill out additional forms when sending packages, said Robert Mintz, a spokesman for Airborne. 
In addition, the company has increased security on the ground at its shipping facilities, adding more guards -- usually off-duty police officers, Mr. Mintz said -- and providing additional training to employees who handle packages. Bomb-sniffing dogs have been used by the company in the past, he said, although X-ray machines are currently not a part of its standard procedures.
The costs of additional security will vary, depending on the size and complexity of the organization. A basic security package for a firm of 25 to 50 people in offices would cost $7,500 to $15,000, according to Mr. Callahan, and would include doors linked to identification cards and the placement of security cameras, but no security guards. The cost of a security guard depends on experience and skills, he said.
While many companies have former law enforcement or military personnel leading their security departments, they may now decide to hire better trained and better paid guards who know how to operate surveillance equipment and who can explain policies and interact better with the public. 
"The days of the security officer reading a book in the lobby have gone away," Mr. Maurer said.

HEADLINE: Venezuela Waits for 'Revolution' to Bear Fruit 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 12 

 BODY:
He still speaks lovingly to the throngs, sometimes for hours at a time on everything from the Bible to Sammy Sosa's bat to his idol, the 19th-century South American liberator, Simon Bolivar. Spotting a familiar face, he stops in midsentence, delighting a crowd by asking about a relative's welfare or how much rain has fallen in a far-off hamlet.
 But these days, President Hugo Chavez is speaking less and less, curtailing his once spontaneous speeches as the crowds have thinned. Gone are the tens of thousands of flag-waving followers who hung on his every word on Bolivar Avenue in the heart of this capital. Instead, at speeches that remain frequent by any measure, he usually addresses several hundred at most, many trucked in from the countryside. 
 Winning office in a landslide election in December 1998 that smashed two longstanding parties, Mr. Chavez, a former army paratrooper and coup plotter, promised to purge the elites from government and obliterate corruption-riddled institutions. 
Holding referendums to win backing for what he has called a peaceful revolution, Mr. Chavez redrafted the Constitution, took control of the National Assembly and installed military officials in important government posts. His promise to ease life for the four of five Venezuelans who are poor while punishing those who squandered the country's vast oil wealth endeared him to millions. 
Under the revised Constitution, he can seek re-election in 2006.
With the economy buoyed by high oil prices, Mr. Chavez steered Venezuela through a period that saw inflation fall and foreign reserves increase, to almost $20 billion. Trying to extricate Venezuela from a recession, the government increased spending 42 percent last year, and the economy grew 3.2 percent.
Yet, many experts and former supporters say, the reforms by the left-leaning president have yielded few real improvements for the 24 million Venezuelans.
"Chavez, as a doctor, does a good job making a diagnosis, but he is disastrous in prescribing medicine," said Julio Andres Borges, leader of First Justice, a small party. "The president builds up everything with his discourse and the hopes of the people. But in the end, the people have seen it is all a paper castle."
More than half the work force is underemployed. Millions of people are street vendors. Crime has risen dramatically, and labor protests seem to occur daily. Squatters are invading land in the countryside, and tens of thousands of upper-class Venezuelans tired of the populist oratory are abandoning the country. Venezuelans are more polarized than ever, from those who see Mr. Chavez as a savior to those who say he is leading Venezuela to ruin.
His displays of friendship with leaders like Presidents Fidel Castro of Cuba and Saddam Hussein of Iraq have also irritated the United States, though American policy toward Venezuela remains one of engagement, rather than exclusion.
Mr. Chavez still enjoys the support of most Venezuelans, several polls show. But unrest is a possibility. Some theorists and political experts suggest that even a coup is possible, a disastrous prospect, because the United States counts on Venezuela for 7.6 percent of its oil.
"The people of Caracas are passing him by, and that could be deadly," said Miguel Otero, editor of El Nacional, a daily. "The day something big happens and he calls for the people, they will not come out for him, or they will come out against him."
Mr. Chavez has lashed out at the press, political opponents and former allies. His vitriol is not new. But many here said it was sharpening.
"This revolution will not go back," he thundered in a recent speech. "The enemies of the revolution are quite wrong, and they are going to fall hard if they try to slow this revolution, which no one can stop."
The attacks against opponents are widely expected to grow if economic growth slows as predicted. This year, 4.5 percent growth was forecast. But that figure is now generally expected to hover above 3.2 percent. Next year, growth might slip below 3 percent, more so if oil prices fall.
Officials contend that one of Mr. Chavez's most significant accomplishments has been prodding the price of oil higher in the last two years through his efforts to institute production cuts among fellow members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.
Half of government operating revenues generated from oil production that is largely overseen by the giant state oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela. Venezuela, which has proven oil reserves of 76 billion barrels, depends on oil for 80 percent of export earnings, $29 billion last year.
Supporters also say the president's opponents are part of an elite minority whose views do not reflect those of most Venezuelans. "They are hysterical," said Jorge Perez, a former economics adviser to Mr. Chavez. "Why? Because they see their interests are going to be wiped away." 
Aurora Morales, who oversees doctrine for Mr. Chavez's movement, said the opposition should accept the fact that Mr. Chavez continues to have widespread support. "Look," Ms. Morales said, "Hugo Chavez was elected president of Venezuela because the people wanted it, and he is still the people's leader."
Indeed, support for Mr. Chavez stood at 56 percent in July, impressive by any measure for a leader about to embark on his fourth year in office, according to a poll by Datanalisis. Yet the poll also showed a decline in support, from a 75 percent approval rating in February 2000.
More significantly, those considered "hard" supporters, people who attend rallies and speeches, dropped, from 48 percent in February 2000 to 31 in July.
Another poll, taken in August by Alfredo Keller & Associates of Caracas, found that 41 percent of respondents said the Chavez administration was better than they had hoped, down from 76 percent in April 1999.
Mr. Chavez draws strength from that fact that the two old parties that once governed are in shambles and that no organized well-known opposition force has emerged. "At the end of the day, it doesn't matter what a sitting president's popularity is, as long as no member of the opposition is more popular," said a Western diplomat who has closely followed Venezuelan politics. At Mr. Chavez's speeches, it is hard to tell that support is slipping. At one recent gathering, followers waving flags and wearing the red berets of his Bolivarian Revolutionary Movement waited nearly two hours in an auditorium until the president showed up. When Mr. Chavez strode on stage, the crowd erupted. He chided, "Discipline, discipline." Supporters screamed his name over and over. 
The rhetoric and actions that create such devotion, however, instill intense hatred among the middle and upper classes. Some speak in apocalyptic terms about what Mr. Chavez is doing to their country. 
At a meeting of Accion Democratica, a party demolished by Mr. Chavez's presidency, one member after another said Mr. Chavez was embarrassing the country and driving away investments. To a former government minister and opponent, Ramon Escovar, the sole recourse is organized protests.
"Imagine a strike, with taxicab drivers and bus workers and subway workers," Mr. Escovar told the group. "If it happens in three cities, it would be a real civil movement. Do you not think that could be reproduced here? Of course it can."

HEADLINE: Asian Session Will Focus On Terrorism And Trade 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
Trade and terrorism will compete for top billing here beginning on Wednesday when 21 Asian and Pacific Rim countries formally open a series of meetings in what will be the largest gathering of government leaders since Sept. 11.
 The attacks and subsequent American airstrikes against Afghanistan have turned the Shanghai assemblage from a relatively toothless good-will exercise into a mildly contentious effort by the United States to strengthen its antiterrorism coalition in Asia. They have also added weight to the annual event, the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, which has in the past been best known, perhaps, for the closing photo opportunity, at which leaders put on shirts that reflect the culture of the host country. 
 China had hoped to use the meetings, for which it is host for the first time, to flaunt its fast-expanding economy and show off its model city at a time when most major economies are slowing dramatically or already in recession. 
But the main attraction will instead be President Bush, who is expected to arrive here late on Thursday. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrives late on Wednesday.
Although Mr. Bush has promised to keep economics on the agenda and is to give a keynote address to business leaders on Saturday, more attention will inevitably be given to his meeting on Friday with President Jiang Zemin of China and on Sunday with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
The meetings will be largely symbolic. But Mr. Bush is widely expected to reassure Mr. Jiang that the United States military effort in Central Asia poses no threat to China. Many Chinese policy makers fear that the American presence near its western border may become long-term, altering the strategic landscape and ultimately undermining China's security.
Beijing has voiced support for Washington's war on terrorism. But the government response to the American attacks on Afghanistan have been measured at best, and largely marked by evident ambivalence.
The sudden American campaign has already made obsolete China's own efforts at building an antiterrorism coalition in Central Asia. It has also weakened China's influence in Pakistan, which Beijing has cultivated as a counterbalance to India, with which China has a longstanding territorial dispute.
Mr. Bush may also try to enlist China's help in persuading Indonesia and Malaysia, both predominantly Muslim nations, to support American military actions in Afghanistan. He will meet the leaders of both countries, who have criticized the American bombing.
Though the American agenda threatens to eclipse Mr. Jiang's carefully crafted show, the fact that Mr. Bush is showing up at all gives Mr. Jiang enormous prestige. Mr. Bush made much in his election campaign and in his administration's early days of intention to play down America's relationship with China in favor of its relationship with Japan.
Yet, despite fighting a war and canceling stops in Japan and South Korea, Mr. Bush has promised to make it to China. His visit is generally expected to put relations with China on their soundest footing so far in his administration.
China also has an agenda, including pressing its objections to America's proposed antimissile shield and urging the United States to end arms sales to Taiwan.
Instead of simply focusing on a multilateral resolution that would outline ways the region's economies can liberalize trade and help reverse the global economic downturn, the leaders of the group, called APEC, and their entourages will also debate a United States-drafted antiterrorism statement that Mr. Bush hopes the assembled leaders will sign. If signed it would be the first time the APEC forum has endorsed a political declaration.
Other initiatives under discussion are suddenly relevant to the war on terrorism. Among them is a program to link Pacific Rim disease-control centers, train health officials how to monitor outbreaks of diseases and plan responses. The program has taken on increased importance because of the anthrax problems in the United States.
Officials are also working on airline, airport and seaport security as well as tightening customs controls. Member nations are expected, too, to propose steps to combat money-laundering and other financial crimes, including the funding of terrorist groups.
Member nations are also expected to call for a new round of talks on global trade regulations at a meeting next month of the World Trade Organization. The meeting is supposed to be in Doha, Qatar, though the site is uncertain because of new security concerns. W.T.O. members at the meeting are generally expected to endorse China's entry into the trading club.

HEADLINE: White House Balks At Further Bailouts 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
In response to a flood of calls for bailouts from industries hurt directly or indirectly by the terrorist attacks, from restaurants and theme parks to steel makers, the Bush administration has developed the following official policy position: forget it.
 But in trying to fend off the pleas for assistance, the administration is in the awkward position of having to explain why it violated its own principle by granting or offering assistance to two economically important and politically powerful industries, airlines and insurers, in the weeks after the attacks. 
 For all the administration's philosophical discomfort with the idea of the government propping up private enterprise, President Bush has already disbursed $5 billion in cash assistance to airlines and is offering loan guarantees, totaling as much as $15 billion, to some carriers. 
The president has also proposed a plan to have the government pay at least 80 percent of claims for damage from any future terrorist attacks in the next year and to cap the insurance industry's liability in subsequent years. 
In general, administration officials said, their policy is that any assistance should be directed at strengthening the economy in general and not at particular industries or companies. In a White House where the economic policy has been built around faith in market forces and a campaign to slow the growth of government, that approach has not generated any noticeable internal dissent.
At the same time, White House officials have specific explanations for why airlines and insurers should be granted exceptions to the rule.
Getting the airlines flying again and keeping them out of bankruptcy was essential to keeping the entire economy afloat and was vital in restoring public confidence after the attacks, administration officials said. Helping the airlines will also ripple through the economy by helping hotels, restaurants, rental car companies and other businesses hurt by the downturn in travel, they said.
In developing a plan to have the government temporarily assume much of the risk of big property losses from another terrorist attack, administration officials said they were not bailing out the insurance industry, but helping the entire economy by assuring that all companies needing insurance would be able to obtain it at reasonable rates. Without affordable insurance, companies in many industries would be unable to function.
Whether the bailouts of the airlines and the insurers were constructed in a way that yields maximum good for the economy and the country at minimal cost to the taxpayer remains a matter of debate.
The justifications for those two bailouts also leave unanswered another question: What if circumstances change in a way that imperils the functioning of the oil industry, for example, or semiconductor manufacturers, or any of the other industries whose products and services are essential to maintaining the strength and vibrancy of the economy in the United States?
"There is no hard-and-fast rule on the national-security justification for government intervention," said Thomas D. Gallagher, a political analyst at the International Strategy and Investment Group, an investment firm.
For now, the administration seems intent on beating back a lengthening list of industries that are telling Congress about how their business has already been hurt by the aftershocks from the attacks -- and how a timely tax break or a new government program might help.
"Attempting to rush from sector to sector applying first aid would be an economically futile and fiscally ruinous mistake," Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the White House budget director, said today.
"The short answer on more bailouts," he said, "is none."
But Congress, on both sides of the aisle, tends to be a softer touch for industries and interest groups, and lobbyists are pushing for a wide range of measures to be included in the economic stimulus package now being negotiated on Capitol Hill.
Hollywood is looking for a tax break to encourage studios not to move film production abroad. Theme parks support a tax credit for travel expenses. Steel makers are looking for help. Restaurants want increased deductibility of business meals.
"It's important not to set bad precedents, which means it's important not to bend too much to the will of industries that may have been hurt," said Robert L. Bixby, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a group that advocates fiscal responsibility.
"The government certainly doesn't want to get into bailing out industries that have been hit in a secondary way, because frankly we've all been hit in a secondary way," Mr. Bixby said.
Barring some major new problem with the economy or national security, the focus in Washington will probably shift from big bailouts of essential industries to helping industries and their workers weather the economic downturn.
In an interview and in a speech tonight in New York, Mr. Daniels said the administration would seek to strip out of the economic stimulus bill any provisions that were focused on particular industries. 
"Other sector-specific bailouts should be avoided," Mr. Daniels said. "Industries heavily dependent on air travel will benefit from the recovery of airlines, and from macroeconomic measures that spur overall economic growth. Our ministrations must stop at causes, not symptoms."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 18, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the Bush administration's opposition to bailouts for industries other than airlines and insurers misstated the amount of loan guarantees offered by the administration to airlines. It is $10 billion, not $15 billion.

HEADLINE: Out of Work, and Out of the Benefits Loop; 
Restrictions Will Keep Millions From Receiving Help

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
When Larry Johnson applied for unemployment benefits the week after the World Trade Center collapsed, he seemed like just the kind of person government officials have been talking about helping since Sept. 11.
 Mr. Johnson, 49, worked the night shift, cleaning the bar and buffing floors, at Windows on the World, the restaurant at the top of the north tower. The terrorist attacks, two hours after Mr. Johnson had left work, killed 79 colleagues and took away his job eight months after he had started it. 
 But a couple of weeks ago, he received a letter from New York State rejecting his application for benefits because he had not earned enough money over the previous 18 months. That technicality is one of the many restrictions in an unemployment system that now pays benefits to about 39 percent of all Americans who are without a job and looking for one, down from about 50 percent in 1975 and even higher levels a half-century ago, according to the Labor Department. 
As the labor force has changed over the last three decades to include more women, more temporary employees and fewer factory workers, the unemployment insurance system has not changed with it in many states and has become considerably stricter in many others, job counselors and economists said.
The system, created in 1935 as part of the Social Security Act, pays an average of $230 a week to unemployed Americans who meet its qualifications. Although the rules vary from state to state, they typically exclude people who do not fit the traditional notion of a laid-off worker -- part-time employees, recently hired low-wage workers and people who quit their jobs or refused a new shift for family reasons.
As a result, because millions of unemployed workers will not qualify for benefits in the first place, many laid-off employees will not be helped by President Bush's proposal to extend payments to a limited pool of those jobless Americans who are eligible.
With the United States probably in its first recession in a decade and companies announcing tens of thousands of layoffs, the gaps in the unemployment safety net could aggravate the downturn, economists say. People without jobs or unemployment benefits -- even people whose spouses work -- are likely to cut their discretionary spending sharply, as many struggle to pay their rent, meet their debt payments and still have enough money for food and transportation.
"I've got to start all over again," said Mr. Johnson, who described himself as running out of the money he had received from his sister and a few charities. "I'm on the edge of being homeless."
Mr. Johnson was turned down because New York, like most states, determines eligibility based on earnings over a 12-month period that ends a few months before the date a job is lost. This is supposed to give the state time to gather employment records, but it often excludes people who have worked for less than a year and were previously without a job.
New York is one of nine states that let people like Mr. Johnson reapply and ask that the most recent months be considered, said Betsy McCormack, a spokeswoman for the state labor department. With each rejection letter, the state includes a form allowing people to make the request.
In addition, Ms. McCormack said, Gov. George E. Pataki has taken steps to help people left jobless because of the attacks, like extending until next month the deadline to apply for disaster-related unemployment benefits.
Still, Mr. Johnson's unexpected rejection, and the difficulties it has caused, is typical of the effect that an increasingly complicated set of rules has had, job counselors said. 
"This is a system that defies explanation in so many ways," said Jeffrey B. Wenger, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a research group in Washington partly supported by labor unions.
Full-time employees who worked for at least a year before losing their jobs rarely fail to qualify for benefits because of income minimums; most states require people to have earned only a few thousand dollars to be eligible.
But people are rejected for many other reasons. Some are turned down because they quit their jobs to care for relatives, leaving them ineligible for benefits once they begin looking for work again. Or because they worked part time and made the minimum wage or slightly above, leaving them short of the income requirements in some states. Or because, like many parents of children, they worked part time before being laid off and are again seeking only part-time work.
"There is a big discrimination against part-time people," said Richard B. Freeman, a labor economist at Harvard University. Like full-time employees, part-time workers pay unemployment-insurance tax while they are working, but in most states they do not receive the benefits of that tax when they are unemployed.
"It's not right," Mr. Freeman said.
Other people, meanwhile, never receive benefits because they do not think it is worth applying or because they do not know they qualify, labor experts said.
A report submitted to Congress last year by the General Accounting Office attributed the long-term decline in unemployment insurance coverage to several economic and political reasons. In past decades, more Americans worked in factories, where regular layoffs made jobless benefits a common part of their lives, and belonged to labor unions, which often reminded members to apply for benefits.
In the 1990's, more states eased eligibility rules than tightened them, Mr. Wenger said, helping the percentage of jobless workers getting benefits to increase slightly. 
The General Accounting Office report recommended a more significant loosening of the rules so that unemployment insurance could catch up to the changes in the work force. The report noted, for instance, that over the last five decades many states have begun rejecting people who had quit their jobs for personal reasons even as the percentage of families with two working parents rose sharply.
The report also said unemployment insurance had become particularly important because of the number of low-wage workers who have entered the work force since the welfare system was overhauled in 1996.
But proposals to expand unemployment insurance have won little political support because they cost money and could give people less incentive to find a job, economists say. In fact, Mr. Freeman said, Australia and many European countries, while still more generous, have reduced their benefits in recent years, making their systems more like that of the United States.
This month, President Bush proposed extending benefits by 13 weeks for people who became unemployed after Sept. 11, who live in states where the unemployment rate rises by at least 30 percent and whose benefits expire. Most states normally allow people to collect for as long as 26 weeks.
The president also asked Congress to give states $3 billion in emergency funds, some of which could be paid to unemployed workers enrolled in job-training classes who are not normally eligible.
Still, with the country entering its first recession since 1991, economists said they were worried that the system's gaps could contribute to a delay in recovery.
"If you want to put money into the economy, put it in the hands of people who are the most desperate," said Richard J. DeKaser, the chief economist at the National City Corporation, a bank based in Cleveland. "People who are unemployed are not going to save money."
If anything, many without jobs and unemployment benefits find themselves dipping into their savings or cutting back on their spending.
Marjorie Goldstein, who joined US Airways as a flight attendant in March after spending 15 years at home raising three children, lost her job late last month as part of the airline industry's huge cutbacks after the attacks. When she applied for unemployment, Pennsylvania rejected her and many of the people with whom she went to flight attendant school earlier this year, saying their work experience was too recent.
"If I were the major breadwinner, we'd be hungry," said Ms. Goldstein, who lives near Pittsburgh.
Because her husband works, she is not worried about paying the essential bills. But with her $1,700 in additional monthly income, the family had bought a new stove, refinished its driveway and paid for day camp for one of the children. Now, she said, they are likely to cut back.
