HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE WIDENING INQUIRY; 
ANTHRAX MAILED TO SENATE IS FOUND TO BE POTENT FORM; CASE TIED TO ILLNESS AT NBC

BYLINE:  By DAVID JOHNSTON and ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
The anthrax mailed to the office of the Senate majority leader was pure and highly refined, consisting of particles so tiny that they could spread through the air without detection, government officials said tonight.
 The officials said the potent grade of highly concentrated anthrax found in the letter sent to Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota could have been made by an expert capable of producing large amounts of it, although it is not yet known who may have manufactured or purchased the anthrax sent to the senator. 
 The letter, which was opened on Monday morning in Mr. Daschle's office, bore strong similarities in language and handwriting to the one sent to the NBC anchor Tom Brokaw in New York and appeared to have been composed by the same person. Officials stopped short of explicitly linking the attacks to international terrorism, but the gravity of the threat instantly transformed the investigation into a major national security concern. 
"We were told it was a very strong form of anthrax, a very potent form of anthrax which clearly was produced by someone who knew what he or she was doing," Mr. Daschle said after a briefing for senators by the F.B.I. and an Army epidemiologist. He said the sample that had been mailed to him "had a fairly significant degree of concentration of spores." 
Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine said the strain was "very refined, very pure."
Heightened concern over the purity and concentration of the anthrax came as a Congressional official said there had been some intelligence warnings last week that suspicious packages would be sent to important places and people.
President Bush was scheduled to fly to California on Wednesday, a one-day stop on his way to an economic summit in China. White House officials said that the trip was still on "as of now" and that Mr. Bush was waiting for final test results on the anthrax found in the Senate. His trip could be curtailed if necessary, the officials said.
Former Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, Mr. Bush's new chief of domestic security, met at the White House with senior federal law enforcement and health officials this afternoon. 
In an interview with Mr. Brokaw on "NBC Nightly News," Mr. Ridge called the threat of bioterrorism "the No. 1 priority this week and for the weeks ahead" and suggested it was time to build up supplies of smallpox vaccine and resume routine vaccinations of children, a practice that was stopped nearly three decades ago. 
The initial findings from an Army medical laboratory at Fort Detrick, Md., came as the police at the Capitol shut down a full eight-story wing of the building where the letter was found, including the suites of 12 senators with the same ventilation system. Hundreds of people who so much as passed through the corridors near Mr. Daschle's office were being tested and treated with antibiotics.
A senior government official said tonight that the anthrax in Mr. Daschle's office was "very highly refined, very small anthrax" and was "the kind that will give you pulmonary anthrax."
Officials said they had not yet determined whether the anthrax that had infected the son of an ABC News producer in New York was the same as that sent to Mr. Daschle. They said the material sent to Mr. Brokaw was very similar to the kind of anthrax that killed a photo editor at American Media Inc., a tabloid publisher in Florida. The German drug company that makes the antibiotic used against anthrax, Cipro, said today that it was tripling production of the drug as public fears mounted.
But Bayer A.G., the maker, acknowledged that even that increase may not be sufficient to meet demand. Cipro is the only drug approved to treat inhaled anthrax, and on Sunday, Health and Human Services Secretary Tommy G. Thompson said the government wanted to increase the national stockpile of emergency drugs to have enough to treat 12 million people for 60 days, six times the current stockpile.
Much remained unclear tonight, including above all who might be responsible for the letters sent to the Senate and NBC, or what links they had to other cases of anthrax exposure in the last two weeks.
A senior government official said that laboratory tests had not matched the anthrax samples in the two letters but that he expected them to prove to be the same.
Investigators were trying to determine whether the two letters were related to other possible anthrax exposures across the country.
Both letters and their envelopes were handwritten in block printing, and copies were released today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. They were unsigned and contained no salutation, the senior official said, and both contained a generalized threat and did not appear to target the addressees.
The official said the letters contained phrases like "Death to America," "You're going to die" and "Allah is great." Investigators did not conclude that the reference to Allah meant that the letter writer was an Islamic extremist or linked to Osama bin Laden, the official said. But officials today refused to rule out any possible motive for the letters. 
Lieut. Dan Nichols of the Capitol police called the shutdown of part of the Hart Senate Office Building "a precautionary measure only" and said security workers planned "extensive testing" of the ventilation system. The air conditioning and ventilation in that section of the building was shut off about a half-hour after Mr. Daschle's aide found the package on Monday morning, lawmakers said.
The White House communications director, Dan Bartlett, said tonight that the president would have no comment until investigators had a conclusive finding about the samples taken from the Senate. 
"We take all these cases involving anthrax very seriously," Mr. Bartlett said. "We will wait for a conclusive test."
He said Mr. Bush did not attend the meeting with Mr. Ridge this afternoon and was still planning his trip to China. "Right now, his itinerary hasn't changed," he said. "The president is confident in the federal agencies that have been responding to this. What do you want him to do? Hunker down? We're waiting for the tests and investigations to take place."
Dr. John Eisold, the attending physician at the Capitol, said several hundred people would be screened and given antibiotics during testing. He said officials wanted to "draw up the net as widely as possible and err on the conservative side and test and treat." 
Officials noted repeatedly that only the letter had so far tested positive for anthrax and that it was too early to have results from nasal swab testing.
At least one senator, Barabra Boxer, a California Democrat whose office is in the wing of the building that was shut, took advantage of the swab tests being offered today. "My staff and I have been tested and given antibiotics as a precautionary measure while awaiting tests results," Senator Boxer said.
At a news conference, the F.B.I. director, Robert S. Mueller III, said threats of attacks against the United States had not diminished since last week, when his office issued a warning that there was a possibility of another attack on the United States in the coming days.
Mr. Mueller said the alert would continue in effect in part because of the anthrax exposure cases. "Quite obviously," he said, "the incidents of anthrax exposures in the last couple of days warrant such a continued state of alert."
Still, Mr. Mueller did not say he believed the anthrax outbreak was the attack warned of in intelligence information received last week.

HEADLINE: Common Interests In a Hazardous World 

BYLINE:  By David Shambaugh and Robert S. Litwak; David Shambaugh is director of the China Policy Program at George Washington University. Robert S. Litwak is director of international studies at the Woodrow Wilson Center in Washington.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
President Bush's trip to China tomorrow to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting may mark a qualitatively new and more mature phase in relations between the two countries. The current campaign against global terrorism, in which the two governments have already cooperated extensively, offers the opportunity to improve a relationship that has been plagued by difficulties.
 Normally a presidential visit to China would generate strong passions and public controversy in the United States, as China has been a lightning rod in American domestic political debates. Disagreements about China policy inside the government, which have often been heated since 1989, have become muted. 
 The principal reason for the lack of controversy is that America and the world are preoccupied by the events of Sept. 11 and the unfolding American-led military campaign in Afghanistan. This lack of attention may be just what the relationship between America and China needs, providing an opportunity for President Bush and President Jiang Zemin of China to meet without strong domestic pressures and heightened international expectations. Simply going to Shanghai will also help familiarize President Bush with the realities of a rapidly modernizing China, giving him a concrete sense of a country often reduced to abstractions and stereotypes.
This first meeting between Mr. Bush and Mr. Jiang provides a chance for the two to stake out mutual interests in the campaign against terrorism as well as to manage other difficult issues, including the spread of weapons of mass destruction, climate change, organized crime and narcotics smuggling, and the future of North Korea.
China's hosting of the APEC conference and imminent entry into the World Trade Organization in early November are also important events in their own right, and tangibly symbolize China's integration into the global economy. In this context, the tensions of recent years between Washington and Beijing may be reduced by multinational management of common problems. Although the two nations will continue to have friction, international coalitions and multilateral mechanisms offer a productive way forward for Sino-American cooperation.
Since President Nixon's opening to China three decades ago, American policy has sought China's integration into the international community. Encouraging Chinese membership in, and compliance with, international institutions has been viewed as important for global stability. Yet China has long suspected multilateral institutions of being stalking horses for American interests.
Interestingly, this view has recently been reversed; China now believes that such institutions may constrain American power or, at the least, keep the United States from acting unilaterally.
Although China is regarded as a full member of the global system, this integration remains more form than substance. China's ambivalence even now about multilateralism and Beijing's selective implementation of international agreements indicate that China is not fully comfortable with the aims, principles and norms that underlie global institutions. China's commitment to the international system needs to be judged by the consistency of its actions.
The international effort to restrict the proliferation of sensitive military technologies is one particularly thorny area that has long roiled Sino-American relations. Last November, Beijing formally committed to Washington that it would curb its exports of missile components and nuclear technology. This important agreement was reciprocated by a Clinton administration decision to make it easier for American companies to launch satellites on Chinese rockets. But last month the State Department slapped sanctions on two Chinese companies accused of circumventing the pledge to curb missile exports by transferring missile parts to Pakistan.
The Chinese government faces a choice. It can either continue selling nuclear technology and missile components, for example, to unstable states like Pakistan or hostile ones like Iran, or it can live up to its commitments and gain international acceptance as a responsible state. In our discussions in Beijing last week with military officials and civilian analysts, it was apparent that Chinese arms control authorities are rethinking China's approach. China cannot be against terrorism one day and selling dangerous technology to states that sponsor terrorism the next. The incentives now clearly cut in favor of Chinese compliance with multilateral nonproliferation norms. Mr. Bush and Mr. Jiang may announce progress on this issue when they meet in Shanghai on Friday.
The mixed, complex character of Sino-American relations resists reduction to any simplistic slogan, whether "strategic partners" or "strategic competitors." America's relationship with China is increasingly enmeshed in a broader global framework. Of course, some Sino-American problems -- Taiwan and missile defense, for example -- are not amenable to multilateral management. But China's increased participation in global organizations may well improve the way our two nations handle this always fraught relationship.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: ISLAMABAD; 
POWELL SUGGESTS ROLE FOR TALIBAN

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
The United States and Pakistan agreed today to work urgently for the creation of a new, broad-based government in Afghanistan that both sides said could include moderate elements of the Taliban movement whose present leadership is now a target for the American-led military campaign. 
 The agreement was the most visible achievement of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's visit here today as bombs continued to fall in Afghanistan on Taliban troop concentrations and on targets associated with Al Qaeda, the terrorist organization of Osama bin Laden. 
 The bombing of frontline Taliban positions near Kabul, the Afghan capital, has been largely avoided pending agreement on what sort of government might replace the Taliban. But in the last 24 hours the bombardment of Taliban positions, including those near the capital, has intensified. 
Secretary Powell said he had come to tell Pakistan that the United States -- long chastised here as having abandoned its cold war ally following the collapse of the Soviet Union -- was returning "to demonstrate our enduring commitment" to "a great Muslim nation."
The secretary said the revivified relations with Pakistan did not represent "just a temporary spike" in American focus, adding that Washington would stay the course to help rebuild Afghanistan and assist in Pakistan's development.
The high praise heaped on Pakistan provided a curious sight: an American secretary state standing next to a general in uniform who seized power in a military coup, and lauding his achievements.
Secretary Powell said the United States would also get more deeply involved -- if asked -- in resolving the longstanding and often violent conflict between Pakistan and India over Kashmir, a mainly Muslim territory claimed by both countries.
The American secretary's visit left no doubt that a far more robust American military and diplomatic initiative lies ahead in southern Asia, one that will require large expenditures, a re-examination of sanctions and other restricive policies and, in general, a much deeper involvement in the region than President Bush anticipated when he came to office nine months ago. 
Speaking at a news conference with Secretary Powell, the Pakistan president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, said, "We agreed that durable peace in Afghanistan would only be possible through the establishment of a broad-based, multiethnic government representing the demographic contours of Afghanistan, freely chosen by the Afghans without outside interference."
Those who could play a role in the formation of such a government, he said, include the former Afghan king, Mohammad Zahir Shah, "political leaders, moderate Taliban leaders, elements from the Northern Alliance, tribal elders" as well as "Afghans living outside their country."
Neither General Musharraf nor Secretary Powell elaborated on whom they considered to be "moderate Taliban leaders." But Dr. Abdullah Abdullah, the designated foreign minister of the Northern Alliance, the main opposition group to the Taliban in Afghanistan, said today that he would not accept any Taliban member in a future government. Pakistan regards the Northern Alliance with suspicion.
Secretary Powell appeared to support the notion of a Taliban presence in a future government. After the current government is toppled, he said, "there would still be those who might find that the teachings" and the "beliefs of that movement" are still very important. "We would have to listen to them or at least take them into account," he said.
General Musharraf's most immediate concern is the political difficulty of holding together a country where many people oppose the bombing in Afghanistan.
"Certainly a majority of the people are against the operation in Afghanistan," he said. "They would like to see this operation to be terminated as fast as possible, and that is what I would urge the coalition -- to achieve the military objectives and terminate the operation."
General Musharraf added, however, that polls show that "the majority of the people of Pakistan" support "my government's action."
The Pakistani president said that this "dichotomy" of public opinion illustrated the precarious political balance he is trying to maintain as thousands of Pakistanis continue to demonstrate, at times violently, against the American-led military campaign in Afghanistan. 
Though President Bush and Secretary Powell have condemned the Taliban leadership as evil, the secretary said today: "You can't export them. You can't send them to another country. You can't ethnically cleanse Afghanistan after this is over. But you can certainly get rid of this particular regime that has driven this country to such devastation."
In less than 24 hours, Secretary Powell packed in meetings with General Musharraf, his cabinet, the Pakistan intelligence chief and his top aides before flying to India. 
In the news conference, Secretary Powell pledged that "in the coming months the United States will take concrete steps to strengthen Pakistan's economy and further broaden our commercial and trade ties."
A senior administration official speaking to reporters afterward said the Bush administration is planning to provide another $550 million in economic assistance to Pakistan on top of the $50 million it made available shortly after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack on the United States.
That money was provided after Pakistan agreed to open its airspace and provide some logisitics and basing facilities to carry out operations inside Afghanistan.
Pakistan would also receive nearly $100 million to help control its borders and cope with the refugee crisis spawned by the military operations in Afghanistan. In addition, a significant share of the $320 million Washington approved for food and medical aid to Afghanistan would be earmarked for Pakistan port facilities, warehouses and logistics as it prepares for an even greater influx of Afghans fleeing the war.
The American secretary said he would take back to Washington General Musharaff's "strong message" that Pakistan wants even more debt relief than the resheduling of $379 million of obligations that was approved last month.
For his part, the Pakistani leader, who seized power in a bloodless coup in October 1999, told Mr. Powell that he was committed to holding democratic elections next year, and he pressed for greater access to the American market to stabilize a teetering economy.
As for Afghanistan itself, General Musharraf said: "The politcal process needs to be placed on a fast track in order to forestall the possibility of a political vacuum. It should not lag behind the fast moving events in the military field, nor should any attempt be made by any warring faction to impose itself on Afghanistan in the wake of the military strikes aginst the Taliban."
This last reference was clearly to the Northern Alliance, whose presence in power in Afghanistan would be unacceptable to Pakistan. 
Consultations on forming a new Afghan government are underway here between Pakistan, representatives of the former king and other Afghan factions. Other consultations are set for Washington and New York this week. A possible United Nations peacekeeping role in Afghanistan was also touched on during the discussions here.
The "success of any political process will also depend on economic conditions," the Pakistani leader said, because "Afghanistan has been destroyed by over two decades of conflict. The social economic infrastructure has been devastated, agriculture is in ruins, pastures have been destroyed, millions of mines litter the landscape."

HEADLINE: Keeping Peace in the Subcontinent 

 BODY:
The last thing Secretary of State Colin Powell needed as he began a delicate diplomatic mission to Pakistan and India this week was a flare-up of violence in Kashmir. Thanks to an untimely attack by India on Pakistani border posts, that is just what he got. The clash served notice, if any were needed at this volatile time in South Asia, that maintaining some sort of equilibrium in relations between Pakistan and India will be essential to waging a successful international war against terrorism. 
 In return for Pakistani support for the American bombing campaign in Afghanistan, President Bush has embraced Gen. Pervez Musharraf's regime in Islamabad and offered Pakistan large amounts of economic aid. Not surprisingly, that has alarmed Indian leaders, who before Sept. 11 had every reason to believe that Washington was eager to build stronger ties to New Delhi. Secretary Powell's difficult job has been to reinforce the new relationship with Pakistan while reassuring India that its interests will not be overlooked. 
 He appears to have accomplished the first part by gaining General Musharraf's agreement to work together to create a new, broad-based government in Afghanistan. To secure Pakistan's cooperation, Mr. Powell in principle endorsed the inclusion of moderate elements of the Taliban leadership. General Musharraf, for his part, did not insist on a fixed deadline for ending American military action. As General Powell completed his visit to Islamabad and began talks in India yesterday, it was clear that the Bush administration has no choice but to get more deeply engaged on a host of regional issues, including Kashmir.
General Musharraf deserves American support for his willingness to help in the campaign against the Taliban and Osama bin Laden. That does not mean he should be given a free hand to support Islamic fundamentalist extremists in Kashmir, the northern Indian state where a Muslim uprising has been raging for years. Pakistan needs to stop supporting guerrilla fighters in the conflict. India must understand that it cannot crush Muslim aspirations in Kashmir with the use of force.
Washington should also press the two nations to lower nuclear tensions. The Clinton administration made significant progress in getting India and Pakistan to agree to end nuclear testing, curb the production of weapons material and halt the export of sensitive material. That effort must be continued.
George W. Bush came into office determined to keep his distance from foreign conflicts that did not directly threaten American interests. He probably would have put the strains between India and Pakistan in that category before Sept. 11. Now, with American forces attacking Afghanistan, Washington will have to be very much involved in maintaining the peace between these two old adversaries.

HEADLINE: Grim Forces Converge at Industry Gathering 

BYLINE:  By KATIE HAFNER 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. 

 BODY:
THE two words used most frequently this week to describe Agenda 2002, the first gathering of computer industry executives since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, were "sober" and "subdued." 
 Attendance at the conference was down 15 percent, from 530 people last year to 450. In fact, said Stewart Alsop, a venture capitalist in Silicon Valley who started the conference in 1987 and oversaw it for 10 years, this was the first time in 14 years that the conference did not sell out. 
 Several people attending characterized the current state of the computer industry as "the perfect storm." That is, a downturn in the economy and the terrorist attacks have converged to foster a level of uncertainty that made last year's conference -- already sober in mood because of the dot-com collapse -- seem upbeat. 
Many of the people attending this time have been through an even more painful period since then as they watched their companies contract or disappear altogether and their personal fortunes wither. 
For years, the annual Agenda conference was equal parts mutual admiration society and sparring ground, the gathering place for the industry's elite members. Until a few years ago, Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates, was a regular, as were chief executives like Scott McNealy of Sun Microsystems and Lawrence Ellison of Oracle. 
The tone for this year's gathering, held at a luxury resort in Scottsdale, was set immediately. In the first five minutes, James Fallows, the executive producer of the conference, asked people in the room to observe a moment of silence for those who died in the attacks on Sept. 11. The names of more than 200 people associated with the computer industry scrolled down a large projection screen. 
At the sessions and in the hallways during breaks, talk was of the economy and of terrorism. One session was devoted entirely to the aftermath of the attacks and the implications for issues like the security of computer networks. 
Kelly Conlin, chief executive of IDG, the company that organizes the conference, said he had considered canceling it before deciding to proceed. "Events like this, particularly in the aftermath of what happened, are a sort of group therapy where people can take consolation," he said. 
Mr. Fallows said that attendance was down not because of the terrorist attacks but because of the lackluster state of the industry. Few people canceled after Sept. 11, he said. 
Despite the subdued mood of those who came, he said, many of them managed "to evoke that image of Rosie the Riveter rolling up her sleeves and getting to work." 
"In this condition of macro-gloom, there are selective opportunities," Mr. Fallows said. "A lot of people have been stressing the advantages to starting an enterprise in these circumstances. Talent is abundant, rent is cheap and there's less competition." 
Some said they were relieved to see that, for the most part, the dot-com participants had disappeared, leaving many from the original Agenda crowd. "They can't afford to come," said Eric Schmidt, chief executive of Google, the Web search company. Mr. Schmidt, who has attended Agenda for 10 years, was referring to the conference's $4,300 registration fee, among the highest in the computer conference circuit.
But the decline in dot-com participation cast the problems of the more traditional companies into sharper relief. 
"A year ago everyone believed that well-managed profitable businesses were immune from the downturn," said Ken Wasch, president of the Software and Information Industry Association, a trade group. "The last year has taught us that in a downturn, no company is immune." 
Some startups were still in evidence. Sergey Brin, president of Google, took the stage and defended his company's decision to continue what many now consider symbolic excesses of the dot-com era like free meals and massages for employees. Compared with a $100 million marketing campaign, he said, "these things cost nothing." 
Excess was not gone entirely absent from the conference. At a private dinner one evening, a successful entrepreneur ordered two bottles of $380 wine. Word spread quickly the next day. Two years ago, such a display of extravagance would not have gone unnoticed either, said Lise Buyers, a partner at Technology Partners, a venture capital firm in Palo Alto, Calif., after hearing about it. "It's just that it's twice as tasteless now," she said.

HEADLINE: A New Image: Why Pros Go Digital 

BYLINE:  By MARK GLASER 

 BODY:
FOR years now, digital cameras have been nice gadgets for the amateur photographer. They offer instant gratification in viewing or sending, without the cost of film or development. And they lend themselves to all sorts of other possibilities once the images are transferred to a computer. 
 But for many professional photographers -- the photojournalists who shoot for newspapers and magazines, and studio photographers who specialize in portraits or advertising work -- digital cameras have been a harder sell. Some resisted because they found digital cameras insufficiently versatile to justify the cost of professional-quality models. And some remain convinced that only film can provide photography worthy of a magazine cover or a museum wall. 
 There are increasing signs, however, that digital cameras are gaining a secure place in the professional camera bag. More and more photographers have experimented with them as an adjunct to film. Some favor digital cameras for certain situations or effects; a few use them exclusively. And digital work was prominent in the memorable photojournalism that emerged from the attack on the World Trade Center last month. 
Newspapers, wire services and even glossy newsmagazines made extensive use of digital images from their own photographers as well as amateur shots from witnesses. Dirck Halstead, a longtime photojournalist who runs a Web site called The Digital Journalist (www.digitaljournalist.org), estimates that two-thirds of photographers at the scene were shooting digitally.
"The advantage of digital in this case was the initial ability to see the photos right away" on a camera's L.C.D. screen, he said, "and also to transmit from nearby delis or drugstores" by transferring the images to a laptop computer and then connecting the modem to a phone line. Digital photographers, moreover, did not have to open their cameras, in a chaotic setting filled with smoke and ash, to reload film, although they did have to change memory cards. 
Many professionals who shoot with only digital cameras were impressed with their results on that difficult day. David Handschuh, a staff photographer for The Daily News, was blown a block away by the force of the implosion at the trade center. He credits emergency workers, who pulled him from the rubble three times that day, with saving his life.
"I lost my glasses, my cellphone, my pager, but not my cameras," said Mr. Handschuh, who is recovering at his home in New Jersey. "They were filled with dust, but the disks were O.K. and the pictures were fine." Over all, the day was a "true test of digital photography in recording history," he said, "and it definitely passed the test. The images will stand the test of time."
The digital road has been a bumpy one for photographers. Early digital cameras offered poor resolutions, suffered shutter delays, became obsolete in months and ran into the tens of thousands of dollars to buy -- and repair. Only recently have the standard Nikon D1 models used by professionals come down to $3,500 (the new D1x is about $5,300).
"It's right on the cusp right now," Maggie Hallahan, a San Francisco-based photographer who shoots both advertising and editorial assignments, said of the professional tendency toward film or digital cameras. "This new generation of pro digital cameras will make a huge difference."
Even Gregory Heisler, a portrait photographer who largely uses film cameras in his shoots of celebrities, could not suppress his enthusiasm for the tiny Canon Elph digital camera he tried out on a recent vacation.
"It's unbelievable, really," he said. "I had this little thing in my vest pocket, with this itty-bitty card that holds 300 pictures on it. I could take a picture of my daughter by candlelight without a flash, and it would look fantastic."
Now a convert to the digital way, Mr. Heisler sees a day in the near future when photographers will only use film as a "craft choice," the way fine art photographers make more expensive platinum prints. 
Photographers in the field have more flexibility with digital cameras to change light sensitivity -- and even switch from color to monochrome pictures -- on the fly. Many envisage a time when digital cameras will surpass film cameras in quality. 
Among the first professional photographers to make exclusive use of digital cameras are those who shoot for newspapers, with their emphasis on speed of delivery. The Associated Press began outfitting staff photographers with digital cameras in 1994 and went fully digital worldwide this year. 
Photojournalists have found that the L.C.D. preview screens on digital cameras have helped them connect with the people they are photographing, by showing them the results and thereby bringing down their defenses. And photographers quickly know if they got the shot, in far less than the time it normally takes to develop film.
Newspapers are rapidly changing from film to digital photography. At The New York Times, all staff photographers now have digital equipment, said Margaret O'Connor, the paper's picture editor, and about half use it exclusively. "We're very bullish on it," she said. On one assignment after another, most recently the fighting in Afghanistan, she said, "even the last holdouts are realizing they can't shoot a story like this without it." 
The Indianapolis Star switched to almost exclusively digital photos two years ago, and provided all 17 of its staff photographers with two Nikon D1 cameras. Matt Detrich, a 32-year-old staff photographer, said he fought hard against going digital at first. But then he had one of those moments in the field that changed his viewpoint. 
Shooting at a sensitive scene, where a father was despairing over his children's deaths in a fire, "I could just hold down the button and shoot," he said. "I was able to see that I had my picture, that it was in focus, it was correctly exposed." Once he knew he had the shot, the photographer could step away and let the family grieve.
Some photojournalists like the flexibility of having both film and digital cameras on the same assignment. Shooting the aftermath of the World Trade Center attack for The New York Times, Angel Franco, a staff photographer, used a Hasselblad film camera for panoramic shots but otherwise relied heavily on two Canon D30 digital cameras -- and his PowerBook laptop computer. 
"In an emergency, where you've lost water and electricity, we could never process film," said Mr. Franco. "Plus, I don't have to worry about running out of film. I can just download the digital pictures off the cards and shoot again."
A colleague at The Times, Fred R. Conrad, an accomplished portrait photographer, finds less to love about digital shooting. While acknowledging its advantages, especially speed, he says that digital photography eliminates many of the "inherent choices a photographer has -- the format, the camera, the lens -- to shape an image." 
And then there is the shutter delay that almost made him throw a $3,000 digital camera to the ground. "It's so maddening to try to take a picture and have the camera say it's busy," he said.
Even the most dedicated proponents of digital have seen its pitfalls. Mr. Halstead, who runs The Digital Journalist, has been at the forefront of digital photography and founded the Platypus movement, which pushes still photographers to acquire video and audio skills. But one of his most famous shots was made on slide film. When the Monica Lewinsky scandal broke, Mr. Halstead recalled seeing her face and searched through slides he had shot while covering the presidential election in 1996. He had an intern go through his old photos, which he archives painstakingly, and unearthed a shot of Ms. Lewinsky hugging the president.
"If the photographers to the left and right of me on that stage that night were shooting digital, they probably erased the files," Mr. Halstead wrote in an editorial on his site. "Monica who?" 
In this case, slides provided an archival edge, but mainly because of the photographer's memory. In fact, the ability to retrieve images readily from a searchable database helped accelerate the use of digital photography by news organizations. 
For freelance photographers, who have to file hundreds of thousands, even millions, of their own photos, the archiving issue is less clear-cut. Ms. Hallahan uses fireproof cabinets to store her slides and the CD's that she has burned with digital images. Not having the computer resources of a big organization, she finds digital storage costly for images that can each be huge files -- 11 megabytes or larger. 
As for digital photos she took only a few years ago, she has little use for them in her portfolio. "I looked back at my archives, my 'best of,' and I wouldn't ever include the digital images I took in a gallery show," she said. "Even the highest-quality digital cameras just didn't have the quality for output." 
Contrast that view with that of a still-life advertising photographer, Gregor Halenda, 35, who has been shooting entirely in digital for six years. He started with an early Phase One system, moved up to Leaf systems and is planning a studio upgrade to a $30,000 Sinar system. These are a step above those used by most photojournalists.
"Digital is a natural fit for me, with my personality being detail-oriented," Mr. Halenda said. At a recent one-day shoot for the Structure clothing store chain, he was able to send the art director and the client away at the end of the day with low- and high-resolution pictures burned on a CD. "They loved that," he said. (Like other film photographers, Mr. Halenda used to perform a similar function by taking instant pictures with a Polaroid camera, but "they were too small to be able to check critical focus," he said, "and the color was awful at best.") 
Harold Feinstein, a 70-year-old fine-art photographer, has also become a digital proponent. His last two books, "One Hundred Flowers" (Bulfinch Press, 2000) and "Foliage" (Bulfinch Press, 2001), were shot completely with digital cameras, and Mr. Feinstein, a master photo printer, says that the print quality has surpassed that of 35-millimeter film.
"Over the last three years, the quality has been spectacular," he said. "With digital, you can go to the edge of your creative intuition -- and not just to the edge, but go overboard." Besides, he said, "I don't miss washing trays in a darkroom."
Once you have gone digital, "there's no going back," Mr. Feinstein said. 
And going forward? Mr. Halstead foresees professional-quality hybrid cameras that will shoot digital still images and video and burn them directly onto blank DVD's, allowing photojournalists to abandon memory cards and digital videotapes completely.

HEADLINE: With Ishmael in That Island City; 
Though Everything Has Changed, Melville's Landlocked Dreamers Linger

BYLINE:  By A. O. SCOTT

 BODY:
The book, published 150 years ago today, speaks to you. I don't mean this as an empty gesture of literary piety but as a literal description. That famous first sentence -- "Call me Ishmael" -- is in the second person. Someone wants your attention. He is a New York character, and the encounter is one most New Yorkers have had at one time or another. A stranger approaches you on the street and starts talking. It's not entirely clear what he wants, but his speech is rapid and urgent. He tells you his name, though it occurs to you that it may not be his real name. You nod, you look at your watch, you keep walking, quickening your pace, instinctively checking the placement of your wallet or purse. Is he panhandling? Threatening? Is he lost? Crazy? Maybe a little:
 "Whenever I find myself involuntarily pausing before coffin warehouses, and bringing up the rear of every funeral I meet; and especially whenever my hypos get such an upper hand of me, that it requires a strong moral principle to prevent me from deliberately stepping into the street, and methodically knocking people's hats off -- " 
 Reflexively, your hand touches the top of your head. But his madness may be divinest sense. Look around you: 
"There now is your insular city of the Manhattoes, belted round by wharves as Indian isles by coral reefs -- commerce surrounds it with her surf. Right and left, the streets take you waterward. Its extreme down-town is the battery, where that noble mole is washed by waves, and cooled by breezes, which in a few hours previous were out of sight of land. Look at the crowds of water-gazers there. 
"Circumambulate the city of a dreamy Sabbath afternoon. Go from Corlears Hook to Coenties Slip, and from thence, by Whitehall, northward. What do you see?"
Call me literal-minded. The other day -- it was not the Sabbath, and it was morning, but my state of mind was appropriately dreamy -- I followed Ishmael's instructions, attempting to provide an earnest answer to his rhetorical question. And I found that, though everything has changed, Ishmael and I inhabit the same city.
This is in part because his city is to some degree a state of mind -- more precisely a state of feeling. That damp, drizzly November describes the internal weather of a great many of us these days even as the outward climate has provided a succession of warm, glittering autumn mornings. The twin towers stood a few blocks to the north, and a quiet crowd assembles, not to gaze out at the ocean, but to look at the wreckage. 
In New York, in normal times as well as traumatic ones, there is a feeling of loneliness in the midst of bustle that seems to have altered little in a century and a half. To call Manhattan "insular" is, strictly speaking, to say that it is an island, but the word carries a connotation of inwardness:
"Posted like sentinels all around the town, stand thousands upon thousands of mortal men fixed in ocean reveries. Some leaning against the spiles; some seated upon the pier-heads; some looking over the bulwarks of ships from China; some high aloft in the rigging, as if striving to get a still better seaward peep. But those are all landsmen; of week days pent up in lath and plaster -- tied to counters, nailed to benches, clinched to desks. How then is this? Are the green fields gone? What do they here?"
All these lonely people, where do they all come from? You can see them still, a few of them, though it's probable that Ishmael's numbers, even in his more nautical age, are inflated. Corlears Hook, a gentle protuberance jutting into the East River between the Williamsburg and Manhattan bridges, was in the mid-19th century a bustling seaside neighborhood of wharves and marketplaces. It is now a quiet zone of high-rise housing developments.
Straddling the F. D. R. Drive between Cherry and Jackson Streets is Corlears Hook Park, where a few solitary souls sit on benches, gazing at the cranes and smokestacks of the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The whoosh of traffic on the drive supplies an approximation of surf, and a schoolyard mural near Montgomery Street depicts an underwater scene of dolphins and whales (blue and gray and happy-looking, no "higher horror of the whiteness" here).
A little farther on, as Brooklyn curves away in the distance and the spans of the Manhattan and Brooklyn bridges run parallel across a widening expanse of sky, you begin to feel the sublime, outward tug of open ocean, and to recollect that insular Manhattan is, like Istanbul or Venice or the Old Amsterdam for which it was once named, a city whose reason for being is water. Ishmael, surveying the clustered masts around the harbor, was contemplating the old economy of seaborne commerce that made New York, even then, a center of world trade. (Melville, ever the prophet, also created, in Bartleby the Scrivener, the prototype of the alienated office worker belonging to a newer economic order.) 
Under the Manhattan Bridge, the first tang of salt hit my nostrils, and the noises of the modern city faded under the slap of choppy waters against the bridge's massive concrete feet. On every third or fourth bench someone sat, daydreaming of whale voyages or just catching a midmorning catnap. Below the South Street Seaport, low red brick buildings Melville might recognize gave way to concrete, glass and steel. A few late New Jersey commuters with their shoulderbags, cell phones and morning papers, trickled from the Wall Street ferry landing, and the gusts of wind grew stronger. 
Coenties Slip, once a narrow cul-de-sac of water, has long since crept inland as the Manhattan landfill extended into the river. It is now a stubby block-long thoroughfare between Water and Pearl streets, bounded on one end by the new Vietnam Veterans Memorial, on the other by the narrow, gridless ravines of the financial district. At the end of the block the wind shifted, bringing a smell of smoldering sheetrock and plastic -- a smell that carried intimations of weary grief and an anxiety that swells and ebbs like ocean waves. I turned away from it, following Ishmael's directions.
But his instruction to turn north on Whitehall may itself have an evasive intention: he was skirting the place where his creator was born in 1819. Continuing south on Pearl Street, toward Battery Park, I approached the black monolith of 1 Battery Park Plaza, which occupies the spot where Melville's family lived. When Herman was 11, his father's business collapsed, and the Melvilles moved to Albany. Two years later, Allan Melvill (his son would add the final "e") died, swamped by debts and unhinged by mental illness.
Families in Melville's fiction, when they exist at all, are realms of gothic unhappiness. Though Ishmael indulges in a brief reminiscence of his mother (who spanked him and sent him to bed in the middle of the day), he seems a man without background or parentage. Like all of the other members of the Pequod's ill-fated crew, he has no last name. He is, in his own words, an isolato, and at sea he finds a paradoxical community of fellow solitaries. 
A community that has something in common with a modern city: once they are united at sea, the ocean-gazing dreamers of the land turn their gazes on each other. Walking through Melville's city, your loneliness takes on a curiously social feeling. After a moment at the tip of the Battery, I turned north toward the busy desolation of West Street, and wound my way through the crowds that maneuvered around the blockaded streets west of Broadway.
Literature offers neither solace nor explanation for the present condition of lower Manhattan. Its value lies as much in its noncorrespondence with the world as in its fidelity to reality. Yes, Ahab might be interpreted as a figure of zealous, terroristic hatred commanding a suicide mission, but to force too much relevance onto "Moby-Dick" is to distort its meaning and corrupt its beauty.
Still, there is one moment in the first chapter that reads today like an eerie, inadvertent prophecy. Ishmael's impending voyage, he tells us, is "part of the grand programme of Providence . . . a sort of brief interlude and solo between more extensive performances." He continues: "I take it that this part of the bill must have run something like this:
"Grand Contested Election for the Presidency of the United States
"Whaling Voyage by One Ishmael
"BLOODY BATTLE IN AFGHANISTAN."
Here, aside from the uncanny coincidence of past and present, Ishmael describes the modern individual's predicament when faced with large movements of history from which he is necessarily alienated. Viewed objectively, our lives are small and inconsequential, our choices nugatory, but they never feel that way, and we struggle to comprehend the nature of the bonds, random or providential, that tether us to history. 
I finished my circumambulation on the West Side, on the far edge of the meat-packing district. Somewhere around here, at the Gansevoort Docks, Herman Melville, a former famous novelist, worked as a customs inspector for more than 20 years. In 1850, in the throes of conceiving "Moby-Dick" and worried about an outbreak of cholera, he moved his family to Pittsfield, Mass.
Thirteen years later, during the Civil War, he moved back, to take up his sinecure at the docks and occupy his brother's house on East 26th Street. The very address of his workplace must have been a daily rebuke: Gansevoort was his mother's maiden name, the name of an illustrious Dutch family and of a hero of the Revolutionary War, Herman's grandfather, General Peter Gansevoort. Melville's own name, as far as he knew, was on its way to being forgotten, the name of a depressive bureaucrat clinched to a desk. 
Back in the heart of the insular city, far from the water, I found a Starbuck's -- fittingly enough, since the coffee bars are named after the Pequod's first mate. And leafing through my battered copy of "Moby-Dick" I searched out those notable evocations of camaraderie and fellow feeling -- the love of Ishmael for Queequeg, the Polynesian harpooner; the utopian moment of sperm-squeezing on the deck -- and came to the end, with its chilling epigraph from the book of Job: "And I only am alone escaped to tell Thee."
The redundancy of "only" and "alone" -- as if solitude could be multiplied by itself -- obscures the fact that this is also a statement of witness, an act of communication. You are still here to listen, or no story could be told: narration requires a community, which is not bound by time or place. Following Ishmael through the streets of his New York, you feel a deep, melancholy pang of isolation and, at the same time, a miraculous harpoon-stab of connection.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 20, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A map of Manhattan in the arts pages on Thursday with an article about following the route of Ishmael, the narrator in Herman Melville's "Moby-Dick," along the southerly shores of the island, located Delancey Street incorrectly. It is the third street south of Houston; the fifth is Grand Street.

HEADLINE: Multinationals at the Gate 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, China 

 BODY:
China is girding itself to defend its huge yet fragile economy from an invasion by foreign companies once its membership in the World Trade Organization is ratified.
 Many Chinese applauded the completion of talks on China's entry to the global trading system, which were overshadowed by the terrorist attacks on the United States. After 15 years of on-and-off work, the talks were scheduled to wrap up in Geneva the week of Sept. 10; the attacks pushed them back a week. The formal gathering set to ratify China's accession, scheduled for Doha, Qatar, in November, seems likely to be relocated and perhaps postponed because of security concerns. 
 But China's membership is now certain by early 2002, starting a process that will transform its economy in ways that are already causing anticipation and anxiety among those who expect to be affected.
"Friends, you clap, but even I don't yet know how big the competition is that we'll face after we enter the W.T.O.," China's prime minister, Zhu Rongji, told a gathering of private businessmen in Nanjing the week the Geneva talks concluded. "My heart isn't yet very settled."
The market-opening process will be gradual, taking at least five years as threatened industries find ways to thwart W.T.O. rules. But there is no doubt about the course China has set, one the leadership hopes will ultimately strengthen the economy despite the dangers encountered along the way.
China's beleaguered farmers are among those most threatened by the changes the country agreed to make to become a W.T.O. member. Duties on imported agricultural products are to be reduced over time to 17 percent from an average of 22 percent now, and the reduction will be even greater for some American farm produce. Import quotas will be relaxed. Both changes will greatly increase the competition farmers face from imports.
Already, Chinese farm incomes are falling, and poverty is spreading in some areas where rural households depend on money sent home by relatives working on construction sites in cities. Labor is plentiful and cheap in the countryside, but total production costs on China's small farm plots are actually higher than in the West, where large mechanized farms provide economies of scale.
China dropped a ban on imports of American wheat last year, and it can now be bought in China for about $36 less a ton than can domestic wheat, putting downward pressure on local prices. That pressure will intensify after China raises its ceiling on wheat imports from the current 2 million tons annually, to 9.3 million tons by 2004.
Competition from efficient foreign agriculture is expected to hasten the already huge migration of people from the countryside into China's cities. The influx will strain urban social services and worsen urban unemployment, which has already risen sharply in recent years as the country has shaken up its industrial sector. China's state-owned industrial concerns have already shed about 35 million jobs the last five years, and government-controlled collectives laid off 16 million more. Economists estimate that another 30 million jobs are in jeopardy after China joins the W.T.O.
Competition for talent will also pose a problem, as many of the best and brightest managers and experts gravitate to multinational companies.
Among manufacturers, the country's fledgling automobile industry may be most vulnerable. Domestically built cars are sold for more than twice what similar models fetch in other countries, in large part because of high production costs. But by 2005, the quotas that limit competition from imports will be abolished, and tariffs are scheduled to slide steadily from as high as 100 percent now to just 25 percent. It is hard to imagine how domestic carmakers, few of which are profitable now, will be able to compete with cheaper, higher-quality imports.
Foreign companies threaten to grab vast chunks of the Chinese market in other fields where, despite years of government goading, domestic businesses are highly inefficient by global standards.
China's banks, for example, may lose as much as half of the market for fee-based banking services to foreign competition once foreign banks begin handling trade financing, credit card transactions and cash management. Foreign banks will be allowed to offer all of those services to both corporate and individual customers anywhere in the country five years after the country's membership becomes effective.
"Given the weak self-discipline and self-development mechanism, the weak infrastructure and the heavy historical burden, domestic institutions are not in an advantageous position," Dai Xianglong, China's chief central banker, said last month.
Foreign financial institutions will be allowed to own stakes of up to 49 percent in fund management companies within three years, and up to one-third in Chinese stock and bond underwriters.
Foreign companies are also expected to build their own modern retail and wholesale distribution networks that could quickly come to dominate distribution of many products, both domestic and imported.
Today, foreign companies may not legally distribute products in China other than those they make here. Nor can they own or manage distribution networks or wholesaling outlets.
China has promised that once it is a member of the W.T.O., those restrictions will be phased out within three years for most products.

HEADLINE: Companies Start Fund to Reward Hospitals for Better Care 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Within days after the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences shocked policy makers in late 1999 by reporting that mistakes in hospitals were killing tens of thousands of Americans each year, some of the nation's largest companies met and agreed to throw their weight behind efforts to make hospitals safer.
 Now, putting cash behind that commitment for the first time, four big New York companies will announce a $2 million incentive program today to encourage hospitals in the state to improve patient safety by requiring doctors to use computerized systems that guard against errors. To receive the bonuses, the hospitals will also have to hire physicians who specialize in intensive care to supervise their sickest patients. 
 For covered employees, the companies will add a bonus to each payment to hospitals that meet these safety standards, which were established by the national employers' organization, the Leapfrog Group. It has grown to more than 80 companies and government agencies that cover 26 million people. 
The New York sponsors -- Verizon Communications, I.B.M., PepsiCo and Xerox -- will join with Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield to offer the program. They cover more than 100,000 employees and their families in 28 counties in the city and eastern New York.
Some of the country's largest employers, including General Motors in Detroit, Boeing in Seattle and members of an Atlanta coalition, the Georgia Health Care Leadership Council, said they were planning similar Leapfrog programs.
Dr. Michael Stocker, chief executive of Empire, said the four New York employers were persuaded to finance bonuses after a recent study led by Dr. John D. Birkmeyer of the Dartmouth Medical School showed an economic payoff in shorter hospital stays, as well as fewer deaths. Other published studies have shown that electronic systems can reduce errors in prescriptions by 85 percent and that intensive care specialists on staff can reduce mortality rates in the intensive care unit by 10 percent, potentially saving thousand of lives.
"Providers have to order tests, prescription drugs and other things inside hospitals on a system backed up by artificial intelligence," said Bruce Taylor, director of benefits planning at Verizon, which covers 40,000 of its employees, retirees and dependents through Empire. "The system can make sure the order is accurate." Starting Jan. 1, hospitals that meet the standards will receive a 4 percent bonus, based on their charges for patients. The bonus will drop to 3 percent in 2003 and 2 percent in 2004. Only 7 or 8 of the 148 eligible hospitals will have complete computerized physician ordering systems by January, and 40 will have intensive care specialists, Empire estimates. But it expects those numbers to rise sharply in the following two years. 
Hospital executives said the bonuses would be tiny compared with the cost of installing the electronic systems: $5 million to $60 million, depending on hospital size and capabilities, which can include complicated record-keeping and information services. 
Hospital technology experts were excited about the possibilities for improving care. "In some systems, when a doctor is ordering a certain drug, a message could pop up on the screen saying the substance is excreted through the kidneys and the patient's kidney functions are worsening," said Dr. Tom Handler, a research director at Gartner Inc., a consulting firm.
Jack Wolf, chief information officer of Montefiore Medical Center, which has installed electronic ordering in 70 percent of the hospital, said: "In the next wave, the system will feed the medical results back into the front end of the process. Then the physician can actually drill down into the outcomes" and see how many patients who took a certain medication actually improved. 
Leapfrog employers are also asking hospitals to report on the number of patients in major categories so employees can see which hospitals have the most experience in treating diseases like cancer or heart disease. Hospitals worry about the costs, of course. "The challenge for any hospital is that only a small percentage of its patients are covered by these employers," said Theresa A. Bischoff, president of NYU Hospitals Center and chairwoman of the Greater New York Hospital Association.

HEADLINE: Thousands of Out-of-Work People Attend Job Fair 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
By the time the doors opened yesterday morning at the Twin Towers Job Expo, a city-sponsored effort to assist New Yorkers who lost their jobs in the wake of the World Trade Center disaster, the line wound three times around the two square blocks at Madison Square Garden and Pennsylvania Station. 
 So huge was the crowd, which city officials said was at least 8,000, that the city plans to conduct at least one more similar job fair. Deputy Mayor Anthony P. Coles said the city had received calls in recent days from 50 companies seeking to take part, companies that could not be accommodated yesterday because of space limitations. "We're going to make this a regular part of what the city does," Mr. Coles said. "The turnout shows that a lot of people want to work in the city and a lot of companies want to hire people." 
 Each of the 200 participating companies vowed to give priority for new hires to people who lost their jobs directly as a result of the attack on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11. 
The companies included the Metropolitan Opera, which was hiring telemarketers but not tenors, to 1-800-TOW-TRUCK, a dispatcher for roadside automobile service that was looking for customer service and sales people. ("If you can use a computer and a phone at the same time, you're halfway to a job," Barry Miller, assistant director of human resources, told a potential recruit. "If you're willing to come to Newark, you're three-quarters of the way.") 
Large corporations like Citibank and AOL Time Warner were represented, as were smaller companies, among them a half dozen security firms that are likely to see increased demand for their services.
But while many of those attending could trace their job needs to the Sept. 11 attack, thousands more have been out of work for months, felled by a slowing economy and the collapse of the dot-com bubble. They came yesterday, too.
Job offers did result for some of those with enough foresight to be among the first in line for the fair, which was conducted on the ground level of exhibition space underneath the Garden's arena seating. In the first two hours, 40 of the participating companies had screened 1,500 prospective employees and offered jobs to 435, Mr. Coles said. Last night, a spokesman said that several thousand people attending the expo received preliminary job offers. But in interviews with people leaving the event, many said they simply dropped off resumes, and few companies were actually offering jobs. 
At day's end, many were turned away from the job fair. Hundreds were waiting when officials announced at least two hours before the official closing time that they would stop letting people in. A spokesman for Mr. Coles said about 2,000 people who could not get in yesterday were given tickets for priority entry to a job fair next Thursday.
Anna Pugliese had arrived at 3 p.m. and waited for an hour before a security guard turned her away. Ms. Pugliese, 52, who was laid off in April from Morgan Stanley in the World Trade Center, said her job prospects had dimmed considerably. "The World Trade Center was where I used to go to leave resumes," she said. "So now I'm left with nowhere to go. This was a mob scene."
Earlier, Duane Reade, the drugstore chain, told 20 people that they would be able to start work on Monday if they passed an employee screening program. All of those jobs are entry-level cashier or shipping and delivery positions paying $5.15 an hour, said Bolivar Garcia, an employee service liaison for Duane Reade. 
"We've had people coming in looking for information technology jobs, people with computer degrees, chefs, cooks," Mr. Garcia said. "These were people used to making $40,000 to $50,000 a year or more. We told them that everybody goes in at the minimum, but you can move up from there quickly. And a lot of people are just looking for jobs, because the bills are catching up."
The Fiscal Policy Institute, a nonprofit research organization, estimated last month that 65,000 jobs were directly affected by the World Trade Center attack, and that 43,000 more were affected by its spillover.
Many of the people in line -- clutching resumes, wearing their best interview suits and shivering in the brisk autumn breeze that turned into gusts that whipped around the Garden -- exhibited a genuine optimism about their prospects, despite the long line, the economic downturn and uncertainty and fear unleashed by the terrorist attack.
Heather Maly, who graduated from Georgetown University in May, followed through on her plans to move from Indianapolis to New York to find work, even a week after the World Trade Center attack. She had signed a Manhattan apartment lease in late August.
"Certainly the disaster caused me to hesitate, wonder should I go or should I not," she said. "But New York is where I wanted to be."
Ms. Maly added: "Now I doubt my decision because no one wants to hire anyone. I was thinking 'I want this kind of job' or 'I want that kind of job.' Now I just want a job."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Once inside the Twin Towers Job Expo yesterday, people filled out forms from companies large and small. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The New York Times Co. Registers a Sharp Drop in 3rd-Quarter Earnings 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
The New York Times Company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings fell sharply as higher circulation revenue was more than offset by a decline in advertising brought on by the weak economy.
 "For much of the past six months, despite the dreary media climate, we believed that we would see signs of recovery by the fourth quarter," Leonard P. Forman, a senior vice president at the Times Company, said in a conference call with analysts yesterday. The attacks on Sept. 11 changed that outlook, he said, and made it very difficult to predict how the company would fare through the rest of the year. 
 The company said that by its preferred method of measuring profits, earnings fell 26.5 percent, to $46.3 million, or 30 cents a diluted share, compared with $63 million, or 37 cents a diluted share, in the period a year earlier. 
The figures in the latest quarter exclude a variety of items, including a profit last year from the sale of four newspapers and nine telephone directories. Over all, net income for the quarter fell 41.5 percent, to $43.8 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with $75 million, or 44 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
Advertising revenue, excluding revenue from businesses that have been sold, fell 14.5 percent in the quarter, to $452.7 million. Ad revenue at the New England Newspaper Group, which includes The Boston Globe, declined more sharply, falling 21.2 percent; at The New York Times, advertising revenue fell 14.4 percent.
The company said higher prices for its publications were the main reason for a 7.3 percent increase in circulation revenue, excluding divested properties, but it added that sales increased at all its publications after the Sept. 11 attacks.
The company's results were in line with analysts' estimates, many of which were revised lower after Sept. 11. Shares of the company fell $1.97, or 4.7 percent, to $40.02 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
The stock price decline probably reflects concern about the company's year-end results, given the uncertain economic climate and the lack of guidance offered in yesterday's conference call, said Michael A. Kupinski, an analyst with A. G. Edwards in St. Louis.
"They're experiencing something industrywide," he said, adding that the focus of the company on major urban markets may make it more vulnerable to the current slowdown in classified and help-wanted advertising than some companies in smaller cities. 
The Times Company said its overall revenue fell 9.2 percent, to $696.9 million, in the third quarter, compared with $767.7 million in the quarter a year earlier. The results last year included revenue from some properties that have since been sold. Excluding those businesses, revenue fell 7.7 percent. 
The company's online venture, New York Times Digital, reported an operating profit of $6.1 million in the quarter, its first quarterly operating profit ever. That is in contrast to a loss of $17 million last year. The profit reflected substantial expense cuts and came despite a decline in revenue.
Operating profit in the company's broadcast business fell 40 percent, to $6.1 million from $10.2 million, largely because of lower advertising revenue. The company said the quarter a year earlier benefited from political advertising, while the latest quarter was hurt by the pre-emption of regular commercials and programming in the wake of the terrorist attacks. Excluding special items, the company said that the operating profit decline in the broadcast segment was 44.9 percent.
Executives at the Times Company refrained from giving guidance regarding results for the fourth quarter or the year. "Economic uncertainty makes it difficult to give guidance for the balance of the year," Mr. Forman said. 

CORRECTION-DATE: October 19, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about third-quarter results for The New York Times Company misstated the operating profit of the company's online division, New York Times Digital. It was $786,000 ($6.1 million was the figure for the company's broadcast business).

HEADLINE: A Downturn Settles In Downtown; 
Shoppers Are Indulging, But Not Near Attack Site

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN and TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
By the time Jose Hernandez arrived at his job at Broome Street Flowers and Interiors in SoHo on Sept. 11, he had already seen the fiery slashes in the World Trade Center and knew a catastrophe was in the making. Still, he followed his routine, prepping newly bought willow and berry branches for display. 
 The branches were never sold, of course. Within an hour, the towers had collapsed and Manhattan was being sealed off below 14th Street. By the time the authorities let Mr. Hernandez back into the store three days later, the berries had shed all over the floor. He was able to save his delicate yucca palms, but those have not sold since, either. A month later, Mr. Hernandez estimates his business is still off some 80 percent. 
 In a shopping district a short subway ride -- and yet a universe -- away, players seemed to be acting out of a different script. A woman walked into Anne Fontaine, a boutique on Madison Avenue and 67th Street where blouses sell for $168 on average, bought six, and asked to have them ironed and delivered.
The terrorist attack on the World Trade Center sent economic shock waves rippling up all of New York's renowned shopping avenues, but display windows did not rattle equally. Consider the disparate impact on SoHo and Madison Avenue, perhaps New York's most famous byways of unapologetic consumption.
Both districts have emporiums filled with delectables as different as spike-heeled boots and antique Japanese crockery. But SoHo -- with its greater proximity to ground zero, greater reliance on tourists and a set of stores that cater not to the deeply entrenched superwealthy but rather their more financially vulnerable, newly minted cousins -- has been in much more pain.
Even these days as the October light illuminates the fire escapes on the converted industrial lofts, the urban-perfect streetscapes are empty. At the flea market at Wooster and Spring Streets, half of the stalls have closed. 
"It is very, very slow," said Avital Alfasi, who sells fleece hats and bohemian velvet scarves. "It is so sad. Normally on the weekends it would be packed with people from New Jersey and Long Island sitting outside and drinking coffee. Now there is nobody. You don't even see shopping bags anymore."
Far uptown, the boutique operators on Madison Avenue say the fallout from the terrorist attack has been far less stark.
True, the kind of sang-froid demonstrated by the Anne Fontaine customer was unusual. For several days after the terrorist attack, business along the avenue dropped off significantly, and several stores say they are still hurting. On a recent Friday afternoon, the Valentino store on 65th Street was devoid of customers, and at Mario Caldi, a nearby men's clothing store where Italian suits are priced from $950 to $2,500, Asad Haider, a salesman, said that nothing had sold the entire day. 
Still, the storekeepers say, the total effect of the trade center disaster has been more like a slap on the cheek than a body blow. Madison Avenue is such an island unto itself that, amazingly, a few store managers even said that sales had been up in the aftermath of Sept. 11. 
Wide flat-screen televisions with the latest in so-called plasma technology priced at $8,000 to $16,000 are continuing to sell at Red Rose Music on 74th Street, said Mark Herman, an audio-visual designer. 
At Zitomer's, an upscale pharmacy on 76th Street, toy sales have increased 10 percent over this time last year. And for reasons that Karl Wong, the toy department manager, cannot explain, many parents started doing their Christmas toy shopping in September.
"We're doing really well," echoed Gloria Karlitz, the manager of a Searle clothing store on 84th Street, where customers have been snapping up $400 winter coats. "Maybe people feel safer on 84th Street than further downtown."
Geography certainly explains, in part, why SoHo is suffering. The silhouettes of the giant trade center towers once loomed above Canal Street. So, their collapse radically changed both the physical and psychic space of the area.
Like the nearby neighborhoods of TriBeCa and Battery Park City, SoHo has been partly depopulated. Those who have stayed put in their homes and businesses still have not wiped away all the ashy fallout from the wreckage and are reconstructing their lives in a way that uptown neighbors have not had to do.
Norman Kornbleuth, owner of the Broadway Panhandler, a popular cookware store on Broome Street, said that most of his regular customers lived beneath 23rd and were too traumatized by events to go shopping. "People are just staying closer to home," he said. His sales are down about 25 percent since Sept. 11.
Proximity to the devastation zone is only part of the equation, however. Madison Avenue is somewhat sheltered from economic downturns by the special nature of its customer base: rich, local and, well, very rich. Local is critical right now as out-of-towners from Princeton to Tokyo are shunning the city. No place is better equipped than Madison Avenue, with its army of immaculately coifed sales associates, to lure customers back on a one-by-one basis.
"Many salespeople have been working with clients for many years,dressing them and giving them advice," said Matthew Bauer, the president of the Madison Avenue Business Improvement District, which represents 650 businesses from 61st to 85th Streets. "Because of these long-term relationships, our stores will be able to weather the storm," he said.
While Madison Avenue boutiques have built business by coddling clients, SoHo, with a less dense population base -- locals tend to live in huge loft spaces in low-slung buildings -- relies heavily on the bused-in hordes. On a recent afternoon, Dom, a furniture store specializing in moderately priced items like inflatable chairs and mirrored globes, was empty. 
"Without the tourists," said the store manager, Luigi Borrata, "it is totally slow."
Then there is the matter of wealth. SoHo has only recently become a truly luxe shopping district with stores like Chanel and Louis Vuitton. It attracts its share of the monied, but in general the stores strategically aim to appeal to a broader clientele than those up on Madison Avenue, which are quite intentionally practical only to those in the stratospheric income levels. Such an ultrarich clientele is naturally more immune to the stock market swings and recession fears that have followed the trade center attack. 
For example, if Jeanne Coogan was worried about her long-term economic prospects last week, she wasn't showing it as she strolled Madison Avenue. Ms. Coogan said she heeded the mayor's call to save the city by shopping. Since the 11th, she has bought about 40 percent more than she usually does in a comparable period, she estimated, including treating herself to such luxuries as a jeweled handbag. 
"I'm living every day like it could be my last," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: At Red Rose Music, above, on 74th Street, customers are still willing to pay up to $16,000 for flat-screen televisions, and some Madison Avenue stores say sales are up. But in SoHo, which relies more heavily on the tourist trade and is much closer to the trade center attack, business is suffering. (Photographs by Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)
