HEADLINE: G.M. Extending Incentives As Ford Posts Another Loss 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
General Motors today extended interest-free financing deals on its vehicles through mid-November, escalating a price war with the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Group that began last month.
 There were signs today that the rising incentive costs were taking their toll. Ford reported a third-quarter net loss of $692 million, posting a second consecutive quarter of losses for the first time in nearly a decade. The loss was in line with analysts' estimates. 
 "I think it will be difficult to earn a profit in the fourth quarter," Martin Inglis, Ford's chief financial officer, said in a conference call. Shares of Ford fell 55 cents, or 3.1 percent, to $17.13. 
Mr. Inglis cited rising incentive costs as a leading problem. After the Sept. 11 attacks, G.M. started offering interest-free financing deals on its entire vehicle lineup in an attempt to bolster stagnant sales. Ford and Chrysler quickly followed suit.
While such deals are good for buyers, they drive up costs for the already beleaguered Big Three, which have been rapidly losing market share to foreign automakers. Executives at Ford and Chrysler have derided the rising tide of incentives as a costly tactic that borrows against future sales by making them less profitable now.
"The 'Ford Drives America' zero percent financing program did jump-start sales in mid-September, and I think that was important," Mr. Inglis said. "However, marketing rose to what I consider to be unsustainable levels."
Mr. Inglis said that incentives ate up 16 percent of revenue, compared with 11 percent last year. He estimated that each percentage point increase in incentives sliced another $1 billion from Ford's annual pretax profits. Asked about G.M.'s decision to extend its "Keep America Rolling" plan beyond the end of this month, to Nov. 18, Mr. Inglis spoke with a touch of irony.
"That was a thrill for me to read this morning that they had extended to the middle of November," he said. "I'm glad they are a very competitive company, and we will have a look at what is required for Ford to remain competitive."
In an interview Tuesday, Wolfgang Bernhard, the chief operating officer of Chrysler, a unit of DaimlerChrysler of Germany, was also critical. "I don't think this is helping the industry," he said. "It's going to make it more difficult for the Big Three to be financially viable in the long term."
Ford's revenue was $36.55 billion, down 9 percent from the quarter a year earlier. The company had operating losses of $502 million, excluding one-time charges, versus operating earnings of $994 million for the year-earlier quarter. The company's net cash level is now at its lowest point since 1992. 
Mr. Inglis said reduced volume was the largest contributor to third-quarter losses. Ford cut its North American production 23 percent from the period a year ago. This was partly because of parts shortages stemming from halted air transportation and border closings after the Sept. 11 attacks, but was also a strategic move as the economic outlook clouded. Ford's Hertz unit reported a profit of $26 million, down from $143 million a year earlier. The car rental industry has been hit hard, as business at airports has fallen off.
Ford, which has also absorbed the cost of replacing millions of Firestone tires on its vehicles, is in the midst of a turnaround effort. The company has consolidated its car and truck development divisions; cut production; said it would cut 4,000 to 5,000 white-collar jobs; canceled bonuses for 6,000 executives; and cut its dividend in half. 
Ford's problems are causing increasing speculation about the future of its chief executive, Jacques A. Nasser. People close to the company say that he has lost the board's confidence and probably will not last the year, but Ford has dismissed such talk. 
"This was a difficult quarter, as our results were affected by an uncertain and slowing U.S. economy, compounded by the tragic events of Sept. 11," Mr. Nasser said today in a statement.
G.M. reports its earnings Thursday. The company, the world's largest automaker, has been losing market share for decades but has a new lineup of light trucks and actually gained share in September, while Ford and Chrysler continued to lose ground. But analysts say G.M.'s short-term gains could hurt profits. 
"G.M. feels like they're in the sweet spot, and they're trying to push their advantage," said Stephen J. Girsky, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, adding, "You don't really know the cost of all this until you know how much in future sales you pulled ahead at a discount."
John Casesa, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said of the strategy,"it's very risky," but added that G.M. had to turn around its market share at some point so it could stay large enough to pay its legacy costs, like health and pension benefits to its many retirees. 
The risk, he said, is that G.M. is pushing incentives "to a level that will destroy everyone's margins."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook; 
In Quiet Corners, the Roots of Afghan Rebellion

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: QUETTA, Pakistan, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
While bombs fall in Afghanistan, a quieter war is being waged in the dusty border city of Quetta and, farther north, in the mud-brick city of Peshawar. It is a clandestine affair, intended to win converts for an attempt to overthrow the Taliban.
 Mujahedeen commanders, tribal chiefs and other prominent Afghans opposed to the ruling Taliban gather in carpet shops, in coffee houses and behind closed doors in both cities to discuss shifting alliances and strategies for exploiting a schism among Taliban leaders. Some travel from Afghanistan, crossing the mountains for talks that could shape the future of their country and the outcome of the American war. 
 In a discreetly guarded, high-walled villa in Quetta, Hamid Karzai receives a steady stream of visitors with rebellion on their minds. Mr. Karzai is an influential Pashtun chief and powerful mediator among the commanders and tribal leaders. Some guests are more welcome than others at his conclaves. 
Two men arrived the other afternoon from Pakistan's intelligence agency, Inter-Services Intelligence. They fell on the unwelcome side of the guest book because anti-Taliban Afghans blame Pakistan, particularly I.S.I., for arming the regime in Kabul, at least until Sept. 11.
"We have changed our policies," one agent said, according to a person who was present. "Don't worry."
Mr. Karzai was having none of it. "You didn't change your policies," he said. "You have been forced to change your policies by the Americans."
End of conversation. The visitors left without a cup of tea, a telling insult in a culture where even adversaries are usually treated politely inside someone's home.
Jamil Karzai, a cousin of Mr. Karzai's, said later that resentments run too deep for Pakistan to play a role in the overthrow and that many anti-Taliban leaders oppose granting Islamabad any role. "We tried Pakistan once and Pakistan failed that test," he said. "Now we are optimistic because of the Americans."
Of course, Afghanistan tried the Americans once, too, and the result was the Taliban.

Education, at a Price
Fatima Sakhi's tiny fingers moved swiftly and nimbly up and down the loom, expertly pulling the threads of wool into place and tying off the knots. Fatima, who is 9 years old, worked in imposed silence on a bench beside five other children, all between the ages of 8 and 12.
In the small, dim room, four sets of child weavers worked intently, producing rugs in traditional Afghan designs for sale in bazaars in Quetta and other Pakistani cities. The refugee children work 5 to 10 hours a day to earn $5 to $7 a month.
Fatima is lucky. She comes at 8 every morning, but leaves at 1 p.m. for school. Most of the 23 other children work until evening.
"Everyone in every family must work in order to survive, no matter how young or how little pay," said Kazim Wahdi, a teacher in the Afghan refugee settlement known as Hazaratown, on Quetta's outskirts.
In this world of shared misery, all things are relative. Fatima's family could not afford the $1 a month it costs to send her to school if she did not work. Is a tedious and difficult job too high a price for a 9-year-old to pay for her education?

Order From Chaos
The pecking order among refugees is well defined. Status depends on how long people have been here, whether they have a job and whether they have relatives who can help.
Few refugees have been integrated into Pakistani society. The government pushes them to the margins, and most say they want to go home when the time comes anyway.
The oldest refugee settlements have turned into villages or towns, and they are the top rung. Hazaratown is next. Most of its 100,000 residents arrived in the 1990's, and they have created a subsistence economy.
Not far away is the bottom rung, a camp with no name where hundreds of refugees arrive weekly. The fortunate ones join relatives already packed into tattered tents or mud-brick hovels. Others huddle in roofless enclosures. There are no jobs or schools, and women walk a mile each way to get water from a well.
The new refugees have one advantage: they can register with the United Nations to receive food assistance, while others get nothing unless they are widows or orphans.
United Nations workers said they had learned to recognize customers who come week after week for months, always claiming to be new arrivals. The rules led to a rare moment of levity recently when an old man walked up to an aid worker, followed by an old woman.
"This is my wife," the old man said. "She is a widow."

Reality Programming
The moment was cinematic: hundreds of young men charging across the shimmering desert sands, hell-bent for a convoy of trucks carrying journalists to the Pakistan-Afghan border. These were not movie extras, and as the mob closed in, screams of "Death to America!" began to sound like "Death to reporters!"
The 500 to 600 men were aiming for the railroad crossing where the vehicles would have to slow. Confronted with an obviously angry crowd, the journalists were of two minds: some shouted at the drivers to speed up, others told them to slow down for a closer look. The open truck carrying six armed Pakistani police at the head of the convoy never hesitated; it bounced over the tracks at full speed, well ahead of the mob.
Half the vehicles made it before the crowd poured onto the highway. Cut off, the others made a hasty retreat as the protesters pounded with sticks on a couple of cars.
The crowd had come from a nearby Afghan refugee camp, it turned out, but the big question was how they had known the journalists were coming. 
With so many journalists cooped up together in a country under military rule, conspiracy theories are always rife. This time fingers pointed to the police, who had allowed the press to take the trip only under duress and who mount a daily effort to keep the foreigners corralled inside the Serena Hotel. No one, however, was willing to go back and interview the young men.

Flying the Coop
The hotel, a walled compound of gracious adobe buildings, has become a gilded cage for the 60 or 70 foreign journalists staying there. Every morning they awake to find the big iron gates rolled closed and guarded by police. Every morning an argument ensues about whether they can get out of the hotel to cover the demonstrations in the streets or buy more rugs in local shops.
The police insist that they are protecting the journalists. The journalists insist that they know the risks. 
The police thought their argument was underscored when they used tear gas to turn back an unruly crowd of 300 men trying to get into the hotel. The journalists were all the more insistent on leaving.
In early October, The Associated Press, Reuters and The New York Times obtained an order from the province's highest court requiring the police to permit them to "move freely to make coverage of the latest developments at their risk and cost."
The order proved ineffective. The senior police officer in charge of keeping the foreigners inside the compound made that clear one morning as about 20 journalists surrounded him in the parking lot and he was handed the order.
The police officer read the order aloud and gave his interpretation. "This has negated the positive," he said triumphantly, stalking off without explaining the mysterious phrase.
The day after the Americans began to bomb Afghanistan, reporters stood on the roof of the hotel and watched smoke rising from fires set by demonstrators across the city.
Late in the afternoon, after pleas and shouts had failed to open the hotel gates, about 30 journalists gathered at the lowest point on the wall and began to scale it. The first over were whacked soundly by police with bamboo staves, but finally there was a large enough group outside that the police relented. 
The journalists were loaded into police trucks for a tour of the city. Shop windows had been smashed and three cinemas showing American films had been burned, but the eeriest scene was a gutted fire truck still smoldering in the middle of a busy street.

HEADLINE: Russia Closing 2 Major Posts For Snooping, One in Cuba 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
Scrapping an outdated symbol of its superpower days, the Kremlin said today that it would abandon its largest electronic eavesdropping post in the West, at Lourdes, Cuba, and spend much of the savings on modern weapons for its armed forces.
 President Vladimir V. Putin also said Russia would begin a long-planned withdrawal from a major Pacific eavesdropping post, at Cam Ranh Bay, Vietnam, on Jan 1. 
 Appearing after a meeting at Russia's Defense Ministry, Mr. Putin cast the closings largely as budgetary decisions, part of his campaign to streamline and rearm a military critically short of money, morale and expertise since the Soviet collapse. 
"The development of the armed forces to a new technological level will require money, and we are going to have to find it," Mr. Putin said. "Standing up to international terrorism has considerable military implications." 
There was no indication, however, that Russia had taken the step as part of any quid pro quo with the United States as Washington tries to assemble a global coalition against terrorism. 
Instead, Mr. Putin emphasized that without better weaponry and more combat training, Russia's armed forces risked turning into a glorified military school where soldiers learned the science of fighting without picking up the skills. 
But the symbolism of Russia's departure from two of its mightiest cold war outposts was impossible to ignore. The Lourdes post, which dates to 1964, was the hallmark of the Soviet presence in the Americas and, for decades, a major concern of American intelligence. 
President Bush today welcomed the Russian decision to close its eavesdropping site in Cuba. "This decision is another indication that the cold war is over," he said in a statement. "President Putin understands that Russia and America are no longer adversaries."
The site at Cam Ranh Bay had been a strategic American base before United States forces turned it over to the Saigon government in 1972. The Soviets, and later the Russians, used it to maintain a Pacific Ocean presence and to eavesdrop on Chinese naval activity.
The abandonment of both sites fits Mr. Putin's pattern of cutting back on global commitments that make little sense in an era when Russia has no clear enemy and scant reason to keep up a worldwide military presence it cannot afford. 
"Moscow's no longer running a superpower," John Pike, an American intelligence analyst who directs the Virginia-based research group GlobalSecurity.org, said in an interview today. "I think that basically, they're just trying to tidy up the map a bit."
Aleksandr A. Pikayev, a military expert at the Moscow Center of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said the decision to leave Lourdes was nevertheless almost certainly a painful one.
"It definitely would be a big surprise for many analysts here," he said.
The two closings will save Russia $200 million a year in rent, all of it for the Cuba site and much of it, apparently, in the form of in-kind payments to the Cuban government, like fuel and food.
The Soviet Union and Russia have used the Cam Ranh Bay base free since the 1970's, but Vietnam said last year that it planned to charge $300 million a year in rent had Russia renewed its lease in 2003.
The chief of the Russian military general staff, Gen. Anatoly Kvashnin, said that for the money spent to rent Lourdes alone "we can buy and launch 20 military satellites into space" and buy dozens of modern radars.
The 28-square-mile Lourdes complex, employing up to 1,500 Russians, is said to be among the biggest eavesdropping stations anywhere. In 1993, President Fidel Castro's brother Raul, Cuba's armed-forces chief, said Russia obtained 75 percent of its strategic intelligence on the United States from data and voice communications intercepted there.
In its heyday Lourdes picked up telephone transmissions throughout the southeastern United States, tracked American naval operations in the Caribbean, sent instructions to Russian ships and submarines and monitored military and civilian space activity at Cape Canaveral.
Russian journalists have said Lourdes provides communications support for Russian intelligence agents in North America and, with another outpost in Russia, manages the nation's spy satellite fleet.
But Russia's global spy-satellite network has deteriorated, and most American telephone conversations today travel by fiber-optic cable, not microwave. Experts say the Lourdes station has turned increasingly toward intercepting transmissions from American spy satellites and on collecting economic and industrial intelligence beamed to and from commercial satellites.

HEADLINE: In America; 
The Democrats Fiddle

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Anyone who thought the city's most influential Democrats would recognize that New York and the nation are caught in a grave crisis, and therefore all cheap and petty and divisive politics should be put aside, has been thoroughly, if not sickeningly, disappointed.
 Enough already with the whining and the finger-pointing and the perennial caviling about this ethnic group and that. 
 Fernando Ferrer and his supporters are unhappy with the way Mark Green campaigned in the days leading up to last Thursday's runoff. They have reason to be unhappy. Mr. Green, a lifelong liberal and self-proclaimed candidate of unity, certainly played the fear card, if not the race card, in his attempt to fend off a Ferrer win by appealing to white voters unhappy with the thought of ethnic minorities in City Hall. 
But that strategy followed Mr. Ferrer's deliberate and very successful effort to forge a coalition of Latino and black voters -- an effort that almost brought the Democratic nomination to Mr. Ferrer, but also dismayed many of the city's white voters and all but invited some candidate to seek the benefits of a backlash.
Now the Ferrer forces are moving beyond the venues of the petty and the unseemly and into the realm of the ridiculous. Roberto Ramirez, a seasoned pol who is the Bronx Democratic chairman and a key Ferrer adviser, is accusing the Green campaign of suppressing the voting rights of minorities. And the Rev. Al Sharpton, another important Ferrer ally, is planning to file a federal lawsuit challenging the results of the runoff election, which are still unofficial but clearly show Mr. Green as the winner. 
Earth to Democrats: a major, life-threatening crisis has enveloped the city and the nation and it would behoove anyone aspiring to leadership to deal with that first and get back to your infantile squabbles sometime in the very far distant future.
In case you haven't noticed, much of Lower Manhattan is in ruins. And the germ warfare that people have worried about for so long is under way. Anthrax has turned up in the U.S. Congress and in the Manhattan office of the governor of New York.
If you could bring yourselves to look at the big picture, you might see that the city you claim to love so much is under siege. Thousands upon thousands of businesses have been crippled. Jobs are vanishing at a frightening pace. Both the city and state are hemorrhaging revenues, and enormous budget deficits loom. According to Felix Rohatyn, "The city is in greater economic jeopardy today than it was in the fiscal crisis of 1975." 
We are experiencing the awful beginning of a precipitous decline in the city's fortunes. So let's stop the mud-wrestling and move on. Let's do it this way: Let's agree that everybody's been offended. O.K.? We're even. Let's stash the lawsuits and stifle the recriminations.
Mr. Ramirez and Mr. Sharpton need to be part of the solution, not part of the problem. They can start by acknowledging that, whatever may have happened in this election, the voting rights of minorities were not suppressed. They should call in their lawyers and their surrogates and tell them to chill.
The two people who can do the most right now to bring New York together are Mark Green and Fernando Ferrer. I know both men and I don't believe either is a racist. They should sit down, one on one, as soon as possible. Lock the door and have it out. There should be no ground rules except one: They can't leave the room until they come to an agreement on the best way to cooperate in leading the city forward during the worst crisis in its history.
Mr. Green met yesterday with Dennis Rivera, the president of the politically powerful health care workers' union and a major Ferrer supporter. The meeting reportedly went well and I would be surprised if Mr. Rivera did not end up supporting Mr. Green. 
But time is growing short. Mr. Green may well be the next mayor and he will have trouble governing successfully without the enthusiastic support of Mr. Ferrer and his constituents. Big-time leadership is needed right now. The two principals should get together and there should be plenty of food in the room, because they need to stay there as long as it takes to work out their differences. The future of a very troubled city is at stake.

HEADLINE: Bloomberg Expands on Economic Plans 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

 BODY:
In releasing a plan for economic development yesterday, the Republican mayoral candidate, Michael R. Bloomberg, rejected the idea of a new state authority to oversee the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan, and also proposed putting high schools on Governors Island to free up school buildings citywide.
 The plan expanded on some ideas he had already hinted at, such as reducing the city's workforce by attrition and moving some city agencies from downtown Manhattan to the other boroughs. In a new twist on an old problem, he suggested that the Police and Fire Departments might grow during a citywide hiring freeze by recruiting workers from other city departments. 
 Mr. Bloomberg's plan also ventured into some new areas of economic development, with proposals on the devastation at the trade center site that were dismissed as inappropriate and naive by his Democratic rival, Mark Green. 
Most notably, Mr. Bloomberg rejected the idea of a new state agency to oversee the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan, as has been contemplated in Albany. Mr. Bloomberg said the city, along with existing agencies like the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, could handle the effort.
His remarks were in keeping with a philosophy he has promoted in his campaign, that there should be less direct state intervention in municipal matters, particularly in transportation and education. His plan yesterday also called for relaxing the need for intervention by the state Financial Control Board when the city runs a budget deficit, at a time when financial experts have worried that the board might exert a stronger hand now that the city's economy is reeling from the terror attack.
"Rudy Giuliani showed that this city can, with help from the state government, with help from the federal government, adequately control its own destiny," Mr. Bloomberg said at a business breakfast at the Grand Hyatt sponsored by Crain's New York Business. "Adding another level of bureaucracy is not something I am in favor of."
In another new suggestion, Mr. Bloomberg proposed turning Governors Island, which is federally owned, into an academic center, where students from across the city would be transported by aerial tramways and water taxis to a complex of new high schools and college campuses. He said that the federal government could be persuaded to hand over the island and that the high school construction could be paid for through bond sales.
By moving high school students to Governors Island, Mr. Bloomberg said, high school buildings around the city could be converted to elementary and intermediate schools. That would keep younger students closer to home and would overcome some of the opposition to new high school construction, he said.
"If somebody's got a better idea, I would be happy to hear it, but it is time to do something," Mr. Bloomberg said at a news conference. "Let us have this piece of property, and let us develop it for something that is good for this city and good for this country."
When asked about Mr. Bloomberg's proposals at a news conference, Mr. Green described them as "displaying the naivete of a novice."
Mr. Green suggested that Mr. Bloomberg was just reading a speech that somebody else had handed him. He also said that Mr. Bloomberg's proposal to have the city control the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan was unrealistic and he questioned the reasons for trying to build schools on Governors Island.
"I don't think he knows the city, and I don't think he understands government," Mr. Green said. "When he's been to all the neighborhoods like I have, perhaps he'll be slightly more insightful and credible."
Mr. Bloomberg, through a spokesman, was equally dismissive of Mr. Green's critique.
"I am happy to match my economic development credentials against a career gadfly with no economic record," Mr. Bloomberg said.
Among some of Mr. Bloomberg's other ideas for development was that the city should not depend solely on the financial industry to anchor Lower Manhattan. It should promote projects like biotechnology, fashion industry complexes and an information technology center, he said.
He also listed several priorities for new development outside Lower Manhattan, including "The Hub" in the Bronx; Red Hook in Brooklyn; Jamaica in Queens, and Fresh Kills Landfill in Staten Island.
In delivering a broad outline of his proposals at the Crain's breakfast, Mr. Bloomberg assumed the role of head cheerleader for the city and said the only way to keep businesses from leaving was to keep their employees happy. He also suggested that companies should not be interested in hiring people who live in the suburbs because they are not "the best and the brightest."
"There is a self-selection process," he said. "People that want to go there aren't the people that you want to have in your company."
Meanwhile, Mr. Green continued yesterday to try to ease some of the bitterness that existed among supporters of Fernando Ferrer, his opponent in the Democratic primary, over the hard-hitting campaign he ran. Mr. Green quietly met with Dennis Rivera, the head of the health care workers union.
Mr. Rivera, who met with Mr. Bloomberg on Monday, declined comment after the meeting, but a spokesman for Mr. Green said the meeting was friendly and productive. He said Mr. Green had called other Ferrer supporters, including Representative Charles Rangel, the Harlem Democrat, and C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president.
The origin of a flier that some Ferrer supporters objected to, which said that a Ferrer-Sharpton ticket would bring down the city, became clear yesterday. It was issued by Isaac Abraham, an advocate for Jewish causes in Brooklyn. 
"We have a democratic right to denounce him," Mr. Abraham said of the Rev. Al Sharpton, explaining that he sent the letter to about 7,000 people. His authorship of the letter was first reported in The Village Voice.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
AOL Meets Projections, But Internet Unit Falls Short
AOL Time Warner said that its third-quarter revenue grew by 6 percent and that its cash flow increased by 20 percent compared with figures in the period a year earlier.
 Despite the results, which met or exceeded analysts' forecasts by most measures, the company's Internet unit, America Online, fell far short of Wall Street's expectations. Investors seized on that weakness and sent the company's shares down $2.69, to $30.81. Page C2. 

Cutbacks in Television Programming
Facing economic strains and a steep downturn in advertising, Sony Pictures Entertainment, Fox Broadcasting and USA Network are cutting back on TV programming. C6.

Stocks Fall on Greenspan Remarks
Stocks dropped after Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, made disappointing comments about the economy and investors worried about bioterrorism. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 75.73 points, or 4.4 percent, to 1,646.34. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 151.26 points, or 1.6 percent, to 9,232.97. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 20.45 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,077.09. C7.

Incentive Program for Hospitals
Four big New York companies will announce a $2 million incentive program today to encourage hospitals in the state to improve patient safety by requiring doctors to use computerized systems that guard against errors. C3.

Ford Has Loss as Price War Widens
General Motors extended interest-free financing deals on its vehicles through mid-November, escalating a price war that appears to be taking a toll. Ford Motor reported a third-quarter net loss of $692 million. C7.

Steps Taken to Make More Cipro
Under intense pressure to respond to fears about anthrax, the government and the drug industry took steps to increase the production of the antibiotic Cipro and approve a broader range of drugs to fight the bacterium. A1.

Satisfying the explosive demand for Cipro has created problems for Bayer. And the company is trying to fend off politicians' calls that other drug makers be allowed to begin producing their own versions of the drug. B8.

Schools Oppose Visa Restrictions
Business schools, graduate programs and colleges have paid close attention to proposals to curb the number of visas issued to students, like a call last month by Senator Dianne Feinstein of California for a six-month moratorium on student visas soon after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. Foreign students are particularly valuable to business schools because they are more likely to pay full tuition. That has made many institutions staunch opponents of what they see as excessively harsh restrictions on student visas. C5.

EchoStar Seeks More Financing
EchoStar Communications is negotiating $5.5 billion in additional financing to bolster its effort to acquire the DirecTV satellite business, executives close to the company said. C2.

EMC Reports a Loss for Quarter
EMC, a supplier of data storage systems, posted its first quarterly loss since 1989 and said that sales had fallen 47 percent. C4.

Profit Falls at Citigroup and Morgan
Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase reported lower third-quarter earnings, but both companies made the case that they had performed as well or better than expected under the circumstances, thanks to cost control measures. C3.

Lingua Franca Suspends Publication
Lingua Franca, a magazine about academic life that became a must-read for intellectuals everywhere, suspended publication. C6.

Neglect in Unemployment Insurance
Unemployment insurance has not kept up with changes in the nation's work force and has been neglected by many state legislatures. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Sees Economic Slide As Temporary 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the damage to the economy from the terrorist attacks should be temporary and that the United States would soon start benefiting again from the advances in technology that helped fuel the boom of the late 1990's.
 In an appearance before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, Mr. Greenspan described the short-term economic outlook as murky, and he said nothing to alter the assumption among investors and economists that the Fed would continue to cut interest rates. 
 "We are looking at a situation which is by no means as bad as numbers of us were fearful it might turn out to be," Mr. Greenspan said. "But it also has not exhibited a sharp snapback, which has been typical of what happens when you get a major hurricane or natural disaster." 
Mr. Greenspan said that once the initial shock from the attacks wears off, the economy should be able to draw on its underlying strengths and recover. In particular, Mr. Greenspan reiterated his faith in the power of technology to rekindle improvements in the growth rate of productivity, the single most important determinant of the economy's ability to expand without generating inflation.
"For the longer term, prospects for ongoing rapid technological advance and associated faster productivity growth are scarcely diminished," he said.
Mr. Greenspan's statements were no doubt intended in part as cheerleading at a time when the economy is plagued as much by fear and uncertainty as by more concrete problems.
But they also made clear that Mr. Greenspan has not given up on the notion of the new economy, the theory that improvements in productivity, or output per hour, had raised the economy's level of performance starting in around 1995. 
"Alan Greenspan is bullish on America," said Gerald D. Cohen, an economist at Merrill Lynch.
In response to questions from members of Congress, Mr. Greenspan reiterated his position that cutting the capital gains tax -- a proposal favored by Republicans as a way to help give the economy a quick boost -- would not have much immediate effect on the economy. He said he continued to view cutting capital gains taxes, or even eliminating them, as good long-term policy.
He said research at the Fed suggested that the best way of providing the economy with short-term stimulus was to provide tax breaks for business investment in new equipment by allowing companies to write off much of the cost of the investment immediately. And he gave a cautious endorsement to the Bush administration's proposal to cap the liability of the insurance industry on claims from future terrorist attacks.
"Even though I recognize that there are very significant difficulties in reconciling free markets and government reinsurance, in this very unusual circumstance they are indeed compatible," Mr. Greenspan said.
Many if not most economists now say the economy has entered a recession, which is usually defined as two or more consecutive quarters in which total economic output declines. The president's chief economic adviser, Lawrence B. Lindsey, said in a speech here today that he now thinks a recession is likely, the first time a senior administration official has acknowledged in public what private-sector economists have been saying for weeks or months.
But there is considerable debate among economists about how quickly the economy will bounce back, especially given the uncertainty about further terrorist attacks and the effect they could have on business, investor and consumer confidence. And there is also a division of opinion among economists about how much, if any, of the improvements in productivity that the nation enjoyed during the second half of the last decade are likely to continue.
In a report issued today, McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm, concluded that productivity will continue to grow at rates higher than it grew for the two decades before 1995, but probably not as fast as it grew starting in 1995.
From 1972 to 1995, productivity grew at a 1.4 percent annual rate. From 1995 through 2000, it grew at a 2.5 percent annual rate. McKinsey concluded that nearly all of the improvement came from six sectors of the economy: retail, wholesale, securities, telecommunications, semiconductors and computer manufacturing.
In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan said productivity growth would suffer temporarily as businesses were forced to take steps like increasing spending on security and backing up their computer systems.
Eventually, he said, productivity would pick up because businesses have only started to exploit the cost savings available from increased use of computers and communications technology, which offer a very high rate of return on investment.
But Mr. Greenspan hedged slightly about whether productivity growth would return to its 2.5 percent annual rate.
"The level of productivity will presumably undergo a one-time downward adjustment as our economy responds to higher levels of perceived risk, but once the adjustment is completed, productivity growth should resume at rates in excess of those that prevailed in the quarter-century preceding 1995," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Technology Shares Fall, With Nasdaq Losing 4.4%

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stocks dropped yesterday after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, made disappointing comments about the economy and investors worried about bioterrorism attacks.
 Technology stock followers, initially encouraged by earnings reports from I.B.M. and Intel on Tuesday that matched or slightly exceeded analysts' forecasts, touched off an early rally. But investors retreated after the confirmation of more than 30 positive cases of anthrax exposure in Washington and by Mr. Greenspan's assessment that the economic outlook for the next few months was uncertain. 
 Of major market gauges, the hardest hit was the Nasdaq composite index, which dropped 75.73 points, or 4.4 percent, to close at 1,646.34.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 151.26 points, or 1.61 percent, to 9,232.97. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 20.45 points, or 1.86 percent, to 1,077.09.
Market breadth was negative. On the New York Stock Exchange, 1,976 stocks declined, compared with 1,157 that advanced. Big Board volume totaled 1.47 million shares.
"Alan Greenspan started us off, but the ongoing fear of anthrax put a lot of concern in the market," said Arthur Hogan of Jefferies & Company. "He was very cloudy about what he wants to say about the future. For the most part his message is, 'We're not sure when this economy turns around.' One of his statements was, 'We're not sure if the fiscal and monetary policy will keep us out of recession.' "
Mr. Greenspan, testifying before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, said a pronounced rise in uncertainty after last month's terrorist attacks had dampened consumer spending and capital investment, and caused a withdrawal from the marketplace that "has been partial and presumably temporary." 
Although analysts said the market at first seemed to have absorbed Tuesday's developments on anthrax risks, investors were unnerved yesterday by the announcement that more than 30 people who worked in or near the office of Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, had tested positive for exposure to anthrax. Later, Gov. George E. Pataki of New York said an environmental test of his Manhattan offices had come back positive "for the probability of anthrax." 
Alan Ackerman, chief market strategist at Fahnestock & Company, commented: "It's discomforting to know that the anthrax threat may be spreading. The extent of uncertainties we're dealing with now make decision-making difficult indeed." 
For much of the week, the market has sought direction from corporate America, which is in the third-quarter earnings season. About 180 of the companies in the S.& P. 500 are to report their results this week, and analysts expect some of the worst profit reports in decades.
Of the bright spots in the market yesterday, I.B.M. shares gained $1.05, to $102.90. John R. Joyce, the company's chief financial officer, said he thought Wall Street's expectations for I.B.M.'s fourth-quarter profit were reasonable. But shares of Intel, which met analysts' forecasts on Tuesday, gave up early gains and fell 39 cents, to $24.57.
Technology issues dropped sharply in the last half-hour of trading after Siebel Systems reported earnings that came in at the low end of Wall Street analysts' expectations. Siebel fell $4.16, to $17.38.
Some other technology issues weighing on the Nasdaq index included Microsoft, down $2.42, to $56.03; Cisco Systems, down $1.37, to $15.60; PeopleSoft, down $5.35, to $23.19; and Xilinx, down $3.27, to $27.48. 
EMC, the big maker of computer storage products, fell $2.24, to $11.21, after posting a net loss of $945.2 million, or 43 cents a share. --------------------

U.S. Treasury Prices Gain
By Reuters
Treasury prices edged higher yesterday after a stock rebound fizzled on the news that Senate staff employees had tested positive for anthrax exposure.
The price of the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose 3/32 , to 103 15/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.56 percent from 4.57 percent on Tuesday. The 30-year bond rose 16/32 , to 100 29/32 . Its yield fell to 5.31 percent from 5.35 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Bush Opposes More Aid Now For New York 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
The Bush administration balked today at providing billions more dollars in new aid to New York this year, in effect quashing any hopes Gov. George E. Pataki might have had that his $54 billion aid request would be considered soon.
 Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the White House budget director, said today that the administration had no intention of asking Congress for more money for any other terrorism-related need, at least until January. He said the issue could be re-examined next year, but he noted that New York was already beginning to get large portions of the $20 billion approved as emergency aid for the state, Virginia and Pennsylvania. 
 Mr. Daniels's announcement underscored the uphill battle that the governor faces in securing more aid. In fact, the aid request that Mr. Pataki shopped around personally on Capitol Hill just last week probably will not survive in its current form. 
A growing number of influential lawmakers on Capitol Hill are rejecting it, describing Mr. Pataki's proposal as freighted with huge spending items not directly related to the terrorist attacks, like transportation projects in upstate New York.
More than that, there seems to be a broader refrain among the state's own Congressional delegation that unless the governor retools his plan, he is jeopardizing the credibility of even the most legitimate aid the state and city are entitled to. Some members have even begun whittling away to come up with a much smaller, more realistic proposal. "It's not dead, but it's definitely on life support," an assistant to a senior House Republican said. 
An assistant to a House leader, while not dooming the proposal entirely, said: "They're just not going to get all that. Conservatives in Congress are watching to see that nobody takes advantage of this crisis to fund their own pork projects."
Another assistant to a prominent Republican senator urged Mr. Pataki, a Republican, to abandon some of the more excessive requests, particularly when Congress needs to cover the rising cost of the nation's war effort. 
"Those extraneous things that have nothing to do with recovering from the attacks will have to fall by the wayside," the assistant said. "You can't go overboard on these things."
That sentiment is being echoed even by members of New York's delegation, who complain that they had little say in outlining the plan that Mr. Pataki submitted. The biggest concern they have is that Mr. Pataki's request undercuts real needs when some conservatives in Congress are looking for any reason to deny giving New York significantly more aid than it has already got.
The governor and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have taken different tacks on seeking more federal aid. The mayor, most notably with a budget modification, charts and graphs, tried to demonstrate that he had put his own house in order -- cutting agency budgets, freezing $1 billion in spending -- just hours before he appeared with Mr. Pataki to announce the $54 billion aid package. And he stressed that the package should not be expanded to include extraneous things. 
The mayor has declined to lobby in Washington on behalf of the Pataki plan, according to officials monitoring the issue.
The governor, by contrast, released the plan, went to Washington the next day and waited nearly a week to impose his own budgetary restrictions, doing so at a previously unscheduled news conference on the same day that the White House budget chief told businesses and state leaders that there would be no more bailouts and urged them toward fiscal restraint.
Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, the dean of the delegation, was careful not to criticize the governor in a recent interview. But he made it clear that he disagreed with the governor's approach, saying, "You can't just throw your whole laundry list at Congress."
An assistant to a Republican House member from New York expressed similar bafflement. "Should we have opened with this hand? Absolutely not," the assistant said. "It's caused sticker shock. Some members of leadership are expressing their concern."
In fact, some members of the delegation have already begun to pick apart the Pataki plan, trying to shape a smaller request that would finance projects directly related to the terrorist attacks and that would be easier to sell on Capitol Hill.
Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat, explained that the delegation members "are assessing which pieces have the greatest chance of winning support in the House, the Senate and the White House" before presenting them.
Three weeks ago, the White House and Congress approved $17.5 billion in disaster aid to help with cleaning up the destruction in Lower Manhattan and restoring public buildings and infrastructure. But last week, the governor released a plan calling for an additional $36.5 billion in federal assistance.
In his plan, Mr. Pataki estimated that the cost of rebuilding would total about twice the amount that the federal government had originally set aside for New York, or $34 billion.
Lawmakers here say -- and the Pataki administration acknowledges -- that that figure could be cut considerably, since it does not reflect the fact that insurance companies will have to help pay for the reconstruction effort. "It struck a lot of people as disingenuous for them not to take into account that insurance would cover some of it," said an assistant to one senior member of the New York delegation.
The other part of the Pataki plan that is meeting resistance is the governor's request for $3 billion to finance transportation projects, including rail, road and bridge upgrades in upstate New York. 
The governor also drew sharp criticism for seeking up to $12 billion in federal aid to make up for the sharp decrease in tax revenue that both the city and state expect in the next 18 months because of the disruption that occurred in Lower Manhattan, the state's economic engine.
In other disasters like hurricanes and earthquakes, the federal government has not bailed out local governments for lost revenues. 
Greg Crist, a spokesman for Dick Armey, a Republican who is the House majority leader, said the proposal would likely meet stiff resistance. "There's going to be a lot of scrutiny," Mr. Crist said.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: COMMANDER IN CHIEF; 
Bush's New Focus Requires A Shift in His China Policy

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 17 

 BODY:
President Bush, who came into office just months ago talking of China as a "strategic competitor," departed for Shanghai today on a trip expected to complete a significant shift in his policy toward Beijing as he seeks to build, maintain and expand a global coalition against terrorism.
 The importance attached to Mr. Bush's appearance at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, where he will meet with the leaders of both Russia and China, was clear simply from the fact that the president was taking the trip while his nation was at war and coping with spreading anthrax attacks. When President Bill Clinton was ordering the bombing of Iraq three years ago, he skipped the meeting. 
 But Mr. Bush made plain that his focus would not be the trade issues that traditionally dominate the Asian gathering.
"Of course we'll talk about economics and trade," he told Air Force personnel and their families during a stopover visit here. "But the main thing that will be on my mind is to continue to rally the world against terrorists," and to remind other leaders "that evil knows no borders."
The events of the last five weeks have made it critical for Mr. Bush to develop ties with China that more closely resemble the "strategic partnership" envisaged by President Clinton and once openly disdained by President Bush. 
All talk of strategic competition has been omitted from Mr. Bush's comments, officials say, and his aides have quietly sanded away all the hard edges from the message he will deliver to his Chinese hosts in his visit, starting on Thursday.
"You won't hear much about dissidents, or Taiwan, or the dust-up with the spy plane," one close adviser to Mr. Bush said this week, referring to the incident last spring when a Chinese fighter hit an EP-3 surveillance plane, forcing it to land. "He can't afford that now. The Chinese have never been in a better mood to rebuild their relationship with Washington, and they know that now the president needs them, too."
James Steinberg, the deputy national security adviser under Mr. Clinton, said, "You'll never hear the words strategic competitor again." 
While conservative Republicans called for a far tougher stance against China and a shift favoring Taiwan earlier this year, they have been silent in the weeks leading up to the Asian trip, mainly, some say, because their focus is elsewhere. 
Mr. Bush, on his first trip to Asia since visiting China when his father was envoy to Beijing a quarter century ago, will meet President Jiang Zemin on Friday. 
The breadth of Mr. Bush's plans for the months ahead will provide the subtext of that meeting and others during three days of intense diplomacy with 20 nations.
While many Asian and Pacific governments have supported his counterterrorism plans -- Australia even said it would send troops, and Japan has offered logistical support -- a backlash is already taking place on the streets of several countries.
The Chinese want to redefine terrorism to provide a further justification for their crackdown on Muslim Uighur separatists and Tibetan independence supporters -- people who might have been known in Mr. Bush's Washington, until a few weeks ago, as dissidents.
Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, who will meet with Mr. Bush on Sunday, also sees his new cooperation with the president as leverage. He has already won a change of wording from the White House, which noted the participation of Al Qaeda terrorists in Chechnya, and he hopes to beat back the administration's plans to abandon the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.
Another leader in attendance will be the new president of Indonesia, Megawati Sukarnoputri, leader of the world's most populous Muslim nation. She has made clear to Washington that while she condemned the Sept. 11 attacks, she cannot sign any declaration endorsing the war in Afghanistan.
Other leaders, led by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, who has his own problems with resurgent hard-line Muslims, have been highly critical of the American military action.
Mr. Bush's aides are scrambling to find a middle ground at the summit meeting with a declaration against terrorism that leaves every country free to define how it pursues that mission. Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, acknowledged recently that Mr. Bush had to be careful about giving other nations too much rope.
"It is clear our job is to make certain that we continue to draw a line in all of our discussions between legitimate dissent or legitimate movements for the rights of minorities," Ms. Rice said, "and the fact that there may be international terrorists in various parts of the world." 
The diplomatic task facing Mr. Bush is complex. Internal divisions run deep in a grouping that embraces countries as suspicious of American intentions as Vietnam, as eager to join the fight as Australia and as jittery as Taiwan.
Overarching all of this political dissonance is a problem Mr. Bush has rarely discussed but will have to confront here: a global economic downturn that has gained speed since Sept. 11 and has yet to be met with a coordinated response.
It is hard to overestimate how the twin economic downturns in Japan and the United States affect Asia's export-oriented fortunes. Many of Asia's weakest economies are reeling, including some that never fully recovered -- and never really reformed -- after the economic crisis of 1997 and 1998.
This might be the first economic summit meeting in memory for which an administration did not offer a briefing about its economic strategy -- another sign that Mr. Bush's focus was almost entirely on terrorism.

HEADLINE: NASA's Longest-Serving Administrator Says He Will Step Down 

BYLINE:  By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
Daniel S. Goldin, who revamped and re-energized the nation's space program during almost a decade as head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, announced today that he was resigning.
 Mr. Goldin, NASA's longest-serving administrator, said he would leave on Nov. 17 and look at opportunities in private industry. 
 He has accepted an interim position with the Council on Competitiveness, a Washington group that promotes American economic and business leadership.
"I decided now is the time," Mr. Goldin said in a telephone news conference. "I love my country. I love this agency, but it is time."
In 1992, President George Bush signaled that he wanted a new direction for the space agency by nominating Mr. Goldin, who had few Washington ties but had been a veteran executive with TRW Inc., a leading aerospace contractor. Known as an innovative administrator, Mr. Goldin set about restructuring NASA from an agency accustomed to expanding budgets and big projects, to one that could operate with decreasing resources.
To the consternation of some agency veterans, Mr. Goldin revamped NASA by decentralizing its administration and overseeing a one-third reduction in its civil service work force. He pushed the agency to do more with less and instituted the sometimes controversial policy of "cheaper, faster, better," emphasizing more small space missions instead of a few large, expensive ones.
The policy was generally considered successful, with the launching of dozens of small spacecraft to study planets, asteroids, comets and other phenomena that cost a few hundred million dollars each instead of the single craft costing more than $1 billion each that tried to do everything at once.
This approach resulted in successes like the Mars Pathfinder probe in 1997 and the NEAR mission that orbited and landed on the asteroid Eros this year. But the policy also was blamed for the loss of two Mars missions in a row last year, with investigators saying they were underfinanced and improperly managed.
Mr. Goldin was allowed to stay on at NASA in the Clinton administration. There he supervised revamping the nation's foundering space station program into the International Space Station, with Russia brought in as a full partner.
The 18-nation project has just completed its first major stage of construction in Earth orbit and is permanently staffed by rotating crews of three astronauts. But NASA now faces more than $4 billion in cost overruns for its share of the project, and the current administration has told the agency that it must make up the excess from existing budgets.
Mr. Goldin said he was sure that NASA would find ways to absorb the increased space station costs and complete the project.
"There is always a crisis at NASA," he said, adding that the agency always managed to overcome them.
Dr. John Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University, said that many of the changes spearheaded by Mr. Goldin were necessary and that approaches like "cheaper, faster, better" appeared to be working.
Mr. Goldin, 61, was born in the Bronx and reared and educated in New York. He said that he would return to California, where he lived before coming to Washington, and that he would work with the White

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW; 
U.S. and China, Entwined in Commerce and Mistrust

BYLINE:  By SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN; Samuel G. Freedman, a professor of journalism at Columbia University, is the author most recently of "Jew vs. Jew: The Struggle for the Soul of American Jewry."

 BODY:
The coming of jihad to American soil, with jets turned into flying bombs and the mails used to carry anthrax, brings on a strange kind of nostalgia for the cold war. Even at its most frightening moments -- the Berlin blockade, the Cuban missile crisis -- Soviet and American leaders pulled back from the brink. The deterrence doctrine of mutually assured destruction assumed an enemy that, unlike radical Islam's holy warriors, did not welcome suicidal martyrdom as the fast track to paradise.
 All the events since Sept. 11, then, have posed a major dilemma for "Dangerous Straits," the documentary about tensions between the United States and China that will be shown on PBS tonight. A joint project of "Frontline" and The New York Times, "Dangerous Straits" clearly was begun before the terror attacks drastically redefined the ranking of America's foes and tore up modern war's rules of engagement, and it struggles to contend with these epic changes. 
 On one hand "Dangerous Straits" tries to stand by its basic premise, arguing that friction between the United States and China over the Taiwan Strait raises the specter of military conflict. On the other hand it tries to acknowledge the newly shared interest of both nations in battling terrorism by Muslim radicals and separatists. The result is a documentary that is both informative and uneven, perceptive and hyperbolic.
While "Dangerous Straits" is being broadcast to coincide with President Bush's trip to Shanghai for the Asian Pacific Economic Conference, the documentary derives from the confrontation six months ago, when a Chinese fighter plane collided with an American spy craft making a routine surveillance of the Taiwan Strait. The damaged American plane landed on a Chinese island, Hainan, and its crew remained in custody until Washington's ambassador to Beijing expressed regret for the death of the Chinese pilot in the episode. Meanwhile, amid a military buildup on the Chinese side of the strait, President Bush approved the sale of defensive weapons to Taiwan and declared American resolve to protect an endangered Taiwan.
That all this amounts to significant tension is self-evident. As produced and directed by Chris Oxley, however, "Dangerous Straits" implies that superpower war was imminent, that "the two countries, both nuclear powers, nearly came to blows." In its visual images, too, the documentary sometimes sensationalizes a conflict that is unsettling enough on its own terms. While the pilot of the downed American jet, Shane Osborne, recounts his exhausting interrogation by the Chinese, the screen flashes scenes that were obviously concocted in a studio: a chair being slammed down on a bare floor, a prisoner's shadow on the wall of a cell, a bare light bulb clouded by the smoke of an inquisitor's cigarette.
Nothing makes these B-movie effects more superfluous (and embarrassing) than the serious analysis that various diplomats, scholars and journalists offer in the documentary. They depict not a nuclear conflagration waiting to happen but a far more complex and fascinating interplay between China and the United States, massive trading partners even as they remain political antagonists. The significance of the showdown, "Dangerous Straits" points out a bit too belatedly, is how it affected that balance.
"I think China's one of those countries that has very complex feelings toward the United States," Kurt Campbell, a former assistant secretary of state, says. "They like our music. They like our movies. They like much about what the United States stands for. At the same time they are deeply dissatisfied with certain aspects of American foreign policy. Many Chinese believe fundamentally that the United States is set on destabilizing China, or at least trying to stop China from reaching its full potential."
For the Bush administration, the documentary explains, relations with China polarize two Republican constituencies. David Sanger, a Washington correspondent for The Times, describes these as "a very business-oriented camp" that sees China as "perhaps the greatest market anywhere in the world" and a "containment crowd" that perceives a "growing military threat from China."
"Dangerous Straits" would have been wise to devote most of its time to exploring exactly the thesis that Mr. Sanger and Mr. Campbell set forth. Their wise words suggest not the zero-sum story of war or peace, enemy or friend, but a narrative of dueling constituencies within each country trying to exploit either business ties or the divisive Taiwan issue for their own gain.
If the United States did not attack Mao's China at the height of the cold war, when Communist forces were raining a half-million shells on the Nationalist island of Kinmen, as "Dangerous Straits" recounts, then how plausible is it to imagine armed conflict with a nation where Motorola has invested $3.4 billion, employs 12,000 people, and sells five million cell phones a year? Is it truly accurate to say, as "Dangerous Straits" does in its final moments, that China regards assertions of Taiwanese sovereignty "with the same severity as if terrorists threatened their country"? Maybe, but a viewer is left to take that claim on faith.
In a quieter passage "Dangerous Straits" more accurately depicts the American engagement with China as a "policy of strategic ambiguity." When this documentary embraces and explores that ambiguity, it succeeds best. These days we know all too well what real war looks like and where it is being fought.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
The stimulus package should fix the unemployment insurance program first.

BYLINE:  By Alan B. Krueger; Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. E-mail: akrueger@princeton.edu.

 BODY:
IT is often said that unemployment insurance is the first line of defense in a recession. The line needs some strengthening, however, because the program has not kept up with changes in the work force and has been neglected by many state legislatures.
 Economists have a well-worked-out theory of unemployment insurance. The program helps laid-off workers maintain consumption and search for a job that matches their skills. But these benefits come at a cost: more generous or longer-lasting benefits reduce the intensity with which unemployed workers look for a job. 
 To balance the intended and unintended effects, most states replace 40 to 50 percent of lost wages. Benefits are temporary, typically lasting up to 26 weeks. Through a financing plan known as experience rating, employers with worse records of laying off workers pay somewhat more into the program to discourage layoffs.
This is a distinctly American brand of unemployment compensation. In France, for example, benefits replace around 80 percent of earnings and last up to two years; there is no experience rating. The relatively low level and short duration of benefits -- and experience rating -- partly account for our lower unemployment rate.
Unemployment insurance is the quintessential economic stimulus: benefits ramp up temporarily in a downturn and reach those most in need. Outlays soared from $14 billion in 1989 to $37 billion in 1992, when the jobless rate peaked, and fell to $21 billion in 1995, when the labor market improved. By building up reserves in prosperous times and spending them in weaker times, the program helps stabilize the economy.
Unlike many other programs being considered for the stimulus package, unemployment insurance provides security for those who do not directly receive benefits. Just knowing that benefits are available in case of job loss inspires confidence. A strong safety net also makes it unnecessary to have industry-by-industry bailouts in response to adverse shocks.
President Bush recently proposed spending $3 billion to extend unemployment benefits by 13 weeks for eligible workers. Extended benefits are a sensible and traditional response in a recession. The distortion caused by longer-lasting or more generous benefits is less significant in a downturn because jobs are less plentiful regardless of how hard people search for work, said Dale Mortensen of Northwestern University, who has done pioneering research on unemployment insurance.
Indeed, a bipartisan group in Congress is questioning whether President Bush's proposal goes far enough to mend the program and the particular way he would extend benefits.
In the president's proposal, benefits would automatically be extended in Virginia, New York and New Jersey, and in other states in which the jobless rate rises 30 percent, but only for those who lost jobs after Sept. 11.
This trigger mechanism has some peculiar implications. If the unemployment rate rises from 3 to 4 percent in one state, extended benefits will kick in, but if it jumps from 10 to 12.5 percent in another, that state will not qualify.
It is also unclear why Virginia, with an unemployment rate of 2.9 percent, the nation's third lowest, should qualify for extended benefits, while Washington -- which is across the Potomac from the the Pentagon and has a 6.4 percent jobless rate, the nation's second highest -- does not.
And why should a worker laid off on Sept. 10 be treated differently from one laid off on Sept. 12? Surely, those laid off before Sept. 11 will face tougher job competition because of the rise in unemployment after the attacks.
The terrorist attacks are not solely responsible for the slowdown: it was already in the works. The number of jobless workers rose 1.4 million in the 12 months before Sept. 11; unemployment claims reached their highest level in nine years over the summer.
Legislation sponsored by Representatives Benjamin Cardin, a Maryland Democrat; Amo Houghton, a New York Republican; and six others would do much more to strengthen the safety net than would the president's proposal. Their bipartisan bill would extend benefits for 13 weeks to those who exhaust their regular benefits in the next year; temporarily increase benefits by 15 percent, or $25 a week, whichever is greater; use more up-to-date earnings records to determine eligibility; and expand eligibility to those seeking part-time work.
Unemployed workers who seek part-time jobs are ineligible for benefits in most states even though their earnings are taxed to finance the program. Because many workers who left welfare for work in the late 1990's must work part-time hours to meet family obligations, they will not have much of a safety net to fall back on if eligibility is not expanded.
Mr. Houghton said, "There are so many part-time workers out there that you can't walk over that issue and think you have addressed unemployment insurance."
Mr. Cardin and Mr. Houghton failed in their bid to attach their $15 billion bill to the stimulus package that steamrolled through the House Ways and Means Committee last week, but they hope it will pass as a free-standing bill if it comes to a vote.
Mr. Cardin lamented that it was hard to understand why temporarily extending benefits to part-time workers had proved so controversial, but both he and Mr. Houghton made clear that they planned to pursue the issue.
In January I used this space to argue that many states -- particularly New York and Texas -- needed to shore up their unemployment insurance programs to prepare for a downturn. More than a dozen states let their experience rating lapse and failed to build up adequate reserves in the 1990's, hindering their ability to expand eligibility and provide adequate benefits.
Fortunately, the federal unemployment trust funds are flush and could be used to support the states in the current downturn if Congress and the administration act. But the longer-term issues -- like better experience rating, more realistic automatic triggers for extended state benefits, and adequate benefits and expanded eligibility in the least generous states -- still need to be addressed.
In announcing his goals for up to $75 billion of additional stimulus spending, President Bush urged: "We don't have time to try to invent new programs. We ought to make those programs that exist work better." Yet his proposal does little to fix unemployment insurance, a time-tested, antirecessionary program.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Some question whether the president's plan to extend jobless benefits goes far enough. A couple checked job listings at the California Employment Development Department in San Francisco. (Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: Essay; 
Bush's Shanghai Gesture

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Here are a few do's and don'ts that will help coalition-wary realists measure President Bush's success or failure at this week's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Shanghai.
 Don't get hung up in a free-trade love feast. Bush is not leaving his command post in terrorist wartime primarily to save the world from recession. Interminable blather about opening up markets is what China's Jiang Zemin wants most. The Chinese leader's diplomatic legions, drawn up in vast cumbrous array, will issue reams of plans for a "Shanghai round" of negotiations, but what makes this Bush trip necessary is getting, face to face, a promise of intelligence sharing about terror groups, to be followed by arrests and extradition. 
 Do focus on the central issue of the new era: All nations must choose sides in the terror war. Muslim Indonesia, with the world's fourth-largest population, is becoming a breeding ground for fanaticism. Bush needs to get commitments from nations like Japan, the Philippines, Australia, Taiwan and South Korea to help Indonesia -- as well as dictator-ridden Malaysia -- resist and root out Al Qaeda and its underworld brethren. 
Do not let China and Russia gang up on us in a trilateral meeting; stick to "bi-lats" only. Jiang wants to use this crisis to justify crackdowns on Taiwan, Tibet and its Muslim Uighurs, while Vladimir Putin sees a chance to brutalize Chechnya again and snatch independence back from Georgia. Bush should hold fast to his unequivocal position: Not all local autonomy need be separatist and not every separatist movement is a terrorist organization. 
Do seize the moment to advance missile defense. Bush shows no sign of wobbling on this. Next month is decision time to continue or to delay development, and that deadline coincides with his "friend" Putin's visit to the Crawford, Tex., ranch. Now is the moment to nail down his agreement to the principles of a "new framework" to replace the outmoded ABM treaty that now renders both nations defenseless. Then both presidents can instruct aides to complete the deal for signing at the November "Crawford summit."
Do not pay for the freedom to build a space shield (or for permission to hit the Taliban out of the formerly Soviet Uzbekistan) with an offer to bring unready Russia into the World Trade Organization or into NATO. No quid pro quo is required when all nations benefit from a planet-wide defense against terrorist missiles containing nuclear or germ warheads. Bush could offer Putin some face-saving wiggle room by promising to consult him before deploying the antimissile shield. 
Do follow up such a preliminary Russian-American missile handshake with a face-to-face pitch to Jiang to relieve the mind of his military. Bush's earnestness and charm are unlikely to stop China's inexorable missile buildup, but Jiang, as he nears retirement, may be looking for a graceful way to accept the newly reinforced American resolve. It's worth a shot.
Don't let our new warmth toward Pakistan allow China to get away with selling missile know-how to that nervous nuclear power. In November 2000, China agreed not to transfer ballistic missile technology to its longtime ally Pakistan. Then it did. When we objected, China stonewalled; we countered by denying U.S. companies the license to launch satellites on Chinese rockets. In Shanghai, Jiang will try to get a pass for its duplicity by saying we all love Pakistan's dictator now. Bush should not allow himself to be so rolled.
Do make clear to China that future relations with the U.S. hinge on sharing the intelligence gathered by its worldwide network of spies. "As you might imagine," a high official traveling with the president understates, "our intelligence relationship with the Chinese is not all that well developed." But even as we continue to steal each other's secrets, it should not be beyond the wit of spooks, when national interests coincide, to exchange secrets about a common enemy. 
This above all: Freedom of world trade, so devoutly to be wished, cannot blossom without freedom from fear. Those who want to participate in prosperity are obliged to join America in crushing the fanatical fearmongers and the nations nurturing them. That should be the message Bush drives home in Shanghai.

HEADLINE: The Shanghai Summit 

 BODY:
President Bush's diplomatic skills will get a workout over the next few days in Shanghai. Instead of talking economics, the usual subject at this annual autumn gathering of 21 Asian and Pacific Rim nations, Mr. Bush will be trying to strengthen the international coalition against terrorism that he has been assembling since Sept. 11. He should use his meetings with other leaders, including Presidents Jiang Zemin of China and Vladimir Putin of Russia, to clarify what help they are prepared to offer and what they expect in return. 
 China has given strong rhetorical support to the American campaign against terrorism and has shared intelligence with Washington. It appears to have encouraged Pakistan, a close ally, to stand with the United States. In return, it seems to expect America and other countries to accept its mischaracterizations of the Falun Gong spiritual movement and separatists in Tibet and Xinjiang as terrorists. Mr. Bush should firmly decline. 
 To reward Beijing for its assistance in the anti-terror fight, Mr. Bush may allow the resumption of some American military and high-tech exports to China that were suspended after the Tiananmen Square massacre of 1989. Unfortunately, Beijing continues to be dangerously lax about its own arms exports. Any easing of American sanctions should be linked to tighter Chinese controls on the sale or transfer of unconventional weapons technologies. 
Mr. Putin has moved aggressively since Sept. 11 to help Washington. Among other things, he has encouraged former Soviet republics in Central Asia like Uzbekistan to open their bases to American troops and planes. In return Mr. Putin has tried to get Washington to mute criticism of Russia's handling of Chechnya, something Mr. Bush should resist. More reasonably, Moscow is pressing Washington to slow its haste to discard the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. If the two countries can cooperate so closely against Osama bin Laden, they should be able to work out ways to amend the treaty to permit reasonable limited missile defenses. 
President Megawati Sukarnoputri of Indonesia, leader of the most populous Muslim country, initially rallied to the American cause, but her government has wavered in recent weeks. She should move against the financial supporters of Indonesia's Laskar Jihad Islamic terrorists. The Philippines needs no encouragement in fighting Abu Sayyaf, an Islamic terrorist organization with ties to the bin Laden network. President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo does need advice from Washington, however, in how to do so more effectively. 
Mr. Bush will not find uniform support for all his antiterrorism policies among the leaders in Shanghai. Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, for one, has been notably critical. But if he can mobilize a shared sense of outrage and a recognition that terrorism is the common enemy of all decent societies, his time will be well spent.
