HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "BAMANA: THE ART OF EXISTENCE IN MALI," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through March 3). African art is about envisioning a moral universe and shaping the world through spiritual energy to conform to that vision. The positive effects are evident in objects and images that unite communities, ease pain, forecast the future and explain the past. Nearly 100 of them are included in this wonderful show by one of the best museums in town. Among the highlights are exquisite iron ritual staffs, personable hand puppets, grave carved-wood maternity figures and a whole herd of the infinitely stylish antelope-shaped crest masks known as Ci-wara. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50, students and 65+; free on Sundays (Holland Cotter).

* "PIETER BRUEGEL THE ELDER: DRAWINGS AND PRINTS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Dec. 2). We could all do worse right now than to lose ourselves for a while in this show of drawings and prints by Bruegel, who knew a thing or two about vice and virtue. The world is anarchic and cruel and can drive all of us to despair sometimes, but good art is a realm unto itself, he tells us, and thankfully we can escape into it from time to time when we need to regain our senses. Against the narcissism of our fin-de-siecle milieu, the mysterious figure of the elder Bruegel comes as a small and fortuitous counterpoint. To judge from his pictures of the deadly vices, or his Everyman as a greedy, nearsighted merchant, or some of the nimbler drawings like "The Beekeepers," an image of lumbering, faceless figures in woven masks and bulky clothes, Bruegel doesn't come across as a compassionate artist, never mind his beloved pictures of peasants and ice skaters. Instead, his dark-humored viewpoint seems strangely moving and modern. Solace, he implies, comes only from the integrity of the artist's effort, not a bad lesson today. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* "ALBERTO GIACOMETTI," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9480 (through Jan. 8). Giacometti as the Sartre of sculpture might lead you to imagine him the right subject for troubled times. But that would be the wrong reason to see this exhibition. The right reason is that like all perceptive and eloquent art, it tells you why it is good to be alive. It investigates the pleasure of thinking and looking long and hard, which is never as simple as it sounds. The work is more varied than you may think -- sometimes black-humored, playful, sensual, even devoutly tender -- and includes plasters, painted bronzes and even a clunky stone garden sculpture, a splendid oddity, that demonstrate the material virtuosity and subtle coloration of an artist too often presumed to be pretty much just dark and heavy. Spread chronologically across two floors, compressed then open, like the art they contain, the show has as its unnecessary excuse the centenary of Giacometti's birth. We don't learn much that isn't already known, but it is a thorough, serious, very elegant exhibition, and there is nothing the matter with being reacquainted from time to time with what great art looks like. Hours: Thursdays through Tuesdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, to 8:15 p.m. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* "BEN KATCHOR: PICTURE STORIES," the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Feb. 10). Set in a milieu of 19th- and 20th-century Yiddish-American culture, characters like Julius Knipl, a real estate photographer, and Nathan Kishon, a slaughterhouse worker dismissed for mixing kosher with nonkosher animal tongues, are the antiheroes of Ben Katchor's zany, loquacious cartoon strips, which have appeared in The Village Voice, The Forward, The New York Press, Metropolis and other publications since 1988. What's most artful about his drawings, mostly in black-and-white with gray ink wash, is their evocation of New York's demoniacal energy, the look of its down-at-the-heels neighborhoods and storefront facades and its ethnic faces. Although this show seems to include miles of cartoons -- with other embellishments, like film projections and a display of fabricated artifacts -- you don't have to eyeball every one of them to agree that Mr. Katchor is an outsize talent, one who has brilliantly explored a very special world. Hours: Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Tuesdays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Mondays, Wednesdays, Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Admission: $8; $5.50 for students and 65+ (Grace Glueck).

* "MEETING GOD: ELEMENTS OF HINDU DEVOTION," American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, (212) 769-5100 (through Feb. 24). Visitors to this amazing, often moving hodgepodge of a show may or may not encounter the divine presence. But they can easily enter into its mood of euphoric reference and spiritual graciousness while also learning a lot about one of the world's great religions. The displays roam through art, craft and kitsch; they include beautiful facsimiles of household Hindu shrines and lavishly costumed, spice-daubed statues. Connecting links are provided by videotapes, music, text panels and most of all the color photographs of Steven P. Huyler, one of the exhibition's organizers. The centerpiece is a stupendous trompe l'oeil re-creation of a sacred banyan tree bedecked with offerings and surrounded by sculptures produced by the museum's diorama artists. It is rare to see so much information, spiritual feeling and visual beauty brought into such effective alignment. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission: $10; $7.50, students and 60+; $6, children (Roberta Smith).

"SIGNAC 1863-1935: MASTER NEO-IMPRESSIONIST" AND "NEO-IMPRESSIONISM: THE CIRCLE OF PAUL SIGNAC," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Dec. 30). These shows give an excellent view of the career of Signac, the first and most fervent convert to George Seurat's color theories and Pointillist technique, and their chief proselytizer after Seurat's death in 1891. Redolent of Signac's intelligence, discipline, faith in progress and unflagging energy, the first show moves in clear-cut chapters, beginning with his awkward attempts at Impressionism and a gallery of beautiful transitional works that are among the show's best. Next come his Seuratesque seascapes and more distinctive figurative works; the radiant St.-Tropez paintings in which he made Neo-Impressionism his own; and his exuberantly eccentric late paintings and not-eccentric-enough watercolors. The importance of Signac's color to the development of Modernism -- starting with Matisse and the Fauves -- is unmistakable, but so is his tendency to be mechanical and a little soulless. The smaller exhibition of work by the artists he knew, from Seurat to Matisse, clarifies both his deficiencies and his achievement. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

* "TRADITIONAL JAPANESE DESIGN: FIVE TASTES," Japan Society Gallery, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through Jan. 6). This inspired exhibition parses nearly 150 objects of everyday use according to distinct, if not entirely separate, sensibilities; and in the process it reveals the complex role that aesthetics has always played in Japan's social, economic and intellectual life. Spanning periods from the prehistoric Jomon to the late-19th-century Edo, the beautifully installed show includes tools, clothing, weapons, shop signs, sake bottles, tea bowls, a range of lacquer and much else. The simple household objects of artisans and farmers are contrasted with a more contrived simplicity of the masters of the tea ceremony. The ostentatious kimonos of noble women are followed by the discreetly luxurious robes of Edo merchants' wives, whose extravagances were restricted by sumptuary laws. Despite considerable diversity in craft, material and visual ideals, the exhibition is united by a profound reverence for the beauty of the natural world and the conviction that it should not be marred by manmade objects. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5 (Smith).

Galleries: Uptown

"EXQUISITE MOMENTS: WEST LAKE AND SOUTHERN SONG ART," China Institute, 125 East 65th Street, (212) 744-8181 (through Dec. 9). New York's big fall show of Chinese painting is installed in a very small space: two galleries at the China Institute that together could fit in a coat-check room at the Met. But square footage doesn't matter. Scale and quality do. Most of the 40 or so paintings in the show, on loan from premier American museums, are also small. Created in the form of album pages and fans, they are a one-on-one sort of art, meant to be brought out every now and then and savored, like love letters, in private. And as with love letters, the emotions conveyed are sweet, intense and sometimes deep (Cotter).

DAVID MANN, James Graham, 1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 535-5767 (through Nov. 3). Mr. Mann's abstract paintings have lush, glossy surfaces and mysterious, swirly depths. He paints translucent glazes over oily, spotty underpainting, then adds gestural shapes like knotted ribbons or jelly fish or fluttering butterflies. Color ranges from the incandescent blood red of "Spanish Manners" to the cool blues and jade greens of "Coincidence." "Inevitable Skin," with its thick, pearlescent pink surface, is weirdly sexy (Ken Johnson).

THOMAS RUFF, "l.m.v.d.r.," Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677 (through Nov. 3). Mr. Ruff's photographs of houses in Europe by the great Modernist architect Ludwig Mies Van der Rohe (i.e., "l.m.v.d.r.") are big and beautifully produced, but bland despite various digital manipulations. Don't miss the nifty stereoscopic viewing boxes: put your nose close to the glass and you discover a remarkably vivid three-dimensional image of a Mies interior (Johnson).

ROBERT THERRIEN, Gagosian, 980 Madison Avenue, at 76th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through Oct. 27). In one of two mercurial sculptures, a football-size metal teardrop is poised upright on the corner of an eye-level table top; in the other, two thick red panels jut divergently from the wall like Minimalist planks or the Dutch door of a giant's house. As his playful, archetypal drawings do, Mr. Therrien's sculptures appeal simultaneously to one's Modernist sophistication and to one's inner child. In this they evoke dreams of pure new beginnings (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

LYNN DAVIS, "Ice," Edwynn Houk Gallery, 745 Fifth Avenue, near 58th Street, (212) 750-7070 (through Nov. 3). In her second show on the subject, Ms. Davis focuses on the architectural structures of icebergs that inhabit Disko Bay, Greenland. Their majestic formations of cubes, towers, arches and cliffs and the reflections they cast in shimmering water make awesome subjects. The austere elegance of these photographs is in keeping with the manmade and natural monuments she has shot in Asia and Africa, but the icebergs are more mysteriously elemental (Glueck).

BODIL MANZ, Garth Clark, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 246-2205 (through Nov. 3). This highly regarded Danish ceramicist makes beautiful cylindrical and oval porcelain vessels with crisp geometric surface designs. Some have walls so thin they look as though they were made of paper. A set of new large and thick pieces with crusty, Expressionistic surfaces are impressive, but they lack the exquisite refinement and seductive intimacy of the smaller works (Johnson).

GERHARD RICHTER, Marian Goodman Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 977-7160 (through Oct. 27). Mr. Richter's latest New York gallery exhibition feels like a cross between a new car showroom and a tutorial in postmodern painting. It is full of undeniably handsome new Richters -- 38 in all -- hot off the assembly line. Dominated by a silvery, penitential gray and filling four galleries, they rehearse the artist's famous disdain for distinctions between abstraction and representation, industrial production and artistic touch. While revealing nothing new about his art, they offer assurance that the product is still reliable, especially if one takes quantity as ultimate confirmation of quality (Smith).

* ALMA W. THOMAS, "Phantasmagoria: Major Paintings From the 1970'S," Michael Rosenfeld Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 247-0082 (through Nov. 3). With each new showing, Thomas's paintings look fresher and livelier, their totally abstract vocabulary of color markings conveying the spirit of a vibrant inner life. After decades of teaching art in the public schools of Washington while doing realist still lifes on her own, she found her voice as an abstract color painter. She pared down her style from tight realist brushwork to geometric, mosaiclike dabs and patches of high-energy hues. Laid down in irregular allover patterns on solid grounds that show through in webs and networks, her late works are sophisticated color structures that still reveal a debt to the natural world. Joy may be in short supply elsewhere, but it resonates in these paintings (Glueck).

VACLAV VYTLACIL, David Findlay Jr., 41 East 57th Street, (212) 486-7660 (through Oct. 27). Born in New York, Vytlacil (1892-1984) studied with Hans Hofmann in the 1920's and later became an influential teacher himself. From 1946 to 1978 he taught at the Art Students League. This selection of modest Cubist-style figurative and abstract pictures, mainly from the 30's and 40's, reveals an artist with a deft touch who thoroughly assimilated the formalist lessons of Hofmann as well as Cezanne, Picasso and Matisse (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

NICOLA DE MARIA, "La Testa Allegra di un Angelo Bello," Sperone Westwater, 121 Greene Street, (212) 431-3685 (through Oct. 27). Mr. De Maria's work is all about color, not that you'd know it from the title of his show, which translates roughly as "The Cheerful Head of a Beautiful Angel." He uses color from its brightest, warmest, most primary manifestations to subtle, sophisticated combinations of hues and textures that seem cued by the stones and mosaics of ancient civilizations. He has covered a gallery wall with a playful mural in which ovoids and parts of circles disport in bright colors on a bright blue ground. In an adjacent gallery appear works of quite another tonal presence, a series of white, heavily impastoed canvases embellished with random scratchings that suggest ghostly faces and bodies, along with patches, pocks, dots and tiny squares of paint. As rough and weathered-looking as the facades of old Venetian palazzos, they are in vigorous contrast to the sunny chromatics of the mural. The tension between the two makes this show all the livelier (Glueck).

TERENCE LA NOUE, David Beitzel, 102 Prince Street, (212) 219-2863 (through Nov. 10). This veteran abstract painter creates dense, colorful crazy-quilt collages of Cubist and biomorphic shapes, Expressionist gesture and quirky symbols on irregularly shaped unstretched canvases. Driven by playful hedonism and cosmic intuitions, Mr. La Noue's paintings have a richly sensuous presence, but feel, ultimately, more tastefully decorative than adventurously imaginative (Johnson).

AMY O'NEILL, "LOKN4U," Spencer Brownstone, 39 Wooster Street, (212) 334-3455 (through Oct. 27). There is a lot of attention to detail in Ms. O'Neill's elaborate theatrical installations. One simulates an old-fashioned carnival game under a blue- and red-striped tent; with inflatable weapons for prizes, it's an antiwar statement. An old bar with dark wood paneling, tacky lights and artificial smoke seeping out from behind the shot glasses has a nice ambience, but its point remains unclear (Johnson).

RAVINDER G. REDDY, Deitch Projects, 18 Wooster Street, (212) 343-7300 (through Oct. 27). This Indian sculptor's painted and gilded fiberglass figures have been among the most visible examples of contemporary South Asian art. For his first New York show, several pieces have been installed at Deitch's hangarlike space, among them colossal heads of wide-eyed women with flowers twined in their hair, and gold-skinned nudes, one of which is a reference to ancient Buddhist sculptures of nature spirits. The results are a hybrid, with roots in the past but also in the pop cultural present: a heroic art with a common touch, kitsch for the ages (Cotter).

Galleries: Chelsea

JEFF BROUWS, "Inside the Live Reptile Tent," Robert Mann Gallery, 210 11th Avenue, near 24th Street, (212) 989-7600 (through Nov. 3). Serpentine roller coasters, dazzling neon signs, sideshow freaks, intrepid high divers, hokey games of chance, Ferris wheels and targets that you sock with a ball are grist for the lens of Mr. Brouws, who has been photographing the dying American carnival scene for more than a decade. In this show, the California-born photographer, who has previously focused on derelict gasoline stations and other highway phenomena, offers a fine wallow in carny nostalgia (Glueck).

FRANCIS CAPE, Murray Guy, 453 West 17th Street, (212) 463-7372 (through Oct. 27). An expert woodworker, Mr. Cape has transformed an entire wall of the gallery into a faux-antique, Early American-style facade, the intricate frame and panel construction painted a warm off-white. But for all its well-built concreteness, it isn't what it appears to be; it's a simulation like a Warhol Brillo box, a slightly surrealistic representation of a certain sort of domestic kitsch, a meditation on the allure of fake traditionalism (Johnson).

MARK COHEN, "Trespass," Bruce Silverstein Gallery, 504 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-3930 (through Nov. 10). Mr. Cohen zeros in on an arm, a leg, a foot, a shoulder tattoo, even a gum bubble so huge that it replaces the face of the young girl blowing it. Taken out of bodily context, these fragmentary (but uncropped) pictures often make fine street poetry. His use of strobe often lends a surreality to his shots, making light as much a part of the impact as the image itself. The head of a young boy, brightly silhouetted by light against the background of a dark street takes on a visionary aspect. Through the eloquence of Mr. Cohen's laconic lens, a town gradually reveals itself (Glueck).

"EPIC PHOTOGRAPHY OF THE CUBAN REVOLUTION," Cuban Art Space, 124 West 23rd Street, (212) 242-0559 (through Oct. 27). For a brief time before the Cuban Revolution turned catastrophic, it had a kind of Hollywood glamour, with troops in scruffy-chic beards and berets and the baby-faced Fidel Castro and the Byronic Che Guevara as superstar leaders. A handful of Cuban photographers, including Raul Corrales and Osvaldo Salas, were responsible for promoting that image, and some of their signature work is on view. The leading image maker, though, was Alberto Diaz Gutierrez, or Korda, who came to the job through a career in fashion photography and advertising and created the image of Che as "Heroic Guerrilla" (Cotter).

BARBARA GROSSMAN, Bowery, 530 West 25th Street, (646) 230-6655 (through Oct. 27). Ms. Grossman had her first solo exhibition at this gallery in 1973. In this, her ninth since then, she presents medium large, bushy Matisse-style paintings in which two or three blocky women in loose dresses read or sing from sheet music against bright, busily patterned rug and wallpaper backgrounds (Johnson).

"INK STUDS," Ten in One, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 604-9660 (through Oct. 27). At its best, as in the work of Daniel Clowes, creator of "Ghost World," the comic book can seem a form of infinite possibility. This unfortunately titled but engaging exhibition features original inked pages by Mr. Clowes as well as samples of variously funny, bizarre and adolescent frame-by-frame narratives by Charles Burns, Kaz, Gary Panter (set designer for "Pee-Wee's Playhouse") and Chris Ware (Johnson).

STEPHEN MUELLER AND DION JOHNSON, Bill Maynes, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 741-3318 (through Nov. 17). Glowing watery plaids, candy-colored stripes and checks, and emblematic shapes that look Middle Eastern are playfully layered by Mr. Mueller in canvases both optically riveting and mystically suggestive. Mr. Johnson combines thick paint -- troweled, combed, smeared and dribbled -- schematic diagrams of machinery, furniture and architecture and neatly painted images in a child's picture book style to dreamy and sensuous effect (Johnson).

BERNIE SEARLE, Axis Gallery, 453 West 17th Street, (212) 741-2582 (through Oct. 27). Ms. Searle's New York debut introduces a promising young South African artist whose aesthetic is still in formation. Over the course of works dating from 1998 to this year, the show traces a development from relatively superficial, almost glamour-magazine images of the artist's body and face covered with spices, to a haunting photo-performance piece called "Still," in which flour becomes a vehicle for labor, ancient ritual and racial difference. But the best piece is "Stain," a series of small photographs that illuminates connections between power, sex and violence with help from the title's dictionary definition (Smith).

BUZZ SPECTOR, "All the Books in My Library . . . ," Cristinerose, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 206-0297 (through Oct. 27). An artist known for making art out of and about books presents witty, large-format Polaroid pictures of items from his collection. "Freeze Freud" has the complete works of the psychoanalyst frozen in blocks of ice. "(All the Books in My Library) By or About Christian Boltanksi" is just that -- a picture of 18 volumes with the spines turned away. In "My Fiction," a large six-panel piece, the artist presents himself shirtless surrounded by stacks of modern literature (Johnson).

Other Galleries

ZARINA BHIMJI, Talwar Gallery, 108 East 16th Street, (212) 673-3096 (through Oct. 27). This show brings a double debut: the inauguration of Talwar Gallery and the first New York solo appearance of the African-born, London-based art Ms. Zarina Bhimji, seen here previously in museum group shows. She offers an idea-rich multimedia photographic installation that touches on different kinds of gardens -- English parks, slave plantations, paradise -- and adds enigmatically sensual abstract images that tie their meanings and histories together. As a bonus, the pictures are gorgeous (Cotter).

* "EXPANDING ON A LEGACY: AMERICAN ART FROM THE MONTCLAIR ART MUSEUM," UBS Paine Webber Art Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, near 51st Street, (212) 713-2885 (through Nov. 30). In the 19th century Montclair, N.J., was a thriving art colony whose best known member was the landscapist George Inness (1825-1894), and had high-minded citizens with cultural aspirations. A splendid result was the Montclair Art Museum, opened in 1914 and today one of the country's leading small museums of American art. This sampler of some 80 paintings, sculptures and American Indian art is meant to bring its treasures to a larger audience while it completes a renovation. A 1782 portrait by Gilbert Stuart; a major Inness landscape; realist canvases by John Sloan and Edward Hopper; a good slice of early Modernist work by Arthur Dove, Stuart Davis and Morgan Russell; an early Abstract Expressionist theme by Adolph Gottlieb; a group of sculptures by names like Daniel Chester Frency, Louise Nevelson, Man Ray and George Rickey, and an elegant Tlingit totem pole from the Northwest Coast make this an appetizing prelude to the feast across the river (Glueck).

"SHIFTING TIDES: CUBAN PHOTOGRAPHY AFTER THE REVOLUTION," Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780 (through Oct. 27). This show begins in the 1970's with revolution-era Cuban photography in a documentary mode and then rapidly brings the picture into the present with young artists today. Conceptually grounded, often multimedia in format and obliquely critical, focused on personal perception rather than historical events, their work is too varied to be tagged by a look or a style. It ranges from the elegiac photomontages of Rogelio Lopez Marin, known as Gory, to the ritualistic tableaus of Marta Maria Perez Bravo to a sardonic take on epic photography by Manuel Pina in the series "Manipulation, Truths and Other Illusions." The title could be applied to the show as a whole (Cotter).

Last Chance

"FIELD OF STONES: SCHOLAR ROCKS, INKSTONES AND PAINTINGS," China 2000, 5 East 57th Street, (212) 588-1198 (through Wednesday). The Chinese scholar rock, a piece of stone discovered in nature, was selected for its unusual form; cradled in a beautiful wooden base, it served as an object of philosophical contemplation. This display of scholar rocks from the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries is notable for being drawn from the collection of a single Beijing collector. The show also includes paintings of stones, inkstones and rocks simulated in wood or porcelain (Johnson).

"INTERWOVEN LIVES: GEORGE PLATT LYNES AND HIS FRIENDS," DC Moore, 724 Fifth Avenue, near 57th Street, (212) 247-2111 (through tomorrow). More than 140 photographs, paintings, drawings and prints tell the story of the New York portrait and fashion photographer Lynes (1907-1955) and the enchanted circle of artists, friends and lovers to which he belonged. Lynes felt his most important works were his male nudes, which combine classicizing style and soft pornography; but his portraits of people like Paul Cadmus, Katherine Anne Porter, W. H. Auden and many others remain most compelling today (Johnson).

JACK YOUNGERMAN, "Wood Relief Paintings and Watercolors," Washburn, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-6780 (through tomorrow). The zingy high colors and color contrasts of Mr. Youngerman's wood relief paintings make this one of his most sparkling shows. Occurring for the most part in jagged, asymmetrical shapes that are at times stylized and emblematic, at others biomorphic like flowers, the reliefs are quirkily incised. The surfaces are painted in the same, different or slightly variant colors. In "Claustral," a rough diamond shape with four points, the deep, lustrous green of the inset makes a subtle and pleasing play with the bright blue of the raised surface. The hand of the artist is always refreshingly visible (Glueck).

GRAPHIC: Photos: Last Chance: A large detail from "Jonathan Tichenor, Fire Island" (1937), by George Platt Lynes, in "Interwoven Lives" at DC Moore. (DC Moore); Giacometti's "Spoon Woman" (1926-27), at the Modern. (Artist Rights Society, New York/ADAGP, Paris)

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
A Detailed Look at Roosevelt, the Intelligence Consumer

BYLINE:  By PHILIP BOBBITT; Philip Bobbitt, a former director for intelligence programs at the National Security Council, holds the Walker Centennial Chair in Law at the University of Texas and is the author of "The Shield of Achilles," forthcoming from Knopf.

 BODY:
ROOSEVELT'S SECRET WAR
F. D. R. and World War II Espionage
By Joseph E. Persico
Random House. 564 pages. $35.
 Can a rather spoiled but handsome paraplegic, deceptive by nature and mistrusted by most of his colleagues, gamely presiding over an intensely isolationist country sunk in the deep trough of an economic depression, manage to defeat the most dynamic economic and military powers of the globe and take his nation to international supremacy? 
 He can if that man is Franklin Delano Roosevelt. In "Roosevelt's Secret War," a well-paced and memorable account of Roosevelt's experiences with World War II intelligence operations, Joseph E. Persico takes up the general theme of American global engagement as refracted through the complex moral and psychological temperament of the American president.
Roosevelt's relentless single-mindedness contrasted with the bonhomie of the aristocratic president. Like many wealthy people in international society, Roosevelt was susceptible to the conspiratorial view of life that a few largely hidden, largely interpersonal events lay beneath most headlines.
This partly accounted for his susceptibility to secret missions by the socialite Vincent Astor, the well-connected columnist John Franklin Carter and the Philadelphia Main Line figure George Earle III. What Roosevelt made of their reports one can only guess, but he repeatedly authorized individuals -- ultimately more than 100 -- to report directly to him, outside customary military intelligence channels and often financed from the president's emergency accounts.
Mr. Persico depicts a Roosevelt whose strongest trait as an intelligence consumer was his relentless pursuit of the big picture and his strategic goals. 
The first of these goals was to get the United States into war before it was too late. When we reflect upon Roosevelt's fears of a Nazi nuclear weapon and the ultimate success of the German ballistic missile program, we can appreciate the urgency of the president's efforts. A Gallup poll taken just a month before Pearl Harbor disclosed that only 17 percent of the American public would support a war against Germany. Even after the Japanese attack, it was not only Hitler's timely, if fatal, declaration of war against the United States, but also Roosevelt's having prepared the public for a moral struggle against Nazism that allowed him to turn to the European theater first, despite the slaughter in the Pacific.
Second, Roosevelt was determined to keep the Soviet Union in the wartime alliance. This was not out of any ideological sympathy or political flaccidness on his part, though he was capable of always appearing in sympathy and he rarely opposed anyone head-on. Rather, it reflected Roosevelt's unsentimental awareness of Soviet power in the Eurasian region and his ruthless assessment of the basic duplicity and unreliability of his Soviet ally if Stalin were presented with a German peace proposal. Roosevelt even went so far as to order captured Soviet codes returned to Moscow, to the dismay of American intelligence officials and the perplexity of their Soviet counterparts.
Third, Roosevelt strictly adhered to the war aim of unconditional surrender when the prospect of German peace proposals to the Western allies might have tempted them into a premature armistice. Roosevelt understood, as many since have not, that the war was about the destruction of fascism and that nothing less than the discrediting of fascism in the eyes of the Great Powers where it had taken hold -- Germany and Japan -- could prevent this malignant ideology from flaring up again.
Finally, Roosevelt's persistent pursuit of the earliest possible second front also reflected his deep understanding of the political purposes of the war. Mr. Persico writes that Roosevelt even made British participation in the Manhattan Project depend upon British consent to Overlord, the cross-channel invasion in 1944.
Like the Scarlet Pimpernel whom he so much resembled in the chatty and frivolous mask with which he clothed his secret purposes, the president apparently ran intelligence operations out of his residence. The newly formed Office of Strategic Services, precursor of the Central Intelligence Agency, sent him an average of five pieces of raw intelligence a day throughout the war. These were not so-called finished intelligence; that is, they were not assessed for their reliability, nor put into the political, diplomatic and strategic contexts that would indicate their usefulness. There was no analysis to cushion the necessary fallibility that accompanies intelligence collection.
Partly this was offset by Roosevelt's experience with raw intelligence when he was assistant secretary of the Navy during World War I. Partly it was offset by the invaluable Oshima cables, in which the Japanese ambassador to Berlin did provide finished intelligence to Tokyo that was intercepted by the United States. But mainly the approach succeeded because Roosevelt's chief interest was not in the accuracy of the questionable products he received, but in his being able to use that information to achieve political results at home and within the alliance.
There are two kind of secrets: those that someone knows (like the date of the Normandy invasion) and those that no one knows (like whether Germany would collapse after the loss of Italy and France). Roosevelt's matchless political judgment rightly put the higher value on the latter.
Mr. Persico's entertaining and even inspiring book has many points of correspondence with intelligence problems today. Mr. Persico asserts that the publication of the news by The New York Times that Winston Churchill and Roosevelt were linked by a scrambled trans-Atlantic line enabled the Germans to intercept this correspondence and decode it, much as the press's report of Osama bin Laden's reliance on cellphones caused him to stop using them.
The Chicago Tribune published Gen. George C. Marshall's Rainbow Five Plan, which detailed the American force structure needed to fight the war, in repeated efforts to show that Roosevelt wanted war to distract the public from his political failures, not unlike the American news media's attempt to portray the Clinton administration's attack on Afghanistan and the Sudan as a "Wag the Dog" scenario.
Then as now, the United States was in a race to defeat a shrewd and creative enemy of infinite malice before he could acquire a decisive weapons technology. 
Like today, the fragmentation of intelligence sharing -- lucidly discussed in Gregory Treverton's new book, "Reshaping National Intelligence for an Age of Information" -- repeatedly thwarted truly effective United States action. Like today, Congress played an approach/avoidance role, alternately outlawing wiretapping and searching the government for Communists.
Classic questions of the period are addressed, and revisionists are dispatched. Did Roosevelt permit the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor to go forward to bring the United States into World War II? Could the United States have done more to rescue Jews or break up concentration camps? Did the president exceed his constitutional authority in his efforts to aid Britain and China before the United States entry into the war? Did American covert action inadvertently provoke the Japanese to attack the United States? Would Roosevelt have used nuclear weapons against Japan? Mr. Persico offers well-reasoned judgments on all these questions and often brings new research to bear.
Through it all, flashing a debonair smile while he placed a fresh Camel cigarette in his ivory cigarette holder, was the purposeful, undeterred president, often in pain but never showing doubt.
In spite of Roosevelt's love of prevarication, his temporizing and his chaotic institutional arrangements, Mr. Persico obviously admires his subject. This entertaining and thoughtful book shows there was much to admire.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph E. Persico (Joseph Schuyler/Random House)

HEADLINE: Aging With Boomers, The Accord Turns 25 

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE KREBS

 BODY:
THE Honda Accord, the car that put the Japanese in the mainstream of the American auto market, is a quarter-century old.
 The first Accord arrived in dealer showrooms in June 1976 as a somewhat sporty but mostly practical hatchback that, while fairly compact, was larger than most Japanese cars of the time. A sedan version came three years later. 
 For the American Honda Motor Company, which had previously offered only subcompacts like the Civic, the Accord was a significant first step toward becoming a major manufacturer with a full line of vehicles. It also gave Honda a major presence in the United States, which remains the company's strongest market.
For the world's auto industry, the Accord represented the Japanese entry into the mainstream car business that Detroit dominated. At the time, Toyota's largest car was the Mark II, now largely forgotten.
For millions of American baby boomers, the Accord mirrored the changes in their own lives. It grew and matured with them as they left college, started careers and raised families. As they moved into middle age and toward retirement, the Accord became ever more comfortable, reassuring and reliable.
Before the Accord, Japanese automobiles were mostly small economy cars, which leaped in popularity after gasoline prices jumped in the early 1970's. Detroit loyalists disparagingly called them "rice burners."
But the Accord struck closer to the heart of the American market, offering more space along with excellent economy. The midsize segment in which it now competes is the single largest part of the market, accounting for annual United States sales of about four million.
Honda sold 75,995 Accords in 1977, the car's first full year on the market, but the line has steadily gained popularity. Honda sold 404,515 here last year, and total Accord sales have topped 7.5 million.
The Accord was the first car from a Japanese company to be an American best seller, surpassing the Ford Taurus in 1989. And although the current Accord has grown dated -- a new version will arrive in a year -- it is likely to regain the sales crown for the 2001 calendar year. It came in first for the '01 model year, which ended on Sept. 30; production of the Toyota Camry, the sales champion of recent years, slipped as that car underwent a thorough redesign.
The Accord has undergone a metamorphosis over the years. The first one, a boxy three-door hatchback, was 162.8 inches long and had a 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine. The sticker price was $3,995.
It has grown substantially, and for 2002 it comes as a coupe and sedan, which are now distinctly different models. The sedan is 189.4 inches long and has a 2.3-liter, 135-horsepower four-cylinder (or a 3-liter, 200 horsepower V-6). Prices range from $16,740 to the upper $20,000 range.
The Accord has had many firsts. It was the first passenger car built in the United States by a Japanese company; Honda began building Accords in 1982 in Marysville, Ohio.
It was also the first gasoline-powered vehicle to meet California's strict SULEV standard (for super-ultra-low-emissions vehicles).
The Accord has served as a platform for other models, including the 3.2TL sedan and 3.2CL coupe from Honda's luxury brand, Acura. Accord components are used in the Odyssey minivan, the Acura MDX sport utility and a Honda sport utility yet to come.

HEADLINE: Russia Becoming an Oil Ally 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE with BIRGIT BRAUER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 18 

 BODY:
With the developed world nervously eyeing the security of oil supplies in the Middle East, Russia is stepping forward as a new friend in need. Alongside its support for the United States' military campaign in Afghanistan, Russia is offering its oil fields as a secure alternative to dependence on the turbulent Persian Gulf.
 Russia and the countries of the former Soviet Union together produce about one-tenth of the world's oil and one-third of its natural gas. Russia's oil industry is booming, with exports up by 9 percent so far this year. Next week, production will begin at a northern gas field with reserves equal to two-thirds of all those in the rest of Europe. 
 Neighboring Kazakhstan is developing huge new fields and expects to more than double its output by 2010. Last month, speaking to businessmen in Germany, Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, offered to step up oil deliveries if supplies came under threat.
"Non-Middle East oil will be seen as being more desirable than ever," said Stephen O'Sullivan, head of research at the United Financial Group, a Moscow investment bank. 
Most analysts say Russia is not now able to export enough oil to completely replace Middle Eastern sources in the event of a major disruption, in large part because of limited pipeline capacity. But construction of new pipelines is expected to gain greater urgency now.
Crucially, in the Caspian basin, where Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan and other states are developing immense reserves, a decade-long rivalry for influence between the United States and Russia could now turn into something more like cooperation. Instead of squabbling over the routes exports would take, the two sides now share a common interest in ramping up total pipeline capacity, the main constraint on growth in recent years.
The opening of a new pipeline from the Tengiz field in western Kazakhstan to a Russian port on the Black Sea is a major milestone for the region, where international oil companies like ChevronTexaco and British Petroleum have spent billions of dollars since the fall of the Soviet Union to explore and develop energy resources.
Throughout the 1990's, Russia and the United States backed competing pipeline routes out of the Caspian basin, a region that the United States Department of Energy estimates holds 110 billion barrels of oil -- about triple the United States' own reserves. For political reasons, the main American objective was to build export routes that avoided crossing either Russian or Iranian territory -- to the irritation of Moscow, which sees the region as within its sphere of influence and pipelines as powerful levers for political control. 
Russia prevailed in 1999, when an international consortium of oil companies led by Chevron began building the $2.6 billion pipeline to Novorossiysk, which made its first commercial delivery of crude oil on Sunday. On top of the billions of dollars in royalties Russia expects to earn over its 40-year life, the pipeline maintains Moscow's direct control over oil flows from the region.
Analysts said that Russia's new alliance with the United States in the coalition against terrorism has accelerated the shift away from antagonism over the vast oil resources of the former Soviet Union.
"The trend was already towards a depoliticization of Caspian energy, and this definitely advances that," said Laurent Ruseckas of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, an energy consultancy in London. "This whole idea of the U.S. and Russia fighting over Caspian oil seems completely outdated. The West would like to see Russian and Caspian oil on stream as quickly as possible."
For its part, now that the Novorossiysk pipeline is open, the Russian government says it no longer objects to construction of a a second pipeline on the Azerbaijan-to-Turkey route that the United States has favored.
"We will not hamper this project," said Russia's energy minister, Igor Yusufov, in an interview, adding that Russia believes it can hold its own in attracting foreign energy investment even if the second line is built. "Our close connections will allow us to bring to fruition more valuable long-term projects," he said. 
Western diplomats doubt that Russia will give up trying to influence and profit from development of oil fields in the former Soviet republics to its south. Mr. Putin's decision to ally himself with the West in the war against terrorism may come at the cost of ceding some of Russia's historical political dominance in Central Asia. The diplomats said it was unlikely that he would surrender what he considers Russia's share of Caspian oil riches.
"The interesting geopolitical issue is whether the Russians will climb down from a zero-sum, even hostile, view of American commercial, political and military relations in the region," said Stephen Sestanovich, a former special adviser to the United States Secretary of State on matters concerning the former Soviet Union. "We are seeing some indications from Mr. Putin that he is telling his government to back off that kind of approach. Will he apply that less competitive outlook to energy issues as well? We'll have to see."
Russia is also extending its energy reach to other lucrative markets. It is pushing ahead with a planned new natural gas pipeline under the Black Sea to Turkey that would increase Turkey's dependence on Russian gas to 80 percent of its needs, from about two-thirds now.
Russia is even making progress with a proposal to build a pipeline to carry Russian crude to eastern China. Though China is busily developing its domestic energy resources, economic growth has been far outrunning its efforts to step up production, and China has been a net oil importer since 1993.
Energy exports have become the lifeblood of Russia's economy, accounting for half its export earnings and one-third of the federal government's budget revenue. A sharp drop in oil prices could wreck its budget and complicate the repayment of the billions of dollars in foreign debt that fall due in the next two years.
Still, Russia's eagerness as a supplier has often put it at cross-purposes with the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, which even before Sept. 11 was straining to prop up world oil prices by restricting supply. Russia's steadily rising production undercuts those efforts, and though the country pledges to cooperate with OPEC, oil executives here say they have no plans to cut back.
Russian oil companies, flush with cash from several years of high prices, have been spending heavily on new equipment and technology to increase production. But foreign oil companies with interests here, like BP and Exxon Mobil, have had a harder time, with new production set back by legal and tax difficulties.

HEADLINE: Germany Revises Projections As Economic Growth Slows 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 18 

 BODY:
The German government acknowledged today that economic growth had stagnated, and it predicted that the economy would expand by just 0.75 percent this year and show meager growth in 2002.
 The downward revision matches forecasts that had already been made by many banks. But it means that Germany, Europe's biggest economy, is perilously close to a recession, and it puts more pressure on the European Central Bank to follow the lead of the Federal Reserve and cut interest rates. 
 The new forecast was made by Hans Eichel, the finance minister. On Wednesday night, the chief economist of the Bundesbank, the German central bank, made a similarly bleak forecast and warned that the budget deficits would rise sharply next year.
"There is much evidence that one will have to expect a longer problem zone," said the economist, Herman Remsperger. "That means not only that an economic turnaround is unlikely this year, but that the situation will only gradually return to normal next year."
Germany, heavily dependent on exports of big industrial products and sensitive to the downturn in the United States, is likely to remain one of the slowest-growing countries in Europe this year and next. Its problems affect much of the rest of the Continent, and all European countries have been hit much harder than they expected by problems in the United States.
Unemployment is once again edging up across Europe, as scores of companies announce plans to eliminate jobs. The list of German companies shedding workers includes Siemens, the electronics conglomerate; Infineon, the semiconductor producer; Adam Opel, the German subsidiary of General Motors; and all of the major banks.
But the same pattern is shaping up elsewhere in Europe, from Philips Electronics in the Netherlands to Ericsson in Sweden.
In contrast with the United States, most European governments have been cautious about trying to stimulate growth by enacting deep tax cuts or stepping up spending.
Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany has repeatedly rebuffed pleas for special programs to shore up particular industries. French leaders are toying with a modest package of tax reductions, some of them temporary, but economists say they are too small to have much impact.
The European Central Bank, which sets monetary policy for all 12 countries that have adopted the euro, continues to resist reducing interest rates.
The economic slowdown is also taking a toll on government budgets. Here in Germany, the Bundesbank predicted that the budget deficit would double from 1 percent of gross domestic product to 2 percent.
European leaders have already given up hope that countries will continue to reduce their budget deficits this year. But fear of higher deficits has been the main reason that governments have not tried to stimulate growth with big new tax cuts or spending projects.

HEADLINE: MasterCard And Visa Lose a Ruling On a Lawsuit 

BYLINE:  By Reuters

 BODY:
A federal court has rejected an appeal to stop an antitrust lawsuit against Visa USA and MasterCard International from including four million retailers. It was the latest blow to the leading credit card networks.
 In a 2-to-1 decision issued late Wednesday, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan rejected an appeal from Visa and MasterCard to stop retailers from receiving class certification in a 1996 suit that accuses them of using their dominance in credit cards to force merchants to accept their debit cards. 
 The suit, led by Wal-Mart Stores Inc., seeks $8 billion in damages, a figure that would be tripled to about $24 billion under federal antitrust law if the retailers win.
Earlier this month, Visa and MasterCard suffered a setback in a separate antitrust case when a federal judge ordered the networks to end a policy that blocked member banks from issuing cards from rivals like American Express.
Visa and MasterCard are owned by major banks and together control more than 75 percent of credit card sales.
"The merchants have won the appeal, and Visa and MasterCard have lost the appeal, as we expected," the plaintiffs' lawyer, Lloyd Constantine, said yesterday. "We are gratified and are now going to trial." A trial date has not been set.
Wal-Mart and other retailers object to having to accept Visa and MasterCard debit cards because they say these cards carry higher transaction fees. Visa has argued retailers must honor all its cards.
Visa, encouraged by a long dissenting opinion from a senior appeals judge on the case, said it would press for a rehearing before the court and, if needed, consider a petition to the Supreme Court.
Visa and MasterCard have argued that the retailer class would be too large to be manageable and that retailers used flawed economic theories in presenting their case.
Retailers contend that without class certification, millions of merchants would be deprived of compensation for damages.

HEADLINE: City Known for Military Jets Is Beyond Them 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: PALMDALE, Calif., Oct. 12 

 BODY:
Few towns have been more closely identified with the military's mastery of the skies than this high desert outpost of sand, Joshua trees and the most advanced aircraft in the world. 
 Chuck Yeager first broke the sound barrier on the legendary testing grounds at Edwards Air Force Base here, and the area's military contractors have built everything from U-2 spy planes to fleets of F-117 stealth fighters and B-2 bombers. 
 But as many of those jets now pound Afghanistan, few people here expect to see much if any impact in the new Palmdale, beyond anxious moments and the waving of flags. The prospect of big new contracts to shore up a military at war, which was often the case in the past, barely causes a stir now because what was once a one-company town -- the company being the military establishment -- has developed into a small city with a booming, highly diversified economy. 
After a devastating recession following the cold war, when the Pentagon reduced its weapons orders, Palmdale has remade itself. The military industries have become just one of many important sources for jobs and identity.
Palmdale is merely a more conspicuous example of a deep transformation affecting scores of cities around the country, one of the main reasons that the economic impact of this new kind of battle will be far different from that of past wars.
If the emblems of the old Palmdale were the huge production hangars, now they are huge box retailers, like Home Depot and Kmart. Its economic pulse is most evident not at the fenced-off runways where residents still come to watch awesome jets roar into the desert skies, but on the freeway, where tens of thousands of commuters jam the lanes each weekday morning for the 65-mile trip to civilian jobs in Los Angeles.
A similar tale is told in other cities in Los Angeles County. Indeed, in the county as a whole, the aerospace industry accounts for less than 3 percent of total jobs today, compared with nearly 8 percent in 1986.
Palmdale, however, has not just changed. It has boomed in an entirely new direction. Twenty years ago, it had a population of 12,277, a great many of those people employed by Boeing, Northrop Grumman or Lockheed Martin -- or at Edwards.
Today, the city has 122,400 residents, many of them young, middle-class families who could not afford $300,000 or more for starter houses in the Los Angeles area. The desert scrub has been replaced with grassy quarter-acre plots with houses at half the cost. The city is now far younger than the rest of the county, and its median household income, about $65,000, is higher. And the Antelope Valley, as the area around the city is known, sends about 57,600 people a day to work in Los Angeles.
Anthony G. Nakonechnyj, a director of photography in the movie industry, is typical. Since moving here seven years ago, Mr. Nakonechnyj said, his daily commute to Los Angeles has gone from a one-hour jaunt to a two-hour endurance contest. But it has been worth it, he said, because he was able to move his family from a rented house with no yard on a busy street in the city to a comfortable home on a one-acre lot with a swimming pool -- at half the price.
"You get to see the stealth bombers flying occasionally, which is really pretty cool, but that's about all you see of the military here," Mr. Nakonechnyj said. "It's a typical bedroom suburb, and we like that."
David J. Myers, president of the Greater Antelope Valley Economic Alliance, a business promotion group, said that the sentimental ties to the military remained strong and that the military facilities, while smaller, were still big employers. But the major events that point to the future are the openings of new industrial plants or large retailers.
Mr. Myers described the recent groundbreaking for a plant for U.S. Pole, a manufacturer of commercial lighting, as a more apt emblem of the city than the heavily guarded hangar nearby where the F-117 stealth fighters were produced. In addition, a number of other manufacturers have taken advantage of the low costs here, and there is a huge mall.
"It surprises a lot of people when they come out here and see how we've changed," Mr. Myers said. "There was a time when we had more congressmen in the valley than supermarkets. But it's just a different world now."
Jackie Snider, the head of the local chamber of commerce, said that when the Pentagon began cutting its procurement budgets more than a decade ago, "this city was in a world of hurt," adding, "It was awful."
But the sprawling growth of Los Angeles and the demand for less expensive housing saved Palmdale, Ms. Snider said. Though residents often complain about traffic jams, she said, they do not complain about being able to shop here rather than having to travel 50 miles for quality produce, as in the past.
Larry Chimbole, a former mayor who has lived in Palmdale for more than 40 years, said the waves of military cuts "almost destroyed the community."
"I mean it was devastating," Mr. Chimbole said.
He said that in the old days, few people even considered commuting across what was known as the cactus curtain between the desert and Los Angeles, for logistical and cultural reasons. The people of the desert had disdain for those in the big city, Mr. Chimbole said.
But the cultural divide has been all but bridged, he added, and the old attitudes evaporated once it was clear what benefits suburbanization would bring.
Boeing, which acquired the plant here where the B-1 bombers were built several decades ago, now has a skeleton staff of about 290 people in Palmdale. "It's just odds-and-ends work, and some work on the space shuttle," said George Sillia, a Boeing spokesman.
Northrup Grumman, which built the bat-winged $2 billion B-2 bombers here, now has about 1,200 local employees compared with 4,500 a decade ago. 
And Lockheed Martin, which built U-2's and the F-117 stealth fighters, has shrunk to about 3,750 employees from 18,000.
"Sure, if you heard there were more B-2's that were going to be built here, people would be pleased," Mr. Myers said. "But we're not going to sink if that doesn't happen by any means. We've just moved on."

HEADLINE: Berlin Journal; 
Picking a Gay Mayor, Maybe, Over an Ex-Marxist

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Oct. 18 

 BODY:
Berlin likes to fancy itself a city without taboos, but it may be about to break two longstanding ones, political and sexual.
 In Sunday's elections for a new government of this capital redux, Berlin's voters are likely to elect an openly gay mayor, Klaus Wowereit, a Social Democrat. More striking yet, perhaps, they could allow the successor to the East German Communist Party a share of power in a city that same party divided when it ordered the building of the Berlin Wall in 1961. 
 Unsurprisingly, in a city formed by superpower clashes beyond its borders, the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on America and the subsequent bombing of Afghanistan are adding another twist to Sunday's outcome. 
If the results reflect the polls, the often bland Mr. Wowereit and the charismatic leader of the former Communists, Gregor Gysi, will finish first and second. But Mr. Gysi's party is the only one that has starkly opposed the American bombing of Afghanistan. That opposition to the war, which the Social Democratic Chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, supports so strongly, makes it next to impossible for him to back a coalition between the two parties in the nation's capital.
Resisting the partnership, however, may be difficult because of the extent of Mr. Gysi's support. It would also rob Berlin of a chance to unite a city whose western and eastern halves are still sharply divided in spirit, even 12 years after the infamous wall came down.
Mr. Gysi campaigns, without apparent irony, on his party's ability to bring Berlin together by empowering those in the east, 40 percent of whom support his party.
His antiwar stance should enhance the appeal of his Party of Democratic Socialism to younger voters in the west. Indeed, the 53-year-old Mr. Gysi is a more compelling and complicated character than Mr. Wowereit: witty, eloquent, ironic, a trained lawyer and national legislator who has lived down a file showing some collaboration (on behalf of his clients, he says) with the Communists' old Stasi secret police.
Mr. Wowereit -- a 48-year-old lawyer thrown into office as a transitional mayor in June -- had one distinction, however. Just before a Springer newspaper, the tabloid BZ, "outed" him as gay, Mr. Wowereit said so openly, and became a national celebrity a week before becoming mayor. He was appointed in a temporary capacity after the collapse of the previous administration in a finance scandal.
In a phrase that has become so famous that someone else has copyrighted it, Mr. Wowereit said: "I'm gay, and it's good that way."
Now, "und das ist gut so" has become the tag line for advertisements and is even used for the party's election Web site (www.spd-und-das-ist-gut-so.de).
Mr. Wowereit's election is acknowledged even by Mr. Gysi as a breakthrough for sexual freedom and tolerance. Dirk Bachhausen, the deputy leader of the Social Democrats' gay and lesbian group, said that Mr. Wowereit's success has been "to show that he is a normal person and citizen, and being gay is simply a part of himself."
The mayoral candidate for the Christian Democrats, Frank Steffel, 35, has by contrast suggested that Mr. Wowereit has "a deformed character." The conservative, widely acknowledged as a disaster, has campaigned ostentatiously with his wife, talks of Munich as Germany's "secret capital" and acknowledges that he used racial slurs about blacks and Turks when he was a teenager.
Berlin is a pauper after years of spending money like water on maintaining its superficially united dualities: three opera houses, three airports, two zoos, two television towers and scores of museums.
The city is $35 billion in debt, with the slowest economic growth of any of Germany's 16 states and an unemployment rate of some 16 percent, compared with a national average of 9 percent.
Mr. Wowereit campaigns on getting the city moving again, as if his party had not been a part of the coalition with the Christian Democrats that fell apart in June and was responsible for much of the lavish spending.
The mayor has been spare on specifics on how to salvage Berlin, and it is hard to point to many accomplishments in his four months of rule. Still, reflecting his own and Mr. Schroder's popularity, the Social Democrats are expected to do well.
While the election may clear a sexual hurdle, the ghosts lurking from the Communist past could prove harder to conquer. Mr. Gysi acknowledges, a touch wearily, that his party has "done the basic reforms, but there's more to be done." 
It was a struggle to get the party to condemn the building of the Berlin Wall, and Mr. Gysi failed to get his party to apologize for it. Now, he is trying to push the party itself over the vanished wall and gain a larger constituency in the west.
"This election is a chance to make the party more popular in the rest of the country," he said. "We want to make clear that we don't stand for walls, but for bridges."
It is a delicate balancing act. On the one hand, the party is popular with easterners for representing their values and current grievances about jobs, lower pay and lower status. But the party is also trying to appeal to the left wing in the west, particularly as the Social Democrats, in power under Mr. Schroder, have moved further to the center.
Beyond the policies, Mr. Gysi's wit comes through, appealing to the young and the disaffected in east and west alike. He likes to say, given Berlin's corruption and near bankruptcy -- "Vote for the P.D.S. -- it can't be worse with us."
A campaign poster shows an old black-and-white photo of infants crawling around, mostly without pants, in the bathroom of East Germany's once ubiquitous state-funded kindergarten. The caption reads: "Not everything was awful, and mommy could go to work every day."

A Social Democrat, Mr. Wowereit is expected to be the victor.; Gregor Gysi, the candidate of the former East German Communists. (Photos by Mark Simon/Black Star, for The New York Times); Klaus Wowereit, in June, after Pariament appointed him mayor. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Profit Increases 2% at Reynolds 

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Oct. 18 

 BODY:
The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company reported a 2 percent increase in third-quarter profit today but warned that lower interest rates on investments would cut into its full-year results.
 The company reported net income of $119 million, or $1.22 a share, up from $117 million, or $1.16 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. 
 Excluding a 9-cent-a-share charge to reflect a reduction in the gain on the sale of Reynolds International, the company earned $128 million, or $1.31 a share.
Analysts expected earnings of $1.29 a share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. 
Revenue for the quarter, which ended Sept. 30, rose 9 percent, to $2.27 billion from $2.08 billion.
Shares of Reynolds fell $3.45, or 6 percent, to $56.68, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Martin Feldman, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said the company's profit was based on fewer outstanding shares and increased interest earnings, not cigarette sales.
"The whole tobacco operation essentially achieved flat earnings," Mr. Feldman said. "The bottom line is that earnings grew largely as a result of a shrinking number of shares outstanding and growing interest income."
In the third quarter, the company sold 23.5 billion cigarettes, down from 24.7 billion a year earlier. The company said shipments of its three full-price brands had fallen 5.8 percent over all. The Camel and Winston brands had increased sales, while Salem was flat.
Higher selling prices cut the volume of sales, Reynolds said. The company said its share of the retail market for the three-month period was nearly unchanged from the period a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Bill to Alter Bankruptcy Seems to Stall 

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
A bill that would have made it more difficult for consumers to dismiss their debts by filing for bankruptcy has effectively been pushed aside in Congress, unlikely to re-emerge this year, lawyers and analysts say.
 The Senate and House passed versions of the legislation in March, and a conference was scheduled for this fall to reconcile the differences. But with consumer confidence considerably weaker since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, lawmakers' enthusiasm for the legislation may have dimmed. 
 "This bankruptcy legislation is more protective of the lenders than the consumer," said Meredith Whitney, an analyst at Wachovia Securities who follows credit card companies. "Given that so much of the economy hinges on the consumer, no one in Washington wants to be perceived as anticonsumer."
Bankruptcy filings have been on the rise this year as consumers and corporations have found it hard to pay their bills. The number of consumers filing for bankruptcy has also risen in anticipation of passage of the bankruptcy bill, which would make it more difficult for individuals to file under Chapter 7 of the United States Bankruptcy Code.
Chapter 7 permits consumers and businesses to shed most of their unsecured debts. Under the bill, more individuals would be forced to file under Chapter 13, which requires debtors to come up with a plan to pay off at least a portion of their debts, usually over three to five years.
With little talk about reviving the legislation, Visa International told its network of bank credit card issuers earlier this week that it was lowering its projections for bankruptcy filings by individuals this year to an increase of 21.1 percent from a previous estimate of a 23 percent increase, Ms. Whitney said. A spokeswoman for Visa declined to confirm the projections, saying the numbers were confidential. Ms. Whitney said she had access to the data because Wachovia is a credit card issuer.
Congressional staff members said the legislation had not officially been tabled, but there were no signs it was a priority, either. A conference to reconcile the two versions of the bill was scheduled for the day after the terrorist attacks, but it was canceled, said Jeff Lungren, a spokesman for the House Judiciary Committee.
Bankruptcy lawyers said the weakness in the economy meant that more consumers would remain in dire straits in the near future.
"The economy was bad before Sept. 11, but things have really deteriorated since," said Max Gardner III, a bankruptcy lawyer in Shelby, N.C. "I have never before seen the sense of personal desperation and fear that I've seen. Filing for bankruptcy provides some certainty in a sea of uncertainty."

HEADLINE: Claims Filed By Jobless Remain Near 9-Year High 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 

 BODY:
The number of workers filing new claims for unemployment benefits approached a nine-year high last week as the Sept. 11 attacks compounded the economic damage from a factory slump, government figures showed today.
 First-time jobless claims increased by 6,000 in the week ended Saturday, to 490,000, the Labor Department reported. 
 Initial applications had soared in the last week of September, to 535,000. Both weeks are the highest since a strike at General Motors in July 1992.
Economists had expected jobless claims to rise last week to 480,000 from the previous week's initially reported 468,000.
Workers are staying unemployed longer, the report showed. The number of people continuing to draw unemployment benefits jumped in the week ended Oct. 6, to 3.65 million. That is the most since 3.70 million in May 1983, when the United States was climbing out of an earlier recession.
Statistics on continuing claims are reported with a one-week lag to new claims.
With manufacturers like United Technologies and service providers like Unisys announcing job cuts this week, analysts expect the unemployment rate to rise.
The unemployment rate rose to a four-year high of 4.9 percent in August and September. Analysts say it may reach as high as 6.5 percent in 2002. It was last that high in March 1994.
"The job picture is getting worse," said Geoffrey Somes, an economist at Fleet Bank in Boston. "Joblessness will continue to increase over the next few months."
The economy lost 199,000 jobs last month, the biggest decline in more than 10 years, the Labor Department reported two weeks ago. Those numbers are based on surveys that do not reflect the job cuts after Sept. 11. Industrial production fell for a 12th consecutive month in September, suggesting factories were still a drag on the economy.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Sharply Lower Sales Propel Losses at Nortel Networks and Corning

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Nortel Networks, the big producer of telecommunications equipment, and Corning Inc., the largest maker of optical fiber used in telecommunications networks, posted third-quarter losses yesterday on falling sales.
 The loss at Nortel, based in Brampton, Ontario, widened to $3.47 billion, or $1.08 a share, from a loss of $586 million, or 20 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales slid to $3.69 billion from $6.73 billion. 
 Excluding special charges, the loss was $854 million, or 27 cents a share. On that basis, analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had expected the company to lose 28 cents a share.
Phone companies have bought less networking equipment this year amid a global slowdown in economic growth, and Nortel and many rival suppliers are not expecting demand to improve for at least a year. Nortel, which is eliminating more than half its work force to cut costs and selling businesses to raise cash, says it can break even in 2002 with quarterly sales figures of less than $4 billion.
Michael Cohen, who manages the Alpha Analytics Digital Future Fund, said, "The current spending environment looks quite bleak." Phone companies, he said before the results were released, "are waiting for demand to catch up with the capacity they already have online."
Nortel reported its quarterly figures after the end of trading. The shares closed in New York at $5.92, down 3 cents. After hours, they sold at $5.90. The company declined to forecast this quarter's results, or next year's, citing the uncertain effects of the attacks on Sept. 11.
Corning lost $220 million, or 24 cents a share, in contrast with net income of $254 million, or 28 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales fell 21 percent, to $1.51 billion from $1.92 billion. Excluding costs related to job cuts and acquisitions, the company said it would have reported a profit of $85 million, or 9 cents a share. On that basis, which is not in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, Corning had been expected by First Call's analysts to earn 3 cents a share.
The company is eliminating as many as 12,000 jobs, or 28 percent of the work force at the beginning of the year, and is closing plants in response to the falling sales.
Before Corning announced its results, its shares closed at $8.02, down 14 cents. In after-hours trading, they settled at $8.30.
Corning said it expected fourth-quarter sales around $1 billion and a loss, excluding certain costs, in the range of 20 to 25 cents a share. Analysts had expected a loss of 6 cents a share, excluding certain costs.

HEADLINE: New York City Jobless Rate Jumps to 6.3% 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
The effects of the World Trade Center disaster are only beginning to show up in economic statistics, but already the unemployment rate in New York City has surged, the New York State Department of Labor announced yesterday.
 In September, the jobless rate leapt to 6.3 percent from 5.8 percent in August, and 5.0 percent in July, all adjusted for seasonal factors. "It's a large jump, not typical at all," said James P. Brown, an analyst for the labor department, adding that the unemployment rate is the highest it has been since October 1999. 
 The surge of unemployment in the city is far worse than the state's increase of 0.2 points, to 4.9 percent. The nation's unemployment rate in September, also 4.9 percent, was unchanged. 
The increase in the unemployment rate, based on statistics collected at a regularly scheduled monthly point, which occurred the week of the attack, reflects the sudden slowdown in the city's economy even before Sept. 11. 
The rate is based on a monthly survey of households, and everyone who worked at all that week is considered employed -- even if those jobs disappeared with the twin towers. 
The rate is almost certain to rise; since Sept. 11, 21,930 people have requested jobless benefits as a direct result of the trade center disaster, the labor department said.
Between the terrorist attack and the already crumbling economy, "it's clear we face a long road back to economic renewal," said Stephen Kagann, chief economist to Gov. George E. Pataki.
A monthly survey of employers' payrolls also took place the week of Sept. 10 through Sept. 14, and so is probably not an accurate picture of the post-disaster economy. Many employers prepared their data before the attack, and even those who had previously announced layoffs may continue to count laid off workers in their payroll until their unemployment benefits expire, according to the office of Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller.
Companies reduced their employment by only 300 positions in September, said the comptroller's office, which adjusts state data for seasonal factors. But the job losses in August were revised upward, to 10,400, from a preliminary figure of 8,200.
The biggest losses in September were in business services, which shed 4,000 jobs, for a cumulative loss of 25,000 positions since April. This sector of the economy includes computer services, advertising, and temporary agencies. Some of those losses were offset by gains in areas like construction and utilities, the comptroller's office said.
The picture on Wall Street was mixed. Securities firms, which had cut 7,200 jobs from May to August, actually added more than 2,000 positions in September, after the comptroller's adjustments. But on an unadjusted basis, which economists prefer for looking at extended time periods, employment in the securities business is now as low as it has been since May 2000.
For New York State, employment fell by 18,200, or 0.3 percent. The northern part of the state has been hard hit by problems at paper plants, while Rochester has been battered by the continued financial decline of major employers like Kodak and Xerox.
