HEADLINE: Father and Son Plead Guilty to Paying Bribes to Bridgeport Mayor's Associates 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 19 

 BODY:
Two contractors, a father and son, admitted today in federal court that they gave bribes to close associates of Bridgeport's mayor, Joseph P. Ganim, to secure contracts that included work on a multimillion-dollar office park.
 The contractors, Alfred Lenoci Sr. and Alfred Lenoci Jr., pleaded guilty to mail fraud and bribery charges in Federal District Court here, bringing to 10 the number of people who have admitted wrongdoing in the three years since the federal government began its investigation into corruption in Bridgeport, Connecticut's largest city. 
 The guilty have included several friends of Mr. Ganim, including his fund-raiser, his former chief of staff and a state economic development employee. In each case, the defendants have said they and an "elected official" benefited from some form of kickbacks, like cash, goods, contracts or services. 
Federal officials have declined to name the elected official. But in one instance, public documents have linked Mr. Ganim to a contractor who pleaded guilty to a fraud charge. In addition, court documents in previous pleas have referred to the address of Mr. Ganim's home.
Mr. Ganim, who will turn 42 on Sunday, "absolutely denies any wrongdoing," said his lawyer, Richard T. Meehan Jr., though he acknowledged that Mr. Ganim appears to be the ultimate target of the federal investigation.
Today, the younger Mr. Lenoci said he paid $500,000 in "consulting fees" to Paul J. Pinto, a Democratic Party fund-raiser and former friend of Mr. Ganim, knowing that some of the money would be forwarded to an "elected official." The money was paid to secure contracts for environmental remediation and demolition at "Bridgeport-related sites," said Ronald S. Apter, one of the assistant United States attorneys prosecuting the 10 cases.
The Lenoci family owns two companies in Bridgeport. The elder Mr. Lenoci is president of United Properties, a development firm, and his son is president of United Environmental, an environmental remediation firm. Neither returned calls left for them today at their offices.
Mr. Ganim's lawyer, Mr. Meehan, said the mayor was saddened "to see this happen to the Lenocis," whom Mr. Meehan described as "very good developers."
"I just think it's another example of the greed and avarice of Paul Pinto and his insidious ability to corrupt and betray the people who have befriended and trusted him," Mr. Meehan said.
In their guilty pleas, the Lenocis admitted they agreed in January 2000 to raise about $500,000 for the unnamed official's coming campaign in their effort to be selected as developer of Steel Point, a harbor development project on the site of the former Carpenter Steel Company, Mr. Apter said. Mr. Ganim, who is serving his fifth term as mayor, was considered a leading Democratic contender for governor before the scandal broke this year.
The younger Mr. Lenoci also admitted paying about $10,000 to subcontractors for work on the residence of an unnamed elected official.
In addition, he and his father said they had provided $35,000 worth of landscaping and other services to Mark R. Trinkley, an official of the State Department of Economic and Community Development, in return for preferential treatment on their application for a $6.5 million state grant. The grant was to finance the construction of a light industrial park on the site of a former housing project known as Father Panic Village, Mr. Apter said. Mr. Trinkley pleaded guilty Sept. 6 to mail fraud and filing a false income tax return.
Both Lenocis admitted today that they had an agreement with Mr. Pinto to pay him $1 for each square foot of office space their companies built in Bridgeport, knowing that Mr. Pinto would forward a portion of that money to the unidentified official. In June, Mr. Pinto pleaded guilty to charges of racketeering, mail fraud and tax fraud.
The Lenocis, who were released on a $100,000 bond, will be sentenced on Jan. 7. Prosecutors said the son could face a minimum of three or four years in prison, and $420,000 in fines and restitution. There was no agreement on the father's sentence. 

CORRECTION-DATE: October 23, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about the guilty pleas of two contractors, Alfred Lenoci Sr. and Alfred Lenoci Jr., to charges of having bribed associates of the mayor of Bridgeport, Conn., misspelled the name of a former housing project where the two men had planned to build a light-industry park. It was Father Panik Village, not Panic.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FUNERAL BUSINESS; 
Disaster's Toll Doesn't Necessarily Mean Profit for Those Who Bury Dead

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN

 BODY:
The funeral industry, one of the few businesses expected to profit in the World Trade Center attack, has seen no significant spike in revenues and, according to some industry analysts, may actually be losing money in the aftermath of Sept. 11.
 People in the funeral business say that even with the staggering number of casualties, funeral homes may stand to lose out, with some discreetly discounting their services or hiring extra help to handle unusually high attendance at memorials. 
 "I would say that's a very, very strong possibility," said Ron Hast, the publisher of Mortuary Management magazine. "These people have looked at this as a way of trying to serve their community." 
Experts like John Carmon, the president of the National Funeral Directors Association, cite many reasons for the disaster's negligible economic effects on the "death care industry," as people in the business call it. The victims were geographically dispersed, he said, and the slow pace of the medical examiner's office, which has thousands of body parts to identify, means that funerals will be spread out over time. In the meantime, funeral homes are not preparing human remains or selling profitable items like coffins.
Instead, funeral directors, who insist they are not watching the bottom line, have taken on the role of organizer or counselor. Many families have bypassed funeral homes, planning services themselves.
"There are times like this when a funeral home probably loses money," said Jim Nolan Jr., a co-owner of Nolan Taylor-Howe Funeral Home in Northport, N.Y. But those cases could be looked at as an opportunity for people who normally must juggle money and death to demonstrate compassion, he said. "The more people who attend funerals and see what we do here and get value from it, the better it is for the industry."
It is difficult to come up with the total cost of funerals and memorial services that have been held so far. But as of yesterday, the Red Cross had paid nearly $5.6 million to 1,029 families for funerals or memorial services and related expenses like limousines and flowers, said Mitch Hibbs, a spokesman for the agency. That is an average of $5,400 per funeral, far less than the agency's initial estimate that each funeral in the metropolitan region would cost about $10,000. In some cases, the low numbers reflect in-kind donations from funeral homes, and in other cases, the Red Cross paid only part of the costs, Mr. Hibbs said.
More funerals have been paid for by the New York State Crime Victims Board; as of Oct. 14, it had filled 2,612 claims, some of which included funeral costs. The amount allocated specifically for funerals has yet to be calculated, said Caroline Quartararo, a board spokeswoman.
The amounts of public and charitable dollars for funerals and memorial services are not enough to significantly affect the balance sheet in an industry where the amount of business at any single home can vary 10 or 15 percent each year, funeral directors say. Funeral homes in the New York City region and in New Jersey combined have an annual revenue of about $700 million a year, said Wilson H. Beebe, the executive director of the funeral directors associations representing both areas. 
In the World Trade Center disaster, there have also been difficult questions to ponder, and sometimes the answers are unavoidably tied to profit. For example, does a family with only some human remains need a full-size coffin for symbolic satisfaction? Many funeral directors say they will follow a family's lead.
"Undoubtedly a tragedy like this does bring out the best in the funeral industry," said Lisa Carlson, executive director of the Funeral Consumers Alliance, which educates people on how to protect themselves from price-gouging. The alliance has received no complaints of abuse or exorbitant charges in the weeks after the attacks, she said.
Mr. Beebe said that for auxiliary enterprises like limousine services, any increase in business has likely been diffuse enough to go virtually unnoticed. At the Batesville Casket Company, a national manufacturer, "it's basically, from a business standpoint, been business as usual," said Joe Weigel, a spokesman.
Even offers of free or discounted services have not drawn an overwhelming number of requests.
For years, Service Corporation International, which owns about 40 funeral homes in the metropolitan area, has offered a free basic funeral package to public servants who die in the course of duty. The package is worth $6,000 to $8,000 and includes a coffin, said Robert Budway, the director of operations for the company's funeral homes. He said that more than a dozen such funerals had been donated for trade center victims, but that the homes perform 15,000 funerals a year in the region. 
If families of police officers, firefighters or emergency medical technicians choose a more elaborate coffin or services not included in the package, Mr. Budway said, the city pays the difference.
Several cemeteries have offered discounts for victims as well. The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, which operates several cemeteries on Long Island, waived overtime and surcharges for work done on Saturdays. But again, with only about 400 bodies identified, few have made use of the offer.
Even funeral directors in suburbs that were disproportionately affected have not had that much to do. Gregory Pfleger, the owner of the Pfleger Funeral Home in Middletown, N.J., where 36 residents were lost, said that he had handled about a dozen memorial services for trade center victims, compared with 325 total funerals a year. He is charging enough to cover supplies, but not overhead, he said. 
"I don't even bring it up that this is what I'm doing. They don't want to talk about what it costs, they just want it done," he said. "Right now, it just seems like the right thing to do."
Yet if the workload has been relatively light, funeral directors said, the emotional toll has been great. "If you talk to a funeral director who has handled five or six or more funerals for the service people, they'll probably never be the same," said Mr. Carmon, of the National Funeral Directors Association.
Even for professionals trained to deal with bereavement, tragic deaths are hard to bear. In addition to handling memorial services, Mr. Pfleger has buried one trade center victim: his next-door neighbor.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gregory Pfleger, of Pfleger Funeral Home in Middletown, N.J., is charging lower rates to families of victims lost in the Sept. 11 attack. (Don Standing for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Albany, Getting Serious About Casinos 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA with JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 19 

 BODY:
The World Trade Center disaster has rekindled serious negotiations for Indian casinos in western New York and the Catskills, with Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature said to be close to a deal for five or six casinos as lawmakers desperately seek new revenues to stave off budget cuts.
 The outlines of a sweeping agreement that would include casinos, New York's participation in the multistate Powerball lottery and the installation of video lottery terminals at horse-racing tracks emerged this week from talks among the Senate, the Assembly and the governor's office. 
 Officials involved in the talks said that revenue from such activities had been tentatively earmarked for, among other things, aid to struggling cities like Buffalo and, perhaps, Yonkers, and for a wide range of social programs run by nonprofit groups that have barely clung to solvency through the state's six-month budget stalemate. 
Officials are trying to close the deal by Monday, when the Legislature will return here. But most of the people involved in the talks cautioned that so many details were unresolved that a pact by Monday was unlikely -- and that, in fact, the whole agreement could still founder.
"The talks have really intensified in the last few days, and they'll continue over the weekend," said a top legislative assistant who like most of those interviewed, insisted that his name not be used. "We know now where the parameters of the deal are, but there's still a few tough issues to get beyond."
Governor Pataki's communications director, Michael McKeon, said today, "We're working closely with the Legislature on an economic package that includes a variety of things and will allow New York to move forward."
The Pataki administration estimates that the trade center disaster will cost the state from $3 billion to $9 billion in lost revenue in the next 18 months, a tremendous blow to a state that was already feeling the effects of the recession before Sept. 11.
The governor has pledged to cut $3 billion in spending over that time, and has asked the federal government to bail the state out, but the response from Washington has been skeptical.
The gambling proposals, which could generate hundreds of millions of dollars a year for the state, have been under discussion for months, but lawmakers say they became more attractive after Sept. 11.
"In Albany, things seem to suddenly occur and move forward when the stars are in alignment," said Assemblyman Jacob E. Gunther III, a Catskills Democrat who has long advocated casinos in that region. "The catastrophe may have been a catalyst."
The deal under discussion envisions three casinos run by the Seneca tribe in western New York -- in Niagara Falls, Buffalo and a still-undetermined location -- and two or three -- including at least one run by the Mohawk tribe -- in Sullivan County, in the Catskills.
Even if the legislation is passed, casino development remains years in the future. The governor must first negotiate agreements, known as gaming compacts, with the tribes, and the compacts are subject to approval by the United States Department of the Interior.
Earlier this year, Mr. Pataki and the Senecas announced the outlines of a compact, but some hard bargaining remains, and there is no deal with the Mohawks.
The Department of the Interior approved a Mohawk casino at the Monticello Raceway last year, but that project fell through.
Since then, the tribe and its development partner, Park Place Entertainment, have reached a tentative agreement with Sullivan County to develop a casino at Kutsher's Country Club, owned by Park Place, and they have had extensive talks with state officials.
The legislation being hammered out does not specify locations for the Catskills casinos, but it is likely that one would be at Kutsher's.
A pact with the Legislature would give Mr. Pataki a prize he has long sought, the power to enter into gaming compacts without legislative approval.
Governors can act alone in hammering out compacts for casinos on reservations, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo did that twice. But all of the new casinos being considered are off tribal lands, and the New York courts have ruled that such projects require legislative approval.
Mr. Pataki, a Republican, has argued that having to take a compact to the Legislature would undercut his bargaining position with the tribes, and asked for a law giving prior approval to his compacts.
But the Democrats who control the Assembly and their allies in organized labor balked, demanding various protections for workers and unions. Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver also insisted that he would not approve casinos in western New York unless the Catskills also got them.
The Republican-controlled Senate expressed some reservations about including the Catskills, particularly in the absence of a firm proposal there, but was eager to approve a deal for western New York.
Complicating the mix, Donald Trump has spent lavishly on lobbyists and campaign contributions, gaining him considerable influence here, particularly in the Senate, and he opposes Catskills casinos that would compete with his casinos in Atlantic City.
Negotiators said they planned to put all the gambling elements -- the Seneca casinos, the Catskills casinos, Powerball and the video lottery terminals -- into a single bill, to improve the chances of passage. Otherwise, they fear, legislators would be able to pick and choose, and some pieces of the package might fail.
The bill being worked out would give the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union the provisions that it had sought, but that the Senecas at first resisted, including allowing workers to unionize simply by having a majority of them sign union cards, rather than requiring an election.
Elizabeth Kelly, a spokeswoman for the Seneca, confirmed that the governor's office had approached the tribal council earlier this week with a compromise on labor issues and that tribal leaders had agreed to it. She would not provide details.
The union already has a deal with Park Place and the Mohawks, who agreed to its conditions.
Mr. Pataki proposed in January that New York join the Powerball lottery, and lawmakers in both houses have said for months that that was likely to win approval.
The video lottery terminals at racetracks, however, were more controversial, meeting some opposition in both parties and in both houses. Some legislators with racetracks in their districts fear that the machines will create social ills, while others see the terminals as a needed financial boost for their local tracks.
Negotiators say they expect the bill to provide for the terminals at Yonkers Raceway and at Aqueduct, and probably at two other tracks upstate, though which ones is still being debated. They are also trying to craft a deal to share the proceeds among all tracks around the state.
Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders have said that the state should find a way to help not-for-profit groups that provide services like counseling for AIDS patients and legal services for the poor, hundreds of which were left out of the budget passed in August.
But it remains unclear how much money they will approve, and which programs will be saved.

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN; 
Pushing Hard for Familiarity, but Missing Some Salient Issues

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

 BODY:
 "The Courage to Lead" is a 30-second advertisement for Bret D. Schundler, the Republican nominee for governor of New Jersey, in his campaign against James E. McGreevey, the mayor of Woodbridge. The ad is appearing on network television in the Philadelphia and New York City markets and on cable television systems in New Jersey.

PRODUCER -- Alfano Communications Inc.

ON THE SCREEN -- The ad opens with Mr. Schundler seated in an office, an American flag nearby. The words, "Bret Schundler on Leadership" flash across a white background. Next, Mr. Schundler is shown walking with his wife, Lynn, and their infant son, along a sidewalk lined with row houses. The words: "Bret Schundler: Jersey City property taxes lower than 10 years ago" appear on screen. Next, Mr. Schundler is shown with a group of people in a school. Text on the screen says, "Bret Schundler: Violent crime down 37%." Then, there is aerial footage of bleak tract housing. The text on screen says," Jim McGreevey: Raised property taxes 59%." Finally, Mr. Schundler is shown amid a crowd of supporters on the night he won the Republican primary last spring.

THE SCRIPT -- Mr. Schundler: "I think the first we have to ask of a governor is to have the courage to lead. To be strong. To cut taxes to help our economy rebound and to keep our people safe."
Announcer: "In Jersey City, Bret Schundler said no to special interests and cut property taxes. He got guns off the streets and reduced violent crime 37 percent. Jim McGreevey raised taxes 59 percent and violent crime has soared."
Mr. Schundler: "We have to reform our programs. We have to do the right thing. We have to put people first. That's leadership."

ACCURACY -- Mr. Schundler cut property taxes several times in Jersey City but over all, they increased during his eight and a half years as mayor. The assertion that Mr. McGreevey raised taxes 59 percent is also misleading. The Schundler campaign gets this result by comparing the total tax levy in Woodbridge between 1991, the year before he took office, and 2001. But tax increases are more commonly measured using the municipal tax rate. By this measure, taxes rose about 30 percent, which is well within the rate of inflation. By the same measure, taxes rose in Jersey City by about 19 percent. The crime statistics, while accurate, are even more misleading. The annual number of violent crimes in Woodbridge has ranged from 309 to 450 during Mr. McGreevey's tenure; last year it was 347. The violent crime rate was 3.6 per 1,000 residents. In Jersey City, the number and rate of violent crimes have indeed fallen more precipitously, but it remains a much more dangerous place, with 9,694 violent crimes committed, or 12 for every 1,000 residents.

SCORECARD -- Mr. Schundler, who is making his first run for statewide office, continues to make an effort to introduce himself and his philosophies to the voters of New Jersey. The ad conveys confidence, which is reinforced by upbeat piano background music. Mr. Schundler makes a pointed effort to portray himself as an advocate of good government and of the people. But while the ad is an effective introduction, this spot alone is not likely to seal a deal with voters who may want to hear more from Mr. Schundler on such salient issues as education and auto insurance.
 DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

LENGTH: 1011 words

HEADLINE: Q&A; 
A Head-On Collision Of Alien Cultures?

BYLINE:  Samuel Huntington, a political scientist at Harvard University, has argued that global politics will be dominated by a "clash of civilizations," most likely pitting the West against the Muslim world and other cultures. Michael Steinberger talked with him.

 BODY:
 Is this the clash of civilizations that you have been warning about nearly a decade? 
 Clearly Osama bin Laden wants it to be a clash of civilizations between Islam and the West. The first priority for our government is to try to prevent it from becoming one. But there is a real danger that it could move in that direction. The administration has acted exactly the right way in attempting to rally support among Muslim governments and people. But there are great pressures here in the United States to attack other terrorist groups and states that support terrorist groups. And that, it seems to me, could broaden it into a clash of civilizations. 
Were you surprised the terrorists were all educated, middle-class individuals?
No. The people involved in fundamentalist movements, Islamic or otherwise, are often people with advanced educations. Most of them do not become terrorists, of course. But these are intelligent, ambitious young people who aspire to put their educations to use in a modern, developed economy, and they become frustrated by the lack of jobs, the lack of opportunity. They are cross-pressured as well by the forces of globalization and what they regard as Western imperialism and cultural domination. They are attracted to Western culture, obviously, but they are also repelled by it.
You have written that "Islam has bloody borders." What do you mean by this?
If you look around the borders of the Muslim world, you find that there are a whole series of local conflicts involving Muslims and non-Muslims: Bosnia, Kosovo, the Caucuses, Chechnya, Tajikistan, Kashmir, India, Indonesia, the Philippines, North Africa, the Palestinian-Israeli conflict. Muslims also fight Muslims, and much more than the people of other civilizations fight each other.
So are you suggesting that Islam promotes violence? 
I don't think Islam is any more violent than any other religions, and I suspect if you added it all up, more people have been slaughtered by Christians over the centuries than by Muslims. But the key factor is the demographic factor. Generally speaking, the people who go out and kill other people are males between the ages of roughly 16 and 30. During the 1960's, 70's and 80's there were high birthrates in the Muslim world, and this has given rise to a huge youth bulge. But the bulge will fade. Muslim birthrates are going down; in fact, they've dropped dramatically in some countries. Islam did spread by the sword originally, but I don't think there is anything inherently violent in Muslim theology. Islam, like any great religion, can be interpreted in a variety of ways. People like bin Laden can seize on things in the Koran as commands to go out and kill the infidels. But the pope did exactly the same thing when he launched the Crusades. 
Should the United States do more to promote democracy and human rights in the Middle East?
It would be desirable but also difficult. In the Islamic world there is a natural tendency to resist the influence of the West, which is understandable given the long history of conflict between Islam and Western civilization. Obviously, there are groups in most Muslim societies that are in favor of democracy and human rights, and I think we should support those groups. But we then get into this paradoxical situation: many of the groups arguing against repression in those societies are fundamentalists and anti-American. We saw this in Algeria. Promoting democracy and human rights are very important goals for the United States, but we also have other interests. President Carter was deeply committed to promoting human rights, and when I served on his National Security Council, we had countless discussions about how to do this. But to the best of my recollection, nobody ever mentioned the idea of trying to promote human rights in Saudi Arabia, and for a very obvious reason. 
Apart from our closest allies, no country has lined up more solidly behind the United States than Russia. Is this the moment Russia turns decisively to the West?
Russia is turning to the West in these circumstances for pragmatic and ad hoc reasons. The Russians feel they are seriously threatened by Muslim terrorists and see it as in their interest to line up with the West and to gain some credit with the United States in hopes that we will reduce our push for NATO expansion into the Baltic states and missile defense. It's a coincidence of interests, but I don't think we should blow it up into a big realignment. I think, though, that they are very worried about the rise of China, and this will turn them to the West.
India and China, two countries that you said would be at odds with the United States, have joined in this war on terrorism. Instead of the West versus the rest, could the clash shape up to be Islam versus the rest?
Conceivably. You have Muslims fighting Westerners, Orthodox Christians, Jews, Hindus, Buddhists. But one must also recognize that there are a billion Muslims in the world, stretching across the Eastern hemisphere from Western Africa to eastern Indonesia, and they interact with dozens of different people. So you might say they have more opportunity to clash with others.
The most frequent criticism leveled against you is that you portray entire civilizations as unified blocks. 
That is totally false. The major section on Islam in my book is called "Consciousness Without Cohesion," in which I talk about all the divisions in the Islamic world, about Muslim-on-Muslim fighting. Even in the current crisis, they are still divided. You have a billion people, with all these subcultures, the tribes. Islam is less unified than any other civilization. The problem with Islam is the problem Henry Kissinger expressed three decades ago with regard to Europe: "If I want to call Europe, what number do I call?" If you want to call the Islamic world, what number do you call? Islam may pose problems because it is less cohesive. If there was a dominant power in the Islamic world, you could deal with them. Now what you see is the different Islamic groups competing with each other.

HEADLINE: Rosie the Riveter In a New Generation; 
Military Industry Regains Self-Respect

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19 

 BODY:
In the heyday of the new economy, the Raytheon Company's military plant in the Southern California industrial town of Goleta was easy to ignore. Corporate mergers and cuts in military spending sliced the work force in half. There was little to keep employees loyal when Internet executives from nearby Santa Barbara came calling.
 "Some of our brethren have gone to the dot-coms," said John Bowen, a senior manager at Raytheon's Infrared Operations, which makes the technology for, among other things, night-vision goggles. 
 Indeed, said John Fennell, a manager of human resources, they could not compete with the fun-and-games work environment promised by the dot-coms. "It became not a sexy place to work," he said, "because we didn't have slides and beer on Fridays." 
Even though the Raytheon plant, which also makes decoys that lure enemy missiles away from American combat planes, is Santa Barbara County's sixth-largest employer, many people ignored its nondescript building and barely knew the company's name. 
But after Sept. 11, Raytheon workers in Goleta, about 100 miles up the coast from Los Angeles, are feeling a renewed sense of self-respect.
Executives are almost surprised by their newfound relevance. While Internet stocks have nose-dived and many Americans are worried about layoffs, Raytheon's Goleta office hopes to fill 150 positions in the next few years.
"It's an ability once more to show we are a stable, vital company," said Jack Saunders, acting general manager of Raytheon's Electronic Warfare Operations.
Something similar is being felt across Southern California, particularly in towns like Long Beach, where aircraft plants once dominated the landscape but have faded in importance in recent years. Many military contractors in the region scrambled over the last decade to transform themselves into anything else. Most notable was Hughes Electronics, which sold its military business to Raytheon in 1997 for $9.5 billion, and became a satellite and media company.
But companies that stuck with the Pentagon are seeing virtues in their old businesses and a revived sense of being needed. Some analysts are even predicting that military contractors here will prosper.
"I would call these companies both the hidden and reluctant beneficiaries of what's going on," said Howard A. Rubel, an aerospace analyst at Goldman, Sachs in New York. "It may not be in a lot of big stuff right away. It will be in parts and small stuff. But this elevates the prestige of the military back to where it should be."
Some of those who joined the exodus have even come back. Kris Brawn, a San Diego-based project manager for Northrop Grumman who works on software for the B-2 bomber, left his job two years ago for a finance-related dot-com, but returned in January after just 13 months.
"Coming back to a defense company gives me the opportunity to proactively make a difference," said Mr. Brawn, who also hated the long hours and time away from his family. And during times like these, he added, "at an Internet company you sit on the sidelines."
But it will never again be like it once was.
During and after World War II, Southern California suburbs blossomed to accommodate the hundreds of thousands of workers building and designing missiles, planes and other weapons. But when the cold war ended, many of those jobs withered away. Companies, in turn, became more streamlined.
In Los Angeles County, 113,000 people now work in aerospace and military jobs, a far cry from the 290,000 of 15 years ago, said Jack Kyser, chief economist at the Los Angeles Economic Development Corporation.
As a result, military contracting in this new era of terrorist warfare will rebuild only gradually as the military turns to companies that offer products that meet specific needs, particularly in information and technology.
Among those expected to prosper is Northrop Grumman, which makes the Global Hawk, an unmanned surveillance aircraft being built in Palmdale, Calif. The company acquired the technology when it bought Ryan Aeronautical, based in San Diego, in 1999.
The military has agreed to buy 60 Global Hawks in the next several years, and Northrop said it expected to hire 100 people to help with research and production.
But in all of Southern California, Long Beach has long been the psychological center of the once-thriving aerospace industry, in part because it benefited most from the World War II military buildup and the commercial jetliner business it spawned in the postwar era.
"If you didn't work on airplanes, you weren't anybody," said Jim Wieser, owner of the Thirsty Isle, a local bar where test pilots celebrated after successful flights, signing posters and drinking 34-ounce schooners of beer well past midnight.
From 1942 to 1945, Douglas Aircraft, which had substantial operations in Long Beach and merged with McDonnell Aircraft of St. Louis in 1967 to become McDonnell Douglas, built about 16 percent of all American planes, according to a company history. Wartime employment peaked at 160,000.
Among those workers was Bette Murphy, now 82, who started in 1942 -- one of the first women the company hired to work on the assembly line. She earned 60 cents an hour working on the B-17 bomber, which was used for daytime bombing raids. "They wanted me to go to the dispensary," she recalled. "I said, 'No, I want to build airplanes.' "
The hangar was camouflaged and soldiers with machine guns were stationed outside. "It was scary," she said. "We had gals from the farm, sales clerks, you name it. There was even a rumor going around we hired hookers from Pasadena."
She stayed at the company 37 years as neighborhoods sprouted around the manufacturing plants, which as recently as a decade ago still had 48,000 workers. But in a sign of changing times, the buildings where she first worked are scheduled to be torn down and the sites turned into high-technology or light-manufacturing operations. 
"Isn't that terrible?" she asked. "We are so proud. It really makes me sad."
Though much of that production is gone now, the Boeing Company, which bought McDonnell Douglas in 1997, is still the largest employer in Long Beach, with 13,000 workers. Near Highway 405, in a hangar large enough to hold 64 blimps and not far from Ms. Murphy's first factory job, Boeing workers now assemble the C-17 Globemaster III, a five-story-high cargo plane designed in the 1980's and heralded as the most versatile plane the Air Force flies today.
"I saw the first flight," said Steven Dunham, a 56-year-old engineer who joined Douglas Aircraft in 1966 and has stayed with the operation through all its twists and turns since. Mr. Dunham tested the stress on the wings of the first C-17, a plane once plagued by so many defects and cost overruns that the government threatened to scrap it.
In September 1991, Mr. Dunham, along with hundreds of workers, lined the runway listening to the control tower on hand-held radios as the plane readied for flight. "When it came zooming down the runway, it kind of gave me a chill," he said. And it still does. Every time a new plane leaves the hangar, Mr. Dunham heads out to the tarmac. And he is not the only one beaming with pride.
After recent news reports lauding the C-17, sales of shirts, hats and sweatshirts with the plane's logo and image soared at the Boeing shop. But engineers and workers are concerned about the future. Boeing recently announced that because of the attacks, it would lay off 30,000 people, many in commercial aircraft production. And some of those are likely to be in Long Beach.
Boeing said this week that it was considering shutting down operations for the 717, one of the company's least-profitable airplanes, which is built there. The Air Force, too, has yet to approve the production of 60 new C-17's.
"We are lobbying everyone," said Mr. Dunham, who is also president of the Southern California Professional Engineering Association. "Even with the reductions, we are going to fight. We are not going to go away."
That may be good news to Beverly O'Neill, the Long Beach mayor, who after watching the aerospace industry in town shrink to a shadow of its former self, has pursued other areas of growth -- helping tourism by expanding the convention center, shoring up the port for international trade and encouraging more retail stores and technology concerns.
"You can long for the past," she said, "but you have to have a sense of reality." 
Still, she has an even greater appreciation for those military workers who built communities like hers. "I hate to say it, but I hadn't been talking about the defense industry before Sept. 11," she said. "It has changed my thinking. This is something we have to protect because it is, in a way, about protecting ourselves."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Executives at the Raytheon Company's military plant in Goleta, Calif., including, from left, John Bowen, John Fennell and Jack Saunders, say they and their employees feel a new stability and vitality since the terrorist attacks on America. (Kim Kulish/SABA for The New York Times); A Boeing plant in Long Beach, Calif., proudly shows the name of its product. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE SALES CAMPAIGN; 
Jet Makers Use Patriotic Theme in Final Bid for Government Contract

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
"The men and women who defend our nation's freedom are the best in the world," a radio advertisement now being broadcast in Washington says.
 The spot is not just an attempt to lift morale, however. "And they deserve the best equipment," it continues. "That is what the Boeing Joint Strike Fighter is all about." 
 The Boeing advertisement is the final pitch in a long and costly advertising and lobbying campaign to persuade the Pentagon to pick its aircraft over a model by Lockheed Martin. The winning prototype will secure the most lucrative military contract in history, the Joint Strike Fighter program estimated to be worth more than $200 billion.
The Boeing spot's patriotic undertones blend with the new mood on television and in advertising, from the "Keep America Rolling" automobile ads by General Motors to the red, white and blue peacock on the NBC logo.
But the direct promotion of military hardware could be jarring at a time when the country is under terrorist attack and at war in Afghanistan. To some, it sounds as though Boeing is taking advantage of a newly martial spirit to secure a Pentagon contract.
Or so its rival suggests. James Fetig, a Lockheed spokesman, said that Lockheed resumed running print ads for its own Joint Strike Fighter model in The Washington Post and trade publications on Monday, and only after it saw that Boeing was pressing ahead with radio and print ads.
"We didn't want to run advertising for military equipment that could look like we are seeking to profit from the tragedy," Mr. Fetig said, noting that Lockheed had pulled all its ads after Sept. 11. So had Boeing. Asked if enough time had passed to resume advertising, Mr. Fetig replied dryly, "Our competitor seems to think so."
Thomas R. Young, Boeing's director of advertising for military aircraft and missile systems, said that Boeing had halted its advertising campaign as "inappropriate" following the attacks, but resumed radio commercials on Oct. 3, and print advertisements in The Washington Post and The Washington Times Oct. 4 and 5. The Pentagon is scheduled to announce the winner of the contract next Friday, though a report by the Congress's General Accounting Office critical of the plane's technology raised the possibility of a delay. 
Mr. Young said that the radio spots and print advertisements did not exploit the crisis because "decision-makers already know that the fighter would not be ready in time to be of service in Afghanistan."
These days all advertisers tread on delicate ground. Most Americans have accepted the notion that buying is patriotic, a way to aid an imperiled economy. But the act of selling -- whether a product or company image -- remains more ambiguous.
A Washington lawyer who represents military contractors said that he has advised his clients to avoid aggressive advertising or litigation that could suggest to the public that they were focused on anything other than serving the nation.
For more than six years, Boeing and Lockheed have vied to produce a fighter-bomber that could replace aging aircraft in three services -- Air Force F-16's and A-10's, Navy F-14's and F-18's and Marine Corps Harriers -- as well as be used by the British Royal Navy and Air Force. The project calls for 3,000 new planes over 20 years.
Officials who helped initiate the fighter program did not seem offended by the rivals' last-ditch effort to push their prototypes.
"This is the biggest program in history and they can't resist playing up their benefits," said Jacques S. Gansler, a professor at the University of Maryland who was under secretary of defense for acquisition, technology and logistics during the Clinton administration.
"I am just not sure any of these ads will have an impact," Mr. Gansler added.
The Boeing radio advertisements, which were scheduled to start on Sept. 12 and were held back after the attacks until Oct. 3, do not directly refer to the terrorist attacks or to the retaliatory bombing in Afghanistan.
Still, some listeners in the Washington area said they thought there was a link. One reason could be that these days, any mention of the American military seems connected to the conflict in Afghanistan and at home.
Boeing's television commercials, also broadcast in the Washington area, do not mention the fighter. Instead, they are a salute to brave young men and women in uniform, a campaign that was actually produced six years ago.
Boeing changed some words of the narration and began broadcasting it after Sept. 20 to show its corporate solidarity with the war effort. The ad is a gauzy montage of images of soldiers and sailors; a female vocalist sings "America the Beautiful."
Before Sept. 11, Boeing had also broadcast TV commercials for its Joint Strike Fighter, placed mostly during Sunday-morning talk shows.
Anne Toulouse, director of corporate brand advertising at Boeing, said that after the attack, those ads were replaced with the salute to the men and women in uniform.
"We did an assessment three of four weeks ago and concluded that we had to be careful about a hard sell," Ms. Toulouse said. "The tone had to be very careful so the message is not misperceived."
Lockheed has also revived television ads that feature a similar tribute, a "Salute to the Armed Forces" -- which also combines images of military personnel, somber words and stirring music -- that was originally produced to celebrate Armed Forces Day.
"Whatever you think of defense contractors, we are very patriotic people," Mr. Fetig said.
Mr. Young of Boeing concurred.
"Any company, ours or Lockheed, has a lot of former military people in it," he said. "They have a pretty good feel for what is appropriate."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: AN OVERVIEW: Oct. 19, 2001; 
The First Ground Strikes, Hints of Terrorism to Come

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN

 BODY:
The anthrax scare has so dominated Americans' consciousness that it was almost possible for a while to overlook the war in Afghanistan. But the harsh reality of combat returned in a rush with the start of American ground operations in and around Kandahar, a city in southern Afghanistan where the Taliban rulers and Osama bin Laden's terrorist network are strongest.
 More than 100 Army Rangers and other special forces swooped down by helicopter on at least one main military target. Two American military personnel were killed in a helicopter accident related to the mission as the helicopter returned to its base in Pakistan. It was not clear what their targets were -- a Taliban stronghold, a bin Laden camp or something else entirely. But military officials said the assault's size was intended to send a psychological and political signal. 

TOUGH NEW TASK -- But as air raids continued, this land operation signaled an important new phase. So did the disclosure that a small number of American special forces were already in southern Afghanistan, trying to organize an effective resistance to the Taliban. The main opposition is concentrated in the north, but from the United States' perspective, the south needs work.
And the task in that part of the country will not be easy, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld warned, saying that the anti-Taliban forces there are not yet strong enough either to bring down the government or to run down Mr. bin Laden's network, Al Qaeda. The Taliban are tough and they are "survivors," Mr. Rumsfeld said. "It would be unwise to think that the outcome is determined," he said. "It's not."
President Bush monitored the attack from Shanghai, where he was attending an economic conference, and said he had "near unanimous" support from Pacific Rim nations for both the military action in Afghanistan and his broader war against terrorism. On this presidential trip, China agreed to share intelligence on terrorist groups. But American officials said they were unsure how much that promise was really worth.

ANTICIPATING TERRORISM -- There was important intelligence from elsewhere, though, and the news was ominous. Officials in six countries in Europe and the Middle East said that based on intercepted communications among bin Laden associates and other tools, they are convinced that more terrorist attacks are coming. They had yet to connect the recent anthrax letters in the United States to Al Qaeda, these officials said, but even if they were Mr. bin Laden's work, new episodes of terrorism can be expected.
Two more cases of anthrax came to light -- a worker at The New York Post and a postal carrier near Trenton. The total number of infected Americans now stands at eight, including a Florida man who died.
Given that several thousand people have been tested with negative results, the small number of actual cases could be considered good news. Then again, through the entire 20th century in this country, there were only 18 known instances of inhalation anthrax, the most severe form of the disease. From that vantage, the current news is far from cheery.
There were also signs that anthrax spores may have spread to other countries, including Kenya, Argentina and Brazil. In Rio de Janeiro, the offices of The New York Times received a letter, postmarked New York City, that tested positive for anthrax traces.

ANSWERS AND QUESTIONS -- One potentially important conclusion was announced in Washington by Tom Ridge, director of homeland security. Letters sent to NBC News in New York, to the Florida offices of a supermarket tabloid and to the office of the Senate majority leader all seemed to share the same strains of the anthrax bacteria. In other words, all may have come from a single source, though that source is still unknown.
A few days ago, the majority leader, Tom Daschle, said he had been told by law enforcement officials that the anthrax mailed to his office was very potent and could infect many people. Now, federal officials are saying that the anthrax found in his office did not seem to be a very high-grade type restricted to military use. Was Mr. Daschle's early account wrong? It was not clear.
More certain, however, was the public unease. There were continuing runs on Cipro, the popular antibiotic for anthrax -- even as far away as Tijuana, Mexico. But there was no sign, federal scientists cautioned, that the anthrax seen thus far had the properties of an effective biological weapon. "It's a weapon of mass hysteria," one scientist said, "not mass destruction."
 CLYDE HABERMAN

HEADLINE: THINK TANK; 
Who the Afghans Are and What Motivates Them: A Reading List

 BODY:
Suddenly Afghanistan, a country that few Americans are familiar with, has been thrust centerstage. Arts & Ideas asked five experts for their pick of the best book on the country.
 Larry P. Goodson, an associate professor of international studies at Bentley College and the author of "Afghanistan's Endless War: State Failure, Regional Politics, and the Rise of the Taliban". 
 Ahmed Rashid's "Taliban: Militant Islam, Oil and Fundamentalism in Central Asia," although redundantly subtitled, is my favorite reference on the Taliban movement. Richly detailed, the book grows out of Rashid's more than two decades of reporting from the region. No book provides as much insight into the Taliban movement's rise and success, including chapters on its religious ideology, organizational structure, heroin economy, policies toward women and shadowy support for Osama bin Laden and the "Arab Afghans." 
His portraits of Afghan leaders whose names are now in the headlines are especially striking, with the recently assassinated Ahmed Shah Masud portrayed as a brilliant and vital "master of guerrilla warfare" adored by his men; the Uzbek warlord Rashid Dostum as a "hard-drinking bear of a man" who has criminals crushed under tank tracks, and the Taliban leader Mullah Mohammad Omar as shy, reclusive and decidedly uncharismatic. This is a must read for anyone wanting to understand America's new war.
David B. Edwards, professor of anthropology at Williams College and the author of "Before Taliban: Genealogies of the Afghan Jihad".
As we contemplate the entry of American troops into Afghanistan, it is worthwhile to recall three books that tell the story of the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan from the soldiers' point of view. Svetlana Alexievich's "Zinky Boys" (the term comes from the zinc coffins in which the bodies of Soviet soldiers were returned home) is a composite oral history of the war in the style of Studs Terkel. "Afghan Tales" by Oleg Yermakov is a collection of short stories dealing with the experiences of Soviet boys growing up at war, while "The Hidden War" by Artyom Borovik is a journalist's memoir that brings to mind the gritty irreverence of Michael Herr's "Dispatches" from the Vietnam War. And if the incompetent commanders, elusive enemy, unnecessary fatalities and frustrated libidos, seem all too familiar to American readers, the stories remind us that there have always been human as well as strategic costs for those who have chosen the course of intervention in Afghanistan.
Barnett R. Rubin, director of studies at the Center on International Cooperation at New York University and the author of "The Fragmentation of Afghanistan" and "The Search for Peace in Afghanistan". 
The French scholar Olivier Roy has written several books that address various aspects of the current crisis. "Afghanistan: From Holy War to Civil War" analyzes how Islamic mujahidin turned into ethnic warlords, paving the way for the rise of the Taliban. Anyone who wants to understand the danger of destroying the Taliban without a plan for political succession should read this book. "The Failure of Political Islam" generalizes this analysis to the whole Muslim world and also provides a unique account of the involvement of Arabs -- including Osama bin Laden -- in the Afghan war. Sayed Askar Mousavi's book "The Hazaras of Afghanistan: An Historical, Cultural, Economic and Political Study" provides a rare evaluation of Afghan society and history from the perspective of the Hazara ethnic group. This predominantly Shia group from the Central Highlands of Afghanistan has formed the country's underclass and been victimized repeatedly by Pashtun-dominated governments, including the Taliban. As Mr. Mousavi make clear, however, the Tajik elements of the so-called Northern Alliance also fought and even massacred Hazaras in Kabul. This book shows both how problematic Afghanistan is as a nation, and yet how committed to that nation's existence even its most oppressed ethnic group remains.
Margaret A. Mills, professor of Near Eastern languages and cultures at Ohio State University and author of "Rhetorics and Politics in Afghan Traditional Storytelling".
Peter Marsden's book "The Taliban: War, Religion and the New Order in Afghanistan succinctly reviews Afghanistan's history and complex ethic and linguistic map, then situates the rise of the Taliban in the context of Islamic reform and revival movements of the modern era and the emergent politics of the anti-Soviet and civil wars. 
Benedicte Grima's "Performance of Emotion Among Paxtun Women" is one of the very few extended studies of Pashtun women. The Pashtun (or Pathan, or Pakhtun, or Paxtun) ethnic group predominates among the Taliban and in Pakistan's Northwest Frontier province, where Ms. Grima conducted her research. Drawing on the words of Pashtun women who tell her their life histories, she argues that a powerful ethic of forbearance severely limits traditional Pashtun's women's ability to mitigate the suffering they acknowledge in their lives.
Ashraf Ghani, adjunct professor of anthropology at Johns Hopkins University. 
War, gender discrimination, drugs and religious extremism are the images that are now dominantly associated with Afghanistan. In "Three Women of Herat," Veronica Doubleday describes the lives of three ordinary women in the provincial city of Herat in the 1970's. She demonstrates the place of music in Afghan society and the aspirations of ordinary people for a decent life. "The Fragmentation of Afghanistan" by Barnett R. Rubin is a monumental study of events from 1978 to 1995. He brings comparative knowledge, detailed empirical analysis and a graceful style to communicate the complexities of Afghanistan.

HEADLINE: Ford Motor Cancels Program To Give PC's toIts Employees 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 19 

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company today canceled its program to give employees personal computers as the company tries to reduce expenses because of slowing sales and financial losses.
 Ford had distributed about 166,000 personal computers and printers to employees from February 2000 until the end of May, when the program was deferred until the fourth quarter. At the time, Ford said there had been questions about how the giveaway affected taxes for workers in different nations. 
 Ford's United States vehicle sales fell 11 percent this year through September, twice the industrywide decline. The company this week reported a third-quarter loss of $692 million, its second consecutive loss. Vehicle demand has fallen this year from a record in 2000 because of a slowing American economy.
 "The economic situation is substantially different than when we launched" the program, said a Ford spokesman, Peter Olsen. "This is one of the programs that came under review for cost-cutting."
 The computers were distributed mostly to employees in the United States and the Philippines, with limited distribution to workers in Britain and Venezuela, he said. Employees were also provided Internet access at a reduced charge of $5 a month. Employees who received computers will retain the cheap access, Mr. Olsen said.
 Ford provided the computers and access through PeoplePC Inc., which is based in San Francisco. 
 When Ford announced the plan, it said it needed employees to be skilled on the Internet. "Individuals and companies that want to be successful in the 21st century will need to be leaders in using the Internet and related technology," Ford's chairman, William Clay Ford Jr., said last year.
 Shares of the Dearborn-based company fell 26 cents, to $16.51. They have declined 30 percent this year. PeoplePC shares, which rose 3 cents, to 14 cents, have lost 81 percent of their value.

HEADLINE: Rome Journal; 
A Bush Admirer Longs to Join America's A-List

BYLINE:  By MELINDA HENNEBERGER

DATELINE: ROME, Oct. 19 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi has never made a state secret of his political crush on the American president, George W. Bush.
 Or of his disappointment when Mr. Bush did not think to put Italy on the list of countries, including Britain, France and Canada, that he thanked for their support on the day the bombing of Afghanistan began. (Mr. Berlusconi, who is famous for taking his politics personally, was said to have been beside himself.) While the leaders of A-list allies got calls from Mr. Bush, Mr. Berlusconi had to hear about the American-led military action from Vice President Dick Cheney. 
 This week, after some prodding from the Italian ambassador to Washington, Ferdinando Salleo, Mr. Berlusconi was at last received at the White House. 
"You can see, when you look at a man and a woman together, or at two men, if they're in touch," said Mr. Berlusconi's spokesman, Paolo Bonaiuti, who was along on the trip. Mr. Bush and Mr. Berlusconi, he reported, "have that look of being in touch."
After returning to Italy, Mr. Berlusconi promptly announced that a pro-American rally would be held here on Nov. 10 -- an idea widely criticized by the right as well as the left.
Mr. Berlusconi apparently feels otherwise, after a state visit to the United States that many in the Italian press found woundingly short on pomp.
He has strategic reasons to bond with Mr. Bush. "He feels left out with Social Democrats in charge" across most of Europe, one Western diplomat noted, "and this is one way to counterbalance that."
He is also under fire for his recent comment that Western civilization is superior to Islam. Today, protesters pelted Mr. Berlusconi's car with eggs as he arrived at a European Union summit meeting in Belgium, whose foreign minister recently said on television that he would give Mr. Berlusconi a zero, on a scale of 1 to 10, for his leadership since the Sept. 11 attacks.
With Europe so hostile to him, no wonder Mr. Berlusconi seeks solace in America. La Repubblica reported that, "George Bush finally made the time to meet the Italian premier, who would have liked to have been greeted with far more solemnity." Corriere della Sera ran a cartoon of Mr. Berlusconi reciting Walt Whitman's "O Captain! My Captain!" to Mr. Bush.
"It's a one-way relationship," said James Walston, a professor of political science at the American University of Rome. "It's embarrassing."
One reason for the low-key reception in Washington, of course, was precisely Mr. Berlusconi's recent comments about the West and Islam.
In some ways, Mr. Berlusconi's frustration is not that new. Italy is the world's sixth-largest economy and a sophisticated Western democracy, but because of its history of revolving-door governments, it has had difficulty being taken with the seriousness and respect it feels it deserves.
After Mr. Berlusconi, who is Italy's richest man, was not invited to a meeting of French, British and German leaders just before today's summit meeting, he showed how much he minded. At a news conference, he said he could not have fit the meeting into his schedule anyway, because he had a previous engagement with center-right leaders from Spain, Austria, and Luxembourg.
Of that group, he boasted that he was "the leader of the most important country."
Mr. Walston said that for both Mr. Berlusconi and Italy, "the preoccupation is, 'Why don't we count more?' " 
Mr. Bush did tell reporters at his joint appearance with Mr. Berlusconi earlier this week that: "I'm pleased to be able to give him a lunch. After all, I had one of the best lunches I've had since I've been the president because of the prime minister." A Berlusconi aide said he was fondly recalling the tricolored pasta in the red, white and green of the Italian flag, prepared by Mr. Berlusconi's personal chef during Mr. Bush's visit to Rome last summer.
Giulio Ferrara, editor of the newspaper Il Foglio, who first suggested the idea of a pro-American demonstration, said his friend Mr. Berlusconi "likes the plain speaking of Mr. Bush, including the gaffes from time to time. That's the bridge between them."
In an interview during his campaign last spring, Mr. Berlusconi was self-mocking about his admiration for all things American: "I am on whatever side America is on, even before I know what it is."
He had been widely criticized in Europe even before the remarks about Islam, particularly over his handling of antiglobalization protests in Genoa, where the police shot and killed one young demonstrator.
The Italian prime minister's pro-American agenda also leaves him at least theoretically vulnerable to criticism at home, where he is popular but America is not. "The main feeling here is anti-American," said his friend Paolo Guzzanti. "The left here thinks the only good Americans are Woody Allen and the Kennedys."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, visiting Washington this week, strolled with President Bush to speak with reporters in the Rose Garden. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Correspondent; 
Building on Prosperity

BYLINE:  By Bill Keller

DATELINE: SHANGHAI 

 BODY:
THE last time George W. Bush visited China, it was 1975 and he was just out of business school. His father was ambassador to Beijing. The son found the country unbearably drab and yearned to go back to Texas and seek his fortune. The few sentences he devoted to that youthful experience in his 1999 campaign biography have been mocked as evidence of his incurious nature and his knack for the obvious, but reading them here this week, I was struck by something else. His unsophisticated reaction to China as a young man -- apparently unchanged as he packaged his life story for the electorate two years ago -- coincided closely with what the Chinese say about themselves today. Mr. Bush took no notice of political or religious repression or the explosive question of Taiwan. He did not suggest that China might be tamed by American pressure.
 His bottom line was the bottom line: "My visit underscored my belief in the power and promise of the marketplace, and deepened my belief that by introducing capitalism and the marketplace, China will free her people to dream and risk." 
 Mr. Bush's return to China this week is, in a sense, a return to the rest of the world. Since Sept. 11 he has been focused, naturally, on mobilizing the world against fundamentalist terror, and he has kept terrorism the headline subject here at his meetings with Asian leaders. But the attack on America has also made the president and his public more attentive students of the globe, silenced the lone-superpower arrogance that marked his first months, enhanced his administration's stature abroad and created new opportunities.
A few months ago our China theology seemed to be in the hands of those Republican pessimists who regard China as the next great threat to American interests. Now, suddenly, American diplomacy seems to be moving more in the spirit of that 29-year-old Harvard M.B.A.
Shanghai is as powerful an endorsement as Mr. Bush could want for his belief in the curative effects of the marketplace. With its peacock skyscrapers, its neon-spangled shopping malls and its Nokia-packing middle class, it is a vibrant contrast to the colorless place Mr. Bush remembered. Compared to the third-world life of rural China, or even the ant-farm bustle of Beijing, Shanghai is a tidy theme-park China. If this city does not represent what China is, it represents what China desperately wants to be.
Young Chinese from the prospering class remind me a bit of George Bush circa 1975, minus the party-animal quality. They are self-absorbed and materialistic. They are devout believers in the global marketplace. They are reflexively nationalistic -- that's the word we use for the other guy's patriotism -- and insulted at the idea that another country would preach to them about internal affairs. They look upon political boat-rockers as trouble. They were children when the government crushed the democracy uprising in Tiananmen Square and, grotesque as this may seem, many think the government was right.
They regard the Communist Party as corrupt and ideologically bankrupt, but necessary for now. They imagine that what would replace it in the near term would be worse -- and certainly bad for business. They see eventual unification with the island of Taiwan as a birthright. They trust that economic development will, in time, lead to political freedoms, as it has already led to expanded personal freedoms, but they are in no hurry. As one accounting student at the Ivy-League Fudan University happily reported: "We don't talk about politics. We talk about the job market."
Although tens of thousands of their peers pursue U.S. degrees, their sense of America seems as superficial as the American sense of their world. "All we know is McDonald's and Hollywood," a young journalist said.
That distance helps explain the unofficial, and dishearteningly ambivalent, Chinese reaction to the attacks on America. A lot of people think that the United States had it coming, that the country that bombed the Chinese embassy in Belgrade and sent spy planes to play chicken along the Chinese coast deserved to be brought down a notch. At the notice board in one school here, a poster materialized on Sept. 12 with "U.S.A." crossed out and "Who's next? Japan!" written in. There is also low-grade anxiety that our campaign in Afghanistan is a grab for strategic advantage in a region that sits astride Caspian Sea oil and on China's western flank.
The first sentiment may be callous and the second paranoid, but neither should be dismissed. They mirror views held in powerful precincts of the Chinese military and Communist Party. And, like the far more virulent antipathy in the streets of the Islamic world, they represent popular feelings that even authoritarian rulers ignore at their peril. 
You don't have to look far for what could have inspired the bristling resentment of American power. The hostile bluster toward China in the first half of this year convinced even a lot of levelheaded Americans that Mr. Bush had decided to make China the new bogeyman. Our new defense strategy shifts the emphasis toward a potential enemy in Asia -- guess who? -- and puts a premium on an antimissile defense scheme that, on paper, would neuter China's nuclear deterrent. In the minds of Mr. Bush's most hawkish advisers, in fact, the really exciting prospect of missile defense is not that it would protect the United States from a rogue nuke but that it would give us a free hand to move in defense of Taiwan.
THE relationship had been growing more civil in the past few months. Americans were pleased when China returned not only the crew of the downed spy plane, but the plane itself in pieces large enough to be reassembled. The Chinese were charmed when Colin Powell visited in July. Presidents Bush and Jiang chat on the hot line. Then Sept. 11, by moving America's cross hairs to a new target, brought a startling change. China has rhetorically enlisted in the war on terror, helped stiffen the spine of its ally Pakistan and offered quiet intelligence help. Mr. Jiang has pointedly not raised in public his generals' uneasiness with the U.S. military campaign in Afghanistan. This is not exactly Tony Blair's dispatching of British commandos, but the Americans are grateful. They take these as real concessions from a Chinese leader who is trying to orchestrate a succession in the face of some strong nationalist resistance.
"Jiang's got his neck out here," said a senior member of the Bush entourage, adopting the newly sympathetic tone that makes China pessimists cringe. There is fresh hope that China will finally keep its overdue promise to stop the proliferation of missile technology in the region, and that in return the U.S. will let China back into the lucrative business of launching our satellites into space. 
This budding rapprochement will be tested by the president's determination to bull ahead on missile defense and by the course of economic reform here. Even the more sanguine China-watchers see a possibility of domestic turmoil as China opens its state-protected farms, factories and banks to the shock of foreign competition. On our side, while President Bush will no longer have Jesse Helms howling anti-Chinese invective from the Senate, there is still a deep reserve of skepticism in the Pentagon, a well-oiled Taiwan lobby and a vociferous Capitol Hill constituency for China-bashing.
American presidents usually take awhile to get a fix on China. Even the first President Bush, more credentialed in geopolitics than any president of this century, missed the significance of Tiananmen Square in the first year of his presidency and was tone-deaf to the outrage it stirred in America. 
The younger Bush sounds as if he wants to shape a relationship based on the same premise that prompted Mr. Jiang in July to invite capitalists into the Communist Party: that the best hope of bringing China fully into the club of civilized nations is to make prosperity the national religion. Some of Mr. Bush's more conservative followers will scoff that, like the President's new friendship with Vladimir Putin, this is an example of faith-based foreign policy. But betting on China's becoming a menace is a good way to make it one. If the new respect endures and grows, Mr. Bush will have salvaged a great good from a great tragedy.
Several readers have pointed out that George C. Marshall was not, as my Oct. 6 column put it, "the last four-star secretary of state." That phrase overlooked both Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. and General Marshall's fifth star.

HEADLINE: No Way to Boost the Economy 

 BODY:
The first item on the House agenda next week will be the Republican leadership's economic stimulus bill. Nobody doubts the need for an economic transfusion of some sort. But this bill is not the right way to achieve it. Even the Bush administration has expressed doubts. Paul O'Neill, the Treasury secretary, described the measure as partly "show business." And while the White House rebuked Mr. O'Neill for his apostasy, President Bush himself is said to have misgivings about adding a huge new layer of tax cuts to those already enacted. 
 Since the package is expected to be passed by the House, it will be up to the Senate to produce an alternative that is efficient, temporary, safe and equitable -- virtues in which the House bill is almost wholly deficient. The legislators can begin by ridding the bill of provisions that have little or no chance of reviving the economy any time soon. 
 For example, eliminating the corporate alternative minimum tax, at a cost of $25 billion in 2002, would not guarantee a single cent of new investment. It would simply give money to businesses that usually find a way to elude taxes through deductions and loopholes anyway. Indeed, misdirected corporate tax breaks could even hamper growth by reducing corporate taxes on the state level, forcing states that are required by law to balance their budgets to cut spending. Lower spending would hinder economic recovery.
The bill would create another short-term danger by lowering tax rates on capital gains held more than one year but less than five years. If investors took advantage of the lower tax rates and sold shares to raise cash, share prices would drop. Private wealth would fall, at least on paper, and consumers would spend less. Both Robert Rubin, the former Treasury secretary, and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, have warned of this possibility.
The package would also pose a threat to the economy's long-term fiscal health. Only two of the bill's 15 tax-related initiatives would expire after 2002. The Treasury would lose a stunning $60 billion in tax revenues -- almost 40 percent of the bill's cost -- in 2003 or later, when the economy should already have recovered. The resulting deficit would drive up long-term interest rates across the entire economy, stunting growth.
Apart from its economic flaws, the measure is flat-out unfair. Of the $54 billion in accelerated tax cuts, every penny would go to the top 30 percent of taxpayers. Half would go to the top 5 percent. Eighty percent of the benefits from the capital gains tax cuts would go to the top 2 percent of households. Only one tax cut, a supplemental rebate for people who paid less than $300 in income taxes this year, would directly help poor and working-class Americans. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that just $2.3 billion of the $100 billion the bill pledges for the stimulus in 2002 would be spent to lengthen cash and health benefits for unemployed workers. Sadly, these groups are the ones most likely to spend and stimulate the economy. They suffer the most during recessions, yet the Republican leadership wants to help them least.
The nation needs a stimulus package that will send money where it is needed most. That might include increasing unemployment benefits through federal subsidies. Existing federal investment programs in high-return areas like education and infrastructure could be accelerated. Any other tax breaks for corporations should be aimed only at new investments that were unplanned or unscheduled -- not just unused -- before Sept. 11. And to minimize the effect on the nation's finances, all these initiatives should expire after 2002.
