HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: PRESIDENTIAL TRIP; 
BUSH MEETS JIANG

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Oct. 19 

 BODY:
President Bush said here today that "support is near unanimous" among Pacific Rim nations for both the military strikes in Afghanistan and the broader war he has declared against terrorism. But to cement the antiterror coalition, he spent his first day in China playing down a series of contentious issues with his hosts and with the president of South Korea.
 At a joint news conference this morning with President Jiang Zemin of China, Mr. Bush made no mention of his missile defense plans, which China has opposed, and alluded only briefly to differences with Beijing over Taiwan, China's military buildup and its treatment of dissidents. 
 The Chinese, perhaps wary of how the first meeting with a new American president would play out, did not broadcast the news conference live, and when excerpts finally ran on local television tonight, they were edited to remove any hint of criticism of Chinese policy. 
The meetings with Mr. Jiang, a prelude to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum beginning on Saturday, included formal talks earlier today and lunch at a Communist Party guest house on the edge of Shanghai. Officials familiar with those closed sessions described the interaction between the two leaders as gracious but without much warmth. And it was unclear whether China's promise to share intelligence on terrorist groups would prove of much value.
"This wasn't like the first meeting with Putin," a senior official said tonight, referring to Mr. Bush's declaration that he had looked into the eyes of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and seen a man he could trust. "It was quite scripted."
Mr. Bush's declaration that Asian countries had overwhelmingly endorsed his strategy came as his aides were trying to toughen language in a statement on terrorism scheduled to be issued on Saturday by the Asia-Pacific forum, the loose group of 21 nations meeting here. It is not known for taking bold stances, except on trade.
The statement, as now drafted, condemns terrorism but makes no mention of the American airstrikes on Afghanistan, at the insistence of Muslim nations like Indonesia and Malaysia that have backed Mr. Bush's declared campaign on terrorism but not the military action against the ruling Taliban.
Today, Mr. Jiang ignored a reporter's question about whether China endorses the Afghanistan operation. Still, administration officials insist that the forum document gives them the support they need. 
Later in the afternoon, meeting South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, Mr. Bush publicly voiced support for the Nobel Peace laureate's "sunshine policy" of engagement with North Korea. Mr. Bush's refusal to do so at a first meeting six months ago at the White House opened a rift between the United States and South Korea. It also revealed the division in the administration between those who wanted a harder line on Communist North Korea and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who argued for a policy of engagement similar to the one pursued by President Clinton. 
After a administration review of Korea policy, Mr. Powell won the argument. Today Mr. Bush declared that "my administration wishes to begin a dialogue with the government of Kim Jong Il," the secretive North Korean leader, and noted that Mr. Kim had not responded.
But while other leaders here had a variety of agendas -- Mr. Putin answered questions about the Russian economy, and many others worried about strategies to restore global economic growth -- Mr. Bush would not be diverted from his focus on terrorism.
"I've come to Shanghai because China and other Asia Pacific nations are important partners in the global coalition against terror," he said.
His words seemed in response to those Republicans who worried he should not be out of Washington at a time of war and anthrax attacks.
This was his first trip abroad since the Sept. 11 terror attacks in New York and Washington, and today one of his senior advisers, Karen Hughes, acknowledged that a number of days ago the White House reconsidered the question of whether to come here at all.
She said "the president concluded that it was very important that he come to make the case" for joining the counterterrorism coalition. 
Mr. Bush got a good deal of what he wanted. President Kim of South Korea praised him warmly for "his calm composure and his very wise decisions in bringing together, first of all, the people of America so that they will be able to effectively fight this war against terrorism." Mr. Kim promised to give the counterterrorism effort South Korea's full support, with his aides adding that the biggest contribution the South could make is nudging the North into reforms that would get it off the State Department's list of nations that support terrorism.
Mr. Bush kept a light schedule here, retreating to his hotel by midafternoon to meet with his aides and make calls back to Washington. He talked several times by phone with his new director of homeland defense, Tom Ridge, and received intelligence updates amid reports, which he declined to confirm at the news conference, that American special forces were on the ground in Afghanistan.
He also raised the possibility that the anthrax scares in the United States were a case of domestic terrorism, though he said he simply did not have evidence about the source. 
"Anybody in America who will use this opportunity to threaten our citizens, will think it's funny as a hoax to put out some kind of threat, will be held accountable and will be prosecuted," he told reporters.
The president was particularly artful in sidestepping the most difficult issues between them. He and Mr. Jiang never discussed the collision last spring of an American surveillance plane and a Chinese fighter. But Mr. Jiang mentioned Taiwan twice, saying the United States must deal with the issue "in accordance with the three Sino-U.S. joint communiques," which bolster the one-China policy that both Republican and Democrats have upheld for nearly three decades.
Mr. Bush said little about Taiwan in public, though a senior administration official who sat in on the closed meetings said he had reaffirmed the one-China policy and then moved on to other subjects.
Mr. Bush also briefly told Mr. Jiang that the American missile defense plan was intended to protect against attacks from rogue states and terrorists, not "multiple launches" from a national arsenal. Mr. Jiang never responded, the official said.
That seemed a somewhat perfunctory review of what may well prove the most contentious issue between the two nations, with China saying it plans to modernize and expand its nuclear arsenal if it feels the missile defense plan undercuts its own minimum deterrent. Bush administration officials say China was already planning that modernization process years ago. 
Similarly, Mr. Bush raised, at least in public, almost none of the long list of human rights abuses in China that the State Department catalogs annually. He did, however, say the fight against terrorism "must never be an excuse to persecute minorities," apparently referring to the Chinese actions against Uighur separatists and others who have resisted government control. The administration has been concerned that Mr. Jiang would use the battle against terrorism to justify repression in China's western regions, including near its border with Afghanistan.

HEADLINE: The New Young Turks 

BYLINE:  By Fernanda Eberstadt; Fernanda Eberstadt's most recent novel is "When the Sons of Heaven Meet the Daughters of the Earth."

 BODY:
 CRESCENT AND STAR
Turkey Between Two Worlds.
By Stephen Kinzer.
252 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.
 Stephen Kinzer came to Turkey in 1996 as the New York Times bureau chief in Istanbul after an intensive stint in Central America. Pessimistic Turks will tell you that Latin America provides an ideal background for understanding Turkey -- a country plagued by coups, earthquakes, a boom-bust economy and a guerrilla war that has killed tens of thousands of conscripts and civilians and flooded the cities with dispossessed peasants. 
Yet colonialism cannot be blamed for Turkey's griefs, unlike Latin America's. Until the Ottoman defeat in World War I, Turks were masters of an empire that in its prime included much of the Middle East, the Crimea, North Africa, Eastern Europe and the Balkans. Turkish schoolchildren are taught that their ancestors were Mongol horsemen, but in fact most Turks you meet boast a Georgian, Macedonian or Kurdish grandparent, and genetic anthropologists are discovering that the contemporary Anatolian gene pool owes less to Turkic invaders than to the earlier populations they conquered. As a consequence of their multiethnic past and 600-year European presence, Turks have long been seized by a collective identity crisis known as the "East-West debate," a sense, as Kinzer explains in "Crescent and Star," his lively account of Turkey in the late 1990's, of remaining between two worlds.
The psychonational ambiguities are multifold. Although its present-day population is 99 percent Muslim, the country has enjoyed uneasy relations with its Arab and Iranian neighbors -- indeed, it is symptomatic of Turkey's anomalousness that its best friend in the region it once ruled has been Israel. Yet although educated Turks may consider themselves Western -- after all, the Europe-Asia line runs through downtown Istanbul -- few European leaders appear willing to return the compliment. The European Union, to whose progenitor Turkey first applied for associate membership in 1959, postponed the country's candidacy decade after decade, judging it unassimilably poor, authoritarian and, one suspects, Muslim. Where, then, is Turkey's rightful home? 
Kemal Ataturk, republican Turkey's founder, believed he had answered this question decisively. To Ataturk, Turkey's sole salvation lay in joining Western civilization, with its premium on reason, equality of the sexes and technological advance. Ataturk abolished the sultanate and the caliphate, outlawed the fez and the veil, imposed Swiss civil law in the place of Shariah, or Islamic law, and substituted the Latin alphabet for Ottoman Arabic script, thus cutting off Turks from the glories of their written past. As he once drily told an American reporter, "I am dictating democracy to my people."
Present-day Turkey is a fast-changing country with areas of immense sophistication and entrepreneurial drive, yet its admirers are sometimes thankful that Ataturk's efforts to convert the Ottoman pasha into a European technocrat were only partly successful. Most Turks appear to have retained a hierarchy of values in which pleasure, tranquillity, respect, openhandedness and family loyalty are at least as prominent as money or career. Kinzer is alive to the delights of so convivial a culture, taking us on an enthusiastic tour of narghile, or water pipe, salons and bar-restaurants overlooking the Bosporus called meyhanes, where Turks drink raki and eat melon and sing along to the mournful tunes of a gypsy band. We meet fighting-camel owners, Kurdish mountaineers, women medical students too pious to shake the author's hand. Best of all, Kinzer introduces us to one of the greatest of 20th-century poets, Nazim Hikmet (1902-1963), a Communist who spent most of his adult life in Turkish jails and died in Moscow, whose passionately patriotic verse was banned in his homeland for years. 
Kinzer revels in the generous contradictions of a country in which cybernet yuppies have evil-eye amulets dangling from the rearview mirrors of their BMW's, and Courvoisier-swilling prime ministers belong to mystical dervish sects. But he is continually frustrated by Turkey's inability to achieve its democratic potential. Turks have been "taught since time immemorial that authority is something distant and irresistible, and that the role of the individual in society is submission." The consequence is an abysmal gap between those who are elected and those who rule. 
Up front, Turkey is governed by squabbling opportunists, many of them the same mediocrities who have been plunging the country into disaster since the Cyprus invasion in 1974. Behind these tired front men, Kinzer explains, are the generals who run the National Security Council: a ruling elite convinced that without its intervention the republic would be dismantled by Kurdish secessionists, militant imams or Marxist-Leninist revolutionaries. When they decide the national politicians are making a mess, the generals step in and restore order.
It is the book's subtlest accomplishment to do justice to Turkey's military. "The average general is better educated, more worldly and in some ways more liberal than the average politician," Kinzer writes. "Unlike many civilian politicians, the generals do not take bribes or extort money from contractors. When they retire they do not live in mansions, and their children do not attend expensive schools or drive flashy cars. Instead they set an example of probity and expect everyone in uniform to follow it." But if Turkey's military elite has retained many of the Ataturkist virtues, it has also made Ataturk's failings permanent and defining features of the state -- his indifference to the economy, his tendency to regard citizens as subjects, opposition as treason and any assertions of religious or alternate ethnic identity as threats to Turkey's territorial integrity. 
Today, it is a crime frequently prosecuted to express ideas or even think thoughts that "run counter to . . . the historical and moral values of Turkishness, or the nationalism, principles, reforms and modernism of Ataturk." It is also a crime for a political party to suggest "that minorities exist in the Turkish Republic based on national, religious, confessional, racial or language differences." 
Despite international prodding, improving human rights does not appear to have a high priority for the Turkish state: torture by the police remains endemic; detainees disappear; government-paid assassins operate freely; editors, academics, religious leaders and members of Parliament are tried for what less thin-skinned countries might consider an opinion. Istanbul's last mayor, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, a young Islamic firebrand who probably will rule the country some day, though not known as an aesthete, served four months in prison for reciting a poem.
One of the destructive effects of the "devlet baba," or "daddy state," has been to keep both politicians and electorate immature. Thus Necmettin Erbakan, who became prime minister in 1996 (and was persuaded by the military to resign a year later in what has been described as Turkey's first "postmodern coup"), can propose forming an Islamic NATO and raising a campaign to capture Jerusalem. Or Osman Durmus, the far-right Nationalist Action party's minister of health, who contributed to the political debacle following the 1999 earthquake by suggesting that victims should refuse Greek blood and Armenian medicine.
To me, the most depressing story in "Crescent and Star" is of the disco-loving antiques dealer who, Kinzer discovers, intends to vote for the Welfare Party, an Islamic party that has since been abolished. But what if they really do create an Islamic state? Kinzer asks. Don't worry, the young man replies, if they try anything serious, the generals will throw them out. These are a bulimic's politics, where you can gorge yourself on dervish demagogues because you know the army is ready to stick its finger down your throat.
But if Turkey is its own worst enemy, luckily it has friends like Kinzer. Recent histories like Nicole and Hugh Pope's "Turkey Unveiled" offer a deeper and more sophisticated understanding of the country. But for painstakingly honest advice as to what needs fixing in order for Turkey yet to become "a light unto the nations," "Crescent and Star" cannot be beat.

HEADLINE: Cartoon Network 

BYLINE:  By David Kamp; David Kamp is a contributing editor at Vanity Fair and writes the Culture Clash column for GQ.

 BODY:
 DUGAN UNDER GROUND
By Tom De Haven.
286 pp. New York:
Metropolitan Books/
Henry Holt & Company. $25.
 THESE are the sunset years of the Greatest Generation of American cartoonists, those hardy men of World War II vintage whose strips and panels dominated the newspaper funny pages over the last half-century. Charles Schulz and Hank Ketcham, of "Peanuts" and "Dennis the Menace" fame, have recently left us; Mort Walker of "Beetle Bailey" and Bil Keane of "Family Circus" are pushing 80. At the same time, the funnies themselves face an uncertain future; newspapers suffer from declining readerships, and the readers of comics today are more often adults than kids, which doesn't augur well in an age of zingier youth attractions like MTV and PlayStation.
Accordingly, there's an elegiac cast to "Dugan Under Ground," the final installment in Tom De Haven's trilogy of novels about a fictional comic strip called "Derby Dugan and His Dog That Talks," a popular, long-running adventure serial starring a bald, itinerant orphan boy and his verbose canine companion, Fuzzy. Whereas the trilogy's first installment, "Funny Papers" (1985), chronicled Derby's origins in the rough-and-tumble world of the Hearst and Pulitzer papers in turn-of-the-century New York, and the second, "Derby Dugan's Depression Funnies" (1996), captured the strip at its 1930's zenith, the new book begins with Candy Biggs, the last in a line of cartoonists to draw Derby, receiving the news from King Features Syndicate that his venerable strip is getting the hook. The year is 1960, when gag-a-day maestros like Ketcham and Walker are hitting their stride and adventure strips have become passe. 
De Haven, like many a comics snob, has professed his greatest admiration for old-timey strips such as Chester Gould's "Dick Tracy" and Richard Outcault's "Yellow Kid," and "Dugan Under Ground" is peppered with bursts of indignation over what the comics have become. "Newspapers are murdering the funnies, shrinking them down and killing them off," says a character named Joel Clark, a former publisher of 1960's underground comics who in 2000 teaches a course entitled "American Comics: A Social and Aesthetic History" at the New School for Social Research. "And don't get me started on comic books! How many superheroes does one country need? No vision, ladies and gentlemen, no originality, style, no subversion! Just coffee mugs! And greeting cards! And Dilbert on a mouse pad!" 
The neat trick De Haven pulls is to bridge the Derby saga from the lamentably vanished golden age of the funnies (Derby "was in the damn newspaper being rousted by a cop the same day the headline read 'Teddy Storms San Juan Hill' ") to that other palmy period fetishized by comics snobs, the late-60's heyday of Robert Crumb's "Zap Comix" and the Rip Off Press's "Fabulous Furry Freak Brothers." Biggs, not long after his sacking, has a chance encounter with a boy named Roy Looby, a kid who was just getting into "Derby Dugan" when it was canceled. Looby becomes the unemployed Biggs's protege. And as the 60's progress and Looby grows up, he revivifies the defunct Derby as a perverse underground-comix character named the Imp Eugene, and becomes a counterculture hero in his adopted city of San Francisco. Voila! -- a whole new milieu to explore.
De Haven is an expert milieu man, getting every last detail right, whether navigating a cartoonists' banquet attended by the "silver-haired Westport strip men" whose unbearably mild material was all the rage in 60's broadsheets -- Bob Dunn (They'll Do It Every Time') was M.C." -- or explaining the extent of Roy Looby's newfound cult fame: "Bootlegged Imp Eugene bumper stickers keep turning up on mud flaps and microbuses, not to mention on Tommy Smothers's acoustic guitar." De Haven, without straight-out strip-mining Robert Crumb's life for a plot, has assigned Looby many of the traits familiar to anyone who's seen Terry Zwigoff's engrossing documentary "Crumb" (1994): the same casually worn misanthropy, the same torturous family dynamic, the same love of old 78-r.p.m. records, the same ready cult of acolytes who misread weirdo iconoclasm as kinship with the hippie movement.
But De Haven doesn't quite capitalize on his selected mise en scene's potential for fun; instead, he seems to have gotten swept up in his central character's misanthropy. The time-jump narrative, which flits back and forth between the present day and the 60's-into-70's period of Looby's greatest notoriety, is essentially an agglomeration of humiliations and grim destinies: Biggs not only loses his strip but is cuckolded by his wife, mutilated in a car accident and ultimately shunted aside by Looby; Looby's kid brother, Nick, dreams of working alongside Roy as he did in their younger days, when he inked Roy's pencil-drawn panels, but ends up a sad-sack sign painter, partnerless after a bad romance with the wife Roy abandoned (and that's another grim story); Roy himself winds up a homeless drifter and a comatose hospital patient. 
De Haven's penchant for grotesquerie, which served him well in the gouty, pustulant Old New York realms of his earlier novels, merely seems curdled and gratuitous here. Roy has been totally bald since the age of 9 ("Alopecia areata, said the pediatrician") and is prone to getting shirt-soaking nosebleeds when he draws; Nick Looby has "thick glasses, bad skin and the physique of a custard doughnut"; their mother's boyfriend has "god-awful eczema at his hairline"; Cora Guirl, Roy's girlfriend for a time, has a "scar that runs from the corner of her left eye raggedly down her cheek to her jawline"; poor old Biggs lost his left ear in that car accident, and suffered the further indignity of having the doctors sew it back on too high ("Makes me look like Mr. Potato Head!"). It's as if De Haven, in the process of leafing through all those old "Zap Comix" for research, with their surfeit of bug eyes, jivey gaits and swollen bosoms, fell prey to the precepts of juvenile freak-out humor. A little of this sort of thing goes a long way in a novel. There's a lot of it.
"Dugan Under Ground" is, alas, the weakest entry in the Derby Dugan series, but collectively, the Derby books, with their multiple viewpoints, carefully interwoven plot lines and potted social-history lessons, are a mighty accomplishment: John Dos Passos' "U.S.A." trilogy as rendered for comics geeks. The funnies have always been too lightly regarded as a great American entertainment form, and it's nice to see someone besides Art Spiegelman laboring to bolster their place. And though this novel is apparently De Haven's last word on Derby, I wouldn't begrudge him if he reversed himself and expanded the trilogy into a tetralogy: after all, isn't it painfully likely that the suits at DreamWorks, in a characteristic rush of boomer nostalgia, would secure the rights to Derby and hire Robert Zemeckis to make an overblown live-action feature starring Haley Joel Osment?

HEADLINE: Long Division 

BYLINE:  By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich's most recent book is "The Future of Success."

 BODY:
 THE RADICAL CENTER
The Future of American Politics.
By Ted Halstead and Michael Lind.
264 pp. New York:
Doubleday. $24.95.
 The attack on the United States has changed the tone and content of American politics, at least for the time being. It has also upended all sorts of received wisdom. An era of big government is beginning, featuring huge expenditures to pump up the economy and ensure the nation's defense and reams of regulations for "homeland security." It is inaugurated under a conservative Republican president who lost the popular election but became more popular than any president in modern history and a once-bitter and factious Congress glowing in bipartisan resolve. For its part, a public that was abysmally cynical about Washington, interested only in political sleaze and sex and eager to throw the bums out, is rallying behind incumbents of whatever stripe. 
This is not the perfect time for a book that seeks to explain why American politics is divisive and immobilized. Yet "The Radical Center," by Ted Halstead and Michael Lind, provides useful insights into a system that's still broken in fundamental ways and may revert to its old ways as soon as the shock wears off. According to the authors, the basic problem is that the two dominant parties have been captured by their extremes. "Instead of expanding their voter bases, both parties have allowed themselves to be taken hostage by narrow pressure groups on certain defining issues," Republicans by "social conservatives and economic libertarians" and Democrats by "a constellation of aggrieved minority groups and public employee unions." Neither camp is willing to think boldly about what's good for the country as a whole. Halstead and Lind propose a new "center" that's not halfway between right and left but outside the standard range of political debate. The result is a sort of triangulation for policy wonks. 
Few of their ideas are new, but they've pulled them together nicely under a few broad themes. Invoking a "new, citizen-based social contract," for example, Halstead, president of the New America Foundation in Washington, and Lind, a senior fellow there, want to chuck universal Social Security and Medicaid and end corporate tax breaks for employee health care and pensions. Instead, everyone would buy basic health insurance and stash away a minimum amount of savings for retirement, while those who couldn't afford these basics would be subsidized. In addition, newborns would be credited with a $6,000 nest egg from the government, which would automatically grow to about $20,000 by the child's 18th birthday -- to pay for higher education or otherwise invested. 
Calling for a new era of "digital democracy," the authors would replace state and local sales taxes with a national progressive tax on personal consumption, with the proceeds rebated to the states on a per capita basis. They favor school choice, but would equalize funding per pupil across the country. They would replace environmental regulations with tradable carbon-emission permits and require companies to pay the market value for use of the electromagnetic spectrum, trees in national forests, minerals on public lands and grazing rights. In pursuit of a new "liberty and community" they would bar affirmative action based on race and allow more skilled immigrants into the United States. 
The authors also advocate a new form of "instant runoff," intended to encourage third parties by enabling voters to rank three or more candidates. If no candidate got a majority, the second-choice votes for the top scorers would be instantly redistributed to them, then the third-choice votes, and so on, until one candidate emerged with more than 50 percent. Halstead and Lind see major-party candidates forging coalitions with third-party candidates to court voters who might be persuaded to pick the major-party candidate as their second choice. 
Their list is something of a hodgepodge, but hats off to Halstead and Lind for at least rising above policy blather and advocating some unconventional things. Notwithstanding that most of these ideas don't have a prayer of being enacted, there's value merely in stirring public debate. Yet their underlying premise that the parties have been captured by their extremes seems dubious. Even before the current detente, it wasn't so much that the parties were captured as that their Congressional wings reflected increasingly distinct demographics. The trend began in the late 1960's, when Richard Nixon launched his Southern strategy to win the region for the Republicans, and continued through the 80's and 90's as America split between a culturally conservative heartland and liberal coasts. Meanwhile, the presidential wings of both parties have been moving relentlessly toward the political middle. Indeed, a plausible case can be made that Americans have been turned off presidential campaigns -- the only times they pay much attention to national politics -- precisely because campaigns have grown so utterly predictable and unremittingly centrist. 
Later in the book the authors suggest that the core problem facing the country is widening inequality. "Mounting inequality of wealth and opportunity has turned the United States into the country with the greatest degree of economic polarization in the developed world. . . . Our nation's transition to an information-based, service-oriented economy has produced levels of wealth and income inequality not seen here since the 1920's." There's a plausible connection between widening inequality and voter disengagement (after all, most of the people who don't vote are poorer than the people who do), but Halstead and Lind don't make it. Nor, curiously, do they seem to be especially interested in energizing the nonvoters. Their agenda is explicitly aimed at independents, professionals, young middle-class whites and "the newly wealthy and influential elites of the technology sector." It's hard to figure why such a putative coalition would fight to overcome widening inequality or lobby for health care subsidies and retirement benefits that would go only to people who couldn't afford to buy or save for them on their own. 
No one knows whether the terrorist attack on America will usher in a new era of high-minded bipartisanship, but I have my doubts. Americans are united in defending the values we cherish, and one of those values is fierce political debate. Paradoxically, this is the very value most at risk in a time of war, when dissenting voices are marginalized or banned from the political arena altogether. Rather than reinforce the "radical center," our greater challenge in the months or even years ahead will be to make ample room for the discordant fringe.

HEADLINE: The Close Reader; 
At War With the World

BYLINE:  By Judith Shulevitz

 BODY:
Anyone who doubts that literary critics can play a part on the bloody stage of history should consider the example of Sayyid Qutb. Qutb, born in Egypt in 1906 and university educated, was a Western-style literary critic until he devoted himself to Islam after spending two years in the United States exposed to what he viewed as our decadence. He died in 1966, when he was hanged along with other Muslim radicals by the government of Gamal Abdel Nasser. Qutb's books of hard-line political theology have had a direct influence on the Saudi Arabian Muslim opposition; the Islamic Salvation Front in Algeria; the Palestinian group Hamas; the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt, Jordan, Iraq and Lebanon; Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the Egyptian cleric jailed for several thwarted terrorist plots and linked to the 1993 World Trade Center bombing; and the Iranian writer Ali Shariati, who helped foster the Islamic revolution in Iran. 
 Qutb's key concept is jahiliyya. In traditional Islamic thought, that word refers to the dark period in Arab history before Muhammad received the Koran, but Qutb redefined it as a spiritual malaise, the condition of having strayed from the path of true Islam. Jahiliyya is any political system that places man above God -- representative democracy as well as Communism -- and all culture inconsistent with Islamic law, including any form of Islamic observance that makes concessions to modernity. Jahiliyya, in this sense, characterizes life as it is lived around the globe today, and opposing it grants Islamic militants their warrant to commit acts of terror anywhere against just about anyone, capitalist or socialist, Arab or Western, Jewish or Christian or insufficiently Muslim. 
 If we have learned anything from the 20th century and its murderous utopianisms -- Stalinism, Nazism, Maoism, Khmer Rougism, a list to which we must now add Islamic extremism -- it is that there are ideas that demand an uncompromising rebuttal. A new book called "The Reckless Mind: Intellectuals in Politics" makes it clear, however, that Western thinkers have often had a hard time rising to the occasion. The author, Mark Lilla, rehearses the sorry histories of the great philosophers who openly collaborated with evil, the most notorious being Martin Heidegger, an enthusiastic Nazi at least in the early years of the Third Reich. But Lilla comes down almost as hard on those who equivocated instead of holding firm, or whose philosophies he believes amounted to moral obfuscation. This list rather surprisingly includes Walter Benjamin, the German Jewish cultural critic who was still flirting with Marxism when he killed himself in 1940 while fleeing the Nazis. Lilla also criticizes the French philosophers Michel Foucault, whose celebration of life on the edge included paeans to violence, and Jacques Derrida, against whom he levels the rather tired accusation of deconstructing morality out of existence.
American intellectuals aren't compiling a very good record either -- or not when it comes to responding to the events of last month. Many on the left have retreated into a knee-jerk anti-Americanism. Many on the right have wasted their time heaping abuse on those who failed to exhibit the correct degree of patriotism or seriousness. Religious leaders haven't been much more impressive, and have mostly evaded the problem that faces religious intellectuals of all faiths, not just Muslims, in an era of fundamentalism: how to accept responsibility for violence committed in the name of religion.
Lilla offers no guidelines for proper intellectual behavior. In his epilogue, he gives us Plato's dictum: self-mastery, or recognition and control of the lust for intellectual supremacy. But he never explains how thinkers are to achieve such mastery, or even know when they have achieved it; nor does he say how it would help in the fight against evil. 
Edward W. Said, in his 1994 book "Representations of the Intellectual," is much more certain about what intellectuals are supposed to do. Their job is to speak truth to power, Said says, and he couples this familiar nostrum with a fierce aversion to power itself: "The intellectual always has a choice either to side with the weaker, the less well represented, the forgotten or ignored, or to side with the more powerful." But this is a recipe for becoming history's fool. Said's doctrinaire oppositionalist never has to rethink his position or perform a fresh moral calculation. He always already knows which side he's on, because the side with power is wrong. Following Said's rule to the letter, an intellectual would have had to side with, say, the Confederacy during the Civil War.
It's tempting to despair of intellectuals right now, but in fact we need them, as we always have, to help us move beyond immediate experience to wider insight. But how should they proceed? The reason no one can come up with rules that stick is that rules don't work: they have a way of suppressing rather than encouraging thought. On the other hand, some rough indications have emerged in the past several weeks that will have to do for the moment. First, we should agree that strict and seemingly objective causal analyses -- economic, diplomatic, postcolonialist, globalist or anti-globalist -- are useful as tools but insufficient in a crisis, because they lack an ethical dimension. Only a well-developed moral sensibility will allow us to determine and say forcefully what is good and worth defending, and what is bad and should be stamped out. 
We also have to admit that we don't yet know what we're dealing with. Hannah Arendt said of totalitarianism that it was horrible in its originality: "Its very actions constitute a break with all our traditions; they have clearly exploded our categories of political thought and our standards for moral judgment." Whatever it is that the followers of Qutb want to foist upon the world, it has already shattered received ideas in the same way. We haven't even come up with the words to characterize it. ("Fascist" and "totalitarian" won't do, since the regimes those terms describe were secular, technologically advanced and involved a total concentration of power, while Islamic ones are theocratic, distrustful of technology and more decentralized.) When the paradigms of the past don't work for the present, all we have to go on is imagination and intellectual honesty. Given that our side values these qualities and the other does not, we'll have to hope that they'll be enough.

HEADLINE: Fear Itself 

 BODY:
Japan in the 1990's is a dismal example, but postwar Germany is a hopeful and instructive one. The German government had nothing to offer but encouragement and leadership. 
A grand partnership and bargain among business, labor and government made reconstruction and prosperity the common goal. Quarterly earnings were de-emphasized, and fairness was a necessary component.
Krugman is right about everything, but we should look to more than central-bank monetary actions and government spending to banish fear and restore prosperity. Our recent prosperity has been fueled by business investment, functionally full employment and consumer confidence. Our downward spiral now is made of large, high-profile layoffs, refusal of business to invest and consumer worry about jobs and income. 
 We need business and government leaders to spread the gospel that layoffs should be forsworn. Corporations should address the country's needs for energy-saving technology and equipment, health care, education and security. Congress ought to subsidize and bail out corporations as it is doing with the airlines, but this should be conditioned on their maintaining and making use of their work force.

Robert M. Hausman
Washington

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
Some Are Traveling Again, to Some Places

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
WHEN the nation's airlines resumed flying a few days after terrorists hijacked four planes on Sept. 11, Linda Myers in Ithaca, N.Y., resolved to go ahead with plans to attend a family bar mitzvah in Kansas City, Mo., over the Oct. 5 weekend. So did her 93-year-old aunt, Anne Lewis, who flew from Boston.
 But that was before the United States and Britain launched retaliatory strikes on Afghanistan on Oct. 7, after which the resolve of many potential airline passengers lessened. Still, Ms. Myers, a writer for the Cornell University news service, said if she had it to do over again, she would still make the trip. "I'd go rather than be cowed into staying home by terrorists," she added. 
 But not everyone is as unconcerned. While passenger loads had been rising slowly since Sept. 11, the allied strikes have added another layer of uncertainty.
"We were doing all right with our bookings right up until the bombing raids," said Marcy Vance, manager of 1 Step Travel in Barboursville, W.Va. "But now with all this talk about more domestic attacks, it's slowed down a lot." 
While many other travel agencies have been hit by cancellations, a surprising number of Americans had booked flights for later this year. Dixie H. Stewart, president of Ship and Shore Travel Agency in Macon, Ga., had booked flights to Europe for clients for next spring.
But that was before the American air strikes. Since then, Ms. Stewart booked a couple to Venice in January, but a family of eight recently canceled its bookings to Disney World in Orlando. 
Conversations with travel industry executives as well as surveys by the AAA Auto Club South and many of the 1,100 Carlson Wagonlit Travel agencies have found that with each successive week after Sept. 11, a small but increasing number of Americans have been boarding airplanes, trains and buses. The Auto Club South survey, among its 3.4 million members, found that travel sales had increased by 30 percent in the two weeks since Sept. 18. But the allied strikes are too recent to be reflected in industrywide passenger counts, although it is widely expected that the numbers are still well below normal. 
The decision to continue flying, according to several travel officials, has been inspired by many things, ranging from a defiance of terrorism to needing a break from "cable fatigue" after camping out for days in front of the television set. 
Some travel agents have coupled their comments with reminders that the lagging economy has also contributed to near-empty airplanes.
While 51 percent of those who responded to the Carlson Wagonlit survey early this month said that it has never been safer to fly, 21 percent of those who found it unsafe cited lax security as the reason. Recent examples of security lapses at 7 of the nation's 20 highest-risk airports -- which Kenneth M. Mead, the Transportation Department's inspector general, disclosed to a Congressional aviation subcommittee on Oct. 11 -- have since done little to make the flying experience inviting. 
Although travel officials say that airplane passengers for almost anywhere have not been this sparse since the Persian Gulf war a decade ago, some agencies in the West and Midwest said that a number of their customers are traveling to Hawaii, even though the island's tourism is in a deep slump. According to Patty J. McGregor, the co-owner of Travel Creations in Hamilton, Mont., Hawaii's popularity has to do with the fact that it is part of the United States, and tourists feel safer going there. Special offers of low fares have also helped. After the strikes against Afghanistan, two clients of the World Travel Center in Larkspur, Calif., switched their bookings from the South Pacific to Kona, Hawaii, said Rita Puccinelli, the agency's owner.
Throughout the United States, the patriotic fervor suggested by the American flags displayed everywhere appears to have inspired increased attendance at some historic sites. For example, visits to Adams National Historical Park in Quincy, Mass., a park that includes the house occupied by four generations of the Adams family that produced two American presidents, soared 61 percent last month over the same month last year. Much of the increase undoubtedly reflects patriotic pride. But some is also attributable to the success of David McCullough's current best-selling biography of John Adams, said Caroline Keinath, the park's deputy superintendent, who recounted a recent conversation with a woman who explained her reasons for visiting the site: "I wanted to be reminded of the principles our forefathers fought for."
Colonial Williamsburg, the restored former capital of colonial Virginia, experienced numerous cancellations after the terrorist attacks, but it has since recorded what Tim Andrews, the city's public relations director, described as a significant rebound each week thereafter. 
Perhaps because many people have to fly to get on a tour bus, tour buses have been noticeably absent at many destinations. The decline has been palpable at Yellowstone National Park, where the number of tour buses last month was down 50 percent from the same month a year ago, said Cheryl Matthews, a park spokeswoman. 
Despite the airlines' woes, Ms. Vance of 1 Step Travel said that it's already hard to get airline reservations for Thanksgiving, adding that bookings through December are also filling up. If most of those bookings translate into flights rather than cancellations, Jerry Cheske, a spokesman for the AAA, agreed that Thanksgiving travel could provide some sense of what to expect at least in the near term for the nation's ailing travel industry.

HEADLINE: Correspondent's Report; 
Slow Crawl at the Border

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA; ANTHONY DePALMA is a reporter for The Times who has been chief of its bureaus in Mexico and Canada.

 BODY:
IT all used to be so simple. Americans who drove into Canada or Mexico on vacation didn't need passports. Customs inspectors rarely left their booths. In rural areas along the northern border, a traveler's biggest worry was getting through before 10 p.m., when officials left an orange traffic cone or two in the road and went home for the night. 
 Crossing the borders of America was so quick and hassle-free, so comfortable and routine, that some Americans didn't feel that they were traveling to a foreign country at all. 
 Not anymore. 
In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on the United States, North America's borders have been battened down and toughened up as officials try to keep out terrorists and prevent future attacks. Passports still are not required, but a comprehensive combination of heightened surveillance, intensified scrutiny, and a general wariness on the part of border officials in all three countries means that traveling to America's nearest neighbors now definitely seems like entering another country, perhaps even another world. 
Since an hour after the attacks on Sept. 11, all 301 ports of entry along the northern and southern borders have been on highest alert, and are expected to remain at that level for some time. Short of shutting down the border completely (despite reports to the contrary, no crossing ever was closed as a direct result of the attacks), this Code Red alert is the highest level of security, a steel trap that is supposed to ensnare people and material law enforcement wants kept out. 
The antiterrorism operations under Code Red mean that all private vehicles, trucks and buses may be inspected, sometimes by agents using trained dogs. The United States Customs Service added to the traffic jams by temporarily shutting down lanes used exclusively for regular international commuters, saying they did not provide sufficient security. 
With 350,000 vehicles and millions of passengers entering the United States every day, imposing all the new security measures stretched out the inspection of each vehicle and added time to a border crossing. Lots of time. 
After Code Red was imposed, traffic backed up for miles at busy border crossings with Canada and Mexico. For days, there were monumental delays that made the wait to cross the border into the United States, in some areas, last nine hours or more. 
More recently, additional American border agents have been put on the line and they have been working longer hours to help keep traffic moving. American border officials say they do not yet have definitive figures, but they say the volume of private vehicles crossing the border generally appears to have diminished, which evidently has also played a role in reducing backups. 
The combination of fewer cars and more border agents means delays have been greatly reduced at most outbound crossings, and wait times have returned to almost what they were before Sept. 11. But the busiest entry points remain clogged, especially heading into the United States. Clear outbound lanes may seem tempting, but monstrous backups on re-entering the United States have discouraged many travelers.
"Tijuana is like a ghost town right now," said Carlos Gomez, general manager of the Senor Frog's restaurant in Rosarito, Baja California, just south of Tijuana. The number of American visitors to his restaurant has dropped 80 percent since Sept. 11, and he is afraid the bombing in Afghanistan will only keep more people off the roads. 
"Americans are afraid to cross the border," Mr. Gomez said. "With a war on, they want to be able to get back faster, but here that can take three hours." 
By all accounts, those who do not stay home are finding it just plain harder to get across the border. Each crossing, no matter how small or infrequently used, is guarded by at least two customs agents every hour of every day. Many ports of entry, like the remote crossings in Antler and Neche, N.D., still close for the night at the homey hour of 10 p.m., but the border agents are supposed to remain on duty until morning, making sure no one disregards the orange traffic cones placed in the road during off hours. 
Congressional critics, like Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, say that simply adding personnel is not sufficient to handle new security concerns. Senator Dorgan said he would continue to push for a strengthening of rural border crossings. 
Though Americans don't need a passport to enter Canada or Mexico, border officials in those countries say it is a good idea for travelers who have passports to carry them when entering their countries. 
Both Canada and Mexico also have bolstered their border vigilance and advise Americans traveling into those countries to be prepared to undergo more thorough inspections than in the past. 
In Canada, the government is hiring 300 new immigration officers as part of a package of measures to tighen border control. The Canada Customs and Revenue Agency has been cautioning Americans without passports to bring photo identification; in the past, a birth certificiate or baptismal certificate was enough. And the Royal Canadian Mounted Police has stepped up patrols of rural border crossings, some of which remain unmanned overnight on the Canadian side.
In Mexico, Enrique Berruga, deputy secretary of foreign affairs, said that since Sept. 11, Mexico has increased security measures on its side of the border, not only for entering vehicles but also for those leaving. Using a system similar to that in major Mexican airports, vehicles are stopped and inspected randomly before entering the United States -- a machine flashes a red light to indicate when a car is to be stopped. 
"We are all in the same neighborhood, and we all now need to have greater surveillance," Mr. Berruga said. At the same time, he added, there is pressure to keep the border functioning smoothly to avoid economic disruptions that would worsen a deteriorating economic picture. 
Tourism, one of Mexico's biggest sources of income, is down as much as 30 percent since Sept. 11. Resorts in the northern states of Baja California and Sonora have been among the hardest hit, Mexican officials said. 
The Mexican government has begun a special tourism promotion at the border and through its consulates in the United States to persuade Americans that it is safe to travel and to solicit suggestions for making Mexico more tourist-friendly in the new era of heightened security.
In Canada, officials say traffic at some border crossings has dropped 50 percent and, as a result, tourism has been badly battered. Toronto and Montreal hotels have reported a wave of cancellations, and regular attractions popular with American road travelers, like the Shaw Festival in Niagara-on-the-Lake, Ontario, have had periods when they issued more refunds than tickets. 
Colleen Blake, the festival's managing director, said American group ticket sales have plummeted, but certain individuals continue to cross the border, including one couple that drove from St. Louis after their flight was canceled. "It's very heartening," Ms. Blake said, "and shows the resiliance of human nature." 
Canadian tourism officials and travel agencies are hoping that there might be some residual benefit for them in the intensified concerns over travelers' security. Susan Iris, the Canadian Tourism Commission's managing director in the United States, said a few travel agents are beginning to see a trend where people who canceled winter and spring trips to Europe and the Middle East are making reservations in Canada, which they can reach without flying. 
"There's a certain comfort level for Americans coming to Canada that's especially important right now," Ms. Iris said.In addition, she noted, the American dollar remains strong, worth about $1.56 in Canada.
Waiting times at the United States's borders with Canada and Mexico, continually updated, are available at the U.S. Customs Service Web site, www.customs.gov/sep11infof.htm.

HEADLINE: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORTS; 
The World Gets Its Guard Up: Mexico City

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON; GINGER THOMPSON is chief of the Mexico City bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
September has marked the nadir of the low tourist season for so long in this city of castles and museums that workers in restaurants and hotels refer to it as "Septi-hambre," a play on the Spanish word for hunger.
 The tourist famine has worsened this year in the wake of the terrorist attacks on the United States. Nearly 90 percent of foreign tourists to Mexico come from the United States, and their absence has left a void at popular attractions from the pyramids at Teotihuacan to the floating gardens at Xochimilco. There are lots of vacancies at the city's high-end hotels and empty tables at tequila bars. Business is down by as much as 30 percent. 
 But in many ways, and in many places, life among Mexican people continues as usual.
In some circles, there are expressions of concern about whether Mexico will become involved in the war. There is worry, too, about whether its airports and borders are secure enough to detect terrorists and stop them from using this country as a backdoor to the United States.
Security has been increased at the Mexico City airport, and travelers are advised to arrive at least two hours before international flights. Inspectors have become more vigilant -- some travelers have even complained of harassment -- in searching bags and raising questions about any kind of video or office equipment. (One agent almost pulled apart a professional photographer's 100-year-old camera, saying he wanted to see how it worked.)
Everywhere, however, there is a palpable edginess about the steady decline in the economy. Mexico's economy relies heavily on tourism -- the nation's third largest source of foreign income -- and exports to the United States. Shrinkage in those sectors has plunged the country into recession and forced hundreds of thousands of people out of work. Cabdrivers, street vendors and hotel bellmen worry openly about making ends meet. Waiters at tourist cantinas and restaurants measure the atmosphere in tips. At the popular Bar La Opera, in Mexico's historic center, waiters took a break from watching television reports of the bombing of Afghanistan to lament that their weekly tips had declined from $100 to $50. And competitions for gigs among mariachi musicians at Plaza Garibaldi have turned into fist fights. 
Luxury hotel operators have said that occupancy at their establishments has dropped between 10 and 15 percent compared with this time last year, especially among business travelers. Still, in spite of a sharp decline in profits for September at the Sheraton Maria Isabel, the company planned to go forward with construction of a 450-room hotel in the city's historic center, officials said.
Crime continues to menace tourists and residents alike. But in the coming months, said officials in Mexico City's Tourism Ministry, the government will deploy 250 "tourism police officers" from the National Auditorium in Chapultepec Park to the fine arts palace, called Bellas Artes, to offer assistance to visitors. Officials also said that some 650 new streetlights would be installed along Reforma, a broad east-west avenue modeled after the Champs-Elysees.
Tourism officials in Mexico hope that its proximity will help keep it an attractive destination for United States tourists -- some 2.5 million of whom travel to Mexico by car. During dinner at La Terraza in the historic district, where the spectacular view of the Zocalo more than compensates for the unspectacular menu, Doug and Marsha Taylor of Seattle said that after the terrorist attacks, they had canceled their plans to visit Bali and decided to come to Mexico for two weeks. After paying less than $30 for their meal, the couple did not seem to regret their decision.
"It's safe, and there's not an automatic anti-American sentiment," Mr. Taylor said. "We can be our normal selves here, and be O.K."

HEADLINE: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORTS; 
The World Gets Its Guard Up: Hong Kong#NEWLINE#An unsentimental look#NEWLINE#at the bottom line

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER; MARK LANDLER is chief of the Hong Kong bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
Despite its claims to being the Manhattan of Asia, Hong Kong has reacted to last month's terrorist attack in New York in a way that reveals the distance between this financial center and its American counterpart.
Hong Kong's government did not hold a memorial service for the victims in New York and Washington. One top official responded to the news with a dry-eyed analysis to reporters of how lower interest rates -- prompted by the weakened United States economy -- would benefit businesses here. 
Local people say Hong Kong's response was not coldhearted but reflects its historic reluctance, as a British colony turned Chinese special administrative region, to involve itself in international politics.
Albert Cheng, a columnist and radio commentator, wrote in the South China Morning Post, "It is not exactly fair to condemn Hong Kong officials for having failed to condemn terrorism, though whether their wording could be stronger is a matter of judgment."
Whatever the reason, Hong Kong has kept throbbing, with little sign of the crisis at hotels, restaurants or tourist attractions. While the business-as-usual mood may be reassuring for visitors, it is a reminder that this is a Chinese city, where feelings about the United States are ambivalent.
Government officials insist that Hong Kong is not a target of terrorism, though the American consulate closed briefly on Sept. 17 because of undisclosed security concerns. At Hong Kong International Airport, security forces stepped up patrols of flights departing for the United States and Britain after Washington launched strikes against Afghanistan.
Police Deputy Commander M. G. Howard said the elite units, armed with automatic weapons, were trained to respond to terrorism or more mundane issues, like passengers frustrated by the rigorous security procedures.
The economic fallout from the crisis is likely to hit Hong Kong in the pocketbook. Plunging arrivals from the United States and Canada have forced airlines to cancel flights, left hotels with empty rooms and robbed Hong Kong of what it had expected to be a bumper year for tourism. 
"It doesn't matter what strategy you have or how much money you have, people just aren't traveling," said Mark Lettenbichler, the general manager of the Ritz-Carlton, a hotel in the Central District that has had a flood of cancellations.
The Hong Kong Tourism Board had projected that 14 million people would visit the city this year, a 7.8 percent increase over 2000, driven in large part by an influx of mainland Chinese tourists. It now says the drop in North American tourists will wipe out that expected increase.
A spokeswoman, Donna Mongan, said the tourism board had pulled its advertising in the United States and Canada to focus on traffic from China and Taiwan, which are less likely to be affected by fears of terrorism.
Ms. Mongan said that Hong Kong might draw tourists over other Asian destinations because of its relative insulation from events. Indonesia and the Philippines have substantial Muslim populations, and the State Department has warned about possible anti-American sentiment in those countries.
 "It's terrible to say we could benefit from this," she said. "But compared to some of our Asian neighbors, possibly we could."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Patrols have been stepped up at Hong Kong's airport. (Justin Guariglia for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 10-21-01: Testimony; 
Signing Up

BYLINE:  By Nina Roberts

 BODY:
 In the wake of Sept. 11, Americans have volunteered their time, their expertise and their blood. Some have enlisted in the Armed Forces. Here, fresh recruits -- the first two joined after the attacks; the second two, before -- discuss the impact recent events have had on their decisions to serve.

Shawn Crouse, 19, carpenter: "To me, if you are an American citizen, you have to want retribution. There is no other way to look at it. War has always fascinated me. I'm a patriot. I'm an American citizen. I would not hesitate to die for this country."

Pablo Narvaez, 28, delivery person: "I don't want to talk to my Muslim friends about the war: what sounds to me like rationale might sound to them like hate rhetoric. My feeling is that somewhere in their hearts, their loyalty is not to America."

Husein Palmer, 24, unemployed: "Fight for our freedom, for our country, why not? I'm down with that. Now that the attack happened, I'm scared. Me and my sergeant were talking, and I asked, Am I going to be in front lines? He tried to calm me down."

Renalda Luli, 20, student: "I joined the Marines as a reserve this summer. Boot camp was really tough, but it's almost like I got born again or something. I want to go active really bad. What happened on the 11th made me want to go even more."

HEADLINE: Film; 
Back on Home Turf, a Breeding Ground of Unrest

BYLINE:  By LAURA WINTERS; Laura Winters's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about the Vietnamese director Tran Anh Hung and his film "The Vertical Ray of the Sun."

DATELINE: PARIS 

 BODY:
ROBERT GUEDIGUIAN'S new film "The Town Is Quiet" ("La Ville est Tranquille") was inspired by a memory of Marseille.
 "There is a hill in Marseille with a basilica that overlooks the whole town," Mr. Guediguian said recently, speaking in French at his production office here. "In the evening, standing there, with the city slowly becoming more quiet, it's easy to imagine that people are peacefully going home. But I've always been haunted by the thought that underneath that apparent tranquillity lurk things that are dangerous and frightening, that could in a moment catch fire. I wanted to talk, in this film, of all the things that make me afraid." 
 In the devastating tapestry that Mr. Guediguian creates in "The Town Is Quiet" -- his 10th film, opening in New York on Friday -- his native Marseille, an unquiet, rough-and-tumble seaport on the French Mediterranean coast, becomes a symbol of a far more universal urban unrest. 
Michele (played by the actress Ariane Ascaride, Mr. Guediguian's wife) unloads fish on the docks at night so that by day she can take care of her unemployed husband, her drug-addicted daughter and her baby granddaughter. Michele has two unlikely allies: a sinister bartender (Gerard Meylan) and a taxi driver (Jean-Pierre Darroussin), who is a disillusioned former union man. Meanwhile, in a high-rise building not far from Michele's, a young, black ex-convict (Alexandre Ogou) preaches peace to his angry friends. But his voice becomes increasingly drowned out by the racist propaganda of the far-right party, the National Front.
For Mr. Guediguian (pronounced gay-dee-GYAHN), such social ills stem from a common root. "Most of these characters, no matter what their milieu, have no real concept of the world," he said. "They go step by step, struggling, without thinking of the big picture. They have lost their sense of direction and their beliefs. But how can one live without some plan, some sort of hope for the future?"
Mr. Guediguian asks these questions but doesn't pretend to have answers. One of the most politically engaged filmmakers working in France today, he is a former Communist who still maintains a strong, if troubled, idealism. Not that his vision is always grim. The film that made his reputation in 1997 was the surprise hit "Marius and Jeannette," a mature love story that is as sunny as "The Town Is Quiet" is dark.
Though all his films are set in Marseille and focus on the working class, Mr. Guediguian has reached a new level with "The Town Is Quiet." "I think this is the film of Guediguian's which has the broadest and most generous vision of Marseille and of French society," said Richard Pena, program director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, which showed the movie earlier this year. "Generous in the sense that his characters may be in trouble but they have their reasons. He's conscious of cinema as a social tool, but I don't think he's a filmmaker who's pushing an agenda. His agenda is to make people reflect."
In person, Mr. Guediguian, who is 47, is warm and unaffected, sporting an aureole of brownish curls and an unabashed Marseillais accent even after 25 years in Paris. He has a quiet authority, which surfaces as he gives a tour of Agat Films & Company, an unusual collective of six producers, including himself. The company, which he helped to shape, has produced several recent French hits, among them Tonie Marshall's "Venus Beauty Institute."
Mr. Guediguian's current standing is a far cry from his early days. Then, he said, "I produced my own movies because nobody else wanted to." But even now he insists on a home-movie ethic. He has written his last six films with Jean-Louis Milesi and has shot all of them using the same small group of actors, including his wife, Ms. Ascaride; Mr. Darroussin, and Mr. Meylan, a childhood friend who is not a trained actor but a night nurse in a Marseille hospital.
"Whereas I once played a 28-year-old man in Robert's films, now I play a 48-year-old man," Mr. Meylan said, speaking on the phone from Marseille. "Robert is quite unique in that he uses the same actors as tangible witnesses to the passage of time, somewhat as Fassbinder did."
The fact that he has worked with the same actors has also made Mr. Guediguian's films a kind of larger chronicle. "Robert's films have become the history of a particular generation in France," said his fellow Agat producer Yvon Davis. "This is a generation that had tremendous ideals, that participated in the events of 1968 in France, but that also partook of the subsequent disillusionment."
Mr. Guediguian's films start always from the personal. "I talk of Marseille because I was born there, and because its colors and its landscapes are my language," he said. "As Chekhov said, if you want to talk of the whole world, talk of your village."
Though his style is realistic, he insists on his films' being extreme. "My films are either comedies or tragedies," he said. "I don't think you should mix the two registers. You have to go to the depths of each one, like opera: only in that way can you move the audience."
This leads to some shocking moments in "The Town Is Quiet." In one, Michele, driven to distraction by the simultaneous crying of her daughter and her granddaughter, warms milk for the baby while she heats up heroin in a spoon for the baby's mother.
Ms. Ascaride's bravura performance as Michele is the heart of the film. "I think Robert has always been fascinated by two types of women: Mary Magdalene and Mother Courage," Ms. Ascaride said by telephone from Paris. "But Michele is the most complex and ambiguous character that Robert has ever called upon me to play. She is someone who is constantly fighting for survival."
Ms. Ascaride, who went blond for the role, was afraid when she first read the part. "I said to myself, 'My God, how can I make her sympathetic?' " she recalled. "The only thing I can liken the experience to is bungee-jumping. I had to throw myself into the void."
On the set, Mr. Guediguian works with his actors intuitively. "He doesn't talk much and gives few directions," Ms. Ascaride said. "At the same time, he is very open to whatever ideas we have for the characters."
One of his goals is to make his characters human, whether they be heroes or villains. "Rather than just dismissing people who are racist, I wanted to show why they get the ideas that they do," he said. His concern with the working class stems from his own background. "I try to speak for my father, for the world that I grew up in," he said.
Mr. Guediguian's father, who worked on the docks in Marseille, is of Armenian heritage; his mother is German. He grew up in the mixed neighborhood of L'Estaque. "It was a communal atmosphere because it was the Mediterranean and we were always outside," he said. "And it was a Communist neighborhood, so I was militant from a young age."
He went to the University of Aix-en-Provence to study sociology. There he met Ms. Ascaride, a fellow student, when she came to one of his classes to speak on behalf of the student union. They married in 1975, and Mr. Guediguian followed Ms. Ascaride to Paris, where she studied at the National Conservatory of Dramatic Arts. Then, in 1979, an acquaintance asked him to collaborate on a screenplay.
Mr. Guediguian found that he liked to write and so, with another friend, Frank Le Wita, he wrote his own film, "Last Summer" ("Dernier Ete"), a melancholy look at a group of young Marseillais friends. Mr. Guediguian scraped together enough money to direct it and was stunned when the film was chosen to play out of competition at the Cannes International Film Festival.
Encouraged, he directed a second film, "Rouge Midi" (1983), a historical saga of a working-class family in Marseille. But he found it hard to find financing for his next two films, "Ki Lo Sa?" (1985) and "Dieu Vomit Les Tiedes" (1989), neither of which was released in the United States. These films, which deal with lost illusions, mirrored his own spiritual crisis at the time. "I had lost faith in the French Communist party," he said, "and I didn't see what I could do in order to fight any more."
HE found an answer with his first comedy, "Money Makes Happiness" ("L'Argent Fait le Bonheur," 1992), a wry tale of inner-city youngsters who try to combat injustice by stealing from the rich. "I realized in my own life that little victories could count," he said, "and I wanted to start making films that would hearten people."
In 1996, after shooting another drama, he decided to make an informal comedy, "Marius and Jeannette," set partly in a friend's courtyard in Marseille. The film, which is about a middle-aged security guard who falls in love with a feisty mother of two, and which stars Mr. Meylan and Ms. Ascaride, became one of the most successful French films of 1997.
"Marius and Jeannette's" charm includes the occasional sly tribute to Marcel Pagnol, the great playwright-director who glorified Marseille before the Second World War. "Pagnol is an unavoidable, if overpowering, father figure," Mr. Guediguian said. "For my first films, I tried to stay far away from him. With my comedies, however, I thought it would be amusing to do certain sequences in the manner of Pagnol, very colorful, but have my characters talking about thoroughly modern political issues."
Since his success with "Marius and Jeannette," Mr. Guediguian has directed and released three more films in rapid succession. But "The Town Is Quiet" is his most ambitious film, and one that seems to indicate a new direction for him. "I've always dealt with the idea of community in my films, but here I deal for the first time with solitude, with the absence of community," he said.
He has taken this concern with solitude even further in a film he finished shooting this summer, "Marie-Jo and Her Two Loves" ("Marie-Jo et ses Deux Amours"). It is the tragic tale of a woman who loves two men and cannot choose between them. "I think for the first time I've left political and social issues aside to concentrate more on my characters' private lives," Mr. Guediguian said.
When asked whether doing something different makes him nervous, he laughed. "Yes, it does," he replied. "But I think fear is part of the satisfaction of taking risks. If I didn't find things to do that frightened me, I would stop making films."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Gerard Meylan and Ariane Ascaride portray former lovers in "The Town Is Quiet" ("La Ville est Tranquille"), a drama set in Marseille and directed by Robert Guediguian, above. (Caroline Delmotte for The New York Times; New Yorker Films)

HEADLINE: Near the Big Dig, New Homes and Offices 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
New commercial and residential developments are nearing completion in the first area of this city to be cleared of elevated roadways and other remnants of an industrial past after 10 years of construction on the Big Dig and related infrastructure improvements. As the developments bring new life to the long-languishing City Square district in the historic Charlestown neighborhood, planners and city officials are pointing to the changes as examples of what might be done in the wake of the enormous physical changes being made by the $14.5 billion Central Artery Project, which is to be completed in 2005. 
 The four City Square projects -- two office buildings, a hotel and a condominium -- are reviving a waterfront district that was once lined by industrial buildings and crisscrossed by freight trains, all in the shadows cast by elevated roads and bridges. 
 In 1990, as part of the gigantic state and federally funded infrastructure rebuilding project, city planners started to draw up zoning rules for this 12-acre district. By 1995, the completed plan included five development parcels, a one acre public park and five additional acres of landscaped space. In 1997 the elevated structures were demolished. 
Once the elevated steel structures came down and new links to Interstate 93 and Route 1 were completed at a cost of $200 million, the potential of the area, which extends to the harbor, became clear. In 2000, when the state requested bids on leases, four of the five parcels were soon leased to developers. That was no accident, according to Linda M. Haar, chief of staff for the Boston Redevelopment Authority. Planning for the area, designated as Central Artery North, "was done not only to serve highway construction but to allow a major infrastructure project to create a livable and attractive urban neighborhood," she said.
Three years ago, the first hint of City Square's fresh-faced incarnation surfaced with the completion of its new park, replete with red brick sidewalks, period lighting and wrought iron benches. Now, construction on the $50 million, 8-building, 117-unit Nautica condominium project across the street is two months from completion, with 35 households already in residence.
"City Square used to be a little dirt pile surrounded by empty lots where people walked dogs," said Courtney T. Kagan, 32, a 10-year Charlestown resident who with her husband and two young children just moved into a $900,000 four-bedroom town house at the Nautica. "Now we have a beautifully manicured park and great new buildings." 
Construction is also under way on the $50 million Gateway Center: two office buildings that total 210,000 square feet and have ground-floor retail and cultural amenities. The first building, covering 170,000 square feet, which features an archway showcasing the harbor, is to be completed in November. The second office building, with 40,000 square feet, is to be done in one year. 
Next month construction is scheduled to start on a $40 million, 168-room extended-stay hotel on a waterfront pier. National Development of Newton, Mass., purchased the 1.25-acre parcel last year for $3.25 million. Earlier this fall, after receiving city and state approvals, the developer started site work for the 50,000-square-foot hotel project on Tudor Wharf, which is to include a public harbor-front walkway. 
The City Square developments will extend a revitalized slice of the Charlestown neighborhood to the water's edge.
Charlestown is one of several Boston neighborhoods whose geographic isolation and decades of economic decline had sowed the seeds of a somewhat insular identity. After World War II, the once buzzing industrial enclave gradually became a neighborhood of low-cost housing, abandoned wharves, warehouses, factories and the vast but eerily quiet Charlestown Naval Shipyard.
Then, in the late 1980's, with the aid of the state and federal governments and private developers, the city transformed the Navy yard into a mix of mostly upscale residences, offices, shops and the tourist-friendly U.S.S. Constitution museum. Sitting on the northern shore of Boston Harbor, spruced-up Charlestown with its spectacular skyline views and an easy walk to the Financial District lured new residents, office tenants and fine restaurants.
In the 1990's, Big Dig construction got under way. It includes rebuilding downtown Boston's roads, bridges and underlying infrastructure, including utility and telecommunications lines. Replacing the elevated artery in City Square with a tunnel was one vital link in the massive effort. The most visible part of the Big Dig is the work to place the few miles of elevated highway that run through the Central Business District along the harbor below street level. That will create about 27 acres of open space and development parcels.
"Within a year, we expect to start choosing designers to draw up a master plan for housing, commercial projects and parks from the North End to just south of Chinatown," said Ms. Haar, the city planner. "It's a great opportunity." 
City Square, the first section of the city to be freed of the old and filled with the new infrastructure, has certainly been opportune for the developers working here. About 100,000 square feet of the 170,000-square-foot office building under construction at Gateway Center was preleased to Keane Inc., a Charlestown-based information technology company and a partner in the development project being managed by the Cornerstone Corporation. 
The developer expects another 50,000 square feet to be put under agreement soon for about $30 to $40 a square foot, the annual rental rate anticipated when the project was started three years ago. Construction has just begun on the second office building, which is to be completed in November 2002. Leasing is to start in the first quarter of 2002.
"We plan to manage and hold on to them for the long term," said Timothy P. Doherty, the project manager for Cornerstone, which is based in Needham. The red brick and copper-topped building with 400 spaces of underground parking was designed by ADD Inc. of Cambridge for the developer, which acquired a 99-year ground lease from the state in a public bid process. 
Nearby, site preparation recently started for the hotel on Tudor wharf as well as underground parking spaces; the identity the hotel company has not yet been announced. Construction of the building, designed by the Boston-based architect DiMella & Schaeffer, is scheduled to start next month and be completed in 2003.
" Many of the business travelers that are the hotel's marketing targets will be working with pharmaceutical and health science companies in the nearby Charlestown Navy yard.
"We're excited about the long-term appreciation potential of City Square, which is now a terrific business environment and residential community," said Thomas M. Alperin, president of National Development. 
Ms. Kagan, whose family recently moved into a 2,300-square-foot, four-bedroom town house condominium at the Nautica agrees. "Charlestown is in the city but feels like a family community; we have a mother's group with 100 members," she said.
The Nautica is on a two-and-a-half-acre site that once sat under an elevated roadway to downtown Boston. The land was leased from the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority for 99 years by Constitution Development Associates of Boston. The 117 one- to four-bedroom condominiums are in eight buildings clustered around an acre and a half of open space that leads to the waterfront, explained Daniel R. Hart, the project manager. It was designed by Neshamkin/French Architects of Charlestown. All but eight of the units have been sold or are under contract, at prices of $145,000 to $1.3 million. 
Ms. Kagan, one of the early buyers, can easily envision the finished product. "A year from now," she said, "the Nautica with all its landscaping and bandstand will feel like living in a park."
