HEADLINE: Art/Architecture; 
An Elegant Marriage Of Inside and Outside

BYLINE:  By Herbert Muschamp

 BODY:
AGGRESSION is a particle, desire is a wave. They represent two different ways of experiencing life. But nowadays it matters to go with the waves. To get through this crisis in our collective and interconnected civic, national and global life, we must all become beach bums and ride our desires. 
 Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio have designed a blue and white wave of a building for Eyebeam Atelier, the advanced electronic media workshop in Chelsea. The project is one of three finalists in a competition organized earlier this year for a new headquarters Eyebeam hopes to build. All 13 of the conceptual designs submitted by other firms invited to participate, as well as the finalists, are on display through Oct. 27 at the future site of the building, 540 West 21st Street, between 10th and 11th Avenues. (Entries can be viewed on line at www.eyebeam.org.) The winner will be chosen in the next few weeks. 
 Whatever the outcome, Diller and Scofidio's project is Olympic class. The most fully developed piece of architecture their office has produced thus far, the design extends into durably built form the conceptual elegance of the "alternative" architecture for which Diller and Scofidio are best known. For a while, it seemed as if the team were treading water. Brilliant divertissements like the Brasserie restaurant, the performance piece "Jet Lag," and "Suitcase Studies," a traveling museum show on the subject of tourism, increased our impatience for something less alternative.
Their situation changed earlier this year, when Diller and Scofidio were awarded the commission to design a new building for Boston's Museum of Contemporary Art. But Manhattan needs their talent now. With the convergence of developer-architects on Lower Manhattan, New York is likely to see more particle buildings than it can handle. The city is ready for new waves.
This is one of three terrific New York projects I saw last week. A report on Jean Nouvel's proposal for a three-building complex in Chelsea appeared in last Sunday's Real Estate section in The Times. Rem Koolhaas is getting his design for the Whitney Museum expansion ready for its close-up in the next weeks. These projects helped dispel the gloomy prospect I had formed since Sept. 11: an emergency reconstruction authority; sweeping powers to condemn property and award development rights; theme park versions of "New York's architectural traditions." The Tyranny of the Appropriate, in perpetuity this time.
The display of Eyebeam's competition entries is a museum-quality show. Jeffrey Kipnis, architecture and design curator at the Wexner Art Center in Columbus, Ohio, calls it the first serious survey of work by the circa 40 generation. There are striking commonalities in the work. Waves and ribbons abound. To my eye, these motifs look like crossbreeds. Computerized blob design has been morphed together with the boxes the computers came in. 
Founded in 1997 by John Johnson, its executive director, Eyebeam is a hybrid nonprofit institution that combines educational programs and media production facilities with publicly accessible galleries and performance spaces. "Access to Tools," the subtitle Stewart Brand chose for the Whole Earth Catalog, the legendary bible for the counterculture in the late 1960's and early 70's, could define Johnson's mission as well. An heir to the Johnson & Johnson fortune, Eyebeam's director projects the benign air of youthful noblesse oblige. His overarching ambition is to train city youngsters in the techniques required to tell stories in the digital age.
It's not a stretch to say that schools have become the city's bandages. Without them, there's little hope that the urban core can sustain its historic role as a center of cultural production. Museums matter to the extent that they pursue a pedagogical role in civic life. But our larger museums and performing arts spaces are primarily centers for cultural consumption. Schools are the key to training productive minds.
Diller and Scofidio get it. Their design is rooted in the differentiation between production and consumption and in their symbiotic relationship. It is a study in interwoven space, where the makers and consumers of media spectacles are presented as two parts of a group performance.
The interior is loosely organized into separate areas for production and presentation that occupy alternating floors in the 12-story building. The production areas (classrooms, audio-visual workshops) are enclosed within the folds of a curving, two-ply ribbon of metal and reinforced concrete that uncoils from the ground floor lobby to an outdoor rooftop theater. Presentation areas (galleries, theaters, a cafe) occupy spaces outside the horizontal enclosures. These cascade downward, like a kind of liquefied, discontinuous atrium that flows in and around the spaces dedicated to production.
As the ribbon unfolds from side to side, floors, ceilings and interior walls are fashioned from its variously flat and curving surfaces. The building's guts (wiring, plumbing, heating and air-conditioning ducts) are sandwiched between the ribbon's concrete and metal plies. On the street facade, the concrete ribbon projects beyond the glazed building envelope. Alternating bands of transparent and blue tinted glass indicate the position of production and presentation areas. The facade itself is folded vertically, down the center, giving it a faceted, crystalline complexity. From the street, people can take in the logic of the interwoven space.
This is the first piece of architecture to deal seriously with the idea of blue. Jean Nouvel has some great blues going on in his design for the Broadway Hotel in SoHo. But Nouvel's colors have more to do with cinematography than digital process. For Eyebeam, blue unmistakably evokes the blue screen used to create special effects. It is an emblem for placelessness, for a weightless, infinite and provisional void waiting to be filled with synthesized locations. As a pop cultural device, the blue screen also carries connotations of Miles Davis, Polynesian cocktails and television ads for Caribbean resorts. The cascading flow of interior space recreates water, the universal solvent. It's an artificial, electronic view of the primordial world before differentiation set in. Then the waters part, and a holographic Julie London emerges in a cloud of foam, someone hands her a mike and she sings "Voice in the Mirror."
New York has seen no new interiors of comparable allure since the decade that produced the Guggenheim Museum, the TWA Terminal, the Ford Foundation, the Seagram Building and the Hall of Science at the New York World's Fair. Sad, but true. Tacky, impoverished space: that's a legacy bequeathed to us by architecture's glorious antimodern moment.
The relationship of inside and outside is the heart of Diller and Scofidio's design. Its significance rests substantially on the sophistication with which it explores the overlap (or ecotone) between objective and subjective space. From a conceptual point of view, the difference between the industrial and informational economies rests on a blurring of the boundaries between our inner and outer worlds. The industrial age systematized our access to things. The information age, as Jeremy Rifkin observes, organizes access to experiences. Experience belongs as much to the mental landscape as to the realm of material reality.
The issue, with regard to media, is the extent to which the consumer of experience becomes the consumed. Can we project our experience out into the world? Or has it become our fate to be restricted to the receiving end? Diller and Scofidio have rendered Eyebeam's Utopian outlook into concise urban form. No architects today can match their elegance in translating social analysis into space.

Above, an exterior view looking southwest from 21st Street. Top left, the interface between exhibition space and a classroom. At left, a shared computer laboratory and classroom. HEADLINE: Film; 
If Only It Hadn't Been His Only One

BYLINE:  By SIMON CALLOW; The British actor and director Simon Callow is the author of "Charles Laughton: A Difficult Actor," "Orson Welles: The Road to Xanadu" and other books.

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
CHARLES LAUGHTON'S "Night of the Hunter" is at the very top of that curious list of only films directed by actors. Below it are Marlon Brando's "One-Eyed Jacks," Peter Lorre's "Der Verlorene" and this writer's "Ballad of the Sad Cafe," to name a few. Laughton's is a haunting and highly personal work, which, despite flaws, is clearly the work of a master. It should have been the high point of his creative life so far, and the harbinger of many more remarkable films. Instead, it slipped almost unnoticed into the stream of 1955's new releases, and he never made another.
 Now the film -- and Laughton's great promise as a filmmaker -- can be seen again in a newly restored print at Film Forum in Manhattan starting on Friday. It tells the story of a murderous preacher, played by Robert Mitchum, who terrorizes two small children in pursuit of their father's stolen fortune. They finally escape into the protective embrace of a good-hearted, gun-toting spinster (Lillian Gish). 
 At the time Laughton took on "Night of the Hunter," when he was 55, his career had become multi-stranded. After a late start -- he only finally gave up running the family hotel in Scarborough to attend the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts at the age of 26 -- he experienced immediate success on the London stage. By 1930, after only three years on the professional stage and despite unconventional looks (he described himself as resembling a "departing pachyderm") and a lack of glamour in the accepted sense of the word, he had established himself as the most original actor in England, playing an Al Capone-style gangster in "On the Spot."
The following year he went to Broadway with "Payment Deferred," repeating his harrowing performance as the bank clerk who murders his wife, causing a sensation there too. He went on to Hollywood, where he made a number of striking films, then returned to Britain to star in "The Private Life of Henry VIII" (1933), which earned him his only Academy Award and made him world-famous. His Henry VIII was impersonated in bars, on playgrounds and in living rooms everywhere, which is one of the more inarguable forms that fame takes.
Returning to Hollywood after a rather disappointing season at the Old Vic in 1933 -- bitterly disappointing to him, if rather less so to the public and press -- he gave a sequence of indelible performances of uncommon pressure and intensity: Captain Bligh in "Mutiny on the Bounty," Javer in "Les Miserables" and Edward Moulton-Barrett in "The Barretts of Wimpole Street." The pressure derived partly from his anguished struggle with his homosexuality; his marriage to the actress Elsa Lanchester soon became one of convenience. His genius was to use his inner tensions in the service of art.
His work takes the art of acting to heights of imagination and poetry, perhaps to a degree rivalled in the 20th century only by Marlon Brando. Art mattered to Laughton. He was a deeply informed, largely self-educated aesthete, an authority on painting and sculpture, a connoisseur of the broadest range of literature. With high hopes for the development of the art of film, he returned to Britain again in 1938, to found Mayflower Productions with Erich Pommer, former boss of the great German studio UFA. But despite the intelligence and ambition of those involved, the three films they produced were oddly unsatisfactory, including Hitchcock's "Jamaica Inn" (1939), a dubious if commercially successful farrago. Disappointed, Laughton returned once again to America, where he was soon to adopt citizenship. Although a Yorkshireman to his fingertips, he was in full flight from everything that he found oppressive about England: the class distinctions, the rigid sexual morality, the weather.
His first film when he came back to Hollywood was "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" (1939), in which he gives the peak performance of his career as Quasimodo. Whether he had burnt himself out with the demands he made of himself to create that image of suffering humanity, or whether his life was changing anyway, he never again invested a part with the same degree of imaginative fervor. While before he had seemed to be living out his life in acting, now he became a supreme craftsman of acting. His creative genius shifted into other areas.
Around this time, in the early 1940's, he found for the first time relaxed sexual fulfillment with a man, a young actor, and this long-delayed resolution seemed to free him up for more communicative, less self-involved forms of activity. He started a series of successful public readings -- of Shakespeare, the Bible, Dickens, Jack Kerouac -- primarily directed at young people; he taught acting in small groups at his house in Los Angeles; and he started directing for the stage. First there was a "Cherry Orchard" staged in a small theater in Los Angeles and cast partly with students. Then, on a grander scale, on Broadway and on tour, the Don Juan in Hell scenes from Shaw's "Man and Superman; "John Brown's Body," a dramatization of Stephen Vincent Benet's epic poem, starring Tyrone Power, and "The Caine Mutiny Court Martial," with Henry Fonda. By this last production, a huge commercial success, it was evident that he had become an exceptional theater director, and his manager, the vigorous, abrasive young agent Paul Gregory, determined that the time was ripe for Laughton to direct on film.
Apart from anything else, Gregory was convinced that Laughton was killing himself with the reading tours (which Gregory had set up in the first place), so at the first opportunity he snapped up what seemed to him a highly promising property, "The Night of the Hunter," a first novel by Davis Grubb that had not yet been published. His instinct was sound; on publication in 1953 the book went straight onto the best-seller list.
Laughton had fallen in love with the novel the moment he read it. Its hypnotic and incantatory tone was deeply appealing to him, as was its essentially American feel; his devotion to his adopted country and its literature was passionate. The novel's depiction of a struggle between good and evil -- the attraction of evil, the healing power of goodness and the ultimate triumph of innocence -- was something to which he could respond. He immersed himself in Grubb's work to such a degree that when the screenwriter, the esteemed James Agee, in his alcoholic befuddlement delivered an unfilmable screenplay, Laughton swiftly adapted the novel himself in a week.
His other collaborators proved more amenable; indeed, he created a singularly harmonious creative team, his chief partners being the cinematographer Stanley Cortez and the composer Walter Schumann. The time pressure exerted by United Artists (which betrayed scant enthusiasm from the beginning; his agent, Gregory, called the studio United Against Artists) meant that every day had to be planned in minute detail. Laughton gathered his team around him at the end of each day's shooting for intense discussions, which the participants remember as inspiring, with Laughton eloquently imparting to them his sense of the charged visual poetry he sought. Mr. Cortez, especially, felt profound sympathy with Laughton's objectives. His earlier encounter, in 1942, with Orson Welles on "The Magnificent Ambersons" had been tense and fraught (though equally productive). Here, shooting mostly on United's lot, he and Laughton worked to create, through the most economic means, some of the most potent imagery to come out of the American cinema.
The river journey of the fleeing children is told in a sequence of ravishing nature shots; while the haunting and ominous presence of the hymn-singing preacher ("Leaning! Leaning on the arm of the Lord!") on the horizon was achieved by a pony and a dwarf. Laughton, Mr. Cortez and his composer, Schumann, used every means at their disposal for expressive intensification, but all within a homespun, wholly American idiom, one that owed much to D. W. Griffith but that paid its borrowings back threefold.
Nor did Laughton's cast let him down. As the mother, the young Shelley Winters (a graduate of Laughton's acting classes) contributed a potent sexual presence if no great histrionic subtlety; Lillian Gish, Laughton's idol as a young man, purveyed the love without condition, the strength without threat, that the story demands; and Robert Mitchum, full of dark silky charm -- Love and Hate written across his face just as surely as they are across his knuckles -- gives the performance of his life, as he always acknowledged.
Almost as important as the adults are the children: Laughton tells the story through their eyes "as a kind of fairy story," he said. Billy Chapin as Billy distills the film's sturdy celebration of innocence in his big-eyed, single-minded performance. Laughton, sure of what he wanted and open to his fellow-artists in trying to realize it, created a rare focus. The second unit director, Terry Sanders, recalled Laughton's simplicity on the set.
"He spoke very quietly, but you sure listened," Mr. Sanders said. "He made you feel you were important, and this was important."
Gish wrote: "I have to go back as far as D. W. Griffith to find a set so infused with purpose and harmony.There was not ever a moment's doubt as to what we were doing or how we were doing it. To please Charles Laughton was our aim." 
Alas, America was not ready for his film. The previews were unfavorably received, and United Artists, never convinced of the film's viability, promoted it half-heartedly, preferring to concentrate on selling their next vehicle for Mitchum, "Not as a Stranger," which he had started shooting even before "The Night of the Hunter" was completed. The reviews were respectful and on the whole positive, though no one was quite able to understand what kind of film it was. Francois Truffaut, reviewing it in Cahiers du Cinema ("it makes one fall in love with an experimental cinema that really experiments and a cinema of discovery that actually discovers"), presciently observed that it would be unlikely if Laughton made another film. He never did.
The failure of "The Night of the Hunter" had broken Laughton's heart. He had found his metier: everything in his career and life so far had been preparing him for filmmaking, but it came too late for him to withstand the rough indifference of the commercial cinema. In the six more years left to him (he died in 1962), he gave a few more performances (including his magisterial Southern senator in "Advise and Consent," his last role); he played King Lear and Bottom at the Shakespeare Memorial Theater in Stratford-Upon-Avon; he continued the reading tours; and he found real love with a charming and handsome young man. But he never found it in himself again to lavish all of his genius on anything so personal and poetic as his lonely masterpiece.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 11, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 21 about the film "Night of the Hunter" misstated the name of the character played by Billy Chapin. It was John, not Billy. The article also included an erroneous version of a line from a hymn sung by the preacher played by Robert Mitchum. He sang, "Leaning on the everlasting arms," not "Leaning on the arm of the Lord."

HEADLINE: Music; 
Classical Recording: Spinning Into Oblivion?

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY TOMMASINI

 BODY:
ON May 1, George Scarlett, the vice president for product and vendor management of Tower Records, issued a directive to all 113 of the company's stores in the United States that rattled the already shaky classical music recording industry. His stark memorandum ordered an immediate buying hold on three independent distributors that have issued recordings highly valued by classical collectors: Allegro, Qualiton and Harmonia Mundi U.S.A. In addition, Tower asked all labels, large and small, for extended terms to pay for products it was ordering, an arrangement that amounted to ordering records on consignment.
 In any other industry such a move would be seen as typical maneuvering in economically strapped times. Classical recording, though, has always been an atypical industry. With rare exceptions, the labels produce specialty items for comparatively small numbers of informed buyers. But getting these products into the hands of those buyers is not easy, and the one retailer that all recording companies, especially the smaller ones, had long counted on was Tower Records, which used to pride itself on stocking virtually everything. 
 The classical recording industry seems to be collapsing, and aggrieved music lovers are looking for someone to blame. During the summer Tower was an easy villain. By fall, the retail chain, though grappling with its own deficit, had reached a tentative agreement with the independents. How long it will last is another matter. 
To be fair, Tower Records received an undue amount of criticism. True, the company has done its share to undermine the industry. A Tower store was once a serious place where classical music lovers could browse through rows of releases and discuss them with informed staff members. Today, after years of gobbling up the market and shoving aside small, independent retailers, the stores have become mall-like behemoths, featuring snack bars, bookstands and video rental departments.
Yet can any retailer be expected to stock everything when the market is so glutted with products? Mr. Scarlett estimates that in classical music alone, there are now some 60,000 items in the catalogs. "It would be physically impossible to stock all that," he said recently. "We don't have the shelf space." Confused consumers have gone from anger to frustration to apathy. Reportedly, the classical share of the total CD market, which had peaked at 7 percent during the height of CD mania, has slipped to 3 percent.
Several seemingly contradictory factors are causing the crisis in classical recording. While recording costs, especially for symphonic and operatic fare have skyrocketed, the cost of producing a CD -- actually making the thing -- has never been cheaper: roughly $1 per disc. For years retrenchment and lack of vision have characterized the five major companies that account for four-fifths of worldwide sales and are under pressure to make big profits: Universal, EMI, BMG, Sony and Warner. Consequently, scrappy independent labels that just aim to stay afloat and enjoy themselves have cropped up everywhere. The market has been flooded with recordings of neglected and offbeat repertory, and live performances from past decades (often obtained by skirting copyright laws, which are hopelessly outmoded anyway).
Some idealistic directors of independent companies view the situation as messy, yes, but full of promise. The little guys have defeated the big shots, all those capitalist banditos who took over the majors and signed up worthy classical artists only to toss them aside when unrealistic profit goals went unmet. Time is up, the argument goes, for those corporate suits who piled more and more versions of the Beethoven Fifth and "Tosca" onto the CD stockpile. Now the indies can rush into the breach.
But with Tower cutting back its services, how will the smaller labels get their products to consumers? Those troublemakers at Napster, who challenged the pop record producers by introducing computer programs that allowed users to download songs and albums free, may actually have been pointing the entire industry to the inevitable solution: the Internet.
Online shopping sites like Amazon.com and Borders already offer ways for consumers and recording companies to bypass retail stores, and this trend will continue. So far, downloading recordings directly through the Internet has been an issue, and a hassle, only in the pop field. That situation may be about to change.
For the moment, the major labels have won a legal battle against Napster. But other direct downloading services, like FastTrack, iMesh and Aimster, are cropping up. Obviously, few people would condone the theft, in effect, of copyrighted work from creative artists and the companies that record them. But if intellectual property rights lawyers and Internet engineers can find a way to compensate artists and producers properly, some manner of direct downloading may represent the future of the recording industry, classical recording included.
Why else would the five competing major companies and other media outlets have joined forces recently to set up Pressplay and MusicNet, two direct delivery downloading services? It would seem that the major companies and their lawyers are searching for legitimate ways to do what the upstarts at Napster got slapped down for.
Before international conglomerates started acquiring record companies about 20 years ago, the classical recording field was not doing badly. During the glory years of Columbia Records in the 1950's and 60's, Goddard Lieberson, a trained composer and critic, was the head of Columbia Masterworks, the company's classical division. The parent company, CBS, expected Lieberson to keep the company in the black and even make a little money. But not a lot of money. Recording classical music was considered a cultural service, a prestige operation.
Lieberson had top-selling classical artists on his roster: Leonard Bernstein, Glenn Gould, Isaac Stern and Rudolf Serkin, among others. But it was understood that, say, Serkin's recording of Beethoven's "Emperor" Concerto would sell many more copies than his version of Max Reger's Piano Concerto. Dividends from Bernstein and Gould releases were used to offset money-losing projects, like the conductor Robert Craft's recordings of the complete works of Schoenberg and Webern, and the monumentally historic series featuring Stravinsky conducting his own works. Albums by artists in the company's popular division, like Bob Dylan, really paid the bills at Columbia, and kept the execs at CBS happy.
Today, the descendant of Columbia Masterworks is Sony Classical, a subsidiary of the Sony Corporation. This once illustrious classical division has been issuing pink slips to its demoralized staff since the summer. Paradoxically, the sensational success of certain crossover artists, like Andrea Bocelli and the Three Tenors on other labels, has had a pernicious influence on classical divisions like Sony's. Suddenly, corporate higher-ups realized that a classical recording could sell in the millions. The classical directors were told, in effect, "Fine, put out your prestige albums of Esa-Pekka Salonen conducting Lutoslawski, and Murray Perahia playing Bach, but find us marketable crossover artists who can pull in some real money."
Sony Classical, like most major companies, devised a two-pronged response. On one hand, they nurtured their top-selling artists like Yo-Yo Ma, signed up new artists like the soprano Jane Eaglen and brought out the Masterworks Heritage line, with reissued important recordings by Bernstein, Fritz Reiner, George Szell and the Budapest String Quartet, smartly packaged and with intelligent liner notes. In 1998, Sony began a highly praised series featuring the music of Gyorgy Ligeti. On the other hand, that same year, the company found its own crossover sensation: a 12-year-old singer from Wales, Charlotte Church.
By 1999 Sony Classical had abandoned the Ligeti project and scaled down the Masterworks Heritage line to almost nothing. Meanwhile, it made millions with the "Titanic" soundtrack album and kept sinking money into Ms. Church. Just the other day, the latest Sony release appeared: "Our Favorite Things," a "Christmas in Vienna" concert featuring Tony Bennett, Placido Domingo, Vanessa Williams and Ms. Church, performing with the Vienna Symphony, no less. Anything for money.
Obviously, executives at Sony Classical, who know how to count, have determined that this album will sell. All you can say is, rest in peace, Goddard Lieberson.
Meanwhile, the Ligeti project was picked up by Teldec, which has begun a sublabel for contemporary music called New Line. But don't count on New Line's longevity. Teldec is owned by Warner Classics, which acquired it a decade ago at great expense, along with Erato, another distinguished classical label. But recently, to cut costs, Warner closed down the headquarters of Teldec in Hamburg and Erato in Paris.
Both are now centralized in Warner's London offices. Among the casualties are Daniel Barenboim and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, which has lost its contract with Teldec. Many other artists have fallen by the wayside. For example, no sooner had two superb Erato recordings featuring a young Russian pianist, Nikolai Lugansky, playing the complete Chopin etudes and a Rachmaninoff program been released than the company canceled his contract.
Things are even starker at BMG, the company that owns and operates RCA Victor: the remnants of a once essential classical label. There have been staff cutbacks of more than 25 percent in response to a loss of $100 million during the fiscal year that ended in June. It will be weirdly fascinating to see what happens to the powerful Universal Classics, which includes Deutsche Grammophon, Philips and Decca, now that it has been acquired by the Vivendi company, known for waste management and environmental services, and now branching out into telecommunications and media.
The current market for classical recordings is chaotic and confusing. The smaller companies are turning out all sorts of unusual recordings. From the budget label Naxos you can pick up piano works by Sigismond Thalberg and the "Christmas Oratorio" by Bach's contemporary Gottfried Heinrich Stolzel. Symphonies by Svenden and piano concertos by Alwyn are available from Chandos, which recently brought back into circulation the 1970's recording of Wagner's "Ring" performed in English translation, a probing performance conducted by Reginald Goodall.
Yet the major companies have a repository of important older recordings of the standard repertory that they have let slip from the catalog. So right now, for example, you can buy a new Naxos album of works for male chorus by Janacek but not the remarkable 1961 Decca recording of Verdi's "Otello," conducted by Herbert von Karajan, with Mario del Monaco and Renata Tebaldi. For a critic, it's an exercise in frustration to recommend your favorite recordings of, say, Debussy. Inevitably half of your choices have been withdrawn.
Many small labels are run by dedicated people who do not expect to make much money. The composer Gunther Schuller manages GM Records, which has produced important recordings of contemporary music. When Mr. Schuller decided to bring out a complete survey of the Beethoven piano sonatas, it was because he had recruited a distinctive pianist with fresh insights into the works: Russell Sherman.
As another example, Peter Kermani and Susan Bush run both Albany Records, an independent label with 600 titles in its catalog that notably champions American music, and Albany Music Distributors, which handles some 90 smaller labels.
"The pullback at Tower Records really hurts us," Ms. Bush said recently. "Whatever we sold elsewhere, we could always count on a check from Tower to come in on the nose. That made for some semblance of cash flow." Ms. Bush is skeptical about the potential for the Internet as an alternative sales source. "Our perception is that many classical consumers are browsers, and older, and sometimes not even computer-literate," she said. "We sometimes put out only 200 copies of a recording. But I'm convinced there are 200 people out there who will want it. We as an industry haven't come up with another way of reaching them." Though some traditional collectors may not like it, that way may have to be the Internet.
The entire classical recording field is about to be challenged again by the arrival of new digital recording technologies: SACD (super audio compact disc) and DVD audio, which, adherents assert, represent staggering improvements over existing CD recording technology. These formats can sample the musical signal -- the sound, that is -- 2.8 million times per second, 64 times the rate for existing CD's. Many audiophiles who find the sound of digital recordings too cold and clinical, and even those analog holdouts who prefer the sound of long-playing stereo records, are getting excited over the new technologies.
In the past, a breakthrough like this would quickly have triggered a huge conversion to the new technology among producers and consumers, just as happened 20 years ago when digital recording was introduced: suddenly the major companies had an excuse to rerecord the entire standard repertory in the new format. Consumers responded with a madcap dash to their local CD stores.
My guess is that this time consumers will not leap so quickly. The industry is too much in flux, the economy too worrisome. Besides, a format war is going on between the competing technologies, and discerning classical music lovers may wait to see who wins. And right now, for all the advances, it is hard to imagine any direct downloading technology that could accommodate these super discs, so crammed with data.
So what will happen? Certainly, online shopping sites will proliferate. But what about direct downloading? A similar uncertainty hangs over the world of printed media. Will computer books relegate printed books to the recycling bin? Will printed newspapers disappear, as more and more people get their daily news online?
In a sense, the musical equivalent of the computer book arrived 20 years ago with the CD, which is, after all, nothing but a plastic-coated floppy disk. Leaving aside the legal complications, the problem with downloading recordings at home is that the results in terms of audio fidelity are inadequate for classical music listeners, especially if you listen through high-quality speakers. Downloading a three-minute rock song is one thing; downloading a three-hour Verdi opera is another. It would consume hours of time and use scads of space on your hard drive. Even then, the sound would not be of high quality.
But eventually that will change. Superfast cable lines that replace telephone hookups are vastly improving the audio quality of downloaded music. Given more time, the industry will solve this problem.
There may also be a middle-ground solution: recording companies will be able to list their complete catalogs online, then take a single order for a particular recording and print out ("burning," it's called) a copy for the waiting consumer. Imagine the space saved in warehouses and retail stores.
Still, direct downloading is also coming, as long as ways can be found to protect artists and producers. Napster, in its anarchic way, provoked a crisis by insisting that downloaded music be free.

BUT freedom of a certain kind is an issue here. After all, some artists have no problem with their work's being circulated on the Internet free. They have determined that, for now, the benefits of exposure outweigh the financial sacrifice. Most newspapers and magazines have come to the same conclusion, at least for now, and offer online access to their publications free. Eventually fees will probably be charged. But not while we are still adjusting to the new online world.
If the classical recording business goes online, music lovers will miss collecting albums they can hold in their hands. We love the idea that all nine Mahler symphonies can fit into a little box on our shelves. It's still a kick to see the entire Callas discography on EMI, 30 complete operas and 17 discs of recitals and rarities, all lined up on two shelves in my living room. On the other hand, I hate looking at the stacks of CD's on the floor in my office. All that clutter could be cleared away if more recordings were made available online.
Music lovers will miss browsing, of course. In the 1980's, the Harvard Coop in Cambridge had a thriving classical music section. Everyone's favorite sales clerk was Pamela Dellal, an aspiring mezzo-soprano by night, the czarina of the Coop's classical department by day. Buyers could count on her for trustworthy recommendations. Ask Ms. Dellal which recording of Purcell's "Dido and Aeneas" to get, and she would persuade you to buy two.
Today the Harvard Coop's classical music department is a mere remnant of what it was; Ms. Dellal is a successful singer; and the Internet is here to stay. If we want classical recordings to survive, we may just have to embrace it.

HEADLINE: Sag Harbor Factory's Toxic Legacy Lingers 

BYLINE:  By PETER BOODY

DATELINE: SAG HARBOR 

 BODY:
BUILT in 1881 by the son-in-law of a whaler on the site of a cotton mill built by out-of-work whaling captains, the Bulova Watch Case building once anchored Sag Harbor's industrial economy. The largest factory in a village of factories, it gave Sag Harbor a blue-collar tinge that made it the "unHampton" even into the booming 1980's. 
 No one calls Sag Harbor the "unHampton" anymore. But in a village where lavish renovations have put a polish on scores of 19th-century houses in recent years, the Bulova plant stands an ugly contradiction, its gutters dangling and its windows broken. Lost under a tangled mantle of ivy is a sign that went up more than 20 years ago, proclaiming the building's renaissance as the Watchcase condominium complex. It faded to illegibility even before the ivy took over. 
 Another legacy of Sag Harbor's industrial past is to blame. For a century, workers poured waste water containing heavy metals from cleaning solvents into the building's drainage system. Despite several years of cleanup efforts, the soil and ground water around the building are still saturated with it. Until New York State removes the building and its grounds from its list of Superfund toxic waste sites, it can't be redeveloped. 
But after nearly 20 years of difficulty and delay, there are new hopes the cleanup will be complete soon and that by this time next year work may begin to convert the building into a posh, Tribeca-style condo with high-priced, high-ceilinged apartments accented by exposed brick and beams.
Most villagers are eager for the conversion to take place. "I think the whole thing is terrific," said Arleen Ball, a local real estate broker. "For years, all of us have looked at that sad building. Let's get on with it." She said the market for condos has been taking off in the Hamptons and that the Bulova units would be snatched up quickly.
Hundreds of Sag Harbor men and women used to work at Sag Harbor's factories, including the Grumman plant on Long Wharf, where components of the Apollo lunar lander were manufactured, and Rowe Industries on the Bridgehampton-Sag Harbor Turnpike, which made small electric motors for toys and toothbrushes.
Patrick E. Malloy, a local entrepreneur, converted the former Grumman property into a retail mall, restaurant and marina in the late 1970's. Rowe Industries, now known as Sag Harbor Industries and owned by Kraft foods, is the only site in the village still devoted to industrial use. It too is a Superfund toxic waste site. A cleanup, paid for by Nabisco -- a subsidiary of Kraft that bought the property -- is just getting under way.
But the Bulova plant, on Washington Street a block east of downtown Main Street, was the biggest of Sag Harbor's factories. Generations of local men and women worked there beginning in 1881, when Joseph Fahys, a German immigrant, married a local woman and moved his watch-making business from Queens to Sag Harbor. He was asked to do so by local business leaders, most of them former whalers or their sons, after the cotton mill they had built on the site burned down. They had begun transporting cotton with their whaling ships in the 1860's after petroleum replaced whale oil as the nation's primary fuel and lubricant.
Bulova bought the factory from the Fahys heirs in 1936 and closed its operation there in 1981. In 1984 the building's next owners made a deal to sell the property to Mr. Malloy.
The deal hit a brick wall when Mr. Malloy's agents discovered that the ground inside the factory's courtyard was saturated with heavy metals, including mercury and arsenic. He reported those findings to the state Department of Environmental Conservation and the federal Environmental Protection Agency.
It took a year and a half, Mr. Malloy said in a recent interview, for the E.P.A. and D.E.C. to decide which of them would have jurisdiction. It took the state another two years to decide how the cleanup should proceed, he added. And it took a lawsuit, filed by Mr. Malloy and the original developers, before Bulova agreed to pay for the cleanup, which didn't get fully under way until the mid-1990's, according to Ray Cowen, regional director of the D.E.C.
Meanwhile, Watchcase Factory Associates, which bought the building from Bulova for an undisclosed sum, remains the owner. Mr. Malloy remains the contract vendee. He, in turn, has a contract to sell the site and its zoning approvals to a group headed by Robert Gladstone, a New York businessman. Neither will discuss the selling price.
In May, all the interested parties and the state agreed on an outline that makes clear how the property can be "delisted" as a toxic waste site, said Randolph Croxton, the New York architect for the Gladstone partnership. "There are no ambiguous, open-ended things," he said.
The key to the building's restoration remains its delisting. Completing that process soon "is certainly the hope of all the parties, including me," Mr. Cowen said. But he warned that "any time you're dealing with environmental contamination, you're dealing with the unknown." Gases produced by the polluted soil and ground water are still collecting inside the building and remain at unacceptable levels for residential uses, he said.
A soil vapor extraction system was operated on the site for several years in the 1990's at Bulova's expense, and for a brief time it appeared to solve the vapor problem, Mr. Cowen said. But subsequent testing showed that air pollution levels were on the rise again inside the building.
More tainted soil must be removed, a process that should take only a few weeks. Another process, called soil sparging, in which air is forced into ground water to make it bubble and release gases, will take months. It must be conducted until the air quality in the building remains acceptable for full-time habitation, and no one knows for sure how long that will take, Mr. Cowen said.
There is also an emerging question about who will have the right to develop the site. In the 17 years since Mr. Malloy signed a contract to buy the Bulova plant, and the two years since he agreed to sell it to the Gladstone group, real estate prices have skyrocketed.
Mr. Malloy indicated that he and Mr. Gladstone's Madison Equities, which has been building commercial real estate in New York for 40 years, may be headed for a court fight. "There were various time frames and conditions" in their contract, he said, and "we believe they have all passed and they have not closed. It's up in the air whether or not they can close at any time." Now there are "notices going back and forth" between the two sides, he added.
Mr. Gladstone asserted that "there is a contract. All of his people are speaking to my people; they clearly recognize it."
Although Mr. Gladstone thinks the property could be developed successfully as a luxury hotel, which he proposed informally last November only to meet with some local resistance, he sees a loft-style condominium project as a valuable addition to Sag Harbor as well.
"It would probably be the only lofts available on the East End," he said. "Sag Harbor has been the most dramatically changed of all the East End communities in the last 25 years, generally for the better. It has kept its character and somehow you don't feel it's a snobby part of the Hamptons. We're banking on the fact that a lot of people will become permanent residents, young and old, and people in the arts." 

GRAPHIC: Photos: Once an anchor of Sag Harbor's industrial economy, the Bulova Watch Case building faces a new life as condominiums, after a toxic cleanup is completed. (Doug Kuntz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A LA CARTE; 
Tastes of Istanbul Settle in Glen Cove

BYLINE:  By RICHARD JAY SCHOLEM; E-mail: licarte@nytimes.com

 BODY:
ASIDE from a picture or two in the rest rooms there are no figs at the two-month-old Wild Fig Turkish Restaurant in Glen Cove. But there are Turkish waitresses in the dining room, Turkish food and wine on the tables, Turkish music in the air and photographs of old Istanbul and handmade Turkish tiles on the walls.
 The extensive menu (mezzes, salads, kebabs, fish, steak, chops, combination plates, pides, specialties, smoothies, desserts) at this sparkling, spacious new storefront at 167 Glen Street (516-656-5645) features simple, super-fresh food, most of it quite good. 
 A roaring wood-burning pizza oven and a row of benches covered with Turkish prayer rugs are at the entrance to Wild Fig. The high-ceilinged dining room with its colorful tile borders, panels and columns, cylindrical blue candleholders and floor-to-ceiling windows is a bright, sunny, cheerful place. 
Rounds of billowing, blistered Turkish pita bread appear moments after patrons are seated and keep coming until dessert time.
Despite a crass neon arrow pointing to its takeout counter, the Wild Fig is a bit more elaborate and expensive than some modest neighborhood Turkish spots, yet still in the economy class. Entrees are less costly than they seem ($9 to $19). They come with vegetables, rice, tomato, onion and yogurt sauces and a choice of soup or salad. The Greek salad, with its mantle of shredded feta cheese, tangy Kalamata olives, hot pickled peppers and superior olive oil dressing, is a cut above most throw-ins, though the usual canned peas and carrots and nondescript rice are less than exciting.
Most mezzes, or appetizers, can (and should) be ordered as part of a sampler platter (four for $9.95, eight for $19.95). The creamy, mild tarma salad, or Turkish caviar, spicy tomato spread with its welcome zing, soothing roasted eggplant salad and tasty mayonnaise-free cubed potato salad with onions and parsley in a lemon and olive oil marinade were especially noteworthy. Use your flat bread to sop, soak and scoop.
Say yes to the boat-shaped brick-oven pides ($8 to $10), or Turkish oven-baked pizzas. Sufficient for four to six eaters, they are super starters. The kashar cheese version ($8) is an appealingly seasoned, light, cheesy, tomato-flecked delight. Also recommended, though not quite as enthusiastically, is lamajun ($8.95), a crisp, though malleable, paper-thin pizza-like possibility sprinkled with minced meat, onion, parsley and sumac that can be rolled into it. Unfortunately, that minced beef doesn't have the spice kick it should and is but one example of the Wild Fig playing it safe, perhaps concerned that Americans might not appreciate the robust seasonings and heady flavors of authentic Turkish cooking. 
In the same category was pureed, though pallid, yellow lentil soup ($2.25) that was resuscitated by three or four shakes of salt, bland babaganoush ($4.50) and two skewers of adama kebab ($11) that needed more vivid seasoning.
Shrimp and flat fish, delivered sizzling hot on metal platters, suffered no such fate. A delicate, easy-to-overcook flounder ($13) was perfectly prepared and served in a tomato and onion sauce that had a sweet, though not unpleasant underpinning. A fine, flaky, full-of-flavor Chilean sea bass ($14), with its ends just a touch overdone, was close behind, and five truly jumbo shrimp ($14), swimming in an oniony tomato sauce, was a dish I'd order again. So was the tender, medium-rare barbecued Romanian skirt steak ($13.50) and the Mediterranean salad crowned with either firm grilled shrimp ($12), a skewer of moist chicken kebab ($9) or a generous tangle of boldly seasoned gyro ($9).
Desserts ($2 to $3), from a bakery in Brooklyn, are the expected sweet, honey-soaked, nut-studded and stuffed crew. The kadaif, a feathery shredded-wheat pastry wrapped around a honeyed ground walnut filling, is probably the best of the predictable bunch. Instead, drink your dessert by ordering a fresh fruit or vegetable juice or smoothie ($2.50 to $3) served in a tall, slim, graceful Pilsner-like glass. These orange, banana, berry, pineapple, mango, carrot and yogurt combinations taste as good as they look.

Openings
Next month when the four DeNicola brothers (Leo, Douglas, James and Joseph) open Ruvo, a 50-seat Italian restaurant at 63 Broadway in Greenlawn (631-261-7700), their grandmother's recipes will be in the kitchen and their father's art will be on the walls.
Ruvo, named for a town south of Naples that is the family's ancestral home, has been constructed with the beams, floors and walls from an upstate barn owned by the DeNicolas' uncle. Their country-Italian restaurant, featuring Tuscan and Southern Italian dishes, will offer fresh, local produce and game at entree prices in the $12 to $19 range.
James DeNicola will preside in the dining room, while his brother Joseph will be the executive chef. 

Potpourri
Stresa, at 1524 Northern Boulevard, in Manhasset (516-365-6956), is holding a fund-raiser for the victims of the World Trade Center tomorrow from 6 to 10 p.m. The four-course, $80 dinner that includes wine begins with a one-hour cocktail hour.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME; 
Contracts Are Hard To Break

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
IF there is one thing a real estate lawyer dreads, it is hearing a client under contract to buy or sell a house or apartment utter the words: "I've changed my mind. Get me out of this deal."
 The reason for the discomfort is not that real estate lawyers are skittish about engaging in legal skirmishes, but that most are not inclined to fight battles they are likely to lose. And trying to get a client out of a well-drafted real estate contract, lawyers say, is often a losing battle. 
 "Whenever a client comes to me and says 'I can't go through with this deal,' " said Eric Gonchar, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, "the first thing I'll usually say is, 'This is not going to be easy.' " 
Indeed, Mr. Gonchar said, since the primary goal of both buyers and sellers negotiating a real estate contract in good faith is to arrive at an agreement that neither party can break, a well-drafted contract will keep the parties in the deal until the property changes hands for the agreed-upon price. 
"Litigation for breach of a real-estate contract can take years to resolve," Mr. Gonchar said. "And it usually ends up costing both sides lots of money." 
Felix Nihamin, a Manhattan real estate lawyer who also practices in New Jersey, said that in most cases, real estate contracts contain provisions -- typically referred to as "contingencies" -- that allow one party or the other to back out of the deal, usually without penalty, under certain circumstances. For example, he said, most contracts are contingent upon the purchaser's obtaining a commitment for a mortgage within a specific period of time. If the buyer cannot obtain the commitment within that time -- after having made a good faith effort to do so -- then either party generally has the right to cancel the contract. 
Another common contingency found in contracts for the sale of a home in New Jersey, Mr. Nihamin said, permits the buyer to have the house inspected to determine whether it has any serious structural or mechanical defects. (In New York and Connecticut, such issues are often addressed before the contract is signed.) In most cases, the buyer will then be able to get out of the deal if the inspection reveals serious problems and the seller declines to either remedy them or adjust the price.
Yet another contingency -- one commonly found in sales contracts for co-op apartments -- is a provision that conditions the sale upon approval by the co-op's board. If the board does not give the approval, Mr. Nihamin said, both parties are relieved of their obligations under the contract. 
"In most cases, the only way out of a contract is if a contingency has not been met," Mr. Nihamin said, adding, however, that it may be possible for a party to get out of a contract if circumstances change significantly after a contingency has been met.
For example, he said, if a buyer loses a job -- or a substantial portion of his or her income -- after a mortgage commitment has been issued, the lender is likely to withdraw the commitment. And while the seller's lawyer could claim that once the commitment had been accepted by the buyer, the contingency had been satisfied, Mr. Nihamin said he believes the change in circumstances may provide a sufficient basis for the buyer to get out of the contract. 
"Within the past month alone, I've gotten three clients out of contracts because of a change in financial circumstances," Mr. Nihamin said, referring to clients who lost all or much of their income as a result of the World Trade Center disaster.
It might also be possible for a buyer to get out of a contract or at least renegotiate its terms if the amount the property is appraised for is reduced after the commitment has been issued and the commitment is conditioned on the original appraisal. 
"I had one deal where the appraisal on a property was reduced by 10 percent," he said, adding that in this case, rather than attempt to cancel the deal, the buyer requested a reduced purchase price, and the seller agreed to it. 
In most cases, however, buyers or sellers who try to wriggle their way out of a real estate sales contract want to do so for more practical reasons: the buyer has found a better house at a better price; the seller has found a buyer willing to pay more money; or one or the other has simply changed his or her mind. 
Scott Konner, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that when a buyer or seller decides to back out of a contract for no legitimate reason, the terms of the contract itself generally dictate what happens next. And most real estate contracts used in New York usually treat defaulting buyers differently than defaulting sellers. 
"In my opinion, Rule No. 1 is that every real estate contract should provide that the total liability of the buyer in the event of a default is the amount of the buyer's deposit," he said, referring to the 10 percent deposit typically paid at the time a contract is signed. Such a provision, also known as a "liquidated damages clause," basically specifies the amount of money that the seller is entitled to if the buyer defaults.
Mr. Konner explained that some contracts -- particularly those used by developers marketing new properties -- may contain a provision giving the seller the right to demand what is known as "specific performance" on the part of the buyer. This means that instead of keeping the buyer's deposit, the seller can instead insist the buyer "specifically perform" the contract by going through with the sale. Generally speaking, Mr. Konner said, if a buyer's lawyer insists that the specific performance provision be taken out of the contract, the seller will usually comply because the courts are quite reluctant to hold a buyer to specific performance. 
On the other hand, Mr. Konner said, buyers generally want the right to demand specific performance from the seller and courts are typically inclined to grant it.
"When you're a seller, you can't just walk away from the deal," he said, explaining that under New York law a buyer is usually entitled to specific performance from the seller even if the contract does not explicitly provide for it. There are certain circumstances, however, where the seller may be able to get out of a contract. For example, Mr. Konner said, when there is a problem with the title to a property that the seller cannot resolve, most contracts allow him to back out of the deal.
Just being legally entitled to demand a defaulting buyer's deposit if you're a seller -- or a defaulting seller's specific performance if you're a buyer -- does not provide any guarantee that either will be easy to get. 
Dennis Greenstein, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that regardless of whether it is the buyer or seller who is in breach of the contract, -- it is generally a court that will end up as the final arbiter of the dispute. And that, he said, often makes it more economical for the parties to work out their differences themselves. 
"The time involved, the cost involved and the uncertainty of the outcome make settling a dispute in court a risky proposition for both parties," Mr. Greenstein said. "So if there is a way for the parties to come to an agreement both sides can live with, that's probably going to be the best possible outcome."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Business Seeks Youth. The Young Seek Housing.

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH; E-mail: libiz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
BRIAN POTTS, 25, lives with his parents in East Islip, in the bedroom where he grew up. It's not his ideal living situation, said Mr. Potts, a video technician who works for Hofstra University. "I could move into a fraternity house near Hofstra," he said. "But I know how the guys live there, and it isn't for me."
 Mr. Potts also does after-hours video work in Manhattan, but his income still falls short of what he needs to rent his own place. As for finding a roommate through a newspaper ad, that's something he rejects as too risky. Meanwhile, the daily commute from East Islip to Hempstead is wearing him out. 
 "I would love to live in a nice, quiet community near where I work, where I wouldn't have to worry about my car being broken into," he said. "But I look at ads and I can't afford it."
Amy Shipman, 22, is preparing to graduate in December from St Joseph's College in Patchogue, where she majors in mathematics and computer science. An intern with Symbol Technologies, she hopes the Holtsville wireless technology giant makes her an employment offer soon. She too lives with her parents, in Ronkonkoma, and expects that's where she'll stay for at least another two years.
"I'd love to move out the day I graduate, but I have to save money," Ms. Shipman said. "Eventually, I'd like to buy a condo." 
Meanwhile she scouts the apartment ads in places like Phoenix.
"The difference in price is phenomenal," she said, comparing housing markets. "In Suffolk, I'm looking at paying $1,000 a month for a one-bedroom. In Phoenix, I get a two-bedroom for $600. That includes swimming pool and gym."
The availability of housing for young people is a perennial problem here. Housing experts say that slandwide the average one-bedroom apartment rents for $1,003, two-bedrooms for $1,230 -- more than most entry-level workers can afford. While some 20- and 30-somethings accept cramped lodgings in undesirable neighborhoods, most chose to continue living under the parental roof, or move somewhere else entirely.
"Living at home is what I'd call the Long Island young adult syndrome," Mr. Potts mused.
That problem is attracting increasing attention these days from Long Island's business and community leaders, who fear that the housing crunch faced by young workers may hurt the region's economic vibrancy and competitiveness. Long Island lost 6 percent of its 20- to 44-year-old population during the 1990's, according to census data, and business and civic leaders -- many of them parents whose own children are priced out of the market -- are stepping up efforts to broaden the region's housing supply.
While many concentrate their efforts mainly on price, others are focused on expanding the range of housing options. Their efforts are encouraging renovation of over-the-store apartments in downtown areas, lobbying local governments to ease up on restrictions against rental units within private homes, and pushing for development of low- and moderately-priced housing in the form of condominiums, rental units and mixed-use communities.
Housing advocates say that more business leaders are joining their coalitions. Developers say that there is slowly growing acceptance of projects calling for mixed-use, denser housing. Some of the projects, including a Long Island Housing Partnership project underway in downtown Bay Shore, are putting up the kind of multidweller rental units close to downtown that many single young professionals find appealing and that Long Island civic groups often find appalling.
Earlier this year, the housing partnership knocked down about eight acres of blighted housing in downtown Bay Shore and is constructing 78 units, about a third of which will be rentals, said James Morgo, the group's president. He said the project exemplified the kind of mixed-use development Long Island needs.
"We're mixing owners with renters, we're rehabilitating a downtown area, and the housing is near public transportation," Mr. Morgo said. "It's already attracting a broad range of younger workers."
Businesspeople are increasingly joining established coalitions of social advocates, clergy, government agency representatives and labor leaders in promoting mixed-use housing developments encompassing lower-priced residences, stores and work sites. Most try to blend owner-occupied with rental units.
"It's not just an issue about the homeless anymore," said Edward Hernandez, a housing advocate and chairman of the board of directors of the Nassau-Suffolk Coalition for the Homeless. Several weeks ago, Mr. Hernandez organized a strategic planning session around affordable housing that drew notables from private industry, banking, health care, public schools, construction and government.
"Everybody has a story where the kids go away to college and when they graduate, they can't find a place on Long Island to rent," Mr. Hernandez said. "The lack of affordable housing hits home in every community."
During the summer, the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington, D.C., research center, released a report naming Long Island the most expensive housing market in the country. A study released recently by the National Low Income Housing Coalition, also in Washington, ranks Long Island among the nation's five most expensive rental markets.
Last month in Farmingdale, at a discussion on high-tech business issues hosted by Polytechnic University's Wireless Innovation Program, executives from three companies listed employee recruitment and retention as the major growth impediment they faced, and linked those concerns directly to housing.
High-tech companies find it difficult to recruit graduates of schools from other areas, the executives agreed, and put the blame largely on housing costs. Most recruiting is done among local graduates, said Phil McLaughlin, one of the panelists. The executives on the panel acknowledged that the practice narrows the region's talent and knowledge pool, and undermines Long Island's ambitions as a center of high-tech innovation.
"There's a real fear that when you hire someone and train him, he is going to leave after a few years, perhaps relocating to another region where there's a higher concentration of high-tech businesses," said Mr. McLaughlin, the vice president and a general manager at EEG Enterprises, a video technology company in Farmingdale. "As a result, we've staffed up with somewhat older people, in their 30's and 40's, who are perhaps less likely to relocate. But that means we're not getting the younger engineers who are enormously productive and who work at lower salaries."
And, he might have added, have the most up-to-date training in emerging technologies.
Long Island's housing stock is about 80 percent single homes, one of the highest percentages in the country, said Matthew T. Crosson, president of the Long Island Association. Most of that housing excludes younger workers not only financially, but in terms of lifestyle.
"Few young people, if any, leave college and buy a single-family house," Mr. Crosson said. "Our region's most pressing need is for rental apartments for young people. In order for us to have the work force we need in the future, we must keep younger people here. That will not happen unless they have attractive places to live." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Phil McLaughlin, vice president of EEG Enterprises in Farmingdale, says there is a fear of hiring and training young people because they might take their skills elsewhere. (Phil Marino for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: How's Business? Terrorist Acts Deal a Blow To the Economy 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON

 BODY:
ON the surface, little has changed in Westchester since Sept. 11.
 Talk on the street has largely returned to the weather, the traffic and the Yankees. If it weren't for the headlines and the flapping flags on car windows, one might not know the nation is at war. 
 But the county's economic landscape has been scarred. The impact of the terrorist attacks can be seen on the merchandise racks and ledger sheets of chain stores, in the pockets of the sidewalk merchant and in the the county treasury. 
News of the attacks initially paralyzed an already declining economy. Some businesses have since rebounded, but many remain weak, from those in the travel-related industry to those that supply Manhattan restaurants.
Some companies have found ways to increase business by tapping into new national currents, including patriotism, fear and sympathy.
Real estate brokers are getting calls from Manhattanites seeking to flee Ground Zero. Niche businesses, like those that sell gas masks and security systems, are prospering.
And there are others, including a man in a wheelchair who for years has sold lollipops on Main Street in White Plains. Now he hawks miniature American flags and key chains. He buys them in bulk in his hometown, Yorktown Heights, and sells them for $2 apiece on the sidewalks of the busy cities down county. 
At the B. Dalton bookstore in The Westchester mall, the display racks near the checkout counter are lined with books on germ warfare, Osama bin Laden and the New York City skyline. Next to a "Halloween Hits" CD is the paperback version of "The Worst Case Scenario Survival Handbook."
Nearby in the mall, a store called The Game Keeper has been briskly selling war games and any other board games vaguely related to the war on terrorism. Old classics, like Axis & Allies, Risk and Stratego are hot, as is New York Chase, which pits a fugitive against New York police detectives and whose box features the World Trade Center.
"This is going to be a big year for us," said James Stone, the store manager. "People want something to keep their mind off all this mess."
But some people cannot manage that. Alex Philippidis, editor in chief of The Westchester County Business Journal, said he has seen a malaise among business leaders.
"We're physically the same, at least until they say 'Ration this and ration that,' but emotionally something has changed," he said. "There is fear in the business world. People are emotionally frayed and that spills over into their business."
Paul Rutkowski, a massage therapist from White Plains, has canceled many appointments. At the counter of the Corner Nook coffee shop recently, while many customers sat reading war headlines, Mr. Rutkowski, who is blind, patted his guide dog and made cell phone calls to customers telling them he had to cancel because his "energy is really down these days."
The sharp drop-off in business in New York City, whether in dining, entertainment or tourism, has had a ripple effect that hurts business in Westchester, said Salvatore J. Carrera, the county's director of economic development and real estate.
"Everybody's hurting," he said. "This touches every industry in the county, from the freelance photographer who could always rely on steady work in the city, to the baker delivering bread to city restaurants that are no longer getting business."
The disaster will ultimately cost the county government many millions of dollars, he said, from the expense of sending assistance teams to the city after the attacks to the $7.25 million the county plans to spend outfitting many of its buildings with new security systems.
But, Mr. Carrera vowed: "We're already coming back. We're trying to make small business owners aware of small business loans and other incentive plans, like sales tax abatements for upgrading your office equipment."
Certain niche industries, he added, have been faring better than usual, including answering the demand for gas masks and other military paraphernalia.
"Army surplus supply stores are doing bang-up business, more than they ever anticipated," he said, adding that security companies are also benefiting from fear of further terrorist attacks.
Since Sept 11, the demand for security systems for commercial and residential properties has "increased on a daily basis," said Howard L. Shapiro, a sales manager for ADT Security in Elmsford, a branch of the national company.
The branch handles residential and commercial alarm systems, including closed circuit television.
"It's unfortunate because of the human tragedy that we have gotten some more business from the disaster," he said, adding that "security has been escalated to a major concern at small businesses, everything from jewelry stores to restaurants.
"With all the talk about what may occur, people are more aware of who's next to them or around them," Mr. Shapiro said. He would not name his clients, but he said that ADT has provided security for "some of the core commercial buildings and banks and department stores in the county."
"Department stores and malls here are frightened that something is going to happen," he said. "They're more aware of the importance of security and they're looking toward systems of one type or another to secure their premises."
Similarly, there is general insecurity in many business circles, said Mr. Philippidis. The week of the collapse, he had scheduled about six business networking events to cover, he said. All were canceled.
"As insensitive an observation as it is, the collapse in the business world was bad timing," he said. "The economy was slipping already. Usually by the second week in September, business begins to take off around here. Children are back in school and the business community is back in full swing.
"We had a lot of national chains coming into Westchester, but now you got to wonder."
But Mr. Carrera said the county was optimistic about getting back on its path to "an economic renaissance." The disaster, he said, has caused an apprehension about living and working in Manhattan, which could wind up bringing business and new residents to Westchester.
"You hate to think of benefiting from a disaster like this, but we'll see an increased activity here in residential and commercial property, and it will happen naturally."
He did admit that the county missed one opportunity after the collapse. County officials were hoping that some companies displaced from the World Trade Center would rent office space in Westchester. The county immediately set up a clearinghouse, offering to companies the large blocks of office space available here, some as big as 700,000 square feet. But county officials were disappointed: there were virtually no takers.
"There were no major signed deals Westchester could beat its breast about," said Mr. Carrera, who still holds out hope.
Because of convenience, many companies moved to New Jersey and to space in Midtown Manhattan recently vacated by failed dot-com companies, Mr. Carrera said.
But other companies did look to the suburbs for offices. American Express and Citicorp, for example, took offices in the Stamford area. Mr. Carrera attributed this to the fact that many of the top executives live there.
He called many of these decisions snap judgments and short-term arrangements. Once the companies eventually "come to their senses," he said, they could well choose to set up offices in Westchester.
Robert T. Guerra, manager of The Westchester mall said that "sales are very strong" at the mall, which closed for the day on Sept. 11 and suffered for days afterward.
"It was a tough week," he said. "People were glued to their TV's. But we've seen an increase, and sales are picking up." The cooler weather has brought customers back school shopping, he said.
"We had a good Columbus Day and the weekends have been strong," he said. Retailers are optimistic about the holiday season, which the mall ushers in by mid-November with holiday decorations and a live Santa Claus.
Many mall merchants, however, said that customer traffic has declined, and there are more items on sale.
Mr. Guerra insisted that business is as strong as ever. Three major companies, he said, are planning to open stores before the holidays: an Elizabeth Arden spa, an Aveda store and a Victorinox store.
Mitchell C. Hochberg, president and chief executive officer of Spectrum Skanska, the largest home builder in Westchester, said that the number of people looking to buy homes dipped the first couple of weeks after Sept. 11, but has since rebounded.
"It's not the way it used to be," he said, "but over the last five years we had a market that was unusually intoxicated." His company has shown homes to a handful of New York City residents.
"They were visibly upset and felt they needed to get out of Manhattan," he said. "They were couples who were very panicked and said, 'We need to move out of New York.' "
Spectrum Skanska has recently completed two residential communities -- the BelleFair in Rye Brook and the Legends at Purchase -- and sold all the units there.
Melissa L. Cohn, who owns Manhattan Mortgage, a large New York-based company with a branch in Purchase, said that because interest rates are so low, "the Westchester market has been on fire" for the past month. Neither war nor rumors of war stop people from house hunting, she said.
"It's business as usual," she said. "People are still marrying, still having kids. What do you expect? You can't put your child in the bathtub."
Nancy Kennedy, a real estate broker who handles northern Westchester, said that even a slowing economy cannot seriously weaken the Westchester real estate market because there are always plenty of prospective buyers vying for a limited inventory of properties.
But when the stock market drops, she added, so do sales of high-end homes, because buyers no longer rolling high choose more modest homes.
"People may be nervous about the market, or they may not have the down payment they had six months to a year ago," said Ms. Kennedy, who works at the Coldwell Banker Perry Kennedy firm in Croton-on-Hudson. Also, she said, people are delaying plans to "trade up," or sell their homes to buy more expensive ones.
"Right after the collapse, things were paralyzed, but over the past two weeks, we're seeing more listings," she said. "People are deciding they have to get on with their lives, and they know that interest rates are phenomenally low right now."
Since Sept. 11, she said, many of her prospective buyers are Manhattan residents seeking to move to Westchester.
"We had a lot of people calling saying things like, 'I want to get out of the city now,' " she recounted. "They were saying, 'I've been thinking about this for a long time, and I want it to happen.' "
Bruce J. Gold, co-owner of Gold Service Movers in White Plains, tells a story about meeting with a customer near Canal Street the morning of the attack. When the planes struck, Mr. Gold fled north and watched the towers burn in his rear-view mirror while driving along the West Side Highway.
"I'll never forget that sight," said Mr. Gold, who has had less luck escaping the aftermath of the disaster.
He has a 20-truck fleet and a steady base of customers. He does not lack for work, he said. But much of his business involves moving clients to or from the city. With the police inspecting trucks at most bridges, his trucks are facing delays. It often takes twice as long to do a given job now, he said.
"It takes four hours to go from Queens to White Plains," he said. "The customer doesn't want to pay for the delay, and my workers get paid by the hour, so it hurts."
Also hurting is Westchester County Airport. After Sept. 11, commercial airlines there could barely sell tickets. Now, business is rebounding slowly, but airport businesses are still suffering. 
For example, you often have your choice of tables at the Skytop Restaurant, which overlooks the runways. The snack bar and newspaper stands get little traffic and there are rarely lines at car rental counters.
The county's airport limousine industry is also suffering. There are roughly 200 licensed companies operating car services in Westchester, with 4,000 cars and 4,000 chauffeurs, said Rich J. Guberti, vice chairman of the Westchester Taxi and Limousine Commission. 
Mr. Guberti said that many companies are ready to declare bankruptcy and others are applying for emergency business loans.
"The first three weeks, business was down 90 percent," Mr. Guberti said. He recently laid off half his staff at Excel Transportation, the large limousine service he owns in New Rochelle. "We are completely dependent upon air travel," he explained. "We're basically airlines on wheels.
"For the past 20 years, we've been taking in $5 million," he said. "Even being optimistic, we'd be lucky if we break $2 million this year."
Referring to the aftermath of the terrorist attacks, he said: "It's not only us. All business in Westchester is hostage to this situation."
A lingering fear of flying plagues travel agencies also. Many smaller companies are finding it harder to keep their offices open and have merged with other agencies. For example, many have joined Rich Worldwide Travel, one of the largest agencies in the county with branches in Harrison and Somers.
"After the attacks, business totally dropped off; no one would go anywhere," said Nathan Devore, co-president of Rich Worldwide. "Even now, most customers will only take domestic flights, not overseas.
"They don't want to be so far away from home," Mr. Devore said, adding that customers will only book a trip "as long as they can get in a car and drive home" if they have to.
To offset slumping business, the company is using promotions and bargains for local trips, including theme weekends in the Poconos, rafting trips in Vermont and overnight visits to the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown. There are half-price specials at the Canyon Ranch in Lenox, Mass.
With fewer corporate employees willing to fly, the agency has begun arranging local hotel rentals that offer teleconferencing.
"Let's just say we're looking forward to ski season," Mr. Devore said, adding that terrorism has reduced prices on certain trips.
"You want a room in Manhattan? I can get it cheap."
