HEADLINE: Eager To Seize The Power 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA FITZGERALD

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
AS autumn leaves litter walkways and mild breezes give way to brisk dawns, there is another unmistakable sign that a change of seasons is upon the State House: the steady buzz of resumes grinding through fax machines.
 For the first time since the 1989, an incumbent governor in New Jersey is not waging a campaign to remain in office, leaving a power vacuum that will quickly begin to fill up after the November election. It will signal a clear change in the way business is conducted -- who is important, who is not and who will get the lucrative state contracts. 
 The shift in power, through a reshuffling of the governor and his cabinet, will also prompt a change in priorities and in the personalities who will pursue them during an unenviable time when tax revenue is dropping and budget deficits appear on the horizon.
Aside from the usual duties the governor's commissioners will face, those serving in a new administration will also be confronted by the daunting task of dealing with homeland security, terrorist threats and the rapid response to possible attacks while at the same time maintaining the public confidence and keeping the state's economy on a stable course. 
Some fear that a cabinet under Bret D. Schundler, the former mayor of Jersey City, will be stacked with conservative Republicans who are not very reflective of the moderate base of the party in the state. Others say the cabinet of James E. McGreevey, the mayor of Woodbridge, will be controlled not only by Mr. McGreevey but also by the Democratic power brokers who are playing a leading role in his campaign.
Among those who are helping to call the shots are the handful of party apparatchiks who prevented Senator Robert G. Torricelli from wrenching the Democratic nomination from Mr. McGreevey last year.
The top advisors in Mr. McGreevey's campaign include his political mentor, State Senator John Lynch; Senate Minority Leader Richard Codey; George Norcross, the Camden County Democratic chairman; and Mayor Sharpe James of Newark.
"There is going to be a key group of players that will remind McGreevey on a daily basis that if it weren't for them, he wouldn't be sitting in the governor's chair," one political observer noted. "They may demand a bigger hand in how things get done."
Tom Gallagher, the communications director for Mr. Schundler's campaign, said it was likely that Mr. McGreevey would be beholden to the special interests that have been financing his race and to the Democratic Party machine, which has been instrumental to his campaign.
But Richard McGrath, a spokesman for Mr. McGreevey, said such talk was unfounded.
"Jim McGreevey has always appointed the best and the brightest, and as governor he would do that with a completely open mind," Mr. McGrath said. "The perverse irony is that the Schundler campaign is making those types of predictions when they have two of the co-conspirators on the Parsons scandal ranking as top officials in their campaign."
Mr. McGrath was referring to the deal approved by the Republican-controlled Legislature to hire Parsons Infastructure and Technology Group to operate the state's auto emissions testing program. The arrangement was widely criticized by the State Commission of Investigation, which found that Parsons and its lobbyists manipulated the state's bidding process to win the contract. Dick Kamin, former director of the Division of Motor Vehicles, oversaw the contract, and Frank Holman, a former executive director of the Republican State Committee, was a lobbyist for Parsons. Mr. Kamin was named by Mr. Schundler as co-chairman of the Republican State Committee, and Mr. Holman has been a top adviser to the campaign.
"It's obvious that Mr. Schundler is very selective on his high-level appointments," Mr. McGrath said. "If he gets elected, New Jersey could expect that he would import the archconservatives that he resembles."
But Mr. Gallagher, the Schundler campaign spokesman, scoffed at the suggestion and said: "Bret Schundler is not beholden to any established political power structure, like the Democratic machine in New Jersey. His appointments would not be beholden to the decisions of the other politicians about who to have in his own administration."
Walter Fields, a consultant working for the Republicans and a former political director of the New Jersey chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said he had been impressed with the way Mr. Schundler had dealt with the diverse interests in Jersey City while mayor.
"He certainly has more experience governing a diverse community than Jim McGreevey, and no one can deny that," Mr. Fields said. "It could serve him well as governor of one of the most diverse states in the country."
No matter what the outcome, the result of this election will drastically alter the stature and structure of the Republican and Democratic parties in the state.
For the first time in a decade, Democrats are well poised to win one, if not all three, seats of government, paving the way for a few law firms and lobbyists to vault to center stage after sitting on the sidelines during the administration of Gov. Christie Whitman. There is a feeling of buoyant anticipation among the ranks of the Democratic Party, where talk of cabinet posts swirl through cocktail party conversations. 
Republicans are neither so united nor so exuberant. As a sign of the festering political wounds afflicting the party, some see a transition of power from Acting Gov. Donald DiFrancesco to Mr. McGreevey as much more friendly than if Mr. DiFrancesco is forced to turn over his office keys to Mr. Schundler.
That the Republicans currently hold the governor's office is of little help to Mr. Schundler. He has been unable or unwilling to appease Mr. DiFrancesco's anger at being left on the sidelines for the governor's race -- a contest in which Mr. DiFrancesco had envisioned himself as the featured star. Mr. DiFrancesco chose to withdraw from the primary amid a flurry of newspaper articles about his business dealings in the private sector, which he believed were fed to the media by Mr. Schundler.
The two men have not formally met since Mr. Schundler won the primary in June. Some within the Republican Party remain hopeful there will be an eventual endorsement from Mr. DiFrancesco, noting that he and Mr. Schundler were recently seen together at a Republican fund-raising event in Philadelphia and appeared friendly. But even if an endorsement does come, it may well be seen as almost meaningless at this late stage in the race. 
"What's weird is that a McGreevey election would not be a hostile takeover, but a Schundler victory almost would be a hostile takeover," said Jon J. Shure, president of New Jersey Policy Perspectives and once a spokesman for Gov. Jim Florio. "There's no doubt there would be more tension in that transition."
Mr. DiFrancesco denies such assertions, saying he will treat each candidate with the same respect, regardless of who wins the governor's race.
"A transition is really an institutional function; it's not about personalities," said Tom Wilson, a spokesman for Mr. DiFrancesco. "This office will be nothing but 100 percent helpful and supportive of whoever wins. They will be given the same level of help and assistance."
To be sure, a smooth transition is crucial, and to a large extent determines how effectively the new governor can operate early in his term.
"If McGreevey wins, I envision a transition to be the same as Byrne and Kean, which is friendly and which leads to early appointments and early information being exchanged," said Harold Hodes, a Democratic lobbyist who was chief of staff to Gov. Brendan Byrne.
Mr. Hodes explained that when the Republican Tom Kean took office, he had a strong relationship with his Democratic predecessor, Gov. Brendan Byrne. For example, Mr. Kean told Mr. Byrne what his preferences were on appointments and policies and that Mr. Byrne helped facilitate them during his final months in office.
With the arriving and departing governors at odds, however, all sorts of wild scenarios can be envisioned about what may happen and who may be appointed to various posts.
As a conservative, Mr. Schundler has rankled the more moderate wing of the Republican Party, causing some legislative candidates to distance themselves from his campaign. The lack of party cohesion, along with a newly drawn legislative district map favorable to Democrats, leaves the state Republican Party splintered and hoping to hang on to its thin majority in the Legislature. 
While Mr. McGreevey is fielding advice from all quarters of his party, Mr. Schundler's kitchen cabinet is somewhat small, reflective of the fact that he sees himself as an outsider with few ties to those in Republican power circles. He has not been particularly active in wooing any of the party stalwarts, preferring instead the renegade approach. Many say Mr. Schundler's wife, Lynne, plays a major advisory role at "Brettquarters" in West Orange along with two political veterans, Lawrence Bathgate II, a leading Republican fund-raiser in the state, and Mr. Kamin, the former head of the Department of Motor Vehicles.
What is certain is that either candidate will bring loyal aides along, those staff members who served them well during their years as mayors.
In Mr. McGreevey's case, it is virtually certain that Gary Taffet, his campaign manager and chief of staff during his first term as mayor of Woodbridge, will be named chief of staff.
"Their relationship is so close, it's like if you talk to Gary, you're talking to Jim," said one Democrat. 
As for Mr. Schundler, it is expected that Mr. Gallagher, a former chief of staff and currently communications director of his campaign, will join the staff at the governor's office should there be a Schundler victory. Mr. Gallagher, also served as communications director in Jersey City and was later named director of the Jersey City Department of Housing, Economic Development and Commerce.
Also being mentioned as a possible chief of staff to Mr. Schundler is Assemblyman Guy Gregg of Morris County, a longtime supporter who may seriously consider the job if Republicans lose their majority in the Assembly. Mr. Gregg is believed to prefer becoming majority leader of the Assembly should the Republicans maintain control of the lower chamber.
The chief of staff and chief counsel are two of the most important jobs in a new administration because they largely determine how friendly the relationship will be between the new governor and the Legislature. Mrs. Whitman's administration was sharply criticized -- particularly from those in her own party -- for not building a close relationship with lawmakers. Peter G. Verniero, whom she later named to the State Suprme Court, was chief counsel and later chief of staff to Mrs. Whitman, but he never cultivated a friendly relationship with the Legislature. That lack of warmth proved crucial when Mr. Verniero later came under fire for the way he handled the investigation into racial profiling as attorney general.
Names being tossed about as possible choices in a McGreevey cabinet include a variety of professionals and party stalwarts. Jeanne Fox, former regional head of the federal Environmental Protection Agency under President Bill Clinton and wife of Mr. McGreevey's political consultant Steve DeMicco, is considered a likely candidate for commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection. She served as acting commissioner in that post under Mr. Florio.
In addition, Tom Giblin, the former state Democratic chairman, is being talked about as a possible labor commissioner. It was Mr. Giblin who remained loyal to Mr. McGreevey during Senator Torricelli's short-lived challenge. 
Mr. McGrath and Jo Astrid Glading, who is Mr. McGreevey's rapid response guru and who worked on Mr. Florio's campaign, are likely to be offered jobs. Ms. Glading, a lawyer who works with Senate Demcrats, could be named as public advocate, a post dismantled by Mrs. Whitman but is to be re-established in a McGreevey administration. 
Joe Vas, the mayor of Perth Amboy, is being talked about as possible commissioner of the Department of Community Affairs in a McGreevey administration. Mr. Vas is the first Hispanic to serve as mayor of Perth Amboy and is prominent in the business community as the owner of a local travel agency and the chief executive of an insurance agency, R&J Associates.
Assemblywoman Bonnie Watson Coleman, an assemblywoman from Mercer County, is considered a serious contender for the post of secretary of state under Mr. McGreevey. Ms. Watson Coleman previously served as chief of staff to Mayor Doug Palmer of Trenton.
Others believe that the community affairs appointment may go to state Senator Wayne Byrant of Camden. Under that scenario, Assemblyman Joe Roberts would move over to the Senate to take Mr. Bryant's seat and Mrs. Watson Coleman would be considered a front-runner as chairwoman of the state Democratic Party.
Sharon Harrington, a partner in the lobbying firm Public Strategies Impact and a deputy campaign manager for Mr. Florio, is also being considered for a senior post. And Zulima Farber, a former public advocate and public defender for Mr. Florio and assistant counsel to Mr. Byrne, is considered a contender for the job of attorney general or chief counsel. 
One power couple likely to emerge in a McGreevey administration is Marianne Espinosa Murphy, a former Superior Court judge, and her husband, Michael Murphy, a former Morris County prosecutor who ran for governor in the Democratic primary in 1997. There are whispers that Mr. Murphy may be considered for the post of chief counsel or possibly for commerce commissioner. Mrs. Murphy is being suggested for a number of positions, including health commissioner.
There are at least three major law firms that are expected to do well in a McGreevey administration. Some of the lucrative contracts that an administration can dole out include legal work for the various state agencies like the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.
Partners from the firm of Wilentz, Goldman & Spitzer, founded in 1919 by David Wilentz, the famed prosecutor in the Lindbergh kidnapping trial, have been long been associated with Democratic campaigns, and Mr. McGreevey's would be no exception. Indeed, campaign finance records show the firm is a top contributor to Mr. McGreevey's campaign, with its lawyers having donated $199,400 so far. Barry Albin, a partner in the firm and a prominent attorney in Woodbridge, is considered a top contender for attorney general. 
Another law firm topping the list of favorites in a McGreevey administration is Scarinci & Hollenbeck. Donald Scarinci, managing partner of the firm and a Democratic fund-raiser, is close to Representative Bob Menendez and was a key figure in repelling Mr. Torricelli's bid to enter the governor's race. Co-counsel to the Democrats on the redistricting commission that yielded a map favorable to their party, he is also considered a candidate for attorney general.
A third law firm that will have close ties to a McGreevey administration is Sills, Cummis, Radin, Tischman, Epstein & Gross. Paul Josephson, a partner in the firm, has also been mentioned as a possible attorney general. Mr. Josephson was chief counsel to Mr. McGreevey in his 1997 gubernatorial bid, and he also was chief counsel to Mr. Torricelli in his 1996 Senate campaign. 
Mitch Ostrer, who until recently was of counsel to the firm of Sills, Cummis, Radin, Tischman, Epstein & Gross, is now working for the McGreevey campaign and has been mentioned as a possible chief of policy and planning.
As for Mr. Schundler, the law firm that stands to become the most influential is Bathgate, Wegener & Wolf, which has done work for Jersey City. Mr. Bathgate, a partner, is a close adviser to Mr. Schundler and has been a leading Republican fund-raiser in the state. He is a friend of President Bush and was one of the few in the party to back Mr. Schundler over former Congressman Bob Franks in the primary. Members of Mr. Bathgate's firm have given at least $61,000 to Mr. Schundler's campaign.
Others mentioned as potential powers in a Schundler administration include Brian McAlindin, the attorney for the campaign, as attorney general or chief counsel to Mr. Schundler. Bea Sena, a councilwoman from Fair Haven in Monmouth County, whom Mr. Schundler appointed co-chairwoman of the state committee, is also expected to be considered for a top post in a Schundler administration. Evan Kozlow, executive director of the state committee, and Joe Farren, its communications director, are also likely to be on a short list of those being considered to serve Mr. Schundler.
Having spent several years on Wall Street, Mr. Schundler has extensive contacts in the private sector and is expected to turn to the financial community to fill some cabinet positions.
Longtime political observers say that regardless of who is elected, any new administration will have to get up to speed quickly because of the rocky period just ahead.
"It's going to a difficult time for whoever the next governor is, from a financial standpoint," said Roger Bodman, a Republican lobbyist who was Governor Kean's commissioner of transportation.
For one thing, neither man has served in a statewide office.
As David Rebovich, a political science professor at Rider University, put it: "Schundler, who doesn't have a tremendous amount of support among his own party, might bring in newcomers to the state political scene, but there might be some anxiety about their knowledge and experience of state problems and the ability of cabinet-level officers to work with the legislators.
"With McGreevey," he added, "the problem will be to bring about a balance between the old Democratic guard coming to Trenton and the various groups that constitute his broad coalition. On the campaign, McGreevey has not felt the need to explain yet how those competing interests will get along, but in his administration he would have to explain to his cabinet that it has to be done, bruised egos and all."

HEADLINE: Preserving Data, and Businesses 

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
THE massive business disruptions caused by the attack on the World Trade Center have produced a surge of interest in backup power systems and redundant data centers, and may increase the appeal of suburban buildings that had been equipped or envisioned as telecommunications hubs before the "telco hotel" business grew bleaker.
 Large parts of lower Manhattan lost electrical power and telephone service as a result of the attacks, forcing companies to scramble to find places with functioning utilities to keep businesses in operation. Now that most have found emergency locations, they are seeking longer-term answers on how to cope with disasters, which by their nature are unpredictable. 
 Putting a backup data center or trading floor in New Jersey, which has the advantage of being on a different power grid than Manhattan, is not foolproof. As some real estate executives noted, the Lincoln and Holland tunnels were closed after the attack, which meant that banks and trading companies would have had a hard time getting computer tapes recording their most recent transactions to backup sites across the Hudson River. 
Operations that were heavily dependent on paper records, like insurance companies and law firms, may completely rethink how they store information, said Snezana Anderson, a managing director of Insignia/ESG, a big brokerage and services company based in New York.
"Law firms and insurance companies stored their records on the lower floors of the Trade Center," Ms. Anderson said. "That's where a lot of the paper you saw flying around came from."
She said it appeared that some companies and firms are likely to keep "some presence in New York, with a backup in New Jersey and another in some place like New Mexico where it won't draw the attention it would in a metropolitan area."
Convinced all along that many companies will need to keep at least their headquarters and substantial parts of their key operations in Manhattan, some landlords have invested heavily in systems that can keep their customers operating even if basic services fail. One such building is at 75 Broad Street, where two floors are dedicated to 25 diesel-engine powered generators (with room for 15 more) that can supply power independent of Consolidated Edison.
The windows of the 17th and 18th floors of the 33-story building have been replaced with louvers to draw in the air needed for combustion and to exhaust fumes. An 18-inch diameter pipe runs around the perimeter of one floor and delivers fuel to each engine. Since the pipe holds 8,000 gallons of fuel, the engines can be started immediately, without waiting for oil to be pumped up from the 32,000 gallons of reserves in the subbasement.
Although the building was completed in 1928, in some sense it was always a "telco hotel," since it was the headquarters of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. Today it has multiple telecommunication and data center tenants, although the cutbacks in the industry have left some spaces in the building vacant.
The building is far enough from the Trade Center that it was not immediately affected by the collapse of the buildings. "We are on the same electrical grid as the New York Stock Exchange, which is very carefully monitored by Con Ed," said Daniel M. Blanco, who is managing director for the building and other telecommunications centers owned by JEMB Realty.
"We were fine for the first 24 hours" after the attack, Mr. Blanco said. But he said that about 7 p.m. on Sept 12 he got a call from Con Ed executives, asking if the building could be disconnected from the grid so the power could be routed to areas of greatest need. "They said, 'You do not have to do this, but it would help a lot,' " Mr. Blanco said.
The request came at a time when Con Ed was taking the desperate step of running power cables along surface streets to bypass a substation damaged by the collapse of the Trade Center buildings.
He said that four 800-kilowatt Caterpillar generators were started to maintain basic building services uninterrupted once the links to Con Ed were switched off. In addition, some tenants, including AT&T, started their own generators to keep their communications networks operating.
AT&T, which had a lot of fiber connections destroyed by the collapse of the Trade Center buildings, quickly installed a microwave antenna on the roof of the building, shifting telecommunications traffic from wires in the ground to signals in the air. The antenna helped customers in the Wall Street area to keep operating after the cables were cut, an AT&T official said.
Staff members were in the building to help with the start-up, because, as a practical matter, if they had left the area they probably would not have been able to get back in, Mr. Blanco said. Even finding a place to eat was difficult. "We were going to Brooklyn to get food for people in the building," he said.
HAVING people in the building who could answer phones and provide answers was an important customer service, Mr. Blanco said, because many of the tenants' data-center and telecommunications operations are monitored remotely. "The calls started coming in right away" after the attack, said William G. Cohen, an executive vice president of Newmark & Company Real Estate, which represents JEMB Realty's multiple technology buildings. "Some guy in the Midwest saw the needles on his gauges jump. They were happy that there was a voice on the other end of the line who had answers."
Not all the calls were from far away. Lava Trading, a securities company, whose executive offices were on the 83rd floor of 1 World Trade Center, has an unmanned data center at 75 Broad. After the collapse of the buildings, executives of the company were assured that their system was still in operation as they scrambled to find a new place to conduct business.
The generators ran until the evening of Sept. 22, when normal electrical service was restored. The successful operation of 75 Broad during the disruption caused by the attack demonstrated the value of the $30 million the current ownership invested in it to become a technology center, Mr. Cohen said.
The generator farm and fuel tank are the most obvious part of this conversion, Mr. Cohen said, but planning where cables will be routed in the vertical shafts, known as risers, is important as well. "Most leases have provisions for installing cables, but most don't say anything about taking them out," Mr. Cohen said.
The result is a tangle of wires and cables in many buildings, some of them connected and some not. At 75 Broad, the location and use of each cable is planned in advance and recorded when installed, he said.
The changes amount to an "adaptive reuse" of an older building, taking advantage of its sturdy construction and its location, which is near many major fiber-optic cable lines. "Just about every major fiber provider passes by the front door," he said.
For others with operations downtown, plans made to deal with a problem that turned out not to be one -- the Y2K situation -- were ultimately quite useful after the Sept. 11 attack. Although the offices of CapitalThinking, a software company, are at 52 Vanderbilt Avenue in Midtown, its operation center was downtown at 25 Broadway.
Because of fears about problems with computers on Jan 1, 2000, Heather Shively, the chairwoman of the company, arranged for a backup site at a building operated by a disaster recovery company, Comdisco, in New Jersey. The Y2K problems were minimal, but the system was in place when the buildings fell and power was disrupted in lower Manhattan.
On Sept. 11, Ms. Shively said, "We started migrating our clients to Comdisco, and the impact on them was minimal even when power was lost." She said the company had invested more than $1 million at Comdisco "although we never anticipated anything like this." She added, "Our Y2K investment really paid off."
She said the continued operation of her business and many others like it "speaks to the importance of the digitization of information" and the ability to move information needed to run a business away from the site of the business. "That is why the economy and New York City did not shut down," she said.
Ms. Shively said she was in Connecticut the day of the attack, but the interruptions in telephone service did not prevent her from communicating with people in Manhattan and elsewhere. "We connected by BlackBerry and instant messaging," she said. "The Internet worked."
Interest in telecommunications space in New Jersey jumped immediately after the Trade Center attack, after languishing for almost a year, said Sean Brady, a senior director with Cushman & Wakefield. "The market for this space was dead, but after Sept. 11 interest in it increased, particularly for space that is well equipped," he said.
As originally planned, most buildings that were to be telco hotels would have housed mostly machines and very few people. The properties varied from old factories in urban locations, like 50 Dey Street in Jersey City, to newer construction in the suburbs, like 4 Gatehall Road in Parsippany. But if they are to be reused as "mirror" or "parallel" sites, duplicating the operations of, say, a trading floor in Manhattan, the buildings will have to accommodate people as well. This means carving out space for offices and amenities and, in the suburbs, providing for parking, brokers say.
"Telcos were designed to house inanimate objects," said Lee Miller, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield in New Jersey, the state that has much of the available telecommunications space. "When you add in people, you have different requirements for offices, parking and heating and air-conditioning."
He said that after a scramble to find temporary space in the wake of the Trade Center attack, many companies are examining their options further in the future. "They are operational now, and they are rethinking their paradigm," he said. They are asking questions like 'Do we really need 3,000 people within one block in New York City?' "
"There is a lot of internal debate going on right now," said James L. Somoza, a director of Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage and services company. "There is one camp that says, 'We have to be in Manhattan,' and another that says, 'We can't be in Manhattan.' " He said it appeared that some companies want operations on both sides of the Hudson River just to be safe.
One of the buildings he is marketing in Manhattan is 85 Tenth Avenue between 15th and 16th Streets. The building is owned by Level 3 Communications, which purchased the structure for its own use. But now about half the building, about 300,000 square feet, is available for lease to third parties, Mr. Somoza said.
In addition to location, many companies are re-examining their technical operations to determine what needs to be done in-house and what is better contracted out, said Jeffrey Hipschman, an executive vice president of Julien J. Studley, a brokerage that represents tenants.
"A lot of companies are finding this to be a good time to look at their data operations," he said. "They are saying things like "Do I really want to run an e-mail server?' " He said many American corporations had traditionally been reluctant to entrust internal communications to outsiders, known as application service providers, or A.S.P.'s in computer industry jargon. 
"Companies today seem more open to A.S.P.'s," he said, noting the providers include some of the best known companies in the industry. "I.B.M. is the classic A.S.P.," he said.
In addition, he said, companies looking to back up trading or clearing operations in Manhattan have several choices that can be used singly or in some combination.
One is co-location. A company can lease a cage in a data center operated by I.B.M. or SunGard Data Systems. The company installs its own equipment, while the building operator supplies such services as security, air-conditioning and fire suppression.
There are also disaster recovery centers, which Mr. Hipschman, the tenant broker, describes as a form of insurance policy. A company sends tapes containing its data to a site with servers in another city, where they can be loaded on servers and processed if the primary site goes down. These are typically batch operations, with 24 hours of data physically transferred to the recovery site daily.
A third option is a mirror, or parallel, site. Transactions recorded on servers at one location are automatically transmitted to servers at another, remote, location. Users have to decide how timely they need the data at the remote location to be; up to the minute is more expensive than hourly, Mr. Hipschman said. He said the Studley company had opted for a mirror site for its own operations. "A site in New Jersey mirrors the data that's in New York," he said.
Some brokers say some companies are seeking to take advantage of space prepared at great expense by telecommunications tenants that is now available at a steep discount because demand had been overestimated. According to Mr. Cohen of Newmark, it costs $300 to $500 a square foot to prepare telecommunications space, compared with about $70 a square foot for office installations.
"Nobody is going out and building new space like this," said Jeff A. Kolodkin, a vice president of Grubb & Ellis, a brokerage and services company. "People are trying to take advantage of what happened in the marketplace and sublease this space cheaply." He said that landlords who were late coming to the telecommunications market are in a particularly poor bargaining position.
The vacancy rate for telecom space in the New York region is about 38 percent, according to Ms. Anderson of Insignia/ESG. 
There may be excess space available now, but it could gradually go away as the need to transfer large amounts of data -- for people who prefer to use teleconferences rather then get on airplanes, for example -- grows, Mr. Kolodkin said. "The world is not going back to the Pony Express," he said. "People still want to move information at the speed of light." 
But, he said, advances in technology may decrease the need for real estate, even if the amount of data flowing through the system increases greatly. "It could be that technology will reduce the amount of space needed for equipment," he said. In the future, "you may only need 5,000 square feet where you need 50,000 square feet now."
ALTHOUGH many companies are looking to geographic diversification to safeguard their operations, at least one developer said there is a technological alternative in Manhattan and said he is prepared to move ahead with it.
Douglas Durst, chief executive of the Durst Organization, which owns more than 7 million square feet of skyscrapers in Midtown, is planning to proceed with the New York CyberCenter on a site between 11th and 12th Avenues and 57th and 58th Streets. The center, intended as the home of technical operations and data centers for financial companies, will have its own generating equipment, which will provide power and air-conditioning to the building, making it independent of the Con Ed power grid all the time, not just in emergencies.
He said he hoped to proceed with demolition of existing buildings on the site as soon as he could get Con Ed to turn off existing power to the site. The attack on the Trade Center had an impact on the project, because Mr. Durst lent the buildings to the Red Cross to store supplies immediately after the disaster.
"We were planning to open in the summer of 2003, but we lost two months," he said. "Now we expect to open in the fall."

HEADLINE: CITIES; 
The Ship Of State Arrives

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO

DATELINE: CAMDEN 

 BODY:
IT may no longer clip along the high seas at 33 knots, or fire shells the size of cars with precision accuracy, but the battleship New Jersey is serving the latest war effort in a very real way: as a testament to the country's military might.
 For politicians, the ship offered the chance to wax eloquent in support of the war on terrorism during last week's rededication ceremony aboard the deck of the new battleship museum on the waterfront here. 
 "If you doubt America's will or question our ability or willingness to defend ourselves, look at this ship," said Senator Robert Torrecelli at last Sunday's ceremony attended by about 1,500 dignitaries, former shipmates and guests.
For many of the 400 people who rushed out on opening day to tour the world's longest, most decorated and most widely traveled battleship, the New Jersey provided something tangible to hang on to during an intangible time. 
"When I heard it was opening, I couldn't wait to get here," said Jim Curley of Bellmawr, who took his 11-year-old son, Ryan, out of school on Monday so they could be on board the first day. "With everything that's going on in the world right now, you never know what might happen."
Along with feeding the patriotic fever that has swept the country since Sept. 11, the warship museum is expected to provide an added boost to this ailing city's revitalization, largely focused on the waterfront.
"Camden is right for this ship, and the Big J is right for Camden," said Acting Governor Donald DiFrancesco just before tossing a ceremonial wreath laden with red, white and blue carnations overboard into the Delaware River.
Berthing the New Jersey just a mile upriver from the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard, where it was built in 1940, was not always a given. The Camden-based Home Port Alliance aggressively lobbied the Navy and beat out the state battleship commission's bid to bring the ship to Bayonne, where it had berthed twice when it was decommissioned after World War II and the Korean War. In addition, the New Jersey served in the Vietnam War and during the attacks in Beirut in 1984. 
During the 90-minute guided tours of the battleship, tourists were given a taste of what it must have been like to be aboard the New Jersey during one of those tours. Knowledgeable docents, many of whom served in the military or worked on ships, took visitors to areas not normally accessible even to shipmates and explained in detail the workings of the ship.
Inside the blue-lighted strategic combat engagement center, visitors could view the radar and tracking systems for some of the ship's tactical weaponry, all except those for the Tomahawk systems, which were removed for security reasons since the Navy still uses Tomahawk cruise missiles. In the navigation bridge, one docent, Bob Locke, pointed out the 18-inch-thick walls meant to protect the captain as he directed the ship from a bank-vault conning tower.
The parts of the ship that elicited the most interest, however, were the nine 67-foot-long, 16-inch turrets, capable of launching 2,700-pound shells a distance of 23 miles, and the very tight sleeping quarters. Triple-tiered bunk beds and three-foot-tall lockers represented all the personal space a crewmember was given. 
Jim Zubert spent three years aboard the New Jersey on its first commission during World War II, at a time when the ship held 3,200. A first-class boatswain, Mr. Zubert, a Brooklyn native who now lives in Pittman, was responsible for firing one of the 16-inch turrets. He slept in the top bunk, where he wrote letters to his new bride, whom he had married during a 14-day leave.
"We had good times and bad times," said Mr. Zubert, 79. "But you only remember the good times."
That World War II tour, part of the South Pacific fleet under the command of Adm. William F. Halsey Jr., earned the New Jersey nine battle stars. In total, the ship was awarded 19 battle and campaign stars and numerous citations, awards and ribbons, making it the most decorated ship in the Navy. One of four Iowa class battleships designed for armament power and speed, the battleship New Jersey measures 887 feet 7 inches long -- exceeding its sister ships, the Iowa, the Missouri and the Wisconsin, by seven inches and making it the longest battleship in the world.
Launched in 1942 on the one-year anniversary of Pearl Harbor, the 45,000-ton ship made its last voyage in 1999 when it was towed from Washington State to Philadelphia and later across the river to Camden. Building the pier and turning the working battleship into a living museum has been a $20 million endeavor. Since it arrived in Camden, almost 1,000 volunteers have logged a total of 90,000 hours helping restore the battleship.
While the public tour covers a good portion of 5 of the ship's 11 levels, volunteers are still hard at work getting more areas ready for public viewing. Dan Farrell, a volunteer coordinator who served in the Navy's air squadron in the late 1960's, has spent nearly every day over the last 10 months crawling around the bowels of the ship tracing leaks, ripping out duct work and painting bulkheads.
"When we got here in December this mess hall was under eight inches of water," said Mr. Farrell, whose crews are also cleaning up sleeping quarters below deck, where they hope to host sleep-over camporees this winter. "There was no heating, no electricity, no running water. The ceilings were falling down."
Dozens of former crewmen who were invited to participate in the rededication ceremony stood on the forecastle of the ship last week comparing impressions of how the ship looked during their time at sea with today. Several veterans commented that the teak floors were not as shiny as they were in their day and that many of the guns were missing.
"She was a great lady and they did a beautiful job on her," said Roger Oosterink, 74, who drove 12 hours from Hudsonville, Mich., to see the ship he served on in 1946 and 1947. "This was one trip I had to make."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The battleship New Jersey at its berth in Camden, with 16-inch guns and parade flags on display. It opened as a museum last weekend, feeding the patriotic fever that has swept the country since Sept. 11. (Photographs by Tim Shaffer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Making Money, At Whose Expense? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "It's Time to Terror-Proof Markets" (On the Contrary, Oct. 7), in which Daniel Akst said the nation should never again let its enemies paralyze its business life:
 Mr. 
Akst said that no one should be ashamed of making money, which he described as "at the core of our civilization." But many people also believe that civilization's core includes good schools, affordable health care, decent housing and a measure of economic security and opportunity for everyone. 
 Wall Street's dominance not only coexists with increases in poverty and inequality, stagnant or falling real wages and housing costs that are out of reach for working families, it also helps to explain them.
The Street has claimed a disproportionate share of the income and wealth of New York City but has remained indifferent to the spectacle of rising social distress during unprecedented prosperity. In times of economic trouble, its instability shrinks the economy and the tax base, jeopardizing the fiscal stability of the city and the security of millions. 
Among the dead and missing from Sept. 11 were immigrant workers who earned a pittance and for whom the basic needs of people in modern society were distant dreams. While we can take pride in our financial prowess and work to preserve it, the city's political leaders need to achieve economic recovery not by paying economic tribute to the financial industry but by reconnecting with the entire city's social fabric and well-being.

SUMNER M. ROSEN
Manhattan, Oct. 12

The writer is professor emeritus of social policy, Columbia University.

HEADLINE: THE RIGHT THING; 
The 'Me, Too' Mind-Set of Disaster Aid

BYLINE:  By JEFFREY L. SEGLIN; Jeffrey L. Seglin teaches at Emerson College in Boston and is the author of "The Good, the Bad, and Your Business" (John Wiley & Sons). His column on business ethics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: righthng@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
"IN a disaster, it's never fair," said Pat Owens, the former mayor of Grand Forks, N.D., a city of 47,000 that was ravaged by floods in April 1997. "You have to make the best choices you can with the dollars you have to work with."
 Ms. Owens, who was mayor from 1996 to 2000, was talking about decisions she had helped to make about which businesses would receive federal disaster money. Regardless of the criteria set forth, Ms. Owens said, ineligible businesses sought relief funds because they felt entitled to the same financial help received by others. "There was nothing we could do," Ms. Owens said. "We just had to tell them they had to pull themselves up by their own bootstraps." 
 In many ways, the devastation caused by the Grand Forks flood pales in comparison with that of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. But soon after the attacks, amid heroic rescue attempts, community support for displaced residents and workers, and myriad fund-raising efforts, it was not long before faraway cries of "Me too!" began to be heard.
Tom Kershaw, founder of the Bull and Finch Pub in Boston, the bar depicted on "Cheers" on television, says he believes he is entitled to low-interest loans and other economic support because the tourism business, upon which his business relies, has softened. Mr. Kershaw said that before Sept. 11, his business was off 11 percent from the same time the previous year. "Now, it's about 50 percent," he said. He attributes the dropoff directly to the attack.
"It doesn't matter in this case whether it's physical or not," Mr. Kershaw said of the damage. "The effect is the same. It's just a matter of intensity."
As the airlines were "jumping on Day 2" to cry for help, he said, "the rest of us were just standing behind them." In other words, if the airlines got theirs, Mr. Kershaw wanted his.
Perhaps a positive spin on that message, said Joseph L. Badaracco Jr., a business ethics professor at Harvard Business School, "is that it's an issue of fairness rather than entitlement."
But deeming that a pub 215 miles away from ground zero deserves similar treatment as the airlines whose planes were hijacked and used as missiles, just because its revenue is off, is a stretch. Even if a compelling case can be made, where do you draw the line? Many companies, while not affected physically, might say their customers stopped coming since Sept. 11. "As a practical matter," Professor Badaracco said, "I'm not sure we could sort out 20,000 companies and how badly they were affected and how much was caused by this problem or just bad management."
Asked why he feels entitled to the same relief from public money as, say, someone whose business was physically destroyed at the World Trade Center, Mr. Kershaw said: "It's my money. I can tell you about years when I gave the government a hell of a lot of money in taxes, and I'd like it back now, thank you very much."
Mr. Kershaw, who is also chairman of the Greater Boston Convention and Visitors Bureau, contended that all business owners who could make an argument that their revenue declines were connected to Sept. 11 should be eligible for some sort of relief. "My big concern," he said, "is that there's probably not enough money to do this."
Perhaps his commitment to protecting the financial health of his constituency of tourism-related businesses is obscuring the larger issue of deciding the right thing to do with limited resources. Such determination, however, rings hollow when others are more obviously in need.
"We had this horrible, unthinkable tragedy," Professor Badaracco said. "And here we have a guy with a successful bar that's going to have a couple of bad months. You know, what's he whining about?"
Mr. Kershaw also owns 75 Chestnut, a Boston restaurant that caters to a local clientele. "It's holding its own," he said. "My local restaurant is not affected in a major way because people in fact are staying home." He said he had already converted one of the rooms above the original Cheers into another bar catering to the local business as well. "I'm proactively working on initiatives to build the business," he said.
That's a smart management strategy. To people in New York who are still busy picking through the rubble of what were once their businesses, it must seem a luxury.

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Hysteria Can Be Hazardous

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER; Jennifer Steinhauer covers health care for The Times. Her column on the economics of health care appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: jestei@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE federal government has said it will spend billions of dollars to combat bioterrorism in our midst. But how much money will Americans waste first?
 There is no question that news reports of a baby and others being exposed to anthrax in the middle of Manhattan are terrifying. In some cases, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is recommending that people who have no symptoms and have not tested positive for anthrax exposure take antibiotics as a precaution. 
 But according to health care officials and doctors themselves, hundreds of prescriptions for ciprofloxican, or Cipro -- the drug that is believed to be most effective in treating anthrax -- are being doled out to people who have no reason to believe that they have ever been exposed to the deadly disease. And New Yorkers are running to the city's emergency rooms in droves -- in many cases bypassing their own private doctors -- to see if that cough, sniffle or blemish is actually evidence of anthrax exposure.
These hospital runs "are overtaxing very valuable resources," Dr. Neal L. Cohen, the New York City health commissioner, said at a news conference at City Hall last week. "It doesn't make sense economically," he added, "and it doesn't make sense medically."
That is especially true because the city's health and emergency management workers are already busy gearing up for other possible attacks, training workers and checking their own pharmaceutical supplies. 
William Grice, vice president for operations at Saint Vincents Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan, said its already busy emergency room has been filled with people anxious about anthrax. Doctors have had to be diverted from patient care to lead impromptu educational groups.
"People who really do not fit the protocol for needing treatment are demanding it," he said. And the hospital's costs are already mounting: about $250,000 to build up stockpiles of drugs, $50,000 for decontamination supplies and training for the emergency department and $30,000 to upgrade equipment on ambulances for paramedics.
"Those are the short-term things we have done," Mr. Grice said. "We feel we have to do more long-term planning."
Misuse of antibiotics is not new. The C.D.C. has even devoted a division to combat this problem, which can lead to resistant strains of illnesses and undesirable side effects. Cipro and similar drugs can cause nausea and diarrhea and, in rare cases, seizures and convulsions or worse. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who took it for urinary tract infections, said he found it to be unpleasant and would not take it now unless he had to.
Doctors are often pressured by nervous patients to prescribe antibiotics that they do not need. But that does not mean that doctors should do it. "It is slightly irresponsible," said Dr. Kevin M. Cahill, a tropical-medicine specialist in Manhattan. "We're drawing down a finite reserve for reasons that are not warranted. And there are real dangers in taking Cipro."
As it stands, the federal government and the pharmaceutical industry have already taken steps to increase the production of Cipro and approve a broader range of drugs that might be used for anthrax illness. Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said the government would approve two generic, broad-spectrum antibiotics, doxycycline and penicillin, for those who have inhaled anthrax.
All of this has caused Bayer, the German company that holds the patent for Cipro, to consider whether it should, in effect, abandon its patent by permitting generic drug makers to produce Cipro for sale in the United States, as some have said they are prepared to do. This also raises questions of whether the drug industry will again be pressed to rethink sticky patent and pricing issues.
There is no question that these are scary times. Anyone with a child cannot help but be gripped by at least momentary fear. Flu and cold symptoms, so common this time of year, can instill the same worry in any American these days.
But there are some cost-benefit decisions that have to be weighed. Do you really want to take up the time of an emergency room -- and in some cases, foot at least some of the bill for the visit -- when workers there may need to care for others who are critically ill, perhaps, someday, someone in your own family? Should the public health dollar be stretched away from education and prevention efforts to responding to questions that can be answered online at www.cdc.gov, the Web site of the disease control centers? 
PERSONAL doctors, who are often too busy to come to the phone, might be better used as resources when true symptoms are present. "It is amazing how much time it takes to answer calls from patients all day long wondering about anthrax," Dr. Cahill said. "I tell them I will fax the C.D.C. Web site page to them."
The government, of course, does not always tell the public everything it knows. In an age when we have come to expect instant answers, its method of distributing information can seem maddeningly incomplete and snail-like. But the facts about the anthrax threat and appropriate responses seem to evolve by the day. This illness, and this war, are new to the government. Public hysteria has its own health risks, including financial ones, and this may not be the best time to take them. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

ORGANIZATION: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL & PREVENTION (58%)

SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 726 words

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
If It Feels Significant, Do It

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
WHAT a difference a year can make. Twelve months ago, most of young America was mired in the material world, obsessed with stock options and where it would luxuriate after retiring at 40. Whiz kids controlled multimillion-dollar companies, the offices were often college dormitory rooms, and the money flowed like merlot. Thank goodness we all had therapists to help us cope with our newfound wealth. 
 Such arrogance! Such solipsism! Such naivete! 
 Twelve months later, the entire world is altered and those of us in our 20's and 30's may have been hit the hardest. And why wouldn't we be? In less than a year we have gone from the kings and queens of a high-technology, high-speed universe to a bunch of scared kids living in chaos. We've never been through a real crisis; we're not equipped to handle one. The Depression, after all, was some mythical event that our grandparents droned on about. Pearl Harbor was a star vehicle for Ben Affleck; Vietnam allowed Tom Cruise, among others, to show off his acting range; and the Persian Gulf war was a made-for-television movie courtesy of CNN. 
The good news is that Sept. 11 has caused people of all ages to re-evaluate their friendships, romantic entanglements and work lives. But reflection can be painful, especially when you think that your job is hardly giving you a raison d'etre. 
"How do you care about ratings or opening-night parties when you see police officers, firefighters or the military putting their lives on the line every day?" asked Sonda Lewis, 31, a publicist at a cable television station in Manhattan. "I'm assembling press kits for some television show that ultimately has no intrinsic value, and these people are risking their lives to save others. Not only am I not saving the world, I don't feel like I'm contributing to it in any significant way."
Of course, people have battled existential angst for centuries. I, for one, have spent the bulk of my existence trying to find a point; I have always envied those -- and there are many -- who manage to live unexamined lives. But this recent spate of personal accounting seems different, more urgent. Maybe it is because everything feels uncertain, from our economy to our safety to our country. Or maybe it is because young people are finally realizing just how fragile and random life is. We spend so much of our lives at our jobs -- and, perhaps more important, derive so much of our identity from them -- that we should try to do something that at least feels marginally significant, right?
So is it possible to find meaning in work when, whether by choice or necessity, you are making blenders or assembling press kits? I'm not sure. I certainly couldn't find value writing about eyebrows and hair defrizzers, which, sadly, I have done. Yes, frizzy hair is unfortunate, but there are worse things than resembling Roseanne Roseannadanna. 
Some people have managed to strike balances between their work life and their sense of self. Ms. Lewis, for instance, treats her day job as just that. Her first loves are theater and her new husband, David, though not necessarily in that order. "I find meaning in love, friendship and acting," she said. "Everything else takes a back seat."
Six years ago, Steven C. Rosenthal, now 34, quit his engineering job at AT&T to start a nonprofit humanitarian organization, Cross-Cultural Solutions, in White Plains. The group sends volunteers to places like India, Ghana and Cuba, and was most recently working with the American Red Cross at ground zero in Lower Manhattan. 
"I understand how people are going through this re-evaluation process -- that was me six years ago," Mr. Rosenthal said. "For years I felt that not only didn't I have as much meaning in my career as I knew I could have, but that I could also add value to other people's lives. That's why I started CCS."
ACROSS the country, volunteerism has skyrocketed, and people are signing up in droves to go into the C.I.A. or the military. 
Ultimately, of course, we all find importance in our own ways; one person's holy grail is another's hair defrizzer. And in the wake of disaster, many people seem to have reached the conclusion that personal relationships should take precedence above all else.
Still, some people honestly believe that the world would be a better place if only we annihilated frizzy hair.
If only it were that simple.

HEADLINE: On Edge, Again 

BYLINE:  By MAX PAGE; Max Page, a former New Yorker, is an assistant professor of architecture and history at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst, and the author of "The Creative Destruction of Manhattan" (University of Chicago Press).

 BODY:
NEW YORK is still the city that never sleeps. Fear will do that.
 Fear of death borne in the air: a jet, a microbe. In Lower Manhattan, the dust has been scrubbed away. Night and day trucks rumble off with more rubble. But the fear persists: there are letters to open, cross-country trips to take. The fear is a psychic anthrax, an almost invisible powder creeping under the windowsills of thought, sifting into the corners of each mind. 
 Fear and this city are no strangers. History reminds us that New York has burned and been occupied by soldiers. It has been besieged by epidemics and riots. Our popular culture has been in dress rehearsal for the city's destruction for decades: in books, at the movies, in computer games, although no amount of history, no number of rehearsals, could prepare New Yorkers for Sept. 11 and the days of grief and worry that followed. 
It was the most perfect and horrific demolition job. Two quarter-mile-tall towers exploding, then imploding, one-acre floors falling through the next one, 200 times over. 
The survivors, blanketed in the gray mist of urban disaster, headed north and east. The attacks' human spores bearing their stories, their fear, throughout the city. 
That unleashed energy was finally absorbed by each resident here, metastasizing into a malaise that has lingered as the country has gone to war and the specter of bioterrorism has grown.
Virginia Woolf wrote in "A Room of One's Own" that after World War I, it was not possible to hum poetry. On the surface, lively lunches at Oxbridge proceeded as before the war. But the "humming noise, not articulate, but musical, exciting" was gone. The war had "destroyed illusion and put truth in its place." 
Many suggest that such is the case with Sept. 11: our world has changed. A controlled fear -- a constant hum of worry, rather than poetry -- seems part of this new world, this new New York. But, after the initial silence, then the muted tones, the city is still somehow humming. Perhaps, Sept. 11 has not created a new city, but in many respects ferried us back to an older, more visceral New York, where it was understood that the city was at risk. And while today the rest of the country is on edge, New York is even more so. New Yorkers understand again that their city is a target.
To 19th-century New Yorkers, who may have been told stories of the city's burning during the seven-year British occupation in the Revolutionary War, or who lost family members to the cholera epidemics of the 1830's, who perhaps watched the burning of much of Lower Manhattan in 1835, or who later saw rioting mobs rage through the city in 1863, the notion that the city was forever was absurd.
Even the city of the 1940's and 1950's was not immune to fears of sudden catastrophe, the distinct possibility of nuclear attack. Sept. 11 bombed us back to the atomic age, when a roar in the sky could instantly evict daydreams from New Yorkers' minds and substitute apocalyptic visions.
Fear and New York are words that have often gone together. Usually, it has been the rest of the country fearing New York, rather than New Yorkers fearing their city. New York, ascending to dominance by the early 19th century, became the most feared city of all. In New York, Americans saw the poor, the immigrants, people of all races. In New York, crowding, crime, disease and radicalism were not only found but nurtured and propagated.
 AMERICAN movies and television, books and newspapers have projected images of urban fear for more than a century. Urban catastrophe movies and novels, paintings and comic books -- many created by New Yorkers themselves -- have used New York to try to reveal the dangers of the American city.
American popular culture has returned to the theme of New York's destruction time and again, almost as a leitmotif that resonates with some of the most longstanding themes in American history: the ambivalence toward cities, the troubled reaction to immigrants and racial diversity, fear of technology's impact, and the tensions between natural and humanmade disasters.
In a nation as religious as the United States, with a strong apocalyptic strain in its popular culture, it is not surprising to find so many examples of catastrophe. But more regularly than any other, New York -- not only our largest city but "the city" of platonic ideal -- has repeatedly met its death by art.
In moments of social upheaval, visions of how New York would be demolished, blown up, swallowed by the sea, or toppled by monsters have proliferated in films and in science fiction novels, as well as in photography, painting and the graphic arts.
In Joaquin Miller's 1886 novel, "Destruction of Gotham," a great fire engulfs the city as lower-class mobs attack the homes and stores of the wealthy. Only when Manhattan had "burned and burned and burned to the very bed-rock" was the apocalypse complete.
Jacob Riis, the photographic chronicler of the slums of the Lower East Side, encapsulated the fears of many Americans in 1890 with his metaphors of the waves of radical immigrants flooding onto the beaches of Brooklyn in his landmark book, "How the Other Half Lives."
At the nearby immigrants' paradise, Coney Island, tenements were routinely set on fire at Dreamland, giving those same immigrants a chance to witness from afar the tenuous world they inhabited on the Lower East Side.
In paintings by the futuristic artist Chesley Bonestell from the cold war 1950's, in popular magazines like Fortune and Collier's, Manhattan is repeatedly devastated by atomic bombs.
In the SimCity software of the 1990's, users could pick what disaster would strike New York, or just watch past disasters play out before their eyes.
And in movie after movie, as has been noted in the past weeks, Hollywood has found inspiration in destroying New York: through earthquake ("Deluge"), tsunami ("Deep Impact"), asteroid ("When Worlds Collide" and "Armageddon"), and monster ("Godzilla" and "King Kong").
Just this summer, in what had become an almost annual rite, New York was destroyed repeatedly on movie screens. The Japanese animated movie "Final Fantasy" showed a devastated Lower Manhattan beneath a dome, to protect it from the assaults of viruslike aliens. In "A.I.," the child robot finds himself drawn to a forbidden zone, called "Man-Hattan," overflowing with water. The World Trade Center towers stand above the water line, one tipped, leaning against the other.
In the millions, we have read these books, watched these movies, played these games, thrilled to the skyscrapers of Manhattan toppling as if it were somehow culturally cleansing. In other words, despite the repeated statement that the events of Sept. 11 were unimaginable, our culture has been imagining, rehearsing, these events for years.
Of course, New Yorkers themselves have been less concerned with catastrophic visions of the city's end, and more preoccupied with the very real catastrophes they have had to confront. Jose Marti, the Cuban revolutionary who lived in New York in the late 19th century, admired the city's resilience after the crippling Blizzard of 1888. 
New York, "like the victim of an outrage, goes about freeing itself of its shroud," he wrote. The democracy of snowfall, covering aristocratic Fifth Avenue as heavily as Mulberry Bend on the Lower East Side, had brought out a "sense of great humility and a sudden rush of kindness, as though the dread hand had touched the shoulders of all men."
The city's early history is studded with events in which distinctions of wealth and race were swept aside by disaster. In a city where rich and poor coexisted, with pigs and prostitutes living alongside Astors and Lenoxes, natural and human disasters were more likely to include everyone. 
In the 20th century, disasters have tended not to directly affect the whole city, like the Triangle Shirtwaist Fire of 1911. Even the anthrax attacks, on the news media and at Gov. George E. Pataki's New York office, have been localized. Right now, strangely enough, it is an office problem, a disease that has been spread through the mail, in the windowless mailrooms of the new economy, and eventually landing on cubicle desks. Yes, some workplaces have been threatened, but so far the city as whole has not been at risk, though it feels as if it is.
It's important to remember that New York has always been better at celebration than fear. New York has always prided itself on humming: ticker tape parades down Broadway, the tall ships at the Bicentennial, that memorable V-J Day kiss (caught by Eisenstaedt) in Times Square: these are New York's emotional landmarks. 
If the "unexpungeable odor of the long past," as E. B. White wrote in 1948 in "Here Is New York," persists in the city, in the endless sediment of New York's people and their histories, it has been overcome by the daily odors of city life. New Yorkers' notoriously short memories have, even so, kept room for celebration.
 ALL this is why we continue to destroy New York in books, on canvas, on movie screens and on computer monitors: because it is so unimaginable for us, in reality, not to have this city. We have played out our worst fears on the screen and in our pulp fiction because, as the city's oracle, Mr. White, wrote in the shadow of the atomic bomb: "If it were to go, all would go -- this city, this mischievous and marvelous monument which not to look upon would be like death." 
Maybe fear is the wrong word for what New Yorkers feel now. There is anxiety, there is uncertainty. New York is no longer an invulnerable porcupine of skyscrapers that can never be attacked. Instead, the city has been rediscovered as a fragile community.
A community built on a delicate mix of people and buildings, the solace of anonymity and the thrill of cosmopolitanism, what Jane Jacobs famously called "organized complexity" in her classic study, "The Death and Life of Great American Cities." Only beyond the five boroughs, in the hinterlands, does the city appear to embody raw chaos.
This new uncertainty has brought New Yorkers together in repeated moments of empathy and concern over the recent weeks. But uncertainty could also lead to a pulling away from public life, New York's enduring justification for being, and a mimicking of the fortress mentality that has rolled across the country.
It might, finally, also remind New Yorkers again of the precariousness of this place, its indispensability to a personal and national identity. It might make New Yorkers want to defend the city even more, by starting an era of unprecedented creativity.
The city that never sleeps because of fear of airplanes, fear of powder, might again become a city that never sleeps because it is too busy creating and telling, building and imagining, eating and singing. Jonathan Larson's words in the musical "Rent" could only have been written in and for New York: "The opposite of war is not peace, it's creation!"
E. B. White wrote: "New York is to the nation what the white church spire is to the village -- the visible symbol of aspiration and faith, the white plume saying the way is up!"
The white plume we saw on Sept. 11 was the cloudy debris of two massive towers collapsing, shrewdly demolished to turn gleaming symbols of the city into burning signs of terror. Our fantasies and nightmares made real, we now wait, almost expectantly, for the next plume, a puff of powder from a No. 10 envelope.
Still, in this time of New York's haunting, I think White was right. New York will remain the way up for us all, the home of our ideals, and the place to which the world looks, for ideas, for success, for art and for a new start.

HEADLINE: When Times Get Tough, Some Go for Plastic Surgery 

BYLINE:  By RUTH LA FERLA

 BODY:
A FEW weeks ago Jody Seiff, a Manhattan nightclub manager, was seized by an indefinable melancholy. "You know how when you feel bad, nothing makes you happy?" she said. "You try shopping, and when that doesn't work, you go to the makeup counter to buy some new colors."
 But last week, when her usual strategies failed, Ms. Seiff, 36, sought balm for her spirits in a plastic surgeon's consulting room. "I had a little bit of collagen done in my lips and in those places where tiny wrinkles were starting to show," she confided. "These things distract you for a time. You feel a little perkier." 
 Americans' consumption of luxury indulgences may have fallen off a cliff since Sept. 11 -- rabbit-fur hats, $100 face creams, platinum charm bracelets. But one unexpected growth area has been outpatient cosmetic surgery, as patients like Ms. Seiff try to salve their unease with a host of skin-deep, but inwardly comforting, remedies. 
It is too early for statistics, but a dozen cosmetic surgeons around the country said that they and their colleagues had found that while major hospital procedures like face-lifts have fallen since mid-September, office procedures like eyelifts and Botox and collagen injections have surged markedly -- by 20 to 30 percent compared with the same weeks a year ago. Some of those procedures can be performed in about an hour and require minimal recovery time.
"Based on what we are hearing, people are beginning to come back around to those procedures that they had planned to do," said Leida Snow, a spokeswoman for the American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery. "We're also seeing new people coming in. Patients are saying, 'If not now, when?' "
The decision may be an outgrowth of a shift in priorities as a result of the terrorist attacks and the declining economy, one that has many Americans buying fewer big-ticket items and postponing vacations, while indulging instead in mini-luxuries they hope will provide a quick fix for the body and the spirit.
"As people's external lives become more questionable, they look inside themselves," said Sander L. Gilman, a professor of liberal arts and medicine at the University of Illinois at Chicago who is the author of "Creating Beauty to Cure the Soul: Race and Psychology in the Shaping of Aesthetic Surgery" (Duke University Press, 1998). "What they are asking is, 'How can I maximize my personal happiness?' and searching for the easiest and most immediate way to change themselves."
Wendy Lewis, a New York cosmetic surgery consultant who connects patients with appropriate doctors for a fee, notices her clients taking a hard look at their emotional bottom line. "They are examining the balance sheet and recognizing there are some things that they are never going to give up," Ms. Lewis said, least of all their minor vanities. "Some of them are telling me, 'I may not have a face-lift this year, but whether there is a bomb or not, I'm going to be a blonde. And I'm not going to give up my Botox.' "
Another factor in the rise of quick-fix procedures is that at times of economic peril, when many are concerned about job security, the rejuvenating promise of cosmetic surgery can be appealing as an investment in the future. It is not unusual for patients to debate whether they should spend their time and money on a vacation or on surgery, said Dr. Malcolm Paul, the president of the American Society for Plastic Surgery, who practices in Newport Beach, Calif. "In their minds, a vacation has benefits which are short term, compared with certain aesthetic procedures, which last indefinitely," he said.
Plastic surgeons attribute the increase in procedures since the attacks of Sept. 11 to everything that has happened -- an increased sense of vulnerability, anxiety over bioterrorism and the continued slippage in the economy. Minor cosmetic procedures have also supplanted face-lifts as a short-term repair for slackened contours.
For many, all of this means that the "should I or shouldn't I" debates have acquired a new urgency. "Some of my patients seem more interested in surgery when they recognize how fragile life is," said Dr. Alan Matarasso, a prominent New York plastic surgeon. They are responding to "that live-for-today feeling," echoed Jane Larkworthy, the beauty director of W magazine. It is a desire that impels them "to actively pursue what they might have put off," she said, "whether it's that art history course or firming that slack skin that's been bothering them for years."
The debate whether cosmetic surgery is a gross vanity has become easier for many to resolve -- surprisingly, perhaps, in the negative. Dr. James L. Baker Jr., a plastic surgeon in Winter Park, Fla., noted that before Sept. 11 his patients often fretted whether they were being overly vain. "But I don't see that anymore," he said. "Before, there was a concern about what other people would think. Now it's more about Me. My patients come in saying, 'I want to look better, and that's it.' Their attitude is, 'If you don't like it, tough.' "
"Did I feel guilty? Not really," said Ms. Seiff, the nightclub manager. Of course, nothing about surgery is cheap. Ms. Seiff spent about $1,000 on a series of injections. "I did ask myself, Could I have spent my money in a better manner?" she said.
Increasingly, doctors said, patients are in search of quick gratification. "People want to live a bit more in the moment," said Dr. Steven Teitelbaum, a plastic surgeon in Beverly Hills.
Dr. Richard Palu, a New York ophthalmic surgeon whose patients include lawyers, doctors and financial executives, said they are opting for cosmetic procedures with minimal recovery time -- several days instead of several weeks. "People are looking for a more modest expenditure and a more modest commitment of their time," he said.
Some patients cited fears of an extended hospital stay, which might leave them out of touch and vulnerable in the event of further terror strikes. Gordana Perlof, 58, a retired travel agent in Marina del Rey, Calif., considered postponing the midface-lift she had scheduled for last month. "But I asked myself what would be the benefit," Ms. Perlof recalled. "I would just have been sitting in front of the television all day."
For New Yorkers in particular, a quick cosmetic fix can be a kind of salve for psyches that are still raw. "It's like anything else -- when you feel bad you buy a little lipstick," said Dr. Helen Colen, a Manhattan plastic surgeon. Dr. Colen has performed 30 collagen procedures and 20 Botox injections in the last two weeks, twice as many as in the same period a year ago.
For some people, an eyelift or a collagen injection is a way of coping with adversity. Whether they have lost jobs or are simply feeling the diffuse anxiety that is increasingly common in an unstable environment, many Americans are going under the knife as "a way of taking control, of saying I'm going to beat this thing," said Dr. Peter Fodor, a plastic surgeon in Beverly Hills and a director of the American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery.
Cathy Solomon, a partner in a small New York cosmetics business, decided last month to have a second round of liposuction. "Truthfully, it took my mind off the fact that I was feeling in the dumps," Ms. Solomon, 50, said. The generalized anxiety of recent weeks, coupled with her own personal fears, certainly gave her pause, she said. "But let's put it this way: it wasn't going to stop me."
Like many Americans, Ms. Solomon has developed an oddly fatalistic attitude. "I'm not going to buy a gas mask," she said, "and I'm not going to live in fear. If I'm going down, I'm going to go down looking good."
