HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 10-21-01; 
Feds Up

BYLINE:  By Jacob Weisberg; Jacob Weisberg is a frequent contributor to the magazine.

 BODY:
Back in the era that ended on Sept. 11, life in Washington was burdened by a curious form of self-loathing. A good many of the capital's residents habitually deplored it as an irredeemably sinful place -- though as missionaries from the heartland they took no blame for its corruptions. You can trace the evolution of this attitude from Ronald Reagan's first Inaugural Address, when he said that government was not the solution but the problem, through Newt Gingrich's railings against the "corrupt" bureaucracy to the rather poignant attempt by that quintessential Washington figure, Bob Dole, to cast himself as an outsider when he ran for president. 
 Even after the Oklahoma City bombing muted the harshest anti-Washington rhetoric, there remained an entire lexicon for deriding the seat of national power. "Inside the Beltway" was a place where "career politicians" squandered "hard-earned tax dollars" on "one-size-fits-all" solutions," or what George W. Bush until recently called, with a kind of leer, "Washington solutions." A friend of mine liked to joke that the word "Washington" had become simply a synonym for "bad," to the extent that someone might well say, "I got sick from eating a Washington oyster." 
 As politically effective as this demagogy may have been, it took a toll on the city's psyche. Someone who constantly runs down the place where he lives and works ultimately diminishes his own power and place in the world. He develops a stake in failure. In Washington itself, two decades of government-hating bred a sour, ridiculous feeling. Meanwhile, the stars of America's two other capitals -- New York and Los Angeles -- were ascendant. These cities knew their problems, but suffered from no comparable level of corrosive self-disgust.
Now, in a flash, the whole mind-set has vanished. Since Sept. 11, Washington's sense of itself has changed utterly. "Washington solutions" have gone from inherently suspect to indubitably essential. The federal government is now seen not just as capable but also as uniquely capable of performing a great variety of urgent tasks: fighting our enemies abroad, stimulating our flagging economy, rescuing bankrupt airlines, rebuilding the ruins in New York City, protecting us from bioterror and making the skies feel safe again. Reagan's old joke about the 10 scariest words in the English language -- Hello, I'm from the government, and I'm here to help" -- isn't a joke anymore. It's the literal attitude of Reagan-revering Republicans who toured the devastation at ground zero.
With this can-do attitude has arrived a renewed feeling of self-esteem. To be in a city under attack, a city now fortified by concrete barricades, checkpoints and armed National Guard troops, confers a sense of centrality and importance to all those whose work is somehow connected with the government. The new mood of vital improvisation recalls descriptions of Washington in F.D.R.'s day and again in J.F.K.'s. Bush's cabinet is now a Churchillian war cabinet, in which dull posts like secretary of transportation have taken on critical significance. Journalists who previously felt unlucky to have to cover a buttoned-down White House in a somnolent era are suddenly imbued with the elan that comes with proximity to a national emergency. All the old forms of political clownishness are out. Even on the Fox News Channel, the food-fight arguments have turned heavy and serious. 
Among the paradoxes of this transformation is that Washington's resurgent self-confidence is a direct result of its own conspicuous failure. We as a nation have turned to the federal government for help precisely because the federal government failed at the one task so basic that it commands assent even from libertarians: defending the physical security of the country from foreign attack. What's more, we are relying most heavily on the very agencies and in some cases the individuals who bear the greatest responsibility for not protecting us more effectively: the F.B.I., the C.I.A., the N.S.A., N.S.C., the State Department and the Pentagon. 
Of course, attitudes toward Washington have always had a strong nonrational dimension. Public confidence in government started to decline in the 1960's for a variety of valid reasons, including Vietnam, rising crime rates and a seemingly irresistible expansion of the size of the federal government. But during the peace, prosperity and shrinking government of the 1990's, the distrust continued to grow. The only thing that consistently makes the public feel more positively about Washington is war. When the war ends, so does the heightened warmth toward government. 
This war may follow that pattern or it may not. But the new mood, both toward Washington and in Washington, tells us something in either case. It indicates that government-hating is a rather superficial and artificial sentiment, a luxury of secure times. When terrorists knock down buildings, when drought wipes out farmers, when the economy threatens to come to a halt, even those who are ideologically hostile to the government turn to it, both logically and reflexively, for help. We suddenly trust Washington not because it has done something new to earn our trust but because the alternative of not trusting it has suddenly become too terrifying to contemplate. 

GRAPHIC: Photo (Wurts Brothers) Chart: "WASHINGTON BEFORE THE WAR""I'm not so sure the role of the United States is to go around the world and say this is the way it's got to be. . . . And maybe it's just our difference in government, the way we view government. I mean, I want to empower people, I don't -- you know, I want to help people help themselves, not have government tell people what to do. I just don't think it's the role of the United States to walk into a country and say, We do it this way, so should you. . . . I think the United States must be humble and must be proud and confident of our values, but humble in how we treat nations that are figuring out how to chart their own course." George W. Bush, during the second presidential debate, Oct. 11, 2000

HEADLINE: Can Peace Finally Come to Kashmir? 

BYLINE:  By Anatol Lieven; Anatol Lieven is a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

DATELINE: LAHORE, Pakistan 

 BODY:
If the United States is serious about removing the sources of anti-American terrorism, then at some stage Washington will have to tackle the conflict in Kashmir. At present this is the last thing American officials want to do. They have enough on their plate in Afghanistan. But as Secretary of State Colin Powell's experiences in Islamabad and New Delhi illustrated, the Kashmir dispute has the potential both to infuriate India and to weaken the regime of our Pakistani ally, President Pervez Musharraf.
 A strong behind-the-scenes American diplomatic initiative needs to begin now, because the context created by the campaign in Afghanistan offers unique opportunities, as well as great dangers, in India and Pakistan. One of the chief dangers is presented by the Jaish-e-Muhammad, the leading Islamist force active in Kashmir. It has been labeled a terrorist organization by Washington and faces a probable sharp reduction in Pakistani support. This means it has little to lose -- and the Jaish-e-Muhammad has indeed threatened a terror campaign not just in Kashmir but across India. 
 This could incite both communal strife within India and even harsher Indian repression in Kashmir, thereby contributing to radical Islamist unrest in Pakistan. It could also lead to renewed fighting between India and Pakistan across the line of control that divides their respective Kashmirs, as shown in recent days by heavy Indian bombardments. 
The opportunities are provided by the sea change that has taken place in Pakistani policies as a result of the Sept. 11 attacks and President Musharraf's decision to support the American campaign in Afghanistan. For the first time, there is a real willingness among leaders of the Pakistani state and army to cut back or end support for the Islamist elements based in Pakistan who fight in Kashmir; and for the first time, in private at least, some are willing to concede that Pakistan's entire Kashmir strategy of the past 54 years has proved fruitless, damaging to Pakistan and in need of radical revision. This is really striking, because support for Kashmiri independence from India has been at the core of the Pakistani army's ideology since the army was founded. It presents a chance that we must encourage India and Pakistan to seize. 
The struggle against Islamist terrorism makes finding a settlement in Kashmir very important to America's national interest. As long as the conflict there continues, it will suck in terrorist elements from elsewhere in the Muslim world, and these will find sympathy and protection from the Pakistani population and some in the armed forces.
Besides, while the rivalry between India and Pakistan is very damaging to both countries, it is increasingly ruinous to Pakistan. The effort to maintain adequate defenses against a country with seven times Pakistan's population has led to military spending averaging around 30 percent of the budget in recent years, dwarfing the amounts spent on education, health, welfare or infrastructure and severely reducing economic growth. Lack of education also contributes to a level of population growth that is among the highest in Asia and continually nullifies improvements in living standards.
These factors create a real danger that Pakistan could follow Afghanistan into collapse -- but on a much larger scale, and with nuclear weapons. Few more menacing scenarios for the growth of Islamist terrorism could be imagined.
If a settlement is to be found to Kashmir, the greatest initial concession has to come from Pakistan. Islamabad must publicly recognize that the greater part of Kashmir will remain under Indian sovereignty, and must drop its demand for the implementation of United Nations resolutions calling for a Kashmiri plebiscite on national status. These resolutions may be justified in principle, but there is simply no way India will accept them. It cannot be forced by Pakistan or anyone else to do so.
In return, New Delhi must drop its pretense that the Kashmir problem is not central to Indo-Pakistani relations and is a purely internal Indian matter in which the world community has no legitimate role. The international terrorist threat, and the possession of nuclear weapons by both India and Pakistan, have rendered these propositions obviously absurd.
If both countries could get over these initial hurdles, then the way might open for a settlement involving partial demilitarization, open borders, new administrative units and internationally supervised regional elections on both sides of the Indo-Pakistani frontier.
Unfortunately, past experience suggests that the parties are unlikely to get over these hurdles without a lot of help from their friends, and above all from the United States.

HEADLINE: The World; 
The High, Hidden Cost of Saudi Arabian Oil

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE

 BODY:
DURING his presidential campaign, George W. Bush warned that the nation faced an oil crisis. He was right, but not in the way he foresaw. The crisis that came has nothing to do with prices at the gas pump, or environmental obstacles to drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska. 
 Rather, it has to do with the political and military price the United States must pay for its dependence on oil from the Persian Gulf. 
 The terms of that dependence have been glaringly obvious since the attacks on New York and Washington. Immediately after Sept. 11, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, led by Saudi Arabia, assured the United States that it would keep oil supplies stable. 
In turn, the Bush administration has refrained from criticizing Saudi silence over the American-led counterattacks against Osama bin Laden and the Taliban, nor has it spoken out about evidence that Saudi citizens finance Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network and other radical Islamic organizations.
Moreover, although the Federal Bureau of Investigation identified most of the hijackers in the Sept. 11 attacks as Saudis, Saudi Arabia has refused to provide passenger lists of flights to the United States, an act the Bush administration has been unwilling to criticize. 
"The stark truth is that we're dependent on this country that directly or indirectly finances people who are a direct threat to you and me as individuals," said Edward L. Morse, former deputy assistant secretary of state for international energy policy under President Ronald Reagan. 
"They won't give us information, won't help track people down, and won't let us use our bases that are there to protect them," Mr. Morse added.
A major reason for that reticence is oil. Five percent of the world's population lives in the United States, but it burns about 19 million barrels of oil a day, or 25 percent of the global daily consumption of 76 million barrels. American cars and sport-utility vehicles alone consume 10 percent of that.
The United States has been angling for influence in the Arabian peninsula since oil was discovered there 70 years ago. American oil companies helped create Saudi Aramco, the state oil company. They were kicked out during the 1973 Arab oil embargo, but the United States and Saudi Arabia quickly reconciled. Several groups of Western oil companies, led by ExxonMobil, will soon develop Saudi Arabia's huge natural gas fields.
Saudi Arabia has all along made certain it was the largest supplier of oil to the United States, oil traders, diplomats and economists said. Saudi Arabia could make more money selling oil to east Asia, but has preferred to sell oil to the United States at lower prices in order to retain its coveted role. 
Over the decades, the Saudis' pursuit of American money and military protection melded perfectly with America's ever-growing oil appetite to turn the two nations into reflexive allies. Saudi Arabia and the United States worked together for years to shape the balance of power in the Middle East and Central Asia. 
From 1980 to 1988, the United States and Saudi Arabia armed Saddam Hussein in his war against Iran. In 1979 , after the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan, the Saudis were part of an alliance formed by the United States to drive them out. 
"We collaborated in the war in Afghanistan: the Saudis, the U.S. and Pakistan," said Gregory Gause, director of Middle Eastern studies at the University of Vermont. "The Saudis had the money, the Pakistanis had the bases and we had the political oomph to get it together."
Because its interests were so densely intertwined with Saudi Arabia, the United States turned a blind eye to its ally's unsavory foreign liaisons and brewing domestic trouble. 
THE United States looked the other way, for instance, as the Saudi government and individuals sent money to the Taliban. Starting in 1999 and extending at least into mid-2000, Saudi Arabia exported 150,000 barrels of oil a day, gratis, to Pakistan and Afghanistan as foreign aid, according to Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, a trade publication. Among oil traders, it is widely believed that the shipments exceeded war-ravaged Afghanistan's needs, and that oil may have been resold to arm the Taliban. 
Saudi Arabia's aid to the Taliban points up the balancing act the ruling al-Saud family has to perform between its foreign and domestic interests. The Saudis consider themselves allies of the United States. But the glue that holds their kingdom together is a puritanical strain of Islam called Wahhabism. By supporting the Taliban and other Muslim groups, the al-Saud dynasty is able to retain the goodwill of the country's clerics. Already, in response to the tacit Saudi backing of the American antiterrorism campaign, a powerful mainstream mullah in Saudi Arabia has issued a fatwa excommunicating the royal family. Fearful of protests, the Saudis have not tried to arrest him. 
In fact, fear of losing power has led the Saudis to pay off just about everyone, which makes oil revenues so crucial. There is the welfare state to coddle the citizenry; the toleration of extremist clerics so that they do not stir up the masses; and the payoffs to other regimes, including a Pakistan with nuclear capability, to keep them friendly.
But that protection money has not stemmed a growing domestic restiveness, as many Saudis have become fed up with a sprawling ruling family they believe is insatiably corrupt. 
"For many of the princes," said one former cabinet secretary in Washington, "the advantages of getting money exceed the advantages of keeping internal unrest down."
Many people in Saudi Arabia and the Middle East loathe the United States because they see it as the protector of a degraded regime in Riyadh. This has put pressure on the Bush administration, intent upon preserving the stability of its largest oil supplier and the appearance of Middle Eastern approval for its fight against terrorism, to toughen its stance on Israel. Prior to the assassination of an Israeli cabinet minister, some kind of shift had been expected by many, including the Israelis. 
"To a certain extent," said Philip K. Verleger, an independent economist and a senior adviser in the Carter administration, "we let U.S. foreign policy be dictated to us by the house of Saud."
IT is unclear what the United States can do to loosen its ties to the Saudi regime, so long as it remains reliant on its oil. Mr. Bush urged the Senate last week to get to work on a comprehensive energy policy. But the White House and most Republicans want to focus on developing domestic oil supplies. Given the fact that the United States has only 3 percent of the world's known reserves, increased drilling will do little in the long run to decrease dependence on the Middle East.
"Sept. 11 should be an alarm bell that we need a balanced, comprehensive energy policy that addresses things we don't like to do: mandating more fuel-efficient vehicles, more domestic oil and gas drilling, becoming more energy efficient as a nation, " said Bill Richardson, energy secretary under President Bill Clinton. 
That, in turn, could give Washington a bit more leeway in its relations with Saudi Arabia, freeing it to press for a reduction in official corruption or for reining in radical Islamic groups. 
Some people, like Dan W. Reicher, former assistant secretary of energy under Mr. Clinton, think that changes that reduce American dependence on petroleum are possible without Americans having to sacrifice the kinds of cars they drive or how they live. 
The question now, Mr. Reicher said, is whether Washington can find the political will to act before an oil crisis explodes. 
"Will patriotism mean more than raising the flag?" he said. "Will it mean raising fuel economy?"

HEADLINE: Bush Calls World Economy Goal of Attacks on U.S. 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Oct. 20 

 BODY:
President Bush declared today that the two American soldiers killed in an accident on Friday -- the first major American casualties in South Asia -- "died in a cause that was just and was right." He also told leaders of the 21 nations assembled here for an annual summit meeting that the terrorists who struck the World Trade Center were trying to bring about a collapse of world markets.
 It is the first time he has suggested that the terrorist network Al Qaeda was seeking to "shatter confidence in the world economic system." He called on businesses around the world to join the fight against terrorism, while acknowledging that new security measures and limits on border crossings ran the risk of undermining world commerce. 
 "Terrorists want to turn the openness of the global economy against itself," he said today in a speech to chief executives, who hold their own meetings in parallel with those of the government leaders. "We must not let them."
The news of the accident in Pakistan that killed two soldiers came just hours before the opening of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum here, and it underscored how Mr. Bush was mixing coalition building with long-distance management of the war. 
He slid past questions about the exact mission of the Special Forces units that were sent in and then taken out of Afghanistan on Friday. The deaths occurred in a search and rescue team on call in case the mission ran into trouble. "There will be moments of sacrifice," Mr. Bush said late this morning, as he was about to meet with Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan. "We've seen two such examples today."
The White House announced today that Mr. Bush would leave Shanghai about half a day earlier than scheduled, after a meeting with Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, ends on Sunday. That meeting is intended to focus on creating a new strategic relationship with Russia, which the war has elevated to a new level of cooperation and intelligence sharing.
Though he got no specific endorsement for military strikes in Afghanistan, including none from Mr. Putin, Mr. Bush could claim a measure of diplomatic success here simply because he prevented any major defections from his informal coalition.
But there were several close calls, as country after country in the region repeated that they wanted to keep civilian casualties to a minimum and the military action in Afghanistan as short as possible. After a meeting today between President Jiang Zemin of China and Mr. Putin, the Russian president's spokesman, Aleksei Gromov, said, "The leaders want an end to the military phase and to move to a political settlement as soon as possible." 
As several leaders express their reservations over civilian casualties, Mr. Bush and his advisers have steadily escalated their verbal attacks on Afghanistan's ruling Taliban. Today Mr. Bush said that "this conflict is a fight to save the civilized world" from an evil regime that starves its people and supports terrorists who live "on the hunted margin of mankind." He added:
"By their hatred they have divorced themselves from the values that define civilization itself," 
While Mr. Bush talked almost exclusively about terrorism and its state sponsors, the national leaders here had other matters in mind. Several focused on the region's fast-declining economy, a subject Mr. Bush touched upon briefly today but without offering any strategy to reverse the downturn. In an interview on Friday, the president of the Philippines, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, said that in many ways Asia was in worse shape now than it was in 1997 and 1998, at the height of the Asian economic crisis. 
Mr. Bush's aides say he came wanting to hear about economic concerns, but it is clear that it is not his priority. None of his most influential economic aides are here. Nor did he speak in any detail about economics. 
As to terrorism, the Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia, and perhaps others, are willing to share intelligence and help identify terrorist cells, Mrs. Arroyo said in the interview. But the proposal appears intended in part to create a group not under American domination. That would allow the leaders of Malaysia and Indonesia to have an antiterror organization of their own at a time each is fighting extremist groups.
Today, Malaysia's prickly, outspoken president, Mahathir bin Mohamad, met with Mr. Bush at his hotel in the center of Shanghai, and the Malaysian leader used the occasion to complain that the war in Afghanistan was taking innocent Afghan lives. Interestingly, the White House allowed photographers to record the meeting, but banned the reporters who usually ask a few questions at the outset of such of a meeting. 
When Mr. Mahathir emerged to speak to business executives, the same group Mr. Bush addressed earlier in the day, he did not mention terrorism. But he did level a strong blast at the forces of economic globalization that Mr. Bush had just hailed. 
"If I had a billion U.S. dollars, I suspect I too would be very committed to a fully globalized world without any barriers and without any constraints on what I can do with my money and how I can make even more money," he said, mocking the group's commitment to free trade. 
Mr. Bush argued the opposite point -- that more globalization, more openness, will help fight terrorism. "I'm here in Shanghai to assure our friends and to inform our our foes that the progress of trade and freedom will continue," he said. "The ties of culture and commerce will grow stronger."

HEADLINE: Do All Airlines Deserve A Taxpayer Rescue? 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

DATELINE: PHOENIX 

 BODY:
AFTER the terrorist attacks forced the nation's airlines to beg Washington for life support last month, America West Airlines, based here, was named repeatedly by industry executives and analysts as the carrier most in danger of failing. 
 In fact, testifying on Capitol Hill on Sept. 19, W. Douglas Parker, America West's young new chief executive, told lawmakers that the airline was losing $5 million a day and would be forced to file for bankruptcy within days if the government did not intervene. 
 Now, in the wake of an emergency cash grant of $60 million from Washington and rising passenger traffic, things are much improved, Mr. Parker said in an interview. But the airline is still preparing to apply for federally guaranteed loans of as much as $300 million under the $10 billion program extended to the industry by emergency legislation. 
Should it get it?
The case illustrates the tricky challenge facing a panel -- led by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman -- that has been given broad powers by Congress to decide which airlines will receive the loan guarantees. 
Lawmakers insisted that taxpayers should not prop up airlines already destined to fail. But that is extremely difficult to determine in an industry where airlines can fly through multiple bankruptcies and still find success. In addition, the pressure from state and national politicians to make sure that their home airlines survive is so enormous that it may be difficult for the panel, known as the Air Transportation Stabilization Board, to deny a guarantee to any applicant. 
Earlier this month, after an intensive round of lobbying, the Office of Management and Budget gave the board, which also includes Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta and Comptroller General David M. Walker, wide leeway to extend loans even to airlines that were operating in bankruptcy before Sept. 11. 
One of those, Midway Airlines, which suspended operations immediately after the attacks, is planning to apply for a loan guarantee, Robert Ferguson, its chief executive, said on Friday. 
The only limitations placed on the board are that loans cannot extend more than seven years and cannot be 100 percent guaranteed by the government. Preference is to go to airlines with the strongest business plans and those willing to compensate the government for the guarantees in the form of fees or stock.
WITH this broad mandate and little precedent for such a wide-ranging loan program, the airlines, their suppliers and their lenders are waiting eagerly to see what the board does. Will it take a hard line and force the industry to consolidate, as some people have advocated? Or, as others have recommended, will it dole out funds more liberally in an effort to preserve competition that will keep fares low?
Samuel C. Buttrick, an analyst at UBS Warburg in New York, said, "The reality is that nobody knows how this process is really going to work."
Phoenix is a fitting home for America West, which has already risen once from the ashes of bankruptcy, in 1994. With $2.3 billion in sales last year, it is the only airline among the scores founded since deregulation that has managed to become a major carrier. 
America West is now the country's eighth-largest airline, carrying about 3 percent of all passengers. But it has always been hobbled by having its biggest hubs in Phoenix and Las Vegas, two cities dominated by low-fare leisure passengers. 
It also competes directly in both markets against Southwest Airlines, the king of low-fare airlines and the most consistently profitable carrier. 
"If you are competing with an airline that is courteous, clean and reliable and offers low fares, that's a difficult challenge," said Michael E. Levine, a former airline executive and regulator who now teaches at Harvard Law School.
Despite its efforts over the years to attract high-paying business travelers, America West has the lowest revenue per seat in the industry. It has made up for that by having among the lowest costs. 
That worked well after the airline was founded in the early 1980's. Employees earned less than their counterparts at other airlines, but a strong company culture did much to balance that. Flight attendants also worked as reservation agents and loaded bags. Every employee was required to buy stock. 
But all that changed after the company filed for bankruptcy during the last big industry downturn, in the early 1990's after the Persian Gulf war. The airline emerged under the leadership of William A. Franke, a turnaround specialist who was not particularly friendly to labor. 
America West's pilots, flight attendants and mechanics soon voted to join unions, and the scene was set for traditional airline-labor rancor. 
Since 1996, America West's operations and overall reliability have seesawed from year to year. In 1998, the Federal Aviation Administration fined the airline $2.5 million for maintenance violations. Operations recovered in 1999 but fell apart the next year, when mechanical difficulties forced the airline to cancel 6 percent of its flights during the busy summer travel season. 
Mr. Parker, who took over for Mr. Franke on Sept. 1 after serving as president, now acknowledges that America West grew too rapidly and deferred discretionary maintenance to save money. "We were running a bad airline," he said. 
Mr. Parker and a young management team have tried to turn things around, with some success. But in August, America West was still at the bottom of the industry in terms of passenger complaints and on-time performance.
More important, the airline ended up paying dearly for its recent missteps when the boom of the late 1990's ended abruptly for the industry earlier this year. After eking out a $7.7 million profit last year, while other airlines were posting strong earnings, America West burned through $100 million in cash from Jan. 1 to Sept. 11, leaving it with just $80 million on the day of the attacks. 
ONLY days before, Mr. Parker said, America West had signed tentative agreements to borrow $200 million in connection with a purchase of airplanes. People with knowledge of the transaction said Airbus Industrie had been willing to provide America West with new replacement jets financed by GE Capital and others, plus an unsecured loan of $200 million, as a cushion to carry the airline through the downturn. 
Such arrangements are not unusual in the airline industry, where Boeing and Airbus often take on financial risk to place their airplanes. But the deal, which was to close this month, collapsed after the attacks.
America West, along with the rest of the industry, suddenly found itself hemorrhaging cash as paying customers disappeared but its large expenses remained. The difference was that America West had a smaller kitty to absorb the shock. 
The $60 million grant provided by Washington, which is half of America West's share of the $5 billion emergency bailout, bought the airline some breathing space. Last week, it raised an additional $70 million in a sale-leaseback deal involving eight of its Airbus A319's, three flight simulators and two spare engines. The airline declined to identify the lender, but people with knowledge of the deal said it was GE Capital. 
John Oliver, a spokesman for GE Capital, would say only that it is continuing to work closely with long-term customers like America West. 
Mr. Parker, a candid and affable financial whiz who will turn 40 on Halloween and looks even younger, said the airline now had time to compose a strong application to the loan board by year-end. 
He said America West was well positioned before Sept. 11, adding that its operating margins were the third highest in the industry, behind Southwest and Continental Airlines. "We agree that the loan guarantee process should not be used to sustain airlines that were going out of business," he said. "We weren't one of them." 
But critics complain that government intervention is undermining market forces that otherwise would press an inefficient industry to consolidate. People with knowledge of the recent sale-leaseback deal said GE Capital would never have lent America West the money if there had been no government loan guarantee. But it is in the financial interest of GE Capital, as America West's biggest creditor, to see the airline receive a loan rather than file for bankruptcy.
POLITICIANS also have a strong interest in America West's survival. The airline contributes $5.2 billion to Arizona's economy, according to a study by Arizona State University. It provides relatively high-income jobs for 13,000 people, 9,000 in Arizona alone. 
The airline has a powerful ally in Senator John McCain, the top Republican on the Commerce Committee. Speaking to some of the airline's best customers at its headquarters on Wednesday, C. A. Howlett, America West's top lobbyist, strongly praised the recent support of the state's two senators, its governor and Representative John B. Shadegg. 
"It is hard to describe the absolute fervor with which those four individuals went to bat for America West since Sept. 11," Mr. Howlett said. 
That kind of support, which has been duplicated for other airlines in many other states, is the reason many analysts believe every carrier that applies will receive a guaranteed loan. "Everybody's going to be a winner," said Mr. Buttrick of UBS Warburg. 
But Mr. Levine, who worked at the Civil Aeronautics Board when the industry was deregulated in the late 1970's, says that by giving preference to applicants that offer the government some equity stake, the rules governing the loan board will discourage the bigger airlines from applying for the guarantees as a way to keep support away from weaker carriers. 
"If you know it is going to cost you something on the equity side," he said, "you are not so quick to show up for this money." 
Mr. Parker said the business plan that America West will present to the loan board will not be a break with the past. The airline will stress the growth of its hubs in Phoenix and Las Vegas, two of the country's fastest-growing cities.
"The formula works," he said, "and I am confident that it has a lot of growth left in it."

BYLINE:  By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
 Stepping Out
With "A Tribute to the American Spirit," a program dedicated to heroes and victims of the Sept. 11 attacks, American Ballet Theater will open its fall season at 7 p.m. tomorrow at City Center. Dancers like Nina Ananiashvili, Maxim Belotserkovsky, Jose Manuel Carreno, Angel Corella, Irina Dvorovenko, Paloma Herrera, Susan Jaffe, Julie Kent and Vladimir Malakhov are to appear in a program of works by George Balanchine, Eliot Feld and Lar Lubovitch, among others, as well as the world premiere of Robert Hill's "Reverie," created for Georgina Parkinson, Martine van Hamel and Frederic Franklin. The company's season continues through Nov. 4; (212) 581-1212.

Medium Rare
John Singer Sargent (1856-1925) may be best known for his virtuosic portraits, but he was also a gifted muralist, particularly in Boston, where the Museum of Fine Arts commissioned him to celebrate the arts in creating decorations for its library entrance, the ceiling above the grand stairway and the dome of the rotunda. Sargent worked on the project for nearly 10 years, constructing a model of the dome and using as his favorite model Thomas McKeller, an African-American hotel worker, who posed for many of the figures. Beginning on Friday, 34 of Sargent's small bas-reliefs and a sculpture that were studies for the museum's dome will go on public view for the first time at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven. "John Singer Sargent: The Painter as Sculptor" continues through April 21; (203) 432-0600.

Summit Meeting
Speakers including Janet Reno, the former United States attorney general, and Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift of Massachusetts are to take part on Saturday in a daylong conference at Barnard College on the impact of the changing role of women on society and the family. "The Barnard Summit: Women, Leadership and the Future" will examine how the participation of women in public life is transforming political, judicial and economic institutions, as well as the family and women themselves; (212) 854-2037.

Honor Bound
The winner is Midori. In ceremonies this evening at Lincoln Center, Midori, the renowned violinist, will be awarded the $50,000 Avery Fisher Prize for outstanding achievement and excellence in music. Inscribed on a marble plaque in Avery Fisher Hall, her name will join those of 16 previous recipients of the prize, among them the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, the pianist Emanuel Ax, the clarinetist Richard Stoltzman and the violinists Sarah Chang and Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg. HEADLINE: New Economy; 
During emergencies, officials need access to wireless communications systems. But regular people do, too.

BYLINE:  By Simon Romero 

 BODY:
ONCE again, the federal government has asked the telecommunications industry to find a way to provide public safety officials with priority access on wireless communications systems in times of crisis. And once again, those involved in the effort are discovering the difficulty of carrying out such a mission. 
 Since Sept. 11, no one has disputed the value of devising priority access methods for wireless systems. For several hours after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, cellular phone networks were flooded with calls, making it difficult for almost everyone, including emergency service officials, to use the systems. Networks were so strained in the hours after the attacks that sending and receiving rudimentary text messages on pagers was far easier than completing a call on a mobile phone. 
 And so comes the new urgency for wireless priority access. Earlier this month, the National Communications System, a White House-level umbrella organization of officials from 23 federal departments and agencies, asked the nation's wireless carriers for proposals on how to provide priority access, first in big cities, then nationwide. The carriers have until mid-December to comply with the government's request. 
"In times of severe wireless network congestion, call completion percentages can drop well below 5 percent," Richard Clarke, the president's special adviser on cyberspace security, said in a statement. "It is essential that we work with industry to deploy priority access service for use in crisis situations as soon as possible."
The National Communications System was set up by President John F. Kennedy in 1963, after a snarl in communications during the Cuban missile crisis among the United States, the Soviet Union and NATO months earlier. The system has continued over the years to try to maintain communications among emergency service officials in times of crisis.
It first asked wireless companies in 1995 to devise a priority access system, but so far little headway has been made. Some in the wireless industry say technological difficulties are to blame. They say the commercial wireless systems, built in the last 20 years, are substantially different than the wireline network that was cobbled together over the course of a century.
Priority access on wireline systems is relatively easy because the central command stations of large local or long-distance phone companies can remotely allow or cut off access to whomever they please without much difficulty. The only requirement is an awareness of which copper wires, fiber optic strands and switches are used by emergency officials, and, in some cases, a sufficient supply of backup power.
But the continent-spanning wireless networks built in the United States in recent years present challenges to planners dealing with priority access. First, there is already a shortage of spectrum, or airwaves, used to carry wireless calls. That is evident in current discussions among the Federal Communications Commission and several communications companies to settle a legal dispute over ownership of more than 200 coveted spectrum licenses auctioned off to large carriers last January. Some industry executives have suggested that specific swaths be reserved for emergency services, though it is not clear how this would be accomplished or what reception such a plan would receive from the government.
There is also the issue of the different and sometimes conflicting technical formats used by various wireless carriers. The disparities make streamlined supervision of the networks difficult. 
What is more, because wireless users regularly move about, often going from one transmitter's cell to another in the course of a single call, it is more difficult to determine a caller's location on wireless networks than on wireline systems. It is also harder to provide users with a dedicated circuit if they are moving between cellular stations. 
And when calling volume on wireless networks increases -- the very periods when priority access would be most needed -- it is harder to assign priorities. Some cellular stations can handle only a certain number of calls before becoming so congested that they are effectively useless to all callers for short periods. This is what happened in New York and Washington in the hours and days after Sept. 11.
For now, wireless carriers have agreed to provide an interim system for 500 officials, as requested by the National Communications System. The industry also said it would begin work on a larger system, capable of supporting 50,000 users, to be available by the end of next year.
"We don't think it's impossible to achieve priority access, but we do recognize some of the challenges we face in getting there," said Kimberly Kuo, a spokeswoman at the Cellular Telecommunications and Internet Association, a trade group in Washington for wireless carriers. "One of the things we're concerned about is the effect this could have on regular wireless users."
Certainly, one of the main reasons people buy cellular phones is to use the devices in case of an emergency. But what if giving government officials priority on wireless networks during a crisis made it even more difficult for regular users to place calls? If people could not communicate with their loved ones, might that add to public confusion and panic, making the work of public safety officials even more difficult?
It is hard to predict with certainty the effect wireless priority access would have on the general population until detailed plans are drawn up. Officials from the National Communications System declined repeated requests to comment last week, saying they did not have a "subject matter expert" available to speak on the matter. 
Last year, after four years of discussion on the issue, the F.C.C., acting on suggestions made by the National Communications System, asked wireless carries to provide priority access to emergency officials on a voluntary basis. Since then, no carrier has produced a specific plan for doing so. 
While the industry discusses ways to widen priority access efforts, some intermediate solutions have also been put forward. One of the most practical involves technology from Nextel Communications, a wireless carrier that primarily serves businesses. 
Nextel provides regular cellular phone service. But unlike other carriers' systems, Nextel's phones also provide a two-way radio service that works like the dispatcher systems used by taxi companies or police departments. Even when cellular systems are flooded with calls, Nextel's radio feature generally works without problems. 
John Perry, manager of disaster communications for the American Red Cross, said he and other Red Cross employees had used Nextel phones to communicate with each other in Washington and New York in the days after Sept. 11. "The Nextel system is limited geographically," he said, "but it works like a dream on the local level."
It is clear to almost everyone involved in the debate over priority access that stopgap proposals are not sufficient. But to the potential dismay of people who are counting on their mobile phones to serve them in an emergency, what appears likely is a system that prizes communication among a handful of important officials at the expense of calls made by everyone else.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Magazines closely weigh ad rates for the fourth quarter and early 2002 in a moribund market.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
MICHAEL G. EARLS has big plans as he reintroduces Appellation magazine next month: a new name, Wine Country Living; an added editorial focus on homes, cooking, culture and lifestyle, as well as wine and travel; and a drive to double the rate base, the circulation guaranteed to advertisers, to 100,000.
 One change, however, is not planned: higher prices for ad pages. Wine Country Living will charge the same rates as its predecessor. 
 "We're moving this forward slowly and making sure we're safe doing it," said Mr. Earls, president and publisher at Appellation L.L.C. in Sonoma, Calif. "We don't want to alienate anyone with aggressive moves at this point." 
Mr. Earls's caution is emblematic of attitudes among executives at media companies as they determine what to charge for ad pages and commercial time in the important fourth quarter and the start of 2002. The economic slowdown that has already diminished demand among marketers is being made worse by the effects of the terrorist attacks.
The result is "what is proving to be the softest advertising market place ever," Joe Mandese, editor of Media Buyer's Daily, an industry newsletter, wrote on Friday.
The big broadcast television networks are in a "scramble to save" the fourth quarter, the trade publication Mediaweek reported last week, trying to avoid steep cuts in commercial prices. In radio, Gary Fries, president of the Radio Advertising Bureau, prescribed steps to reverse ad revenue declines that included enlisting senior managers to "return to the front lines" and sell spots.
The sagging market has emboldened the buyers -- advertisers and the agencies that represent them -- to resist price increases, and even to demand significantly lower rates.
Pricing, particularly for print, "has gotten very much out of whack," said Jon Mandel, co-managing director at MediaCom in New York, the media services division of the Grey Global Group.
"A rising tide raised all the ships and a lowering tide is lowering all the ships," he added. "Unfortunately, some in the print world will find they're stuck in the mud."
Mr. Mandel will discuss the outlook for advertising as a member of a panel at a general session today of the American Magazine Conference. The conference, at the Sheraton Hotel and Towers in Midtown Manhattan, is sponsored by the Magazine Publishers of America and the American Society of Magazine Editors.
Several publishers say they realize buyers are behaving like the hard-nosed customer in the Meineke commercials who declares he is "not going to pay a lot for that muffler."
"Costs have gone up dramatically in the last year," said Steven T. Florio, president and chief executive at Conde Nast Publications in New York, the division of Advance Publications that operates magazines like Architectural Digest, GQ, Glamour, Gourmet and Vogue. "On the other hand, if we passed all those costs on to the advertisers, we wouldn't sell much advertising."
That is why Conde Nast is raising ad rates 4 percent for 2002, compared with an 8 percent increase in 2001. The increase is "fair for us as a company," Mr. Florio said, "and fair -- and marketable -- to the advertising community."
One magazine, Forbes, has decided against raising ad rates for 2002 after two years of what James S. Berrien, president at the Forbes Magazine Group in New York, called "very aggressive increases."
"Let's face it, this is a competitive market place," Mr. Berrien said, "and this is the year for us to take an aggressive pricing strategy in the other direction."
"At a meeting with Steve and Tim, I said, 'I'd like to go with a zero,' " he added, "and Steve said, 'It's the capitalistic thing to do: an economic stimulus package.' " His references were to executives at the parent, Forbes Inc., Steve Forbes, president and editor in chief, and Timothy C. Forbes, chief operating officer.
A Forbes competitor, Fortune, plans "a very modest increase" in ad-page rates, in the low single digits, said Mike Federle, publisher in New York, "the most modest we've taken in my six years here."
"We respect the times and everything our advertisers are going through," he added. "Next year is not the year to be bold coming off the blocks." Fortune is part of the Fortune Group division of Time Inc., owned by AOL Time Warner. 
Advertisers are "re-evaluating their media buys," which will make 2002 "very challenging," said Stephanie George, president at InStyle magazine in New York, a Fortune sibling in the Time Inc. stable.
Still, "they'll want to place their dollars where they know the biggest payoff is," she added. "That's when the cream rises to the top."
InStyle will raise ad rates 10 percent, Ms. George said, but will also raise the circulation rate base 6.7 percent, to 1.6 million.
Normally, the circulation gains, coming as many other magazines lose readers, would have led InStyle to try raising ad rates even more, "but not in the year we're heading into," she added.
Another magazine increasing both ad rates and the rate base for 2002 is The New Yorker, another Conde Nast publication. Its ad rates are going up 10.5 percent as the rate base goes up 6.3 percent, to 850,000.
"I don't think anyone can say going they're feeling very bullish," said David Carey, vice president and publisher at The New Yorker. "It's going to be a tough six months."
Heading into Sept. 11, Mr. Carey recalled, his ad pages were down about 3.5 percent from the corresponding period in 2001. But since then, he added, "we've given a fair amount back because travel and retail" -- two ad categories hit particularly hard by recent consumer anxieties -- "are the drivers in the fourth quarter."
As a result, Mr. Carey estimated that The New Yorker would end 2001 with a decline in ad pages of 12 percent to 13 percent from 2000.
Still, "some travel business is coming back," he said. "We've just had some airlines book some branding advertising in December." He is also cheered by the circulation growth -- the rate base increase is the second in five months -- and the subscription renewal rate of 76.5 percent, "the highest in our history."
"We're going to be in business for a long time," Mr. Carey said, "not just for the fourth quarter of 2001 and the first quarter of 2002."
That long-term perspective, though, contrasts markedly with the increasingly short-term perspective taken by marketers.
"More clients are choosing to wait until the last minute to make financial commitments to advertising," said Karen Jacobs, senior vice president and director for print investment at Starcom Worldwide in Chicago, a unit of the Starcom MediaVest Group media services division of the Bcom3 Group. "They're not necessarily spending less money, but there's less willingness to let go of the money," she said.
Ms. Jacobs described the current preference as "just-in-time media buying," echoing the term used to describe the cost-saving parts-delivery strategy pursued by makers of products like automobiles.
But will there be more last-minute media buys, made just in time to salvage this year -- and 2002 -- for the media companies? Time, last minute or not, will tell.

HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
News Media Risk Big Losses To Cover War

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL with FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
There is never a good time for a war, but for big media and news companies, the timing of the current crisis is especially poor.
 Even before Sept. 11, advertising sales, which underwrite most news operations, were already taking on water. Since Sept. 11, the advertising business has capsized. 
 But for news companies and the businesses that own them, lower ad revenue is only part of the problem. They are also having to tear up their budgets to give this big story the resources it warrants. 
For major news companies, the question so far is not whether they can afford to cover the crisis, but whether they can afford not to. 
Most say they are trying to look beyond the short-term financial impact to see the long-term value that extensive coverage can bring to their news "brands." They remember that when CNN distinguished itself during the Persian Gulf war, the cable network's halo lasted for years.
"We're going to spend whatever we need to spend to cover the story appropriately," said J. Michael Kelly, chief financial officer of AOL Time Warner, which now owns CNN as well as the news magazine Time. "That's how you build brands in this business, by being renowned for your editorial coverage of these kinds of stories."
Like CNN, the major broadcast television news operations are owned by international conglomerates with deep pockets: ABC News by Walt Disney, CBS News by Viacom and NBC News by General Electric. And because news is just a small -- if highly visible -- part of what each of those companies do, they may eventually become reluctant to let news spending hurt their overall financial results, especially if the crisis drags on. 
By contrast, at businesses like The Washington Post or The New York Times, where news is the main operation, there may be less leeway for trimming costs -- and so less ability to avoid financial pain.
In an electronic video message to employees last Friday, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the Times Company chairman, said the unsettled economic climate would cause the company to fall short of its earnings goal this year and that the company would probably miss its goal for 2002.
Nonetheless, he said, "The quality of our journalism is at the heart of our company's success, and we will do everything we can to continue providing our readers and viewers and listeners and users with world-class news reports."
According to estimates culled from companies and Wall Street analysts, United States news companies may have already spent as much as $100 million beyond their previous budgets to report the conflict. That is in addition to more than $500 million in advertising revenue lost by television networks in the days immediately after the attacks, as they went to 24-hour news.
Were the current level of crisis coverage to persist for a year, the major United States television news units would incur hundreds of millions of dollars in additional costs. The networks would potentially lose hundreds of millions of dollars more in lost ad sales if developments warranted a return to round-the-clock coverage.
One Wall Street analyst estimated that each of the three major broadcast networks was now incurring about $1 million a day in extra costs covering the war on terrorism. 
If that estimate is close to accurate, it will roughly double the budget for each of the three major broadcast news divisions and turn them from slightly profitable to severely unprofitable. Analysts and executives estimate that -- not counting the highly profitable prime-time news magazine programs -- each of the three major broadcast news divisions generates $400 million to $450 million in annual revenue and incurs $350 million to $400 million in annual costs.
If each of the broadcast news divisions did have an additional $350 million in annual costs for covering the crisis, it would have a significant impact on the financial results of their parent companies. Such a hit to the corporate income statement could potentially reduce each media giant's earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization -- a key financial yardstick for media companies -- by 5 percent or more.
On condition of anonymity, an executive close to one of the major broadcast news divisions said that at current spending levels, his network was incurring no more than about $36 million in additional annual costs, a relatively negligible amount. The executive warned, however, that the figure could balloon should the crisis take a new turn.
As far as newspaper companies are concerned, one analyst, Lauren Rich Fine of Merrill Lynch, gave a rough cost estimate, suggesting that Gannett and The New York Times Company had each spent $3 million to $4 million so far for extra newsprint, travel, auxiliary staff and communications. Through spokeswomen, both companies declined to discuss such costs.
"Newspapers are in a very odd spot right now in terms of both serving the public good and trying to serve shareholders," Ms. Fine said. "You wish there were times when investors cut companies slack and appreciated what they were doing."
In an earnings conference call with analysts last week, Knight Ridder's chief executive, P. Anthony Ridder, said the company had lost $9 million in ad revenue because of the Sept. 11 attacks and had spent an extra $2 million "covering the story following the attacks."
Boisfeuillet Jones Jr., publisher of The Washington Post, said, "We're spending more than we were before, and we're saving more where we can, too, to partly offset it."
"It certainly is adding to costs at this point," he added, "but that's expected."
In both print and video, at least some of the additional costs will be recouped. Higher ratings for news are already increasing advertising revenue for some networks, although it may be too soon to get anything more than rough estimates. In the end, an all-news operation like CNN may very well come out ahead on its war coverage.
Mark Harrad, a spokesman in New York for AOL's Turner Broadcasting unit, which includes CNN, said that in the first week of October CNN increased its advertising rates to reflect the network's expected higher viewership. He did not quantify the increase, which will not affect advertisers that had already contracted for time on the network.
"For CNN, I think it's a net gain," said Richard A. Bilotti, a media analyst at Morgan Stanley. But he said he thought the crisis would probably result in a net loss for the broadcast networks.
Media executives have to hope that any financial loss will be outweighed by the long-term good will and cachet that their efforts may attract to their brands. But in the heat of the crisis, at least one news executive says that brand-building is not what he is thinking about right now. 
"After we're done, we look back and say, 'Did we help ABC News, or did we make mistakes and hurt ABC News?' " said Alex Wallau, president of the ABC television network. "In this case, I think we've helped the brand, but that's not something we think about when it occurs. I think that that is a mindset that comes after everything is over."
The trouble, from a business standpoint, is that no one knows when everything will be over.

HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
Newsweeklies Run to Keep UpOn Tricky Turf

BYLINE:  By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK 

 BODY:
At 11 a.m. Friday, about two dozen Newsweek staff members gathered around a conference room table. The photo department had just been reopened after an anthrax scare that proved to be a false alarm. And word had spread that morning of new activity by United States Special Forces on the ground in Afghanistan, throwing up in the air the contents of the issue closing the next day.
 "I think we should go ahead and work up a special ops cover," began Mark Whitaker, Newsweek's editor, "but I think that for the moment we should stick with 'sleepers,' " a feature called "The Terrorist Next Door," about Al Qaeda cells in the United States and overseas. 
 He added, "We may want some more shots of ground troops moving in because what we had on Capitol Hill yesterday wasn't great." The Capitol photographs showed federal agents in protective suits inspecting for anthrax. 
The news media are confronting a changed world, where surreal pictures of teams in airtight helmets entering the empty Capitol do not automatically rank as a week's most potent images, and coverage is a special challenge for a newsweekly.
Newsmagazines distill complex events into a single digestible package for the broadest possible readership, and they depend more than anything else on the single image on each cover to seize attention. Since Sept. 11, they have faced a host of new questions, like how to cover the public's fears without inflaming them or promoting bias against Arab-Americans.
Newsstand sales of Time, Newsweek and U.S. News & World Report all leaped to more than 10 times their average levels in the week after Sept. 11, setting new records, according to preliminary estimates at the magazines. Since then, sales have remained several times as high as their usual levels.
But newsmagazines have also faced a financial squeeze as advertisers have pulled back from pitching products amid images of terror and war. "The advertising environment was bad and is now worse than bad," said Brian Duffy, editor of U.S. News & World Report.
After weeks of clamoring from Newsweek's advertising sales staff, Mr. Whitaker said, he decided this week to publish a significant feature article unrelated to the attacks for the first time since Sept. 11. That is something the magazine's competitors have not done. The article is a report on technology and education that was originally intended to run on the cover the Monday after the attacks; it will now appear in abbreviated form inside. "Some of the ads have stayed," Mr. Whitaker said. "A lot have gone away."
Each of the magazines has adopted its own strategy. For example, Newsweek has stressed in-depth features as long as 10,000 words, while Time has concentrated on shorter dispatches from many angles.
All the magazines have struggled to keep their distance from the events unfolding around them. "Covering the war in Afghanistan is difficult enough," said Mr. Duffy, of U.S. News, "but those difficulties pale in comparison with the difficulty of covering what is going on here."
On the Monday after the attacks, all three newsmagazines ran covers featuring flags, and Newsweek ran the striking headline "God Bless America." Mr. Whitaker acknowledged that some thought the headline unduly jingoistic but said he saw it differently. "One of the things we do is play back what is happening in the country," he said.
Still, James Kelly, managing editor of Time, said he would not have run it. "That would not be our style," he said. "It is incumbent on any editor to be sure the magazine doesn't become a rah-rah cheering section for the administration." 
Not that Time was much different. On its cover that week the letters of the magazine's name appeared in red, white and blue. "I'm not putting out The Nation magazine here," Mr. Kelly said. (The Nation, a left-leaning magazine, featured on its first cover after the attacks an article arguing for nuclear arms control.)
The next week, the country's attention turned to Osama bin Laden as the suspected terrorist behind the attacks, and the newsmagazines faced the question of how to depict him. The cover of U.S. News featured a photograph of Mr. bin Laden's face in a gun's cross hairs, and Newsweek altered Mr. bin Laden's photo to look like an infrared image.
Time, however, ran an undoctored close-up. "I was very concerned that our image of bin Laden be completely straightforward: this is what he looks like," Mr. Kelly said.
But putting Mr. bin Laden's face on Time's cover had unintended consequences. The next week, anti-American protesters in Pakistan and elsewhere turned Time's cover into posters that were carried at rallies and posted on walls.
As federal officials delicately began to raise the specter of new biological or chemical attacks within the United States, the newsmagazines faced a new question: how to cover the public's fears without aggravating them? Or, to put it another way, how to avoid fomenting more fear, thereby helping the terrorists? The question is especially thorny because journalists' instincts are to spell out the highest stakes and greatest risks for their readers, as Newsweek did in two covers this year about the slowing economy under these headlines: "Laid Off: Is Your Job Safe?" and "How Scared Should You Be?" 
Mr. Whitaker, however, defended the magazines' coverage of even speculative dangers. "One of the reasons that Sept. 11 happened was that no one imagined that the terrorists could do something so evil," he said. "It wasn't just a failure of intelligence -- it was a failure of imagination." In any event, he added, the magazines' first covers about bioterrorism proved to be prescient.
Still, before deciding on each of Newsweek's two biological terrorism covers, Mr. Whitaker said, "we were satisfied that there was enough panic out there that we could be a source of providing a little context and facts." 
The magazine initially considered illustrating a biological and chemical weapons article with a cover featuring a gas mask and a single word in capital letters: "Bioterror." But the headline was scrapped in favor of a less alarming one, returning for the second time this year to the question "How Scared Should You Be?"
All three newsmagazines simultaneously turned their attention to the cultural roots of Mr. bin Laden's attacks, devoting covers to Islamic radicalism. For Newsweek's cover, Mr. Whitaker said, he considered using a close-up photograph of an angry Arab shouting in protest, but rejected it. "I thought it was sort of predictable," he said. Instead, Newsweek ran an image of an Arab child holding a machine gun, while Time used the same image Mr. Whitaker had rejected. 
Asked about the image, Mr. Kelly, of Time, said he had deliberately picked a face that looked ordinary. "I thought this person, when he is not yelling, looks perfectly reasonable," he said.
On Friday, Mr. Whitaker said, he debated similar issues about stereotyping or demonizing Arabs in preparing Newsweek's cover about secret terrorist cells. The magazine prepared two alternative covers under the headline "The Terrorist Next Door," one with a clearly Middle Eastern face and the other with one more ethnically European. Mr. Whitaker noted that not all members of Mr. bin Laden's network were Arabs -- a few are radical European Muslims. In the end, the magazine fudged the question by treating the photograph of the Middle Eastern man to make it look more abstract, like an illustration.
When Mr. Whitaker woke up on Saturday morning and read the papers, he decided to scrap the "sleepers" cover after all to reflect the onset of a ground war in Afghanistan. "We want a news story that has legs for the next week," he said, "and it became clear overnight that this was ongoing, the raids were going to continue." The cover illustration depicts a Green Beret commando with a machine gun and the headline, "Special Ops: Can Our Commandos Finish the Job?" The magazine's answer is a limited yes, Mr. Whitaker said, pointing out that the troops cannot solve the problem of Afghanistan's future.

HEADLINE: Displaced, but Lucky 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Schools Closest to Twin Towers Struggle for Continuity" (Education page, Oct. 17): As I looked outside my window on the morning of Sept. 11, watching events unfold and buildings collapse with frightening speed and proximity, I tried not to imagine the worst for my sisters, who are students at the High School for Leadership and Public Service. I later found out that they had lived through things too grim to detail here. 
 That afternoon, they returned like war-torn soldiers, armed with tales of dodging fiery debris and concrete rain as well as praise for all of the ordinary people who helped them along the way. They were lucky to come away unscathed. 
 Reading your article, I felt that they and the other students at Leadership and Public Service and the High School for Economics and Finance finally got some of the recognition that they need to keep going, still displaced and trying to pick up the pieces.

STACY TORRES
New York, Oct. 17, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Letter 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: Subsidies for Poor Proposed To Aid Argentine Economy 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 21 

 BODY:
Senior Argentine officials struggled today to avert a default on the nation's debt and to revive President Fernando de la Rua's political fortunes by putting the final touches on a new economic policy. 
 The new plan is intended to cut government spending sharply while increasing consumer spending and subsidies to the poor. It represents a fine-tuning, rather than a break with the government's previous policy to cut government deficits in an effort to bring down interest rates and to spur an economy that has been in recession for 40 months. 
 Since legislative elections last Sunday, in which the opposition Justicialist Party took control of both houses of Congress, Mr. de la Rua has been negotiating on several tracks simultaneously. He is trying to keep his Alianza coalition of center-left parties from breaking apart, to avert a direct collision with the opposition and to convince investors that the country will not default on debt or devalue its currency. 
The new economic plan is to be announced early this week, along with a reshuffling of the cabinet and an agreement with opposition governors on how to apportion more than $1 billion in disputed federal revenues to the provinces.
Officials say they hope that the combined weight of the changes will strengthen Mr. de la Rua's flagging presidency. During his two years in office, he has been buffeted by a Senate bribery scandal, the resignation of his vice president and his own frequent cabinet changes. His public approval ratings have dropped to single digits.
By cutting more than $600 million in government spending, officials said, the new economic program is devised to convince investors that the government is committed to balancing its budget next year and not to adding to the $132 billion public debt. But the plan also offers critics several new social initiatives for the poor and help for a shrinking middle class.
Poor families are expected to become eligible for subsidies ranging from $20 to $40 per month per child, and to receive $150 debit cards to increase their spending power. Consumers will pay 3 percent less in value added taxes when they pay by credit card, a measure intended to increase spending and to combat tax evasion. And rather than cut year-end bonuses for government employees, the government will pay them in installments over 12 months.
Another measure would allow the government to accept dollars as tax payments and to pay employees with dollars. Leaks of this policy in the local press were interpreted as a sign that Domingo Cavallo, the economy minister, was studying the option of dropping the peso in favor of making the United States dollar Argentina's currency in case of a future financial emergency.
Fears of a debt default and devaluation here and on Wall Street have grown in recent days after reports that the government is pressuring local pension funds and banks to swap as much as $16 billion in government bonds for securities that pay lower interest rates. As consumption and manufacturing continued to slide, tax receipts were 14 percent lower last month than in the previous September.
In recent weeks, several prominent Wall Street analysts have argued that Argentina should convert its economy to dollars in order to reduce the perception that the country will eventually devalue its currency, thereby reducing interest rates as confidence increases.
In public statements in recent days, Mr. de la Rua has repeated his pledge never to devalue the peso but he has left the door open to a possible dollar conversion.
The economic plan has already been criticized by several prominent political leaders, who argue that the government needs to stimulate the economy by pumping up public spending and restructuring its foreign debt to reduce interest payments.
"I think we are on the brink of a nationwide social outburst," Gov. Adolfo Rodriguez Saa, a Justicialist leader from San Luis Province, said Saturday.
Several leaders of Mr. de la Rua's own Radical Party, which governs in alliance with the Frepaso social democratic party, have sharply criticized Mr. de la Rua and called on the president to fire Mr. Cavallo, the economy minister.
"We cannot keep giving the government blank checks," said Federico Storani, the Radical Party leader in Buenos Aires.
Former President Raul Alfonsin, who is a senator-elect and president of the Radical Party, said, "Cavallo's cycle is over," at a staged meeting last week with national labor leaders, who have already carried out six national strikes against Mr. de la Rua's policies and are threatening more general strikes.
The Radical Party caucus in the Chamber of Deputies has threatened to oppose any new austerity measures, while Justicialist members have warned that they may vote to rescind the special emergency powers the Congress gave to Mr. Cavallo this year.
Juan Pablo Cafiero, the social welfare minister, the last remaining member of Frepaso in the cabinet, resigned Saturday night in protest of budget cuts.
The virtual rebellion by the Radical and Frepaso Parties against the president they elected in 1999 has forced Mr. de la Rua to rely heavily on the opposition Justicialists to go along with his program in Congress.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Fernando de la Rua of Argentina fine-tunes his program. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Coca-Cola Site in India Bombed In a Protest Over Afghanistan 

BYLINE:  By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Oct. 21 

 BODY:
A banned, far-left rebel group bombed a Coca-Cola plant in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh today. Its members left behind a note in the local Telugu language saying the attack was to protest the American bombing of Afghanistan and threatening more such actions. 
 The early morning attack heavily damaged the plant, but did not kill or injure anyone. A dozen or so members of the rebel group, the People's War Group, rode up to the plant by jeep and motorcycle and locked the night security guards in a room before entering the factory, according to a statement from Coca-Cola. 
 The bombing is likely to be a setback to efforts by the state's chief minister, Chandrababu Naidu, to attract foreign investment to Andhra Pradesh, whose capital, Hyderabad, has become a center for India's high-technology business. 
The People's War Group had earlier issued a news release denouncing what it described as American terrorism and imperialism in Afghanistan and holding the United States responsible for capitalism in the world, J. Puranachandra Rao, the superintendent of police in Guntur district, said in a telephone interview tonight.
The People's War Group, which says that it is fighting to help poor peasants, has been making violent guerrilla attacks on the state government for years.
In its statement, Coca-Cola said it had called on the government to protect its plants and offices. It noted that all its 5,500 employees are Indian and that its operations "are all Indianized."
Irfan Khan, vice president for Coca-Cola India's corporate affairs, said the company had repeatedly been subjected to extortionate demands and threatened with attacks. "In the past, we never succumbed to these pressures," he said, but added, "We are worried about the security and safety of our staff and plants."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: HEALTH; 
Officials Fear Tuberculosis Epidemic in Camps

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 

 BODY:
Even as aid workers struggle to provide enough food to countless Afghans displaced by war, drought and Taliban repression, health officials say they are increasingly concerned that both Afghanistan and Pakistan face another threat: a potential epidemic of tuberculosis.
 Pakistan and Afghanistan already have high incidence of tuberculosis, with more than 350,000 people developing the disease each year. Now, the crowded refugee camps threaten to become a mass incubator of the disease, creating a health crisis that could last for years after the fighting stops, World Health Organization officials said last week. 
 "You put people in compressed spaces in a time of great stress -- that kind of situation we fear can lead to a major epidemic," said Mario Raviglione, who supervises tuberculosis programs for the health organization. "We're going to be dealing with this for a long time unless we do something about it now."
The health organization, the World Bank, several United Nations agencies and more than a dozen nations seeking to fight tuberculosis outbreaks plan to meet in Washington this week to discuss a strategy to fight the disease around the world. The crisis in Afghanistan will be high on the agenda, Mr. Raviglione said.
Twenty-two nations, including the world's two most populous, China and India, are considered to have serious problems with tuberculosis, even though the disease is both preventable and highly treatable with proper medical care.
Worldwide, cases have soared in recent years, with some 8.7 million people developing the disease last year. About two million people died of tuberculosis last year, almost all of them in poor nations, where most people do not receive vaccinations and the sanitary conditions are not good. 
A grouping of some 120 public and private groups devoted to fighting the disease has raised about half of the $9.3 billion that its members say would be required to wipe out the disease over the next five years. Aside from official sources, some private charities and individuals, including George Soros, the financier, have made tuberculosis a major focus of their philanthropy.
The problem had become so acute in Afghanistan that the health organization raised money to treat victims there despite the difficulty of administering aid under the Taliban, Mr. Raviglione said. The program had been expected to begin last month, but was disrupted by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States and the allied response.
That effort is now focused on refugee camps, but health officials said the money they had raised -- just over $1 million -- is proving inadequate.
"To say that are resources are short in this area is a great understatement," Mr. Raviglione said.
